translated: Or is it independent?🔽The first is indeed accepted,

analyzed: tena asmad pakṣasya eva siddheḥ
translated: because our position is established by that alone.

analyzed: śāstrasya bhagavat eka niṣṭha tāyāḥ samanvaya sūtre vakṣyamāṇa tvāt
translated: Because in the Sāmanvaya Sūtra it will be said that scripture is solely devoted to the Lord.

original: dvitīyaṃ dūṣayati na pṛthagiti //🔽na pṛthak cānumeśvare // / / //
analyzed: dvitīyam dūṣayati na pṛthak iti  na pṛthak ca anumā īśvare
translated: He refutes the second by saying not separately etc.🔽Not separately means that inference is not a valid means of knowledge regarding the Lord, the cause of the world.

original: īśvare jagatkāraṇe pṛthak svatantrānumā ca na mānamityarthaḥ /
analyzed: īśvare jagatkāraṇe pṛthak svatantrā anumā ca na mānam iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that separate independent inference is not a valid means of knowledge.

analyzed: tathā hi
translated: To explain:

original: yattāvatsāmānyato jagatkartṛtvasiddhāvanumānam tatra kiṃ kāraṇādisākṣātkāravatkartṛpūrvakatvaṃ sādhyam /
analyzed: yat tāvat sāmānyatas jagat kartṛ tva siddhau anumānam tatra kim kāraṇa ādi sākṣātkāravat kartṛ pūrvakatvam sādhyam
translated: As for the inference that establishes the general existence of a creator of the world, is the probandum the fact that it is preceded by a creator who directly perceives causes and other things,

analyzed: sa kartṛka tva mātram vā
translated: or is it mere being created?

analyzed: ādye dṛṣṭāntasya sādhya vaikalyam
translated: In the first case, the example is deficient in the probandum.

analyzed: nahi kulāla ādiḥ ghaṭa ādi kāraṇāni dharma adharma ādīni sākṣātkurute
translated: For the potter and others do not directly perceive the causes of the pot and other things, such as dharma and adharma.

analyzed: atas eva kadācid pratihata icchaḥ bhavati iti ced
translated: If it be said that it is for this very reason that the desire is sometimes obstructed,

analyzed: kim etāvatā
translated: what is the use of this?

original: sādhyavaikalyāparihārāt /🔽kathañcidasya hetuviśeṣaṇatve sādhanavaikalyaṃ ca dṛṣṭāntasya syāt /
analyzed: sādhya vaikalya aparihārāt  kathañcid asya hetu viśeṣaṇa tve sādhana vaikalyam ca dṛṣṭāntasya syāt
translated: Because the incompleteness of the probandum is not avoided.🔽And if it is in some way a qualification of the reason, there would be incompleteness of the proof in the example.

analyzed: kevala vyatirekī tarhi ayam astu iti ced na
translated: If it be said that it is then to be a negative-only [reason], no.

analyzed: viśeṣaṇa asiddheḥ
translated: Because the qualification is not established.

analyzed: dvitīye siddhasādhanam
translated: In the second [alternative], there is the establishment of what is already established.

analyzed: adṛṣṭānām jīvātmānam eva kartṛ tva upapatteḥ
translated: Because it is possible for the unseen [forces] to have the unseen souls themselves as agents.

analyzed: teṣām kāraṇa anabhijña tvāt na iti ced na
translated: If it be said that it is not so because they are ignorant of the cause, no.

analyzed: kulāla ādīnām akartṛ tva prasaṅgāt
translated: Because it would follow that potters and others are not agents.

analyzed: adṛṣṭa adhiṣyātra api kenacid bhāvyam iti ced na
translated: If it be said that even in this case something must be produced by an unseen [force], no.

analyzed: adhiṣṭhātṛ kṛtyā abhāvāt
translated: Because there is no function of a supervisor.

analyzed: na tāvat nodana ādikam
translated: First of all, it is not the impulse etc.

analyzed: a dravya tvāt
translated: Because it is not a substance.

analyzed: na ca atiśaya janma
translated: And there is no production of an attribute.

analyzed: guṇe guṇa antara anupapatteḥ
translated: Because an attribute cannot have another attribute.

analyzed: na ca atīndriya ādheya śaktiḥ
translated: And there is no power that is to be added which is beyond the senses.

analyzed: anabhyupagamāt
translated: Because it is not accepted.

analyzed: na ca sahakāri samavadhānam
translated: And there is no concurrence of cooperating factors.

analyzed: adṛṣṭāt eva tad upapatteḥ
translated: Because that is possible even from the unseen [forces].

analyzed: na api kārya kāri tvam
translated: Nor is there the activity of the effect.

analyzed: tasya adṛṣṭa svabhāva tvāt
translated: Because that has the nature of the unseen [forces].

original: tarhyutpattyanantarameva kiṃ na kuryāditi cet na /
analyzed: tarhi utpatti anantaram eva kim na kuryāt iti ced na
translated: If it be said that then why does it not do it immediately after arising, no.

analyzed: prabala adṛṣṭa antara pratibandha ādinā iti vadāmaḥ
translated: We say that it is due to the obstruction by a stronger example, etc.

analyzed: kiñca kārya tvam pakṣe kutas siddham
translated: Moreover, how is it established that the effect is the subject?

analyzed: a bhūtvā abhāvi tvāt iti ced na
translated: If it is said that it is because it exists after not having existed, that is not so.

analyzed: tasya eva kārya tvāt
translated: Because that itself is the effect.

analyzed: kathañcid bhede pi bhāga asiddha tvāt
translated: Even if there is some difference, it is not established in part.

analyzed: na khalu giri sāgara ādīnām a bhūtvā abhāvi tvam asmābhiḥ upalabhyate  tarhi dravyeṣu tāvat sāvayava tvāt kāri anvaya siddhiḥ astu iti ced na
translated: For we do not perceive the non-existence after not having existed of mountains, oceans, etc.

analyzed: sāvayava tvam hi
translated: If it is argued that in substances, let there be the establishment of the concomitance of the effect due to having parts, that is not so.🔽For having parts means

analyzed: samavāyi kāraṇavat tvam uta pariṇāmi kāraṇavat tvam vā  ādye prativādi asiddhiḥ
translated: either having an inherent cause or having a transforming cause.🔽In the first case, there is non-establishment for the opponent.

analyzed: dvitīye vā ādi asiddhiḥ  kiñca yasya kārya tva mātre pi
translated: In the second case, there is non-establishment for the proponent.

analyzed: vipratipattiḥ sa katham kāraṇavat tām eva abhyupeyāt
translated: Moreover, how can one who has doubt even about mere being an effect accept the existence of a cause?

analyzed: nanu kṣiti ādīnām pratyakṣatas eva pradeśavat tvam anubhūyate
translated: But the existence of parts of earth, etc. is indeed experienced by direct perception.

original: anyathā kathaṃ bhūtale ghaṭabhāvābhāvau yugapatsambhavata itrata cenna /
analyzed: anyathā katham bhū tale ghaṭa bhāva abhāvau yugapad sambhavataḥ ced na
translated: If it is argued that otherwise, how can the presence and absence of a pot on the ground be possible simultaneously, that is not so.

analyzed: tarhi evam ākāśa ādīnām api kārya tva prasaṅgāt
translated: Because in that case, space, etc. would also be effects.

analyzed: katham anyathā gagane
translated: Otherwise, how can there be

original: pakṣiṇo bhāvābhāvau yugapaditi tatrāpi vaktuṃ śakyatvāt /
analyzed: pakṣiṇaḥ bhāva abhāvau yugapad iti tatra api vaktum śakya tvāt
translated: Because it can be said in the same way about the existence and non-existence of birds simultaneously.

analyzed: saṃyogasya satva atyanta abhāva samāna āśraya tvāt evam iti ced
translated: If it is argued that it is so because conjunction exists in the same substratum as the absolute non-existence,

analyzed: samam prakṛte pi
translated: it is the same in the present case also.

original: khananādinā yeṣāṃ vibhāgo nodanādinā ca yeṣāṃ saṃyogaste kṣityādīnāmavayavāḥ pratyakṣasiddhā iti cet /
analyzed: khanana ādinā yeṣām vibhāgaḥ nodana ādinā ca yeṣām saṃyogaḥ te kṣiti ādīnām avayavāḥ pratyakṣa siddhāḥ iti ced
translated: If it is argued that the parts of earth etc. are directly perceived, those whose disjunction is by digging etc. and those whose conjunction is by striking etc.,

original: tatkiṃ saṃyogavibhāgisajatīyadravyāntaravattvaṃ sāvayavatvamityuktaṃ bhavati uta tadārabdhatvam /
analyzed: tat kim saṃyoga vibhāgi sajatīya dravya antaravat tvam sāvayava tvam iti uktam bhavati uta tad ārabdha tvam
translated: then is it said that having another homogeneous substance that has conjunction and disjunction is having parts, or is it being composed of that?

analyzed: ādye paramāṇubhiḥ vyabhicāraḥ
translated: In the first case, there is inconstancy with atoms.

analyzed: dvitīye vyartha viśeṣaṇa tvam pūrvavat asiddhiḥ ca iti
translated: In the second case, the qualifier is useless, and there is non-establishment as before.

analyzed: etena vivāda adhyāsitam karma prayatna ādhāra jam iti etat api nirastam
translated: By this, that action which is the subject of dispute is also refuted as being supported by effort.

analyzed: yat api pṛthivī udake prayatnavatā dhṛte iti anumitam
translated: And that which is inferred as being held by earth and water by one who has effort,

analyzed: tat api pūrvavat siddha sādhanam
translated: that also is a proof of what is already established as before.

analyzed: kiñca saṃyoga vega prayatna vat adṛṣṭam api kasmāt guru tva pratibandhakam na kalpyate
translated: Moreover, why is not unseen force which is like conjunction, speed and effort, also assumed to be a counteragent to gravity?

analyzed: apāti tvam ca sandigdha asiddham
translated: And non-falling is doubtful and non-established.

analyzed: mahat tvena patatā anupalambha sambhavāt
translated: Because it is possible to not perceive it due to its greatness.

analyzed: etena carama anumānam api nirastam
translated: And by this, the last inference is also refuted.

analyzed: kṣiti ādikam vikartṛkam anupalabhyamāna kartṛka tvāt gagana vat ityādinā sat pratipakṣa tā ca sarva anumānānām  anupalabhyamāna
translated: And all inferences have a counter-argument, such as The earth, etc. are without a maker, because their maker is not perceived, like the sky, etc.

analyzed: tvam ca asmad upalabdhi ayogya tvam iti na kaścid kṣudra upadravaḥ
translated: And not being perceived means not being suitable to be perceived by us, so there is no small harm.

analyzed: para sukha ādau vyabhicāraḥ iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that there is deviation in the case of the happiness of others, that is not so.

analyzed: tasya anumānāt upalabdheḥ
translated: Because that is perceived through inference.

analyzed: tarhi kṣiti ādi kartā api anumānāt upalabhyate iti ced na  anumānāt īśvara upalabdhau asmat anumānasya duṣṭa tvam
translated: If it is argued that the maker of the earth, etc. is also perceived through inference, that is not so.🔽Because our inference is faulty in the perception of God through inference.

analyzed: tathā ca anumānāt īśvara upalabdhiḥ iti itaretarāśraya prasaṅga tvaāt
translated: And thus there is the fallacy of mutual dependence in the perception of God through inference.

original: anayaiva diśā sarvāṇi jagatkāraṇamātrasādhanāni svatantratānumānāni nirasanīyāniiti / /
analyzed: anayā eva diśā sarvāṇi jagat kāraṇa mātra sādhanāni svatantra tā anumānāni nirasanīyāni iti
translated: In this very way, all inferences proving God as the mere cause of the world and independent should be refuted.

original: yacca śivādīnāṃ jagatkāraṇatve pariśeṣānumānaṃ tadapi kiṃ śāstrānusāri kiṃvā kevalam /
analyzed: yat ca śiva ādīnām jagat kāraṇatve pariśeṣa anumānam tat api kim śāstra anusāri kiṃvā kevalam
translated: And that inference by elimination regarding Shiva, etc. being the cause of the world, is that also based on scripture or is it independent?

analyzed: na ādyaḥ
translated: Not the first.

analyzed: śāstrasya bhagavat eka para tāyāḥ vakṣyamāṇa tvāt
translated: Because it will be said that the scripture is solely about the Lord.

analyzed: dvitīyam dūṣayati na pṛthak ca iti
translated: The second [argument] is refuted [by saying]: If [the two arguments] are not separate,

original: īśvare śive jagatkartari ca pṛthaganumānaṃ na mānamityarthaḥ /🔽tatkathamityata āha puṃstveti //
analyzed: īśvare śive jagatkartari ca pṛthak anumānam na mānam iti arthaḥ  tat katham iti atas āha puṃstva iti
translated: the meaning is that a separate inference regarding Śiva, the creator of the world, is not valid.

analyzed: puṃstva hetu balāt eva pūrva uktena eva vartmanā
translated: How is that? For that reason, [the author] says: By the power of the reason of masculinity, by the very path stated before...

analyzed: pūrva uktena eva
translated: By the very

analyzed: vartmanā śaiva āgama prāmāṇya anumāna nirākaraṇa mārgeṇa eva
translated: path, by the very method of refuting the inference of the validity of the Śaiva scriptures,

analyzed: sat pratipakṣa tvena eva iti arthaḥ
translated: the meaning is that [the second argument] is simply contradicted.

original: evakāro na dūṣaṇāntarānveṣaṇena vṛthā manaḥ khedanīyaṃ sphuṭadoṣe satīti dyotayati / /
analyzed: eva kāraḥ na dūṣaṇa antara anveṣaṇena vṛthā manaḥ khedanīyam sphuṭa doṣe sati iti dyotayati
translated: The word only indicates that the mind should not be needlessly troubled by searching for another fault when there is an obvious one.

original: īśvaravākyatvaṃ kathamatra hetuḥ syādityata āha puṃstveti //
analyzed: īśvara vākyatvam katham atra hetuḥ syāt iti atas āha puṃstva iti
translated: How can the fact of being a statement by a Lord be a reason here? For that reason, [the author] says: By the power of the reason of masculinity...

analyzed: pūrva uktena eva  vartmanā iti sat pratipakṣa tā mātram atidiṣyam
translated: By the very🔽path, only contradiction is indicated,

analyzed: na tu sa hetuḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: but the meaning is that it is not a reason.

analyzed: ayam atra prayogaḥ
translated: Here is the argument:

analyzed: śivaḥ na jagat kāraṇam puṃstvāt devadatta vat iti
translated: Śiva is not the cause of the world, because of being a male, like Devadatta.

analyzed: nanu śivaḥ kena pramāṇena siddhaḥ
translated: But by what means of valid knowledge is Śiva established?

original: atha pariśeṣato jagatkartṛtvaṃ tasminnanumimānasya tavāpi kutaḥ siddhaḥ /
analyzed: atha pariśeṣataḥ jagat kartṛ tvam tasmin anumimānasya tava api kutas siddhaḥ
translated: Or if you are inferring the status of being the creator of the world in him by the method of elimination, how is he established for you?

analyzed: loka pravāda ādinā iti ced
translated: If it is argued that it is so because of popular belief etc.,

analyzed: mama api tathā iti astu
translated: let it be so for me also.

analyzed: bhavat abhimate brahmaṇi hetuḥ anaikāntikaḥ iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that the reason is inconclusive with regard to Brahman accepted by you, it is not so.

analyzed: kevala anumāna vādinam prati anīśvara vāda aṅgīkāreṇa pratyavasthānāt
translated: Because it is a counter-argument against one who advocates inference alone by accepting the doctrine of non-existence of God.

original: nanu jakatkāraṇatvaṃ śivaniṣṭhamanyatrānupapattau satyāṃ kiñcinniṣṭhatayā pramitatvāditi hi pariśeṣānumānam /
analyzed: nanu jakat kāraṇatvam śiva niṣṭham anyatra anupapattau satyām kiñcid niṣṭhatayā pramita tvāt iti hi pariśeṣa anumānam
translated: But is it not that the inference by elimination is that the cause of the world must belong to Śiva, because it is known to belong to something, if it is not possible to be anywhere else?

analyzed: tat katham asya ayam pratipakṣaḥ iti ced na
translated: If it is asked how this is a counter-argument to that, it is not so.

analyzed: viruddha artha sādhana mātreṇa pratipakṣa sambhavāt
translated: Because a counter-argument is possible merely by establishing a contradictory meaning.

analyzed: prayogāt pi eka dharma niṣṭha tāyāḥ pramāṇa prayojana śūnya tvāt anyathā evaṃvidha ārthika pratipakṣāṇām anyatra anantarbhāvena adūṣaṇa tva prasaṅgāt
translated: Even from the point of view of application, the belonging to a single property is devoid of proof and purpose. Otherwise, such counter-arguments would not be fallacies if not included elsewhere.

analyzed: na ca evam astu iti vācyam  pratirodhaka tvasya apratibandhaka tva
translated: And it cannot be said that this should be so.

analyzed: sya anubhava siddha tvāt
translated: Because the establishment of an obstruction is established by experience.

analyzed: nanu evam sati sāmānya siddhiḥ anupapannā āpadyate iti ced
translated: If it is argued that in that case the establishment of universals becomes untenable,

analyzed: āpadyatām
translated: let it be so.

analyzed: tad anumānānām dūṣita tvāt
translated: Because their inferences have been refuted.

analyzed: kim atas yadi evam iti ced
translated: If it is asked what follows from this if it is so,

analyzed: siddhaḥ sautra hetuḥ iti āha śāstra yoni tvam iti
translated: The reason stated in the Sūtra is established, he says: The fact that it has the Veda as its source.

analyzed: śāstra yoni tvam etena kāraṇasya balāt bhavet
translated: This [fact that it has the Veda as its source] would be the cause [of the existence of the world] by force,

analyzed: etena ukta prakāreṇa
translated: by this [above-mentioned] method.

analyzed: kāraṇasya jagataḥ iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The cause of the world, this is the remainder.

original: balātprakārāntareṇāsiddhibalāt / /🔽jagatkāraṇasyānumānāvedyatvaṃ śrutibhirapi siddhamityāha nāvedaviditi //🔽nāvedavinna tarkeṇa matirityādivākyataḥ /🔽tarko jñāpayituṃ śakto neśitāraṃ kathañcana // / / //
analyzed: balāt prakāra antareṇa asiddhi balāt  jagatkāraṇasya anumāna a vedya tvam śrutibhiḥ api siddham iti āha na a veda vid iti  na a veda vid na tarkeṇa matiḥ ityādi vākyataḥ  tarkaḥ jñāpayitum śaktaḥ na īśitāram kathañcana
translated: By force, by the power of the non-establishment in another way.🔽That the cause of the world is known by inference is also established by the Vedic texts. He says: Because of the statement that one who is not learned in the Veda cannot understand it by reasoning,

analyzed: na a veda vid manutā idam
translated: because of the statement that one who is not learned in the Veda cannot understand this,

analyzed: tam bṛhantam
translated: that great one,

analyzed: na eṣā tarkeṇa matiḥ āpaneyā
translated: that this [truth] cannot be grasped by reasoning,

analyzed: na indriyāṇi na anumānam vedāḥ hi eva enam vedayanti
translated: that the senses and inference cannot [grasp it], for the Vedas alone make it known,

analyzed: ityādi vākyataḥ
translated: and so on.

analyzed: iti jñāyate iti śeṣaḥ
translated: It is to be understood, this is the remainder.

analyzed: tarkaḥ iti anumāna mātra upalakṣaṇam
translated: Reasoning is a mere indication of inference.

analyzed: īśitāram
translated: The Lord, the cause of the world, the maker.

analyzed: kathañcana sāmānyatas viśeṣataḥ ca
translated: In any way, generally and specifically.

original: yadapi kāryatvādihetoḥ pakṣadharmatābalādanyasmādvānumānadīśvarasya sārvajñādisiddhiriti tadapi pratipakṣaduṣṭatvādayuktamityāha vanakṛttvādīti
analyzed: yat api kārya tva ādi hetoḥ pakṣa dharmatā balāt anyasmāt vā anumāna dīśvarasya sārvajña ādi siddhiḥ iti tat api pratipakṣa duṣṭa tvāt ayuktam iti āha vana kṛt tva ādi iti
translated: As for the argument that the omniscience etc. of God can be established through inference based on the property of the subject or other means using the reason of being an effect, etc., that too is incorrect due to the fault of the counter-example. He says:

analyzed: vanakṛt tva ādi rūpeṇa pakṣa bhūtasya ca īśituḥ
translated: In the form of being a forest-dweller, etc., the Lord who is the subject,

original: kiñcijjñānaṃ hi puṃstvena śakyaṃ sādhayituṃ sukham // / / // /
analyzed: kiñcid jñānam hi puṃstvena śakyam sādhayitum sukham
translated: a little knowledge can be easily established by the reason of being a male.

analyzed: nanu atra evam prayoktavyam
translated: But here it should be used in this way:

analyzed: īśvaraḥ kiñcid jñaḥ paṃra tvāt devadatta vat iti
translated: God has a little knowledge because of being a male, like Devadatta.

original: tatreśvaraḥ pramito vā na vā /🔽ādye yena prayatpra
analyzed: tatra īśvaraḥ pramitaḥ vā na vā  ādye yena prayat pra
translated: There, is God known or not?

analyzed: māṇena siddhaḥ tena eva tasya sārvajña siddheḥ dharmi grāhaka pramāṇa virodhaḥ
translated: If the first, by whatever means of valid knowledge He is established, by that very means His omniscience is established, so there is contradiction with the means of valid knowledge that grasps the subject.

analyzed: dvitīye tu āśraya asiddhiḥ
translated: If the second, then there is non-establishment of the basis.

original: tatkathamucyate īśituḥ kiñcijjñatvaṃ ca puṃstvena sādhayituṃ śakyaṃ hīti tatrāha sukhamiti //
analyzed: tat katham ucyate īśituḥ kiñcijjñatvam ca puṃstvena sādhayitum śakyam hi iti tatra āha sukham iti
translated: How then can it be said that the little knowledge of the Lord can be easily established by the reason of being a male? There it is said: easily.

analyzed: tat katham iti atas uktam vanakṛt tva ādi rūpeṇa pakṣa bhūtasya iti
translated: How is that? Therefore it is said: in the form of being a forest-dweller, etc., the subject.

original: prasiddhakartṛrahitaṃ vanaṃ sakartṛkaṃ kāryatvādityādinā yo vanādikartā siddhaḥ tenaivākāreṇa taṃ pakṣīkṛtya prayoge na ko 'pi doṣa ityāśayaḥ
analyzed: prasiddha kartṛ rahitam vanam sa kartṛkam kārya tvāt ityādinā yaḥ vana ādi kartā siddhaḥ tena eva ākāreṇa tam pakṣīkṛtya prayoge na kaḥ pi doṣaḥ iti āśayaḥ
translated: The idea is that when the creator of the forest, etc., who is established by such arguments as The forest, etc., have a creator because they are effects, is made the subject in that very form in the argument, there is no fault at all.

original: vanakṛttvaṃ parvatādhārakatvamityādirūpo dharmastenopetasya /🔽nahi vanakartetyetāvatā sarvajña iti labhyate /
analyzed: vana kṛt tvam parvata ādhāraka tvam ityādi rūpaḥ dharmaḥ tena upetasya  nahi vana kartā iti etāvatā sarvajñaḥ iti labhyate
translated: Endowed with that means endowed with the property in the form of being the creator of the forest, the supporter of mountains, and so on.🔽For by merely being the creator of the forest, omniscience is not established.

analyzed: prasiddha vana kartuḥ asarvajña tvāt
translated: Because the well-known creator of the forest is not omniscient.

original: sa evakṣityādikarteti kathaṃ na sārvajñyamiti cenna /
analyzed: saḥ eva kṣiti ādi kartā iti katham na sārvajñyam iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that he is the creator of the earth, etc., how can omniscience not be established? No.

analyzed: tad bhāve pramāṇa abhāvāt
translated: Because there is no evidence for his existence.

original: nahi kāryatvādihetuḥ kartāramiva tasya sarvatraikatvaṃ gamayituṃ śaknoti /
analyzed: nahi kārya tva ādi hetuḥ kartāram iva tasya sarvatra ekatvam gamayitum śaknoti
translated: For the reason of being an effect, etc., cannot establish the oneness of the creator everywhere, as it does with the creator.

analyzed: lāghavāt eka tvam āśrīyate iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that oneness is accepted due to simplicity, no.

analyzed: loka darśana anusāreṇa kartāram kalpayataḥ gaurava āśrayaṇasya eva usya ucita tvāt
translated: Because for one who imagines the creator in accordance with worldly perception, it is only proper to accept the more complex view.

original: loke hi gajagavayagardabhādīnāṃ ghaṭādīnāṃ ca nirmātāro vijātīyā evopalabhyante /
analyzed: loke hi gaja gavaya gardabha ādīnām ghaṭa ādīnām ca nirmātāraḥ vijātīyāḥ eva upalabhyante
translated: For in the world, the creators of elephants, buffaloes, donkeys, etc., and pots, etc., are only of different species.

original: naca vanakartā kiñcijjña iti sādhane kimīśvarasyeti vācyam /
analyzed: na ca vana kartā kiñcid jñaḥ iti sādhane kim īśvarasya iti vācyam
translated: And it should not be said that when it is established that the creator of the forest is not omniscient, what is the use of establishing the same for God.

analyzed: tasya ca īśvara tāyāḥ pareṇa
translated: And that is more than the status of God.

analyzed: anyathā vana kartari siddhe kim īśvara siddhau āyātam iti api syāt
translated: Otherwise, when the maker of the tree is established, what is the use of establishing God? This too could be said.

analyzed: na kevalam kiñcijjñatva sādhanam sukaram
translated: Not only is the proof of knowing something easy,

analyzed: kintu sva kṛta kārya ajña tvam api śakya sādhanam iti āśayena āha vṛkṣakṛt iti
translated: but the proof of knowing one's own created effects is also possible. With this intention, he says the maker of the tree.

analyzed: vṛkṣa kṛt na akhilam vṛkṣam vetti puṃstvāt hi caitra vat
translated: The maker of the tree does not know the entire tree, because of being a male, like Caitra.

analyzed: vṛkṣakṛt iti pūrvavat dharmi grāhaka virodha āśraya asiddhi parihārāya uktam
translated: The maker of the tree is stated like before to avoid the contradiction of the subject being unestablished.

analyzed: prasiddha kartṛ rahitā iti api yojyam
translated: Devoid of a well-known agent should also be added.

analyzed: anyathā siddha sādhana tā prasaṅgāt
translated: Otherwise, there would be the fallacy of proving what is already established.

analyzed: akhilam iti ārambhaka avayava saṅkhayā pala parimāṇa viśeṣa sahitam  asmāt ādīnām vipratipanna vṛkṣa jñāna mātra sadbhāvāt anaikāntya parihārāya akhilam iti uktam
translated: Entire means along with the number, parts, and specific dimensions of the components.🔽Entire is stated to avoid the fallacy of inconclusive evidence, since we and others merely have the knowledge of the disputed tree.

analyzed: hi iti vipakṣe bādhaka abhāvam sūcayati
translated: Because indicates the absence of a counter-argument.

original: nahi yo yatkartā sa sakalaṃ tajjānātīti niyamaḥ /
analyzed: nahi yaḥ yad kartā sa sakalam tat jānāti iti niyamaḥ
translated: There is no rule that one who is the maker of something knows it in its entirety.

analyzed: kulāla ādau abhāvāt
translated: Because it is not so in the case of a potter and others.

analyzed: anupayogāt ca tad jñānasya iti
translated: And because the knowledge of that is not useful.

original: anenaiva nyāyena sarvatra pratipakṣasambhavāt satyasaṅkalpatvāśarīritvanityajñānecchāprayatnatvaduḥkhādirāhityādikamapi nānumānena sādhayituṃ
analyzed: anena eva nyāyena sarvatra pratipakṣa sambhavāt satya saṅkalpa tva aśarīri tva nitya jñāna icchā prayatna tva duḥkha ādi rāhitya ādikam api na anumānena sādhayitum
translated: By this very reasoning, since the counter-example is possible in all cases, the possession of true resolve, the state of being bodiless, the nature of eternal knowledge, desire, and effort, the absence of suffering, etc. cannot be established even by inference.

analyzed: śakyam iti āśayavān āha ityādi iti
translated: With this intention, he says and so on.

analyzed: ityādi anumayā spardhi na anumānam para īśituḥ  śaktam vijñāpane
translated: Inference like this is not able to inform about the supreme Lord.

analyzed: ādi śabdaḥ prakāra vacanaḥ
translated: The word and so on means in this way.

analyzed: para īśituḥ satya saṅkalpa tva ādi upetasya
translated: Of the supreme Lord, who is endowed with true resolve and so on.

analyzed: ābhāsa samāna yogakṣemam ca īśvara anumāna jātam iti āha ca atiprasaṅgaḥ iti
translated: And the class of inferences about God are of the same nature as the appearances. He says and there is over-extension.

analyzed: ca atiprasaṅgaḥ numayā īdṛśā  īdṛśāḥ āgama ādi sahāya sampadam apahāya atyanta atīndriya artheṣu
translated: There is over-extension with such an inference.

analyzed: prayujyamānayā anumayā atiprasaṅgaḥ ca bhavati iti arthaḥ
translated: Such an inference, which is employed in matters that are completely beyond the senses, without abandoning the wealth of being accompanied by scriptures and so on, there is over-extension. This is the meaning.

analyzed: atiprasaṅgam eva darśayati vastu tvāt iti
translated: He shows the over-extension, saying because of being a real thing and so on.

original: vastutvāt turagaḥ śṛṅgī puṣpavat khaṃ sutairyutā /
analyzed: vastu tvāt turagaḥ śṛṅgī puṣpa vat kham sutaiḥ yutā
translated: Because of being a real thing, the horse has horns, the sky is endowed with flowers and sons,

original: citriṇī ca rasaḥ ṣaṣṭho rasatvāt sottaro bhavet // / /d //
analyzed: citriṇī ca rasaḥ ṣaṣṭhaḥ rasa tvāt sa uttaraḥ bhavet
translated: and the sixth taste is variegated. Because of being a taste, it would be superior.

analyzed: citriṇī vandhyā
translated: Variegated means barren.

original: ṣaṣṭho raso rasāntaravānityukte prathamādirasena siddhasādhanaṃ syāt /
analyzed: ṣaṣṭhaḥ rasaḥ rasa antaravān iti ukte prathama ādi rasena siddhasādhanam syāt
translated: If it is said that the sixth taste has another taste, then the proof would be established by the first taste.

analyzed: saptama rasavān iti ukte aprasiddha viśeṣaṇa tā syāt
translated: If it is said that the seventh has a taste, then there would be the fault of the qualifier being unknown.

analyzed: atas sa uttaraḥ iti uktam
translated: Therefore, it is said to be with a remainder.

analyzed: īśvara anumānasya pramāṇa tāyām eteṣām api prāmāṇyam syāt iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The meaning is that if the inference of God is valid, then these [means of knowledge] would also be valid.

analyzed: nanu vastu tvam ghaṭa ādau anaikāntikam iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that existence is inconclusive in a pot and so on, it is not so.

analyzed: tasya api pakṣa tvāt
translated: Because that [pot] is also the subject [of the inference].

analyzed: turaga ṛṅga ādīnām anupalambha bādhaḥ iti ced
translated: If it is argued that the horn of a horse and so on are contradicted by non-apprehension,

analyzed: kṣiti ādi sa kartuḥ api evam eva
translated: it is the same for the maker of earth and so on.

analyzed: ayogya tvāt na upalabhyate iti ced
translated: If it is argued that it is not apprehended because it is not fit [to be apprehended],

original: turagaviṣāṇamapi evamamevāstu /🔽na canu viṣāṇaṃ nāma mahattve satyudbhūtarūpaḥ
analyzed: turaga viṣāṇam api  na canu viṣāṇam nāma mahattve sati udbhūta rūpaḥ
translated: let the horn of a horse be just like that.

analyzed: śarīra avayava viśeṣaḥ
translated: And a horn is not a part of the body with increased form when it has greatness.

analyzed: sa katham upalabdhi ayogyaḥ syāt iti ced
translated: How can it be unfit to be apprehended?

analyzed: kartā api tarhi kulāla ādiḥ iva mahattve sati adbhuta rūpa śarīravān katham upalabdhi ayogyaḥ bhaviṣyati
translated: If it is argued that the maker, like a potter and so on, having a body with increased form when it has greatness, how will it be unfit to be apprehended,

analyzed: aśarīra tvāt na upalabhyate iti ced  rūpa abhāvāt turaga viṣāṇam api tathā astu
translated: if it is argued that it is not apprehended because it is bodiless,🔽let the horn of a horse be like that because of the absence of form.

analyzed: viṣāṇam rūpavat eva iti ced
translated: If it is argued that a horn is only with form,

analyzed: kartā api śarīravān eva
translated: Even the creator exists only with a body.

analyzed: śarīram kartṛ tve n upayuktam iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that the body is not useful for being a creator, it is not so.

analyzed: kim upayogena
translated: What is the use?

analyzed: na hi tad utpattyā vyāptiḥ bauddhānām iva bhavatām
translated: For you, unlike the Buddhists, there is no pervasion by its production.

analyzed: dharma ādimattvam śarīri tve prayojakam iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that having a body is the reason for being a creator, it is not so.

analyzed: tasya api kartṛ tvena sādhanāt iti
translated: Because that too is to be proved as being a creator.

analyzed: nanu katham atra prayoktavyam
translated: But how is it to be used here?

original: anumānatvaṃ yadi kāryatvādau varteta tadā tadaviśiṣṭe vastutvādauapi
analyzed: anumāna tvam yadi kārya tva ādau varteta tadā tad aviśiṣṭe vastu tva ādau api
translated: If the nature of being an inference were to occur in being an effect, then it would occur in existence, which is not distinguished from that.

analyzed: varteta iti evam iti
translated: In this way.

original: nanu vicāraśāstramārabhya jagatkāraṇe 'numānānavakāśavyutpādanaṃ vyāhatamityāśaṅkāṃ pariharannupasaṃharati upakramādīti //
analyzed: nanu vicāra śāstram ārabhya jagat kāraṇe numāna anavakāśa vyutpādanam vyāhatam iti āśaṅkām pariharan upasaṃharati upakrama ādi iti
translated: Now, the explanation of the impossibility of inference regarding the cause of the world, beginning with the treatise on inquiry, is contradicted. Anticipating this doubt, he concludes with the words from the indications of the beginning etc.

analyzed: upakrama ādi liṅgebhyaḥ na anyā āsyāt anumā tatas
translated: Inference cannot be different from this, due to indications such as the beginning.

analyzed: āgama anugṛhīta anumāna upalakṣaṇam etat
translated: This is a metaphor for inference aided by scripture.

analyzed: āgama anugrahe hi sarvāṇi etāni anumānāni eva
translated: For when scripture is favorable, all these are indeed inferences.

analyzed: pakṣa dharmatā ādīnām aṅgānām apauruṣeya tayā svatas pramāṇena śāstreṇa siddheḥ
translated: Because the components such as being a property of the subject are established by the scripture itself, which is authoritative because it is not of human origin.

analyzed: pratipakṣa ādīnām ca tad virodhena bādhāt iti saṅkṣepaḥ
translated: And because the counter-arguments etc. are contradicted by that. This is the summary.

analyzed: tat evam jagat kāraṇa tvasya ṇasya  śāstra eka samadhigamya tvāt na anumāna ādinā
translated: Thus, since the quality of being the cause of the world🔽is to be known only through the scriptures, it is not proper to state the over-extension of the definition

analyzed: lakṣaṇasya ativyāpti kathanam yuktam iti siddham
translated: by means of inference, etc. Thus it is established.

analyzed: atha atra parakīya bhāṣyasya apavyākhyāna tvam
translated: Now, the other party's commentary here is a misinterpretation

analyzed: atra kecid śāstrasya yoniḥ iti
translated: Here some explain the source of the scripture as follows.

analyzed: tat anupapannam prakṛta anupayogāt
translated: That is not correct, because it is not relevant to the present context.

analyzed: nahi śāstra kāraṇatvam jagat kāraṇatve hetuḥ
translated: For the quality of being the cause of the scripture is not the reason for the quality of being the cause of the world.

analyzed: vyāpti adarśanāt
translated: Because no pervasion is seen.

original: pūvarsūtre jagatkāraṇatvena pratītaṃ sārvajñaṃ brahmaṇo vedakāraṇatvena sphuṭīkriyata iti cenna /
analyzed: pūvarsūtre jagat kāraṇatvena pratītam sārvajñam brahmaṇaḥ veda kāraṇatvena sphuṭīkriyate iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that the omniscience of Brahman, which is known as the cause of the world in the previous aphorism, is made clear as the cause of the Veda, that is not so.

analyzed: vedasya api sakala jagat antarbhāvāt
translated: Because even the Veda is included in the entire world.

original: kathaṃ cānantapadārthātmakasya prapañcasya kartṛtvena na sphuṭaṃ tadekadeśavedakāraṇatvena sphuṭībhaviṣyati sārvajñam /
analyzed: katham ca ananta padārtha ātmakasya prapañcasya kartṛ tvena na sphuṭam tad eka deśa veda kāraṇa tvena sphuṭībhaviṣyati sārvajñam
translated: And how will the omniscience, which is not clearly manifested as the cause of the world consisting of infinite things, be made clear as the cause of a part of it, the Veda?

original: atha jagatkāraṇatvaṃ pradhānādivyudāsena brahmaṇyeva sādhayituṃ hetutvenoktaṃ sārvajñaṃ śāstrayonitvena sādhyata iti cenna /
analyzed: atha jagat kāraṇatvam pradhāna ādi vyudāsena brahmaṇi eva sādhayitum hetu tvena uktam sārvajñam śāstra yoni tvena sādhyate iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that the omniscience, which is stated as the reason to establish the quality of being the cause of the world in Brahman alone by excluding primordial matter, etc., is to be established as the quality of being the source of the scripture, that is not so.

analyzed: asiddhi prasaṅgāt
translated: Because it would lead to the fallacy of non-establishment.

analyzed: nahi brahmaṇaḥ jagat kāraṇatvam an aṅgīkurvāṇaḥ veda kāraṇatvam aṅgīkaroti
translated: For one who does not accept Brahman as the cause of the world does not accept it as the cause of the Veda.

analyzed: āgamena sādhyate iti ced
translated: If it is argued that it is proved by scripture,

original: tarhi jagatkāraṇatvameva tena kiṃ na sādhyate /
analyzed: tarhi jagat kāraṇatvam eva tena kim na sādhyate
translated: then why is not its being the cause of the world also proved by that?

analyzed: īkṣati adhikaraṇa ādinā janma ādi sūtrasya punarukta prasaṅgāt ca
translated: And because of the possibility of repetition of the argument beginning with the origination of the world in the aphorism beginning with īkṣate (the first aphorism of the Vedānta Sūtras).

original: jagatkāraṇatvena savarjñatvaṃ na siddhayati vedākartṛtvādityāśaṅkayedamuktamiti cenna /
analyzed: jagat kāraṇatvena savarjñatvam na veda akartṛ tvāt iti āśaṅkayā idam uktam iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that this is stated to remove the doubt that omniscience is not established by the cause of the world because of not being the author of the Veda, it is not so.

analyzed: tathā sati pratijñā mātra tva prasaṅgāt
translated: Because if it were so, it would lead to the absurdity of being a mere proposition.

analyzed: viyat ādi viṣaye pi evam āśaṅkā prasaṅgāt
translated: And because the possibility of doubt would arise even in the case of ether and so on.

original: viyadadhikaraṇādau sāpi nirākariṣyata iti cet na /
analyzed: viyat adhikaraṇa ādau sā api nirākariṣyate iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that it will be refuted in the section on ether and so on, it is not so.

analyzed: tarhi tena eva idam gata artham syāt  kiñca veda kartṛ tva abhāvena
translated: Then this would be already established by that itself.

analyzed: sārvajñyam na sambhavati iti śaṅkā eva nirdalā
translated: Moreover, the doubt itself is baseless that omniscience is not possible due to the absence of being the author of the Veda.

analyzed: nahi tad kartrā eva tat jñātavyam iti niyamaḥ sti
translated: For there is no rule that it is to be known only by its author.

analyzed: kiñca veda kartṛ tvam katham sārvajñya sādhakam
translated: Moreover, how does the absence of being the author of the Veda prove omniscience?

original: yo yāvadarthapratipādakasya vākyasya praṇetā sa tato 'pyadhikamarthaṃ jānātyeva /
analyzed: yaḥ yāvat artha pratipādakasya vākyasya praṇetā sa tatas pi adhikam artham jānāti eva
translated: One who is the author of a sentence conveying a certain meaning knows that much meaning and more.

analyzed: yathā pāṇinyādiḥ
translated: Like Panini and others.

original: ayaṃ cāśeṣārthapratipādakasya śāstrasya praṇetātaḥ kathaṃ na sarvatra iti cet na /
analyzed: ayam ca aśeṣa artha pratipādakasya śāstrasya praṇetā atas katham na sarvatra iti ced na
translated: And since he is the author of the treatise that sets forth all things, why is he not everywhere? If this is asked, it is not so.

original: kimidaṃ vedapraṇetṛtvaṃ nāma /🔽kiṃ pramāṇāntareṇārthamupalabhya svecchayā padādini
analyzed: kim idam veda praṇetṛ tvam nāma  kim pramāṇa antareṇa artham upalabhya sva icchayā pada ādini
translated: What is this called authorship of the Vedas?

analyzed: prabandhana
translated: Is it the act of arranging the words etc. according to one's own will after perceiving the meaning by another means of knowledge,

analyzed: katṛ tvam kim vā uccāraṇa mātram
translated: or is it mere utterance?

analyzed: ādye pauruṣeya tva āpattiḥ
translated: In the first case, it would follow that it is authored by a person.

analyzed: dvitīye sārvajñya asiddhiḥ
translated: In the second case, omniscience would not be established.

analyzed: upādhyāya ādi vat
translated: Like a teacher and so on.

analyzed: rajjau bhujaṅga vat brahmaṇi āropitaḥ vedaḥ iti ced
translated: If it is argued that the Veda is superimposed on Brahman like a snake on a rope,

analyzed: katham tarhi pāṇini ādi dṛṣṭāntaḥ
translated: then how is the example of Panini and others?

analyzed: nahi pāṇinā avāropitam vyākaraṇam
translated: For grammar is not superimposed by Panini.

analyzed: katham ca evam sati sārvajñya siddhiḥ
translated: And how, in that case, is omniscience established?

analyzed: tasya eva vijñāna śakti vivarta tvāt śāstrasya iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that the treatise is the manifestation of the power of knowledge of Brahman itself, it is not so.

analyzed: viyat ādīnām api prakāśa śakti prasaṅgāt
translated: Because it would follow that space etc. also have the power of manifestation.

analyzed: avidyā gata āvaraṇa ādi śakteḥ api brahmaṇi tāttvika tva prasaṅgāt ca
translated: And because it would follow that the power of covering etc. present in ignorance is also real in Brahman.

original: kiñca vede jñānakaraṇatvaśaktirbrahmaṇi ca tatkartṛtvaśaktiriti kiṃ kena saṅgatam /
analyzed: kiñca vede jñāna karaṇa tva śaktiḥ brahmaṇi ca tad kartṛ tva śaktiḥ iti kim kena saṅgatam
translated: Moreover, what connection is there between the power of being the instrument of knowledge in the Veda and the power of being its agent in Brahman?

analyzed: kutra ca idam upalabdham āropya gatā śaktiḥ āropa adhiṣṭhāne vāstavī iti
translated: And where is this found that the superimposed power is real in the basis of superimposition?

analyzed: tasmāt apavyākhyānam eva tat iti uktaḥ eva sūtra arthaḥ
translated: Therefore, that is indeed a misinterpretation. Thus, the meaning of the sutra is stated.

analyzed: iti śrīmat nyāyasudhāyām śāstra yoni tva adhikaraṇam
translated: Thus ends the chapter on the source of the scriptures in the glorious Nyāyasudhā.
III. The chapter on the non-contradiction of the scriptures.

analyzed: atha śrīmat nyāyasudhāyām samanvaya adhikaraṇam
translated: Now, in the glorious Nyāyasudhā, the chapter on the non-contradiction of the scriptures.

analyzed: pūrvapakṣa racanā  om tat tu samanvayāt om
translated: The arrangement of the prima facie view🔽Om. That is to be understood from the non-contradiction of the scriptures.

analyzed: tat tu samanvayāt
translated: That is to be understood from the non-contradiction of the scriptures.

analyzed: astu śāstra eka samadhigamyam jagat kāraṇam
translated: Let there be the cause of the world which is to be understood only from the scriptures.

original: tathāpi śāstrata evānyeṣāṃ harahiraṇyagarbhādīnāṃ pradhānādīnāṃ ca jagatkāraṇatvapratīterativyāpakamidaṃ lakṣaṇam /
analyzed: tathā api śāstrataḥ eva anyeṣām hara hiraṇyagarbha ādīnām pradhāna ādīnām ca jagat kāraṇatva pratīteḥ ativyāpakam idam lakṣaṇam
translated: Even so, this definition is too wide, since the scriptures present other causes of the world such as Hara, Hiranyagarbha, etc., and Pradhana, etc.

analyzed: na ca tat śāstram viṣṇu param iti vācyam
translated: And it cannot be said that those scriptures are about Vishnu.

analyzed: abhiyuktaiḥ śiva ādi paratvena vyākhyāta tvāt
translated: Because they are explained by the learned as being about Shiva and others.

original: yadyapi nāmāni sarvāṇītyādiśrutyā śivādināmnāṃ viṣṇau śaktimātramavasīyate /
analyzed: yadi api nāmāni sarvāṇi ityādi śrutyā śiva ādi nāmnām viṣṇau śakti mātram avasīyate
translated: Although the Shruti passage beginning with all the names establishes that the names of Shiva and others have power only in Vishnu,

analyzed: tathā api na tātparye pramāṇam asti
translated: nevertheless, there is no proof of their intention.

original: yatparaḥ śabdaḥ sa śabdārtha iti hi nyāyaḥ /
analyzed: yad paraḥ śabdaḥ sa śabda arthaḥ iti hi nyāyaḥ
translated: For the rule is: that which is the purport of a word is the meaning of that word.

analyzed: na ca śakti mātreṇa tātparyam kalpayitum yuktam
translated: And it is not proper to assume the purport merely by the mere power [of the words].

analyzed: atiprasaṅgāt  anyatra tātparyasya ca
translated: Because of overextension.

analyzed: jñāpakam abhiyukta vyākhyānam asti iti uktam
translated: And it has been said that the explanation by the learned is the indicator of the purport elsewhere.

analyzed: tasmāt alakṣaṇam etat iti āśaṅkaya parihṛtam sūtrakṛtā tat tu samanvayāt iti
translated: Therefore, fearing that this [purport] is not a defining characteristic, the author of the commentary has refuted it with the aphorism But that [purport] is by the connection [of the words and their meanings].

analyzed: om tattu samanvayāt om
translated: Om. But that [purport] is by the connection [of the words and their meanings]. Om.

analyzed: sūtra vākya yojanā
translated: The arrangement of the sentence of the aphorism

analyzed: tatra anvaya padārtham āha te eva iti
translated: There, he states the meaning of the word connection with those alone.

original: ta evānvayanāmānas / / / // / / //🔽upakramādaya evānvīyante śaktitātparyagocareṇa sambaddhayante tathā jñāyanta iti yāvat vākyānyetaiḥ ityanvayanāmānaḥ /
analyzed: te eva anvaya nāmānaḥ  upakrama ādayaḥ eva anvīyante śakti tātparya gocareṇa tathā jñāyante iti yāvat vākyāni etaiḥ iti anvaya nāmānaḥ
translated: Those alone are named connections🔽The introductions and so on are connected, are related, by the scope of power and purport, and are known thus. The sentences are thus named connections by these.

original: atropakramādiprasiddhapadaṃ parityajya yaugikānvayapadaparigrahaṇeneheṇe🔽daṃ sūcayati /🔽na śāstratātparyāvagatāvāpātapratītirvyākhyātṛvacanaṃ vā liṅgam /
analyzed: atra upakrama ādi prasiddha padam parityajya yaugika anvaya pada parigrahaṇena iheṇe  dam sūcayati  na śāstra tātparya avagatau āpāta pratītiḥ vyākhyātṛ vacanam vā liṅgam
translated: Here, by abandoning the well-known word introduction and adopting the etymological word connection, he indicates the following.🔽The prima facie understanding based on the purport of the scripture, or the statement of the commentator, is not the indicator.

analyzed: kintu upakrama ādayaḥ eva
translated: But rather the introductions and so on alone.

analyzed: teṣām avyabhicāri tvāt
translated: Because they are invariable.

analyzed: pratīti vyākhyānayoḥ tu vyabhicāri tvāt
translated: Because the understanding and the commentary are variable.

original: yatrāpi pratīvyākhyāne na vyabhicaratastatrāpyupakramādyanusandhānapūrvakatvenaiva na tu svataḥ /
analyzed: yatra api na vyabhicarataḥ tatra api upakrama ādi anusandhāna pūrvakatvena eva na tu svatas
translated: Even where they do not deviate in the explanation of the purport, there also it is only by being preceded by the consideration of the beginning etc., and not by themselves.

analyzed: atas upajīvya tvāt upakrama ādīnām eva tātparya liṅga tvam iti
translated: Therefore, because they are the basis, the beginning etc. alone are the indicators of the purport.

analyzed: tat idam āha te eva iti
translated: This is what is said by those alone.

analyzed: sūtra vākyam yojayati taiḥ iti
translated: He connects the sutra with the sentence by them.

analyzed: taiḥ samyak pravicārite
translated: When they are well considered.

analyzed: mukhya arthaḥ bhagavān viṣṇuḥ sarva śāstrasya na aparaḥ
translated: The primary meaning is Lord Vishnu, not anyone else, of all scriptures.

analyzed: anena anvayāt iti ekavacanam samudāya artham iti uktam bhavati
translated: By this it is said that the singular number in from that refers to the collective meaning.

analyzed: tena ca teṣām avirodham sūcayati
translated: And by that he indicates their non-contradiction.

analyzed: sam śabda arthaḥ samyak iti
translated: The meaning of the word sam is well.

original: tasya ca pravicārita ityadhyāhṛtakriyayā sambandho darśitaḥ /
analyzed: tasya ca pravicāritaḥ iti adhyāhṛta kriyayā sambandhaḥ darśitaḥ
translated: And its connection with the understood verb considered is shown.

original: nanu ca pratītivyākhyānavadupakramādīnāmapi kvacittātparyavyabhicāradarśanātkathaṃ liṅgatvamityāśaṅkānirāsāya samyak pravicārita ityuktam /
analyzed: nanu ca pratīti vyākhyāna vat upakrama ādīnām api kvacid tātparya vyabhicāra darśanāt katham liṅga tvam iti āśaṅkā nirāsāya samyak pravicāritaḥ iti uktam
translated: But since the beginning etc. are also seen to deviate from the purport somewhere, like the explanation of the understanding, how can they be the indicators? To remove this doubt, it is said when they are well considered.

original: upakramādīnāṃ śrutyādīnāṃ ca sannikarṣaviprakarṣābhyāṃ sāvakāśatvādinā ca balābalaviniścayapuraḥsaraṃ virodhe balavatā durbalabādhayā vākyārthavimarśaḥ
analyzed: upakrama ādīnām śruti ādīnām ca sannikarṣa viprakarṣābhyām sāvakāśa tva ādinā ca bala abala viniścaya puraḥsaram virodhe balavatā durbala bādhayā vākya artha vimarśaḥ
translated: The consideration of the meaning of a sentence, preceded by the ascertainment of the strength and weakness of the introductory portion etc. and the direct statement etc. by proximity and remoteness and by the presence or absence of scope etc., is

analyzed: samyak pravicāraṇam
translated: the proper investigation.

analyzed: tena na upakrama ādi mātram liṅgam ucyate
translated: Therefore, the introductory portion etc. are not said to be the only reason.

analyzed: yena vyabhicāra udbhāvanam saṅgaccheta
translated: By which the raising of the fallacy of non-applicability would be appropriate.

analyzed: kintu samyak pravicāra lakṣaṇa avāntara vyapāra upetāḥ eva upakrama ādayaḥ
translated: But the introductory portion etc. are only those that are accompanied by the intermediate operation characterized by proper investigation.

analyzed: na ca te kvacid vayabhicaranti iti uktam bhavati
translated: And it is said that they never fail to apply anywhere.

original: pravicārita iti bhāve ktaḥ /🔽pravicāre kṛte satīti /
analyzed: pravicāritaḥ iti bhāve ktaḥ  pravicāre kṛte sati iti
translated: The kta suffix in 'vicārite' (investigated) denotes the state.🔽It means when the proper investigation is done.

analyzed: śāstre pravicārite sati iti vā
translated: Or when the scripture is properly investigated.

analyzed: etat avagamyate iti vākya śeṣaḥ
translated: The remainder of the sentence is 'this is understood'.

analyzed: mukhya arthaḥ iti āvṛttyā saṃśabdasya artha antaram
translated: The word 'main' is repeated as the meaning of the word 'sam' (all).

analyzed: sarvā iti api sam śabda arthaḥ eva
translated: 'All' is also only the meaning of the word 'sam'.

analyzed: śāstrasya arthaḥ iti śāstra yoni iti pūvarsūtrāt anuvṛttasya vyākhyānam
translated: The meaning of the scripture is explained as the continuation of the previous aphorism 'the source of the scripture'.

analyzed: bhagavān viṣṇuḥ iti tad śabda arthaḥ
translated: The meaning of the word 'tat' (that) is Lord Vishnu.

analyzed: tuśabdaḥ va dhāraṇe
translated: The word 'tu' (but) is for determination.

analyzed: tad vayākhyānam na aparaḥ iti
translated: The explanation of that is 'not another'.

analyzed: tathā ca evam sūtra yojanā
translated: And thus the Sūtra is to be explained in this way.

original: anvayādupakramādiliṅgasamudāyāt śāstre samyak pravicārite sati sarvaśāstrasya bhagavatyeva
analyzed: anvayāt upakrama ādi liṅga samudāyāt śāstre samyak pravicārite sati sarva śāstrasya bhagavati eva
translated: When the entire scripture has been well examined by means of the collection of evidence such as context, etc., then, because of the proper application of words to the Blessed One alone,

analyzed: samyak vacana vṛttyā anvayāt śakti tātparya lakṣaṇa sambandha avagamāt tat viṣṇu ākhyam brahmā eva
translated: the relation characterized by power and purport is understood. Therefore, that Brahman called Viṣṇu alone

original: jagajjanmādikāraṇatvena śāstrayoni na tu harahiraṇyagarbhādaya iti /
analyzed: jagat janma ādi kāraṇa tvena śāstra yoni na tu hara hiraṇyagarbha ādayaḥ iti
translated: is the source of the scripture as the cause of the creation, etc. of the world, and not Hara, Hiraṇyagarbha, etc.

analyzed: ananta guṇa paripūrṇa tvam hi pradhāna lakṣaṇam
translated: For being complete with infinite qualities is the definition of the primary (Brahman).

original: tatra ca śāstraṃ pramāṇīkriyamāṇaṃ vacanavṛttyā sarvameva ca yuktam /
analyzed: tatra ca śāstram pramāṇīkriyamāṇam vacana vṛttyā sarvam eva ca yuktam
translated: And when the scripture is taken as authoritative, then everything is proper by the application of words.

analyzed: lakṣaṇa ādinā vṛttau vācya artha guṇa alābhāt
translated: Because the qualities of the denoted meaning are not obtained in the case of the application by definition, etc.

analyzed: vācye tad guṇa prasaṅgāt ca
translated: And because the qualities of the denoted meaning would follow.

analyzed: evam katipaya vākyaiḥ ananta guṇa a pratipādanāt  vākya antara viṣayasya ca
translated: Thus, because the infinite qualities are not conveyed by a few sentences,

analyzed: t tva prasaṅgāt ca
translated: and because the qualities of that would follow for what is the subject of another sentence,

analyzed: atas saṃśabdasya āvṛttiḥ upapannā
translated: therefore the repetition of the word all is proper.

original: nanu janmādyasya yata iti yacchabdaśravaṇāttadbrahmeti prakṛtam /
analyzed: nanu janma ādyasya yatas iti yad śabda śravaṇāt tat brahma iti prakṛtam
translated: But since the word that is heard in from which the origin, etc. of this (universe) (Sūtra 1.1.2), that Brahman is the subject.

analyzed: tat eva atra maṇḍūka plutyā anuvartiṣyate
translated: That alone will be carried over here by the leap of a frog.

analyzed: kim punar atra tad grahaṇena
translated: What, then, is the purpose of mentioning that here?

analyzed: mā evam
translated: Not so.

analyzed: tuśabdaḥ tāvat atra itara vyāvṛtti artham upādeyaḥ
translated: The word 'tu' (but) should be used here for the purpose of excluding the other.

original: naca tasya tadityanuktau anvayaḥ pratyetuṃ śakyate /
analyzed: na ca tasya tat iti anuktau anvayaḥ pratyetum śakyate
translated: And without saying 'that', the relation cannot be understood.

original: yato 'vadhāraṇaṃ tato 'nyatra niṣedha iti vacanāt /🔽nacānuvṛttenānvayapratītirbhaviṣyatīti vācyam /
analyzed: yatas tatas nyatra niṣedhaḥ iti vacanāt  na ca anuvṛttena anvaya pratītiḥ bhaviṣyati iti vācyam
translated: Because it is said that negation is of what is other than what is determined.🔽And it should not be said that the relation will be understood by what is common.

analyzed: śrutena anvayāt iti anena eva sambandha pratīti prasaṅgāt
translated: Because it would follow that the relation is understood by the very statement 'from what is heard, the relation'.

analyzed: tatra upayoga abhāvāt na iti ced na
translated: If it is said that it is not so because there is no use there, it is not so.

analyzed: anvaya padāt eva tad siddhiḥ iti ced na
translated: Because it is appropriate that it serves the purpose of refuting the explanation of the relation.🔽If it is said that that is established by the word 'relation' itself, it is not so.

analyzed: tasya upakrama ādīnām liṅga tva pratipādane eva caritārtha tva sambhavāt
translated: Because it is possible that it serves the purpose of establishing the indicativeness of the introduction etc. itself.

analyzed: atas sārthakam sūtre tad grahaṇam
translated: Therefore, the mention of that in the aphorism is meaningful.

original: saṃśabdena sakalapadānāṃ lakṣaṇayā brahmaprātipadikārthamātraparatvamucyata iti vyākhyānamakhaṇḍārthanirāsena nirastam /
analyzed: sam śabdena sakala padānām lakṣaṇayā brahma prātipadika artha mātra paratvam ucyate iti vyākhyānam akhaṇḍa artha nirāsena nirastam
translated: The explanation that the word 'sa' (together) expresses the meaning of the root 'brah' (to be great) alone by implication of all the words is refuted by the refutation of the indivisible meaning.

analyzed: nirākariṣyate ca uttaratra iti na iha nirākṛtam
translated: And it will be refuted later, so it is not refuted here.

original: tadevaṃ jagajjanmādikāraṇatvena mukhyayā vṛttyā varṇapadavākyātmakāśeṣaśāstrapratipādyaṃ nārāyaṇākhyaṃ brahmaiveti susthaṃ lakṣaṇamiti siddham
analyzed: tat evam jagat janma ādi kāraṇatvena mukhyayā vṛttyā varṇa pada vākya ātmaka aśeṣa śāstra pratipādyam nārāyaṇa ākhyam brahma eva iti sustham lakṣaṇam iti siddham
translated: Thus, it is well established that the definition is sound, that the Brahman called Nārāyaṇa, which is the subject matter of the entire scripture consisting of letters, words, and sentences, is primarily the cause of the creation, etc. of the world.

analyzed: iti śrīmat nyāyasudhāyām samanvaya adhikaraṇam
translated: Thus ends the chapter on Anuvāda in the commentary of Śrīmat Nāyavivṛti.

analyzed: īkṣati adhikaraṇam
translated: Chapter IV: The Chapter on Meditation (Īkṣaṭyādhikaraṇa).

analyzed: atha īkṣati adhikaraṇam
translated: Now begins the chapter on meditation (Īkṣaṭyādhikaraṇa).

analyzed: om īkṣateḥ na aśabdam om
translated: The defense of Brahman being the subject matter of the entire scripture.🔽Om. Not by the word, because of meditation. Om.

analyzed: īkṣateḥ na a śabdam
translated: Not by the word, because of meditation.

analyzed: vacana vṛttyā eva sakala śāstra pratipādyam brahma iti uktam tat ākṣipya samādhātum idam adhikaraṇam ārabhyate
translated: It has been said that Brahman is the subject matter of the entire scripture only by the primary meaning of the words. That is disputed and resolved in this chapter.

analyzed: tathā hi  yatas vācaḥ nivartante aśabdam asparśam  ityādi śruteḥ
translated: It is as follows.🔽From the śruti: From which words turn back, the wordless, the intangible,

analyzed: śabdaḥ na yatra puru kārakavān
translated: and from the smrti: Where there is no word, no agent, etc.,

analyzed: ityādi smṛteḥ ca brahma avācyam avasīyate
translated: it is concluded that Brahman is inexpressible.

analyzed: vacana vṛttiḥ ca dravya guṇa kriyā jāti nimittā
translated: And verbal usage is based on substance, quality, action, genus, and cause.

original: naca brahmaṇo dravyādiyogo 'sti /🔽kevalo nirguṇaśca'niṣkalaṃ niṣkriyaṃ śāntam' /
analyzed: na ca brahmaṇaḥ dravya ādi yogaḥ sti  kevalaḥ nirguṇaḥ ca niṣkalam niṣkriyam śāntam
translated: And Brahman has no connection with substance, etc.

analyzed: ityādi āgamāt
translated: It is said in the Āgamas: It is alone, without qualities, partless, actionless, peaceful, etc.

analyzed: tat katham tasya vācya tā sambhavati
translated: How then can it be the meaning of that (word)?

analyzed: aupaniṣada tvam tu
translated: But the fact of being taught in the Upanisads

analyzed: ca lakṣaṇayā vṛttyā sambhavan na vācya tām apekṣate
translated: can be (regarded as) the meaning (of the word) by implication, and does not require that it should be the expressed meaning.

analyzed: atas vācya tvāt brahmaṇaḥ na vacana vṛttyā śāstra gamya tvam iti
translated: Therefore, because Brahman is inexpressible, it is not the object of the scriptures in the sense of being their expressed meaning.

original: apara āha na sarvaśāstrapratipādyatvaṃ brahmaṇaḥ sambhavati niścayopāyābhāvāt /
analyzed: aparaḥ āha na sarva śāstra pratipādya tvam brahmaṇaḥ sambhavati niścaya upāya abhāvāt
translated: Another (commentator) says: It is not possible for Brahman to be the subject-matter of all the scriptures, because there is no means of ascertaining it.

analyzed: upakrama ādayaḥ hi tad niścaya upāyāḥ
translated: For the means of ascertaining it are the introductory passages, etc.

analyzed: taiḥ ca asmad ādi adhigata śāstrasya kathañcid brahma viṣaya tā avadhāraṇe pi asmad anadhigata śāstrasya tad para tā avadhāraṇa ayogāt  anantāḥ vai vedāḥ
translated: And even if the determination of the subject-matter of the scriptures known to us is somehow made to apply to Brahman by those (means), it is impossible to determine the subject-matter of the scriptures unknown to us as being about Brahman.🔽For it is said in the scriptures: 'The Vedas are endless.'

analyzed: iti śruteḥ anantam hi śāstram avagamyate
translated: For it is understood that the scriptures are endless.

analyzed: na ca ananta śāstra adhigamaḥ smākam kalpa koṭi śataiḥ api sambhavati
translated: And it is not possible for us to understand endless scriptures even in hundreds of millions of kalpas.

analyzed: viphalaḥ ca śāstra eka deśasya brahma para tva adhyavasāyaḥ  eka deśa antare tad viparīta pratipādanasya api śaṅkanāt
translated: And it is futile to determine that a part of the scriptures is about Brahman,🔽because even the teaching of something contrary to that is suspected in another part.

original: naca vastuni vikalpaḥ sambhavati iti atrāpi sandehaḥ samāskandati /
analyzed: na ca vastuni vikalpaḥ sambhavati iti atra api sandehaḥ samāskandati
translated: And alternative views are not possible in regard to an existent thing. Therefore, doubt also creeps in here.

original: ityato na sarvaśāstraprāmāṇyājjagajjanmādikāraṇaṃ samastaguṇaparipūrṇaṃ brahma siddhayati /
analyzed: iti atas na sarva śāstra prāmāṇyāt jagat janma ādikāraṇam samasta guṇa paripūrṇam brahma siddhayati
translated: Therefore, the existence of Brahman, which is the cause of the creation, etc. of the world, and which is full of all perfections, is not established by the authoritativeness of all the scriptures.

original: ityevaṃ prāpte avācyatvaśaṅkāṃ tāvannirācaṣṭe sūtrakāraḥ īkṣaternāśabdamiti //
analyzed: iti evam prāpte avācya tva śaṅkām tāvat nirācaṣṭe sūtrakāraḥ īkṣateḥ na aśabdam iti
translated: When this is the prima facie view, the author of the aphorisms now sets aside the doubt of indescribability with the aphorism Not indescribable, because of the word 'sees'.

analyzed: īkṣateḥ na a śabdam om
translated: Not indescribable, because of the word 'sees'.

analyzed: tat vayācaṣṭe īkṣaṇīya tvataḥ iti
translated: He explains that with Because of the state of being seen.

analyzed: atra īkṣateḥ iti dhātu nirdeśaḥ
translated: Here, sees is the indication of the verbal root.

original: na cāvivakṣitārthaṃ śabdamātraṃ brahmaṇo vācyatve heturbhavitumarhatīti tadartho 'nenopalakṣyate /
analyzed: na ca avivakṣita artham śabdamātram brahmaṇaḥ vācya tve hetuḥ bhavitum arhati iti tad arthaḥ nena upalakṣyate
translated: And mere sound, whose meaning is not intended, cannot be the reason for Brahman being the object of denotation. Therefore, its meaning is indicated by this.

analyzed: naca brahma asambandhi īkṣaṇam api atra hetuḥ bhavati atiprasaṅgāt
translated: And the seeing not related to Brahman cannot be the reason here, because of the absurdity of the conclusion.

original: sambandhaśca na kartṛtvādirūpaḥ śrutyananugamāt vipakṣe bādhakābhāvācca
analyzed: sambandhaḥ ca na kartṛ tva ādi rūpaḥ śruti ananugamāt vipakṣe bādhaka abhāvāt ca
translated: And the relation is not in the form of being the agent, etc., because that is not in accordance with the Vedic text, and because there is no contradiction in the contrary.

analyzed: va prasaṅgāt ca
translated: And because of the absurdity of the conclusion.

analyzed: atas īkṣaṇam brahma karmakam eva hetu tvena vācyam
translated: Therefore, the seeing must be stated as the reason only with Brahman as the object.

analyzed: na ca etat api yuktam vyadhikaraṇa tva prasaṅgāt
translated: And this also is not proper, because of the absurdity of the subject being different.

original: tasmādīkṣaṇakarmatvameva hetutayā vivakṣitam ityāśayenoktam īkṣaṇīyatvata iti //
analyzed: tasmāt īkṣaṇa karma tvam eva hetutayā vivakṣitam iti āśayena uktam īkṣaṇīya tvataḥ iti
translated: Therefore, the state of being the object of seeing alone is intended as the reason. With this idea, it is said Because of the state of being seen.

analyzed: īkṣaṇīya tvataḥ viṣṇuḥ vācyaḥ eva
translated: Viṣṇu alone is to be spoken of, because he is to be seen.

analyzed: tat iti anuvartate
translated: The word that is continued.

analyzed: tena viṣṇuḥ iti āha
translated: Therefore, he says Viṣṇu.

original: na vidyate vācakaḥ śabdo yasya tadaśabdam /
analyzed: na vidyate vācakaḥ śabdaḥ yasya tat aśabdam
translated: That which has no word as its denotator is called indescribable.

original: avācyamityarthaḥ /🔽vācyamiti vaktavye nāvācyamiti vacanaṃdvau nañau prakṛtamarthaṃ sātiśayaṃ gamayataḥ' /
analyzed: avācyam iti arthaḥ  vācyam iti vaktavye na avācyam iti vacanam dvau nañau prakṛtam artham sa atiśayam gamayataḥ
translated: The meaning is inexpressible.🔽When it should be said denoted, the statement not denoted conveys the intended meaning to a high degree, with the two negative particles.

analyzed: iti vacanāt avadhāraṇa artham iti abhipretya uktam vācyaḥ eva iti
translated: With the intention that the word alone has the meaning of restriction, it is said he is to be spoken of.

analyzed: nanu avadhāraṇam api kimartham
translated: But why is the restriction also for the purpose?

analyzed: ucyate
translated: It is said:

analyzed: tattva nirṇaya artham hi nyāya sūtram
translated: For the purpose of determining the truth, the aphorisms of logic are composed.

analyzed: nirṇayaḥ ca sva para pakṣa sādhana upalambhābhyām eva bhavati
translated: And determination occurs only through the means of knowledge of one's own and others' positions,

analyzed: na anyatara mātreṇa
translated: not by one alone.

analyzed: yathā uktam
translated: As it is said:

analyzed: vimṛśya pakṣa pratipakṣābhyām artha avadhāraṇam nirṇayaḥ iti
translated: Determination of the meaning by examination through one's own and others' positions is determination.

analyzed: tat atra avadhāraṇe kṛte vācya tva vidhiḥ avācya tva niṣedhaḥ ca iti ubhayam api śruti arthābhyām pratijñātam syāt
translated: Here, when the restriction is made, both the injunction of being denoted and the prohibition of being undenoted would be promised by the Vedic text and its meaning.

analyzed: ubhaya sādhana arthaḥ ca īkṣaṇīya tva hetuḥ vijñāyate
translated: And the reason of being seen is understood to be for the purpose of establishing both.

analyzed: tathā ca nirṇayaḥ bhavet
translated: And thus there would be determination.

original: vācyamiti tu pratijñāte parapakṣapratiṣedho na kṛtaḥ syāt /
analyzed: vācyam iti tu pratijñāte parapakṣa pratiṣedhaḥ na kṛtaḥ syāt
translated: But if it were said that Brahman is the object of speech, then the denial of the opponent's position would not have been made.

analyzed: na ca tad artham anyat sūtram asti
translated: And there is no other aphorism for that purpose.

analyzed: atas yuktaḥ yam nirdeśaḥ
translated: Therefore this statement is appropriate.

analyzed: evam anyatra api veditavyam
translated: It should be understood in the same way in other places as well.

analyzed: idam uktam bhavati
translated: This is what is said:

analyzed: brahma vācyam bhavitum arhati
translated: Brahman should be the object of speech.

analyzed: na punar avācyam īkṣaṇa karma tvāt ghaṭa vat
translated: It is not again inexpressible, because it is the object of seeing, like a pot.

original: īkṣaṇīyatvaṃ ca brahmaṇaḥsa etasmājjīvadhanātparātparaṃ puriśayaṃ puruṣamīkṣate'ātmanyevātmānaṃ paśyet' /🔽ityādiśrutisiddhamiti /
analyzed: īkṣaṇīya tvam ca brahmaṇaḥ saḥ etasmāt jīva dhanāt parātparam puriśayam puruṣam īkṣate ātmani eva ātmānam paśyet  ityādi śruti siddham iti
translated: And the perceptibility of Brahman is established by such Vedic texts as He sees that supreme person, the supreme self, within this self, and One should see the self in the self.

analyzed: nanu brahmaṇaḥ vācya tva abhāve kim bādhakam
translated: But if Brahman is not the object of speech, what is the contradiction?

analyzed: īkṣaṇīya tvam na syāt
translated: It would not be perceptible.

analyzed: tathā ca brahma jñāna abhāvena śāstra vaiyarthyam anirmokṣaḥ ca syāt iti ced na
translated: And then, due to the absence of knowledge of Brahman, the scriptures would be useless and there would be no liberation. This is not so.

analyzed: vācya tvasya avyāpaka tvāt īkṣaṇīya tvasya avyāpya tvāt ca
translated: Because being the object of speech is not an all-pervading property, and perceptibility is not a pervaded property.

analyzed: na hi avyāpaka nivṛttiḥ avyāpya nivṛttim āpādayati
translated: For the cessation of what is not all-pervading does not entail the cessation of what is not pervaded.

analyzed: yitum śaknoti
translated: It cannot be made to do so.

analyzed: īkṣaṇīya tvam hi pratyakṣa anumāna āgama tad ābhāsa nimittam vyāpakam yuktam
translated: Perceptibility is rightly regarded as all-pervading, having perception, inference, verbal testimony, and their fallacies as its cause.

analyzed: vācya tvam ca śabda vṛtti viśeṣa upādhikam vyāpyam eva iti
translated: And the fact of being expressible is pervaded only by the qualification of being a particular kind of verbal usage.

analyzed: mā evam
translated: This is not so.

analyzed: na tāvat idam mokṣa artham upadiṣyam brahma īkṣaṇam pramāṇa ābhāsa janyam
translated: First, this seeing of Brahman, which is taught for the sake of liberation, is not produced by false means of knowledge.

analyzed: bhrānteḥ avidyā nivartaka tva abhāvāt
translated: Because error does not remove ignorance.

analyzed: na api pratyakṣa anumāna jam
translated: Nor is it produced by perception or inference.

analyzed: śāstra eka samadhigamya tāyāḥ sādhita tvāt
translated: Because it has been proved that it is to be known only through scripture.

original: tathāca prakārāntarābhāve sati yadi brahma vācyamapi na bhavettadekṣaṇīyamapi na bhavediti bādhakaṃ sambhavatyeva /
analyzed: tathā ca prakāra antara abhāve sati yadi brahma vācyam api na bhavet tadā īkṣaṇīyam api na bhavet iti bādhakam sambhavati eva
translated: And so, if Brahman were not even expressible, when there is no other way, then it could not even be seen. Thus the contradiction is indeed possible.

analyzed: na ca vyāpti abhā sambhavaḥ
translated: And the pervasion is not false.

analyzed: vyatireka sambhavāt
translated: Because the negative concomitance is possible.

original: yat yatkārakāviṣayaḥ tat tatkriyāviṣayaḥ yathā kuṭhārādyaviṣayo gaganaṃ na chidāviṣaya iti sāmānyavyāptisambhavācca / /
analyzed: yat yad kāraka aviṣayaḥ tat tad kriyā viṣayaḥ yathā kuṭhāra ādi aviṣayaḥ gaganam na chidā viṣayaḥ iti sāmānya vyāpti sambhavāt ca
translated: Whatever is not the object of an instrument, that is not the object of an action, just as the sky, which is not the object of an axe etc., is not the object of cutting. Thus the general pervasion is possible.

analyzed: nanu mā abhūt pramāṇa ābhāsaiḥ pratyakṣa anumānābhyām ca aikṣaṇam brahmaṇaḥ
translated: But let the seeing of Brahman not be by false means of knowledge or by perception and inference.

analyzed: mā ca bhūt vācyam
translated: And let it not be expressible.

analyzed: tathā api śabda lakṣya tayā īkṣaṇīyam ca bhaviṣyati
translated: Even so, it will be seen as the object of verbal testimony.

analyzed: tathā ca vipakṣe bādhaka abhāvāt aprayojakaḥ hetuḥ
translated: And so, in the absence of a contradiction in the contrary case, the reason is inconclusive.

analyzed: iti atas āha na ca iti
translated: Hence he says: And not otherwise.

analyzed: na ca anyathā
translated: And not otherwise.

analyzed: lakṣya tvam kvāpi dṛṣṭam hi
translated: For somewhere the character of being denoted is seen.

original: hi yasmādanyathā vācyatvābhāve lakṣyatvaṃ kvāpi na dṛṣṭam /
analyzed: hi yasmāt anyathā vācya tva abhāve lakṣya tvam kvāpi na dṛṣṭam
translated: For, since the character of being denoted is not seen anywhere else than in the case of being denoted,

analyzed: tasmāt avācya tve brahmaṇaḥ lakṣya tva ayogā
translated: therefore, in the case of Brahman, the character of being denoted is not possible in the absence of being denoted.

analyzed: bhāvāt lakṣaṇayā api na īkṣaṇīya tvam iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The remainder is: It is not to be seen even by indication, because of the absence of existence.

original: kenacicchabdena vācyameva hi tīrādikaṃ kenacillakṣyaṃ dṛṣṭamiti / /
analyzed: kenacid śabdena vācyam eva hi tīra ādikam kenacid lakṣyam dṛṣṭam iti
translated: For it is seen that only that which is denoted by some word is denoted by another word.

analyzed: avācyasya api lakṣya tve anavasthitiḥ
translated: If that which is not denoted were also denoted, there would be an infinite regress.

analyzed: nanu avācyam api lakṣyam kim na syāt
translated: But why should not that which is not denoted be denoted?

analyzed: tatas ca vipakṣe bādhaka abhāvāt aprayojakaḥ yam prasaṅga hetuḥ
translated: And then, in the absence of any counter-example, this reductio ad absurdum argument is irrelevant.

analyzed: iti atas āha kim tat iti
translated: Hence he says: What is that?

analyzed: kim tat iti anavasthitiḥ
translated: What is that? There would be an infinite regress.

analyzed: anyathā iti anuvartate
translated: Otherwise is to be supplied.

analyzed: yadi avācyam api brahma lakṣyam iti aṅgīkriyate
translated: If it is accepted that Brahman, even though not denoted, is denoted,

analyzed: tadā kim tat iti jijñāsā pravṛttau anavasthitiḥ syāt
translated: then, in the inquiry into what that is, there would be an infinite regress.

analyzed: idam uktam bhavati
translated: This is what is said:

original: lākṣaṇiko hi śabdo na śrutamātro 'rthāntare dhiyamupajanayati tatrāgṛhītaśaktitvāt /
analyzed: lākṣaṇikaḥ hi śabdaḥ na śruta mātraḥ rtha antare dhiyam upajanayati tatra agṛhīta śakti tvāt
translated: For a figurative word, merely on being heard, does not produce the idea of another meaning, because its power has not been apprehended in that case.

analyzed: kintu vācya artha arthe
translated: But in the case of the denoted meaning,

analyzed: buddhim utpādya tad anupapatti darśane sati
translated: Having produced the idea, when the non-applicability of that is seen,

analyzed: na tāvatā api
translated: even by that much,
because the perception of the non-applicability of the denoted meaning is only the cause for abandoning it.

original: kiṃ nāmārthāntarasya svarūpato vācyārthasambandhitayā cāvagatau satyām /
analyzed: kim nāma artha antarasya svarūpataḥ vācya artha sambandhi tayā ca avagatau satyām
translated: What is it? When the other meaning is understood both in its own form and in its relation to the denoted meaning.

original: gaṅgādiśabdena hi svarūpato gaṅgādisambandhitayā cāvagatameva tīrādikaṃ lakṣyaṃ dṛṣṭam /
analyzed: gaṅgā ādi śabdena hi svarūpataḥ gaṅgā ādi sambandhi tayā ca avagatam eva tīra ādikam lakṣyam dṛṣṭam
translated: For what is denoted by the word 'bank' is seen to be the object indicated, which is understood both in its own form and in its relation to the Ganges, etc.

analyzed: na anavagata svarūpam kūrma roma ādi
translated: Not something whose form is not understood, like the hair of a tortoise.

analyzed: na api anya sambandhi tayā avagatam tīra ādi
translated: Nor is the bank, etc. understood in its relation to something else.

analyzed: tathā ca vaidika śabda lakṣya tve brahmaṇaḥ pratītiḥ aṅgīkāryā
translated: And so, if Brahman is the object indicated by Vedic words, its cognition must be accepted.

original: naca tīrādivatpratyakṣādinā tasya pratītiḥ sambhavati /🔽tato lākṣaṇikaśabde prayukte vācyārthe 'nupapattiṃ paśyato lakṣaṇīye 'rthe kiṃ tadyadanena lakṣyamiti jijñāsāyāṃ śabda eva prayoktavyaḥ /
analyzed: na ca tīra ādi vat pratyakṣa ādinā tasya pratītiḥ sambhavati  tatas lākṣaṇika śabde prayukte vācyārthe paśyataḥ lakṣaṇīye rthe kim tat yat anena lakṣyam iti jijñāsāyām śabdaḥ eva prayoktavyaḥ
translated: And its cognition is not possible by perception, etc., like that of the bank, etc.🔽Therefore, when an indicative word is used, one who sees the non-applicability of the denoted meaning should seek to know the indicated meaning, thinking 'What is that which is indicated by this?' and the word itself should be used.

original: tenāpi cenna vācyaṃ kintu lakṣyameva tarhi punaḥ kiṃ taditi jijñāsāyā anivṛttatvācchabdāntarameva vācyam /
analyzed: tena api ced na vācyam kintu lakṣyam eva tarhi punar kim tat iti jijñāsāyāḥ anivṛtta tvāt śabda antaram eva vācyam
translated: And if that also does not denote but only indicates, then the inquiry 'What is that?' would not cease, and another word should be denoted.

analyzed: tena api ced lakṣyam eva punar jijñāsā eva iti aparyavasānam syāt
translated: And if that were also to be the object of inquiry, then there would be an infinite regress of inquiry.

analyzed: pūrva pūrva lakṣaṇa asiddhau uttara uttara lakṣaṇa asiddheḥ mūla kṣatiḥ
translated: And if the preceding characteristics are not established, the succeeding characteristics cannot be established, so the root is damaged.

original: yadi ca kenacicchabdena vācyaṃ syāttadā taduktāvuparatajijñāso lākṣaṇikakāryaṃ pratīyāt /
analyzed: yadi ca kenacid śabdena vācyam syāt tadā tad uktau uparata jijñāsaḥ lākṣaṇika kāryam pratīyāt
translated: And if it were to be denoted by some word, then when that is stated, one whose inquiry has ceased would understand the denoted meaning.

analyzed: vācya tve pi sambandha grahaṇāya pūrva siddheḥ apekṣita tvena anavasthiteḥ iti ced na
translated: Even if it were denoted, since the prior establishment is required for the apprehension of the relation, there would be an infinite regress. If this is argued, it is not so.

analyzed: abhimāni adhikaraṇe vaktavya tvāt
translated: Because it is to be stated in the section on the superimposition.

original: tasmādvipakṣe 'navasthālakṣaṇabādhakasadbhāvādavācyatve lakṣyatvaṃ na syāditi yukto 'tiprasaṅga iti /
analyzed: tasmāt vipakṣe navasthā lakṣaṇa bādhaka sadbhāvāt avācya tve lakṣya tvam na syāt iti yuktaḥ atiprasaṅgaḥ iti
translated: Therefore, since there is the presence of the invalidating factor in the form of an infinite regress in the case of the contrary, the object of inquiry would not be denoted. Thus the absurd consequence is proper.

original: lākṣaṇiko hi śabdo na śrutamātro 'rthāntare dhiyamupajanayati tatrāgṛhītaśaktitvāt /
analyzed: lākṣaṇikaḥ hi śabdaḥ na śruta mātraḥ rtha antare dhiyam upajanayati tatra agṛhīta śakti tvāt
translated: For a denoted word, when merely heard, does not produce the idea of another meaning, because its power has not been apprehended in that case.

analyzed: kintu vācya artha arthe
translated: But in the case of the denoted meaning,

analyzed: buddhim utpādya tad anupapatti darśane sati
translated: having produced the idea, when the inconsistency of that is shown,

analyzed: na tāvatā api
translated: even then not by that alone.
Because the perception of the inconsistency of the denoted meaning is the cause of merely abandoning that.

original: kiṃ nāmārthāntarasya svarūpato vācyārthasambandhitayā cāvagatau satyām /
analyzed: kim nāma artha antarasya svarūpataḥ vācya artha sambandhi tayā ca avagatau satyām
translated: What is it? It is when the form of something else is understood both as related to the denoted meaning.

original: gaṅgādiśabdena hi svarūpato gaṅgādisambandhitayā cāvagatameva tīrādikaṃ lakṣyaṃ dṛṣṭam /
analyzed: gaṅgā ādi śabdena hi svarūpataḥ gaṅgā ādi sambandhi tayā ca avagatam eva tīra ādikam lakṣyam dṛṣṭam
translated: For it is seen that the bank etc., whose form is understood both as the form of the Ganges etc. and as related to the Ganges etc., is the object indicated by the word Ganges etc.

analyzed: na anavagata svarūpam kūrma roma ādi
translated: Not something whose form is not understood, like the hair of a tortoise.

analyzed: na api anya sambandhi tayā avagatam tīra ādi
translated: Nor is the bank etc. understood as related to something else.

analyzed: tathā ca vaidika śabda lakṣya tve brahmaṇaḥ pratītiḥ aṅgīkāryā
translated: And so, if Brahman is the object indicated by Vedic words, its cognition must be accepted.

original: naca tīrādivatpratyakṣādinā tasya pratītiḥ sambhavati /🔽tato lākṣaṇikaśabde prayukte vācyārthe 'nupapattiṃ paśyato lakṣaṇīye 'rthe kiṃ tadyadanena lakṣyamiti jijñāsāyāṃ śabda eva prayoktavyaḥ /
