original: tatrāpi puruṣaśabdena mukhyato harirevokta iti sthite tatkathamityata āha purīti //
analyzed: tatra api puruṣa śabdena mukhyatas hariḥ eva uktaḥ iti sthite tat katham iti atas āha puri iti
translated: Even there, it is established that by the word Puruṣa, Hari Himself is primarily spoken of. Then, how is it so? Therefore, he says Puru etc.

original: puri śete yataḥ so 'tha puruṣaśceti gīyate // / / //
analyzed: puri śete yatas saḥ tha puruṣaḥ ca iti gīyate
translated: Because He sleeps in the city, therefore He is sung as Puruṣa.

analyzed: atha tasmāt
translated: Then, from that.

analyzed: puri śarīre
translated: In the body, in the city.

analyzed: atra upapadasya saptamyāḥ a luk
translated: Here, there is no elision of the locative case ending of the preposition.

analyzed: tasya ca ikārasya ukāraḥ
translated: And the i of that becomes u.

analyzed: dhātu śakārasya ṣakāraḥ nirvacana tvāt
translated: The ṣ of the verbal root śa becomes ṣ, because it is a derivation.

analyzed: adhikaraṇe śeteḥ ḍaḥ
translated: The ḍ of śete is in the locative case.

analyzed: evam ātma ādi śabdān vyākhyāya teṣām sṛṣṭim vivṛṇoti kriyā iti
translated: Having thus explained the words Ātman etc., he describes their creation with the word kriyā etc.

analyzed: kriyā pravartaka tvena prādurbhāvaḥ hareḥ janiḥ
translated: The manifestation of Hari as the instigator of action is His birth.

analyzed: ākāśa ādiṣu na anyā asti hi abhimānaḥ bhimāninaḥ
translated: In Ākāśa etc., there is no other conception of the conceiver.

analyzed: abhimāni śarīrasya sākṣāt bhūtasya ca udbhavaḥ
translated: The origin of the body of the conceiver and of the element itself.

original: sākṣājjanmaiva kiṃ na syādityata āha nānyeti //
analyzed: sākṣāt janma eva kim na syāt iti atas āha na anyā iti
translated: Why not be the direct birth itself? To this he says 'not other' etc.

analyzed: hi śabdaḥ nityaḥ nityānām ityādi śruti prasiddhi sūcakaḥ
translated: The word 'hi' indicates the well-known fact of the eternal being the cause of the eternal etc.

analyzed: abhimānaḥ mama idam iti buddhiḥ
translated: Conceit is the idea 'this is mine'.

analyzed: janiḥ iti sambandhaḥ
translated: The connection is with 'birth'.

analyzed: bhūtasya iti upalakṣaṇam oṣadhi ādi bhautikasya ca iti api grāhyam
translated: The word 'of the existent' is a synecdoche; it should be understood to include what is made of plants etc.

analyzed: sākṣāt udbhavaḥ eva janiḥ iti anvayaḥ
translated: The direct origination itself is the birth; this is the connection.

original: yadyevamātmākāśavāyvagnyappṛthivyoṣadhyannapuruṣapadairmukhyato harirevoktaḥ anyadamukhyatastataḥ kiṃ prakṛta ityata āha
analyzed: yadi evam ātma ākāśa vāyu agni ap pṛthivī oṣadhi anna puruṣa padaiḥ mukhyataḥ hariḥ eva uktaḥ anyat amukhyataḥ tatas kim prakṛtaḥ iti atas āha
translated: If it is so, Hari alone is mentioned by the words 'Self', 'space', 'air', 'fire', 'water', 'earth', 'plants', 'food', and 'man' primarily, and others secondarily. Then what is the subject matter? To this he says

analyzed: evam iti
translated: 'Thus' etc.

analyzed: evam deha ādi paryantam āgatam harim eva tu
translated: Thus, having come up to the body etc., Hari alone is referred to

analyzed: parāmṛśati tasya eva pañca rūpa tva vittaye
translated: for the knowledge of His having five forms.

original: tyaktavā bhūtādikaṃ sarvaṃ sa vā eṣa iti śrutiḥ // / / //
analyzed: tyaktavā bhūta ādikam sarvam sa vai eṣaḥ iti śrutiḥ
translated: The scripture, having abandoned all beginning with the elements, says 'He is that' etc.

analyzed: atra deha śabdāt prāk ātma śabdaḥ dhyā āhāryaḥ
translated: Here, before the word 'body', the word 'Self' should be supplied.

original: sa vā eṣa puruṣa iti śrutiḥ prakṛtamapi bhūtādikaṃ sarvaṃ tyaktavā'tmādidehaparyantamāgataṃ taiḥ śabdaiḥ prakṛtaṃ harimeva parāmṛśati /
analyzed: sa vai eṣa puruṣaḥ iti śrutiḥ prakṛtam api bhūta ādikam sarvam taiḥ śabdaiḥ prakṛtam harim eva parāmṛśati
translated: The scripture, having abandoned all the subject matter beginning with the elements, refers to Hari alone, the subject matter coming up to the body etc. by those words.

analyzed: tasya eva sṛṣṭi kartuḥ śarīre nna maya ādi pañca rūpa tva jñāpanāya iti
translated: In order to show that the five forms beginning with food belong to the body of that very creator of the universe.

analyzed: idam uktam bhavati
translated: This is what is said.

original: nānnamayādīnāṃ parabrahmatvaparigrahe sa vā eṣa puruṣa iti parāmarśavirodhaḥ /
analyzed: na anna maya ādīnām para brahma tva parigrahe sa vai eṣa puruṣaḥ iti parāmarśa virodhaḥ
translated: When the food-body etc. are accepted as the supreme Brahman, there is no contradiction with the reference That is this person,

analyzed: ātma pada uditasya parāmarśaḥ yam iti svīkārāt
translated: because it is accepted that this is a reference to what is denoted by the word Self.

analyzed: na ca na asau para brahma
translated: And that is not the supreme Brahman.

original: tasmātparaprāptikāmena jñātavyatayoktādetasmātpunaḥ satyajñānānantatvena lakṣitādātmana iti prakṛtānusandhānāt /
analyzed: tasmāt para prāpti kāmena jñātavya tayā uktāt etasmāt punar satya jñāna ananta tvena lakṣitāt ātmanaḥ iti prakṛta anusandhānāt
translated: Therefore, by the connection with the subject matter, it is said that from this which is mentioned as to be known, again, from the Self characterized by existence, knowledge, and infinity,

analyzed: na ca sannihita parāmarśa parityāgena dūra prakṛta parāmarśa aṅgīkāraḥ nucitaḥ iti vācyam
translated: and it should not be said that it is improper to accept a reference to what is remote, abandoning a reference to what is present.

analyzed: ātma ādi puruṣa anta sarva śabdaiḥ api tasya eva prakṛta tva aṅgīkārāt
translated: Because it is accepted that even by all words beginning with Self and ending with person, that alone is the subject matter.

analyzed: na ca īśvarasya utpattiḥ anutpannā
translated: And the Lord is not produced, not unborn.

analyzed: prādurbhāva apekṣayā vyākhyānāt
translated: Because it is explained in relation to manifestation.

analyzed: na ca etat aprāmāṇikam vyākhyānam
translated: And this explanation is not unauthoritative.

analyzed: kāraṇa tvena iti upapādayiṣyamāṇa tvāt
translated: Because it will be explained that it is because of being the cause.

analyzed: na ca evam bhūtādi sṛṣṭeḥ aprāmāṇika tva āpattiḥ
translated: And thus the creation of the elements etc. is not unauthoritative.

analyzed: ākāśa ādi śabdānām bhūta ādi para tvasya api svīkārāt
translated: Because it is admitted that the words 'space' etc. refer to the elements etc.

analyzed: aneka atha ṛtāyāḥ ca upapādayiṣyamāṇa tvāt
translated: And because it will be shown that they have multiple meanings.

analyzed: na ca evam teṣām api prādurbhāva mātra āpattiḥ
translated: And thus their mere appearance is not established.

analyzed: sāmānyatas śrutasya sambhava śabdasya yathāyogyam vyākhyāna upapatteḥ
translated: Because the word 'sambhava' (appearance), which is heard in the general sense, can be explained as appropriate.

analyzed: na ca evam api anna rasa mayasya prakṛta sarva ātmaka tva āpattiḥ
translated: And thus the appearance of the food-rasa-maya (Brahman) as the essence of all the topics is not established.

analyzed: prakṛtānām api bhūta ādīnām parityāgena hareḥ eva parāmarśa aṅgīkārāt
translated: Because, even though the elements etc. are the topics, the reference to Hari alone is accepted by abandoning them.

analyzed: na ca etat anyāyyam
translated: And this is not unreasonable.

analyzed: ākāśa ādi śabdānām harau eva mukhya tvena tasya eva utkaṭa tayā buddhi sannidhānāt
translated: Because the words 'space' etc. are primary in Hari alone, because of the prominence of Him alone in the mind.

analyzed: na ca īśvara parāmarśaḥ vyarthaḥ
translated: And the reference to God is not useless.

analyzed: tasya eva anna maya ādi pañca rūpa tā jñāpanāya prakaraṇa antara ārambha artha tvāt
translated: Because the beginning of a new section is for the purpose of indicating that He alone has the five forms beginning with food-rasa-maya.

analyzed: tasya ca lakṣaṇa vivaraṇa artha tvena upayogasya ukta tvāt
translated: And because it has been said that it is useful as an explanation of the definition of that (God).

analyzed: tathā ca annamayasya brahmatve nupapatti abhāvāt na tad pravāha patitānām prāṇamaya ādīnām abrahmatvam kalpanīyam iti
translated: And thus, in the case of the food-maya (Brahman) being Brahman, there is no incompleteness, so the prāṇa-maya etc. which are included in that stream should not be assumed to be not Brahman.

analyzed: nanu kim anena bahudhā saṃvidhānena
translated: But why this elaborate explanation?

analyzed: śarīra mātra parāmarśaḥ yam kim na syāt
translated: Why not just take it as referring to the body alone?

original: maivam /🔽tathā satyeṣa puruṣa ityetāvatā pūrṇatvena sa ityasya vaiyarthyāpatteḥ /
analyzed: mā evam  tathā sati eṣa puruṣaḥ iti etāvatā pūrṇa tvena saḥ ityasya vaiyarthya āpatteḥ
translated: No, that is not so.🔽If it were so, then with just this person, it would be complete, and he would be meaningless.

original: bhavatpakṣe 'pi tat samānamiti cennetyabhipretyāha sa iti //
analyzed: bhavat pakṣe tat samānam iti ced na iti abhipretya āha saḥ iti
translated: If you think that is the same in your view too, he says he with the intention that it is not so.

analyzed: saḥ iti ātma pada uddiṣyaḥ eṣa jīva śarīra gaḥ
translated: He refers to the one designated by the word self, who is in the living being's body.

analyzed: eṣaḥ iti jīva śarīra gaḥ parāmṛśyate
translated: This is referred to as being in the living being's body.

analyzed: śarīra gaḥ iti eva ukte parameśvarasya śarīri tvam pratīyeta
translated: If it were said to be in the body alone, it would be understood that the Supreme Lord has a body.

analyzed: atas jīva iti uktam
translated: Therefore, living being is said.

original: kiñca śarīraparāmarśe sa vā eṣa puruṣo 'nnamaya ityeva vaktavyam /
analyzed: kiñca śarīra parāmarśe sa vai eṣa puruṣaḥ nna mayaḥ iti eva vaktavyam
translated: Moreover, if it were a reference to the body, it would have to be said that person is made of food alone.

analyzed: rasa śabdaḥ tu vyarthaḥ  prayojana anupalabdheḥ
translated: But the word rasa (sap) would be meaningless.🔽Because no purpose is seen.

analyzed: annāt puruṣaḥ iti eva prakṛta tvāt ca
translated: And because from food, the person is the subject matter.

analyzed: na ca asmad pakṣe rasa śabdasya vaiyarthyam
translated: And in our view too, the word rasa (sap) is not meaningless.

analyzed: anna mayaḥ iti eva ukte prākṛta anna maya tvam iti eva pratīyeta
translated: If it were said made of food alone, it would be understood as being made of ordinary food.

analyzed: tad nivṛtti artha tvena sārthakyāt iti āśayavān āha sāra iti
translated: With the intention that it is meaningful as the purpose of negating that, he says sāra (essence).

analyzed: sāra anna mayaḥ eva ayam na loka anna mayaḥ prabhuḥ
translated: He is made of the essence of food, not of the essence of the worlds.

analyzed: iti tam rasa śabdena viśinaṣṭi śarīra gam
translated: Thus, the Śruti passage distinguishes the Self residing in the body by the word 'rasa' (essence).

analyzed: rasa śabdaḥ hi sāra vācī
translated: For the word 'rasa' denotes essence.

original: rasasāro varaśceti śabdāḥ paryāyavācakā iti vacanāt /
analyzed: rasasāraḥ varaḥ ca iti śabdāḥ paryāya vācakāḥ iti vacanāt
translated: Because of the statement that the words 'rasa', 'sāra' (essence), and 'vara' (excellent) are synonymous.

analyzed: tatas ca anna rasaḥ nnasāraḥ
translated: And therefore, 'annaras' means the essence of food.

analyzed: anna śabda artheṣu
translated: Among the meanings of the word 'anna', the primary meaning is that characterized by eating and so on.

analyzed: s tad pracuraḥ iti uktam bhavati
translated: It is said that it is abundant in that.

analyzed: tasya tātparyārthaḥ sāra anna mayaḥ iti
translated: The implied meaning of that is 'made of the essence of food'.

analyzed: iti jñāpayitum iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The rest is: 'in order to make that known'.

analyzed: viśinaṣṭi śrutiḥ
translated: The Śruti passage distinguishes (the Self).

analyzed: api ca
translated: Moreover,

original: śarīraparāmarśo 'yaṃ cettasyedameva śiraḥ ayaṃ dakṣiṇaḥ pakṣaḥ ayamuttaraḥ pakṣaḥ ayamātmā idaṃ pucchaṃ pratiṣṭheti sarvaṃ vyarthameva syāt
analyzed: śarīra parāmarśaḥ yam ced tasya idam eva śiraḥ ayam dakṣiṇaḥ pakṣaḥ ayam uttaraḥ pakṣaḥ ayam ātmā idam puccham pratiṣṭhā iti sarvam vyartham eva syāt
translated: if this refers to the body, then all of this - 'this is its head', 'this is its right wing', 'this is its left wing', 'this is its body', 'this is its tail', 'this is its support' - would be pointless,

analyzed: śarīra śiraḥ prabhṛteḥ pratyakṣa siddha tvena upadeśa anapekṣaṇāt
translated: because the head of the body and so on are directly perceived, and so do not require instruction.

analyzed: nanu īśvare pi anupapattiḥ eva
translated: But in the case of God also, there is the same impossibility.

analyzed: tasya śiraḥ prabhṛti avayava abhāvāt na
translated: Because He does not have parts such as a head. No.

analyzed: prakāśa vat ca iti vakṣyamāṇa tvāt
translated: Because it will be said that He is like light.

analyzed: tathā api anupapattiḥ
translated: Even so, there is an impossibility.

analyzed: īśvaraśiraḥ prabhṛtīnām apratyakṣa tvena idam iti nirdeśa ayogāt iti ced na
translated: If it be said that the head, etc. of the Lord cannot be referred to by the word 'this' because they are not perceptible, it is not so.

analyzed: lakṣaṇayā upapatteḥ iti āśayavān āha idam iti
translated: With the idea that it is possible by metonymy, he says 'this'.

analyzed: idam iti eva nirdeśaḥ vastra prāvṛta vat vibhoḥ
translated: The designation 'this' would be by metonymy in the head, etc. of the Supreme Lord, even though not perceptible,

analyzed: śiraḥ ādeḥ bhavet jīvaśiraḥ ādau vyavasthiteḥ
translated: because the head, etc. of the individual soul are established in the perceptible head, etc. of the Lord.

analyzed: idam iti pratyakṣe pi parameśvara śiraḥ prabhṛtau lakṣaṇayā bhavet eva
translated: The designation 'this' would be by metonymy even in the head, etc. of the Supreme Lord, though not perceptible,

original: vibhoḥ śiraāderjīvaśiraādau pratyakṣe vyavasthiteriti lakṣaṇābījasambandhaṃ darśayati /
analyzed: vibhoḥ śiraḥ ādeḥ jīva śiraḥ ādau pratyakṣe vyavasthiteḥ iti lakṣaṇā bīja sambandham darśayati
translated: because the head, etc. of the individual soul are established in the perceptible head, etc. of the Lord. Thus he shows the connection with the seed of metonymy.

original: nanu mukhyaprayogaṃ parityajya lākṣaṇikaṃ prayuñjānasya prayojanaṃ vācyam /
analyzed: nanu mukhya prayogam parityajya lākṣaṇikam prayuñjānasya prayojanam vācyam
translated: But the purpose of one who abandons the primary usage and employs the figurative one must be stated.

original: dṛṣṭaṃ hi gaṅgāyāṃ ghoṣa ityādau pāvitṛyādijñānamiti cenna /
analyzed: dṛṣṭam hi gaṅgāyām ghoṣaḥ ityādau pāvitṛya ādi jñānam iti ced na
translated: For it is seen that in 'the village on the Ganges', etc., the knowledge of the purifying, etc. is the purpose. If it be said that this is not so,

analyzed: prakṛte rūḍha lakṣaṇa tvāt iti bhāvena uktam vastra prāvṛtta vat iti
translated: because in the present case it is a figurative usage based on common property, he says 'as if clothed in a garment'.

analyzed: saptamī arthe vatiḥ
translated: The suffix 'vati' has the sense of the locative.

original: yathāpratyakṣe 'pi jānuni pratyakṣavastraprāvṛte pratyakṣavastrasannidhānādidamiti nirdeśastathā prakṛte 'pītyarthaḥ /
analyzed: yathā apratyakṣe jānuni pratyakṣa vastra prāvṛte pratyakṣa vastra sannidhānāt idam iti nirdeśaḥ tathā prakṛte pi iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that just as in the knee, even though not directly perceived, when covered by a directly perceived cloth, it is referred to as this in association with the directly perceived cloth, the same is the case here.

analyzed: nanu mukhye bādhaka abhāvāt kutas lakṣaṇa āśrayaṇam iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that in the primary meaning there is no contradiction, so why resort to secondary meaning? It is not so.

original: śarīraparigrahe vaiyarthyasya sphuṭatvāt / /🔽kiñca sarvameva ta āyuryantīti prāṇaanna
analyzed: śarīra parigrahe vaiyarthyasya sphuṭa tvāt  kiñca sarvam eva te āyuḥ yanti iti
translated: Because the futility of accepting a body is obvious.

analyzed: maya jñānāt mokṣaḥ śrūyate
translated: Moreover, it is heard that liberation comes from the knowledge of all that as life.

analyzed: kadāpi maraṇa abhāvaḥ hi sarvam āyuḥ
translated: For all life means never dying.

analyzed: na ca asau vinā mokṣāt yujyate
translated: And that is not possible without liberation.

analyzed: na ca śarīra parigrahe tat yujyate  tam evaṃvidvān ityādi
translated: And that is not possible if one accepts a body.🔽The scripture beginning with One who knows him thus...

analyzed: śruti virodhāt iti āha tam iti
translated: says Tam etc.

analyzed: tam viditvā asya muktiḥ syāt na anya jñānāt kathañcana
translated: Having known him, there would be liberation, not in any way from the knowledge of anything else.

original: taṃ paramātmānaṃ viditvā sākṣātpaśyata iti śeṣaḥ /
analyzed: tam paramātmānam viditvā sākṣāt paśyate iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The meaning is that having known the supreme self, one sees him directly.

analyzed: tena samāna kartṛ tā
translated: The same agent is referred to by tena.

analyzed: brahma śabda ādayaḥ api atra bādhaka tayā vaktavyāḥ
translated: The words Brahman etc. should also be stated here as contradictory.

original: nanu ca vikāraśabdāditi sūtrakāreṇānnamayādīnāṃ brahmatvāṅgīkṛtāvekāmanupapattiṃ pariharatā lakṣaṇayā sarvānupapattiparihāro 'pi sūcitaḥ /🔽ata eva bhogyatvamatra cādyatvamityādinā bhāṣyakṛtā tatraivānupapattiparihāraḥ kṛtaḥ /
analyzed: nanu ca vikāra śabdāt iti sūtrakāreṇa anna maya ādīnām brahma tva aṅgīkṛtau ekām anupapattim pariharatā lakṣaṇayā sarva anupapatti parihāraḥ sūcitaḥ  atas eva bhogyatvam atra ca ādya tvam ityādinā bhāṣyakṛtā tatra eva anupapatti parihāraḥ kṛtaḥ
translated: But the author of the Sūtras, in removing one difficulty in the doctrine of the identity of the Self consisting of food, &c, with Brahman, by explaining the word modification in a secondary sense, has at the same time indicated the removal of all difficulties; and on that account the author of the Bhāṣya has removed the difficulties in the Sūtra in the same place, beginning with the words, The being the object of enjoyment is here the first point to be considered, &c

analyzed: brahma śabda uditaḥ iti ādikam api tatra eva kartum ucitam
translated: It would therefore have been proper to remove the difficulties in the Sūtra also in the same place, beginning with the words, The Self which is declared by the word Brahman, &c

analyzed: vyavadhāne kāraṇa abhāvāt
translated: For there is no reason for separating the two passages

analyzed: anyathā utsūtrita tva prasaṅgāt iti
translated: Otherwise the Sūtra would be introduced without reason

analyzed: mā evam
translated: This is not so, we reply

analyzed: tad sūtra sūcitasya api arthasya vyavadhāne prayojana sadbhāvāt  anna maya ādīnām pañcānām api abrahmatva upapādaka upapatti ābhāsāḥ tatra nirākṛtāḥ
translated: For even if the meaning of the Sūtra be indicated by another Sūtra, there is a reason for separating the two passages, because the two passages have different purposes🔽In the Sūtra under discussion the apparent reasons which prove that the five, the Self consisting of food, &c, are not Brahman are refuted

analyzed: anna maya mātra viṣaya anupapatti parihāraḥ tu atra iti anena jñāpyate
translated: The removal of the apparent reasons which prove that the Self consisting of food only is not Brahman is here set forth, this is what is meant to be stated by the words, The removal of the apparent reasons, &c

original: kiñca netaro 'nupapatteriti sūtraṃ kecinna tāvadannamayaḥ paramātmā parāmarśādyanupapatteriti vyākurvate /
analyzed: kiñca na itaraḥ nupapatteḥ iti sūtram kecid na tāvat anna mayaḥ paramātmā parāmarśa ādi anupapatteḥ iti vyākurvate
translated: Moreover some explain the Sūtra, It is not the other, on account of the impossibility, as follows, The Self consisting of food is not Brahman, on account of the impossibility of the application to it of the meditations, &c, contained in the Upaniṣad

analyzed: tat api nirākartum atrā idam uditam iti
translated: In order to refute this interpretation also the present Sūtra has been propounded

analyzed: atra āha
translated: Here the pūrvapakṣin raises an objection

analyzed: jīvaḥ eva anna maya ādi śabda arthaḥ
translated: The individual soul is the meaning of the words ‘consisting of food’ and so on.

analyzed: sa hi anna vikāra śarīra avacchinna tvāt bhavati anna mayaḥ
translated: For, being limited by the body which is a modification of food, it becomes consisting of food.

analyzed: prāṇa manaḥ buddhayā ānanda upādhi avacchinnaḥ ca bhavati prāṇa ādi vikāraḥ ghaṭa ākāśam iva ghaṭa vikāraḥ
translated: And being limited by the limiting adjuncts in the form of life, mind, intellect and bliss, it becomes a modification of life, etc., like a jar which is a modification of clay.

analyzed: tena prāṇa maya tva ādi upapattiḥ
translated: Thus the propriety of its being consisting of life, etc., is established.

original: tathāca sa vā eṣa puruṣa iti parāmarśastadupādhiviṣayatayā hi śliṣyataro bhavati /
analyzed: tathā ca sa vai eṣa puruṣaḥ iti parāmarśaḥ tad upādhi viṣaya tayā hi śliṣyataraḥ bhavati
translated: And thus the reference to it as ‘that person’ becomes appropriate, as it is the object of those limiting adjuncts.

analyzed: rasa śabdaḥ ca anna stha sthaviṣṭha bhāga vyāvṛtti arthaḥ bhaviṣyati
translated: And the word ‘rasa’ (juice) will have the sense of excluding the solid parts of food.

original: idamiti nirdeśaśca mukhyārthaḥsampadyate prāṇamayādiṣu sarvatra śiraḥprabhṛtyavayavānāṃ vaktavyatvena tatprāye siddhasyāpi kathanopapatteḥ
analyzed: idam iti nirdeśaḥ ca mukhya arthaḥ sampadyate prāṇa maya ādiṣu sarvatra śiraḥ prabhṛti avayavānām vaktavya tvena tad prāye siddhasya api kathana upapatteḥ
translated: And the reference to it as ‘this’ becomes appropriate, as the head and other limbs are to be mentioned everywhere in the case of the person consisting of life, etc., and it is proper to mention what is well-known in the case of what is mostly similar.

original: śarīritvamavayavitvaṃ priyādiyogo brahmapucchatvaṃ cetyetatsarvaṃ samañjasaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: śarīri tvam avayavi tvam priya ādi yogaḥ brahma puccha tvam ca iti etat sarvam samañjasam bhavati
translated: Thus all this—being embodied, being composed of parts, being connected with what is dear, etc., and being the tail of Brahman—becomes consistent.

original: naca vaktavyaṃ śarīrādikośā eva kutastarhi nāṅgīkriyante /
analyzed: na ca vaktavyam śarīra ādi kośāḥ eva kutas tarhi na aṅgīkriyante
translated: And it should not be said that only the bodies, etc., are accepted as the sheaths. Why are they not accepted?

original: tathā cānnamayaprāṇamayamanomayavijñānamayānandamayā me śuddhayantāmiti śrutyantarānuguṇyaṃ ca syāditi /
analyzed: tathā ca anna maya prāṇa maya manaḥ maya vijñāna maya ānanda mayāḥ me śuddhayantām iti śruti antara ānuguṇyam ca syāt iti
translated: And thus there would be conformity with another scriptural passage: May my food-made, life-made, mind-made, knowledge-made, and bliss-made (bodies) be purified.

analyzed: kośeṣu brahma śabda ādi anupapatteḥ
translated: Because the word Brahman and so on are not possible in the sheaths.

analyzed: anya tvam antara tvam śarīra tvam ca upādhi apekṣayā jīve pi upapadyante
translated: Otherness, internality, and embodiment are possible even in the individual soul in relation to the limiting adjuncts.

analyzed: nanu jīva pakṣe pi anupapattiḥ asti
translated: But even in the case of the individual soul, there is an impossibility.

original: brahmaśabdo hi nirādhāro na paramātmanā vinopapadyate /
analyzed: brahma śabdaḥ hi nirādhāraḥ na paramātmanā vinā upapadyate
translated: For the word Brahman, which has no basis, is not possible except with the Supreme Self.

analyzed: adyate tti ca iti
translated: It is eaten, it eats.

analyzed: sarva ādya tvam sarva attṛ tvam prāṇam devāḥ
translated: The life-breath is the gods.🔽From which the speech.

analyzed: iti yatas vācaḥ
translated: Thus it is the object of worship of all gods.

analyzed: iti vāc manasā agocara tva vijñānam devāḥ
translated: The knowledge is the gods.🔽Thus it is the object of meditation of all gods.

analyzed: iti sarva deva upāsya tvam jyeṣṭha tvam saḥ kāmayata
translated: It desired.

original: iti saṅkalpapūrvakaṃ sarvasraṣṭṛtvaṃ sarvāntaratvamityādīni nālpatarajñānaśaktayādisampanne jīve sambhavanti /
analyzed: iti saṅkalpa pūrvakam sarva sraṣṭṛ tvam sarva antara tvam ityādīni na alpatara jñāna śaktayā ādi sampanne jīve sambhavanti
translated: Thus the creation of all preceded by resolve and the internality of all are not possible in the individual soul, which is endowed with a limited knowledge, power, etc.

analyzed: tad hetu vyapadeśaḥ ca asaṅgataḥ syāt
translated: And the declaration of its cause would be irrelevant.

analyzed: māntravarṇika vyākhyāna tā ca bādhyeta
translated: And the explanation based on the words of the mantra would be contradicted.

analyzed: na ca jīva jñānāt mokṣaḥ yujyate iti
translated: And it is not proper that liberation should come from the knowledge of the individual soul.

analyzed: mā evam
translated: No, that is not so.

analyzed: upaniṣad artha an abodhāt
translated: Because of the non-understanding of the meaning of the Upanishads.

original: atra hi jīvabrahmaṇorekatvaṃ vivakṣitam /🔽tatra yāni vākyāni śuddhavirodhīni tānyupahitasaṃsārisvarūpāpekṣāṇi /
analyzed: atra hi jīva brahmaṇoḥ eka tvam vivakṣitam  tatra yāni vākyāni śuddha virodhīni tāni upahita saṃsāri svarūpa apekṣāṇi
translated: For here the oneness of the individual soul and Brahman is intended.🔽Among them, those statements that are contradictory to the pure Brahman depend on the limited individual soul's own nature.

analyzed: brahma śabda ādīni tu tad svabhāva siddha paramātma svarūpa apekṣāṇi
translated: But those that use words like Brahman depend on the nature of the supreme Self, which is established as its nature.

analyzed: aikya vivakṣā ca atra vākya śābalya anyathā anupapattyā eva gamyate
translated: And the intention of oneness here is understood by the non-applicability of the contradiction of the sentences.

original: nacaivaṃ vinigamanāyāṃ kāraṇābhāvātparamātmaivānnamayādiśabda🔽vācyomahākāśadharma evāvacchinnakāśe vyavahriyate /🔽yāvānvāyamākāśastāvāneṣo 'ntarhṛdaya ākāśaḥ' / iti /
analyzed: na ca evam vinigamanāyām kāraṇa abhāvāt paramātmā eva anna maya ādi śabda  vācyaḥ mahākāśa dharmaḥ eva avacchinna kāśe vyavahriyate  yāvān vai ayam ākāśaḥ tāvān eṣaḥ ntar hṛdaye ākāśaḥ iti
translated: And thus, in the ascertainment, there is no reason. The supreme Self alone is denoted by the words food-made etc.🔽The attribute of the great space is spoken of in the limited space.🔽As great as this space is, so great is this space within the heart.

analyzed: na tu paricchinna dharmaḥ vitasti mātra tvam mahā ākāśe
translated: But the attribute of the limited one, namely, the size of two outstretched fingers, is not in the great space.

analyzed: na ca brahma puccham pratiṣṭhā iti anupapannam
translated: And it is not improper to say Brahman is the tail, the support.

original: asya jīvasya brahma pucchamāyatanamadhiṣṭhānaṃ nijaṃ svarūpamityarthopapatteḥ /
analyzed: asya jīvasya brahma puccham āyatanam adhiṣṭhānam nijam svarūpam iti artha upapatteḥ
translated: The meaning is proper: This individual soul's own nature is Brahman, the tail, the abode, the basis.

analyzed: tasmāt na itaraḥ
translated: Therefore, It is not the other.

original: ityanupapannamityāśaṅkāṃ parihartuṃ bhedavyapadeśācceti sūtram / /🔽oṃ bhedavyapadeśācca oṃ //
analyzed: iti anupapannam iti āśaṅkām parihartum bheda vyapadeśāt ca iti sūtram  om bheda vyapadeśāt ca om
translated: To remove the doubt that this is not possible, the aphorism is: Because of the teaching of difference.🔽Om. Because of the teaching of difference.

analyzed: bheda vyapadeśāt ca
translated: And because of the teaching of difference.

analyzed: āditye puruṣe ca ayam iti bheda upadeśataḥ
translated: Because of the teaching of difference between this in the sun and the person,

analyzed: na asya abhedaḥ sti jīvena
translated: there is no non-difference of this with the individual soul.

original: tatra caśabdaḥ pratijñāsamuccayārtha iti bhāvena sūtraṃ vyācaṣṭe āditya iti //
analyzed: tatra caśabdaḥ pratijñā samuccaya arthaḥ iti bhāvena sūtram vyācaṣṭe ādityaḥ iti
translated: And there, the word ca (and) has the sense of combining the thesis. With this idea, the aphorism is commented upon as in the sun etc.

analyzed: syāt etat evam kathañcid
translated: This may be so in some way.

analyzed: yadi asyām upaniṣadi jīva paramātmanoḥ abhedaḥ vivakṣitaḥ syāt
translated: If the non-difference of the individual soul and the supreme self were intended in this Upanishad.

analyzed: na ca evam
translated: But it is not so.

original: sa yaścāyaṃ puruṣe yaścāsāvāditye sa ekaḥ' /
analyzed: sa yaḥ ca ayam puruṣe yaḥ ca asau āditye saḥ ekaḥ
translated: He who is this in the person and he who is this in the sun, he is one.

analyzed: iti puruṣa āditya śabda upalakṣita apakṛṣṭa utkṛṣṭa sakala jīvānām niyamya tayā adhikaraṇa tvena paramātmanaḥ ca niyāmaka tayā adhiṣṭhātṛ tvena bhedasya eva atra upadeśāt
translated: Thus, because here only the difference is taught between the individual souls, which are inferior and superior, and are indicated by the words person and sun, as the objects of regulation, and the supreme self, as the regulator, as the presiding deity,

original: tathārasaṃ hyevāyaṃ labdhvā'nandī bhavati' /🔽iti labdhṛlabdhavyatayāyadā hyevaiṣaḥ' /
analyzed: tathārasam hi eva ayam labdhvā ānandī bhavati  iti labdhṛ labdhavya tayā a yadā hi eva eṣaḥ
translated: For he, having obtained that essence, becomes blissful.🔽When he indeed goes forth...

analyzed: iti upāsaka upāsya tayā upasaṅkrāmati
translated: ...he goes forth to that.🔽He who knows Brahman as thus becomes Brahman himself.

analyzed: iti prāptṛ prāpya tayā abhīṣā asmāt
translated: Thus, there is difference between the enjoyer and the object of enjoyment.

original: iti niyamyaniyāmakatayā ca bhedopadeśā draṣṭavyāḥ /🔽yaduktaṃ vākyaśābalyānyathā
analyzed: iti niyamya niyāmaka tayā ca bheda upadeśāḥ draṣṭavyāḥ  yat uktam vākya śābalyā anyathā
translated: And the teaching of difference should be seen as being due to the relation of the controlled and the controller.

analyzed: nupapattiḥ atra pramāṇam iti
translated: As for what was said, that the non-apprehension of difference is the means of knowledge here,

analyzed: tat ayuktam
translated: that is not correct.

analyzed: kevalam brahma para tayā eva vākyānām samañjasīkṛta tvāt
translated: Because the sentences are made consistent only by being about Brahman.

analyzed: tatas na jīvaḥ nna maya ādi śabda vācyaḥ iti
translated: Therefore, the individual soul is not denoted by the words beginning with 'made of food'.

analyzed: nanu katham ucyate na asya paramātmanaḥ bhedaḥ sti jīvena iti
translated: But how can it be said that there is no non-difference of this supreme self with the individual soul?

analyzed: anumānataḥ tad abhedasya pramita tvāt
translated: Because that non-difference is known by inference.

original: tathā coktavidhayānnamayatvādikaṃ jīvasya kiṃ na syāt /
analyzed: tathā ca ukta vidhayā anna maya tva ādikam jīvasya kim na syāt
translated: And so, how can the individual soul not have the nature of being made of food etc. in the way described?

analyzed: na ca ukta bheda upadeśa virodhaḥ
translated: And there is no contradiction with the teaching of difference stated above.

analyzed: anumāna virodhena tasya eva anya paratva upapatteḥ iti āśaṅkā parihārāya sūtram kāmāt ca na anumāna apekṣā iti
translated: Because it is possible that that (teaching) has another meaning due to contradiction with inference. To remove this doubt, the aphorism is: And because of desire, there is no need for inference.

analyzed: tat vayācaṣṭe na anumā iti
translated: He explains that as follows: He says 'not inference' etc.

analyzed: na anumā kāma cāriṇī
translated: Inference does not roam at will.

analyzed: vimatāni śarīrāṇi mad bhoga āyatanāni yat
translated: Because those bodies that are mine are the abodes of my enjoyment,

analyzed: śarīrāṇi iti ādikā tu tattva jñāne hi apekṣyate
translated: But the inference beginning with 'bodies' etc. is needed for the knowledge of reality.

analyzed: pratyakṣa ādi viruddha tvāt
translated: Because it contradicts perception etc.

analyzed: om kāmāt ca na anumāna apekṣā om
translated: Om. And because of desire, there is no need for inference. Om.

analyzed: kāmāt ca na anumāna apekṣā
translated: And because of desire, there is no need for inference.

analyzed: sampratipanna sva śarīreṣu siddhasādhana tā parihārāya vimatāni iti uktam
translated: In order to avoid the fallacy of proving what is already established in the case of one's own body which is accepted by both parties, 'disputed' is said.

analyzed: yat yasmāt śarīrāṇi
translated: Because these are bodies.

analyzed: śarīra tvāt iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: because of being a body.

analyzed: mad śarīra ādi
translated: Like my own body, etc.

analyzed: vat iti dṛṣṭāntaḥ  ādi grahaṇāt vipratipannāni indriyāṇi mama eva karaṇāni indriya tvāt sampratipanna vat ityādīnām upādānam
translated: This is the example.🔽By the word 'etc.', the disputed senses are included, which are inferred to be my own instruments, because they are senses, like what is accepted.

analyzed: nanu etāni anumānāni pratikṣetram kṣetrajñānām abhedam sādhayanti
translated: But these inferences prove the non-difference of the individual souls from the Supreme Self in each body.

original: natu jīvānāṃ paramātmābhedam /🔽tena vimatā ātmānaḥ paramātmanaḥ tattvato
analyzed: na tu jīvānām paramātma abhedam  tena vimatāḥ ātmānaḥ paramātmanaḥ tattvato
translated: Not the non-difference of the individual souls from the Supreme Self.🔽Therefore, the disputed souls are not really different from the Supreme Self,

analyzed: na bhidyante ātma tvāt paramātma vat ityādi anumānam atra śaṅkanīyam
translated: because they are souls, like the Supreme Self, etc. This inference should be suspected here.

analyzed: na tu idam iti  mā evam
translated: But this is not so.🔽This is not so.

analyzed: nahi jīvānām upahita svarūpāṇām eva sākṣāt abhedaḥ sambhavati
translated: For the individual souls, which have limited forms, the non-difference cannot be direct,

analyzed: pratyakṣa ādi virodhāt
translated: because of the contradiction with perception, etc.

analyzed: tatas ca nirupādhikena rūpeṇa abhede numānam paryavasyati
translated: Therefore, the inference concludes with non-difference in the unqualified form.

analyzed: tathā ca katham na prakṛta saṅgatiḥ iti
translated: And how then is there no connection with the subject matter?

analyzed: tattva jñāne
translated: In the knowledge of reality, the knowledge of reality is the purpose.

analyzed: na apekṣyate
translated: It is not required.

analyzed: tattva jñāna kāraṇam na bhavati iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that it is not the cause of the knowledge of reality.

analyzed: kutas
translated: Why is that?

analyzed: pratyakṣa ādi viruddha tvāt
translated: Because it is contrary to perception and other means of knowledge.

analyzed: hi śabdaḥ dṛṣṭānta sūcakaḥ
translated: The word hi indicates an example.

analyzed: tat ayam prayogaḥ
translated: This is the argument.

analyzed: vimatāni śarīrāṇi iti ādikā anumā anumāna tvena parā abhimatā
translated: The inference accepted by the opponent, starting with the bodies in question, is not valid.

analyzed: yathārtha jñāna kāraṇam na bhavati
translated: It is not the cause of knowledge in accordance with reality.

original: pramāṇaviruddhatvāddahanānuṣṇatāsādhanānumānavaditi /🔽pratyakṣādiviruddhāpi sadanumā kiṃ na syādityata uktam kāmacāriṇīti //
analyzed: pramāṇa viruddha tvāt dahana anuṣṇa tā sādhana anumāna vat iti  pratyakṣa ādi viruddhā api sat anumā kim na syāt iti atas uktam kāma cāriṇī iti
translated: Because it is contrary to the means of knowledge, like the inference proving that fire is not hot.🔽Even if it is contrary to perception and other means of knowledge, can inference still be valid? To this he says wandering at will.

analyzed: tat vivṛṇoti akṣa iti  akṣa āgama bhaya ujkhitā
translated: He explains that with the senses and so on.🔽Inference is free from the fear of contradiction by the senses and scriptures.

analyzed: anumā kāma vṛttā hi
translated: It wanders at will.

analyzed: akṣam pratyakṣam  anumānam api atra upasaṅkhayeyam
translated: Aksa means perception.🔽Inference should also be included here.

analyzed: akṣa āgama bhaya ujkhitā iti
translated: Free from the fear of contradiction by the senses and scriptures means

analyzed: tad virodha bhaya ujkhita iti arthaḥ
translated: free from the fear of contradiction with them.

analyzed: kāma vṛttā puruṣa icchā anusāri pravṛttimatī
translated: Wandering at will means proceeding in accordance with the desire of the person.

original: nanvanena kiṃ vipakṣe bādhakamuktamityata āha kutreti // /
analyzed: nanu anena kim vipakṣe bādhakam uktam iti atas āha kutra iti
translated: But what is the counter-argument stated by this? To this he says where and so on.

analyzed: kutra na avasaram vrajet
translated: Where would it not find an opportunity?

analyzed: kim ākṣepe
translated: What is the question?

analyzed: sarvatra api avasaram vrajet iti arthaḥ  tat katham iti atas āha jaḍaḥ iti
translated: The meaning is that one should go to every opportunity.

original: jaḍa ātmaiva vastutvāt prameyatvājjaḍaṃ citiḥ /🔽ghana ākāśa ityādyā vāryante kena hetunā // / / //
analyzed: jaḍaḥ ātmā eva vastu tvāt prameya tvāt jaḍam citiḥ  ghanaḥ ākāśaḥ ityādyāḥ vāryante kena hetunā
translated: How is that? Therefore it is said: The dull self, etc.

analyzed: ātmā jaḍaḥ jñāna anāśrayaḥ vastu tvāt ghaṭa vat
translated: The dull self is indeed the object of knowledge, like a pot.

analyzed: ākāśaḥ ghanaḥ nibiḍa avayavaḥ  prameya tvāt pāṣāṇa vat iti sākṣi pratyakṣa viruddham
translated: Space is dense, with compact parts.🔽It is contradicted by perception, like a stone.

analyzed: jaḍam ghaṭa ādikam
translated: The dull pot, etc.

analyzed: citiḥ cetanam
translated: Consciousness is the conscious.

analyzed: prameya tvāt ātma vat iti anumāna viruddham
translated: It is contradicted by inference, like the self.

original: caitanyakāryasya sarvathāpyanupalambhāt /🔽ādyapadena brāhmaṇena surā peyā dravadravyatvāt /
analyzed: caitanya kāryasya sarvathā api anupalambhāt  ādya padena brāhmaṇena surā peyā drava dravya tvāt
translated: Because the effect of consciousness is never perceived.

analyzed: kṣīra vat iti āgama viruddhasya grahaṇam  kena iti ākṣepe  yadi pratyakṣa ādi virodhinaḥ pi anumā tvam syāt iti śeṣaḥ
translated: By the first statement, that Brahmins should drink liquor, because it is a liquid substance, like milk, the contradiction with scripture is included.🔽By by whom is meant: if inference were to contradict perception, etc., then what is cited would also not be, because there is no difference.

original: pratyakṣādiviruddhamapi yadyaikyānumānaṃ pramāṇaṃ syāttadodāhṛtamapi kiṃ na syādaviśeṣādityuktaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: pratyakṣa ādi viruddham api yadi aikya anumānam pramāṇam syāt tadā udāhṛtam api kim na syāt aviśeṣāt iti uktam bhavati
translated: This is what is meant.

analyzed: nanu atra katham prayoktavyam
translated: But how should this be employed here?

analyzed: yathānyāsam aveti evakāreṇa āha
translated: The word 'eva' (only) is used to indicate that it is exactly as stated.

analyzed: tarhi pratijñā pada vyāghātaḥ syāt iti ced
translated: If it is argued that there would be a contradiction with the thesis,

analyzed: astu
translated: let it be so.

analyzed: nahi pratyakṣa ādi virodhāt ayam garīyān
translated: For this [contradiction] is not weightier than the contradiction with perception etc.

analyzed: samaḥ ca para anumāne
translated: And it is equal in the inference for others.

analyzed: tad parihāraḥ pi atra tulyaḥ
translated: And the reply to that is the same here.

original: nanvākāśo ghana iti sādhane kālādau vyabhicāraḥ / na /
analyzed: nanu ākāśaḥ ghanaḥ iti sādhane kāla ādau vyabhicāraḥ na
translated: If it is argued that in the proof that space is dense, there is deviation in time etc., it is not so.

analyzed: pakṣa tulya tvāt
translated: Because it is equal to the subject.

analyzed: yat atra vaktavyam tat upariṣyāt vakṣyate iti
translated: What is to be said here will be said later.

analyzed: nanu atha atas brahma jijñāsā iti atra eva jīva īśa bhedaḥ samarthitaḥ
translated: But here itself in 'Now, therefore, the inquiry into Brahman', the difference between the individual soul and the Lord is established.

analyzed: tathā janma ādi sūtreṇa api
translated: And also by the aphorism beginning with 'birth' etc.

analyzed: atas jīva aikyam iti ukta tvāt
translated: Therefore, because oneness with the individual soul is stated,

original: atrāpi punastatsādhane punaruktatā syāditya āha na jīveti //
analyzed: atra api punar tad sādhane punarukta tā syāt ityaḥ āha na jīva iti
translated: there would be repetition again in proving that here also. To this he says 'not' etc.

analyzed: na jīva bheda sūtrāṇām śaṅkayā atra punar ukta tā
translated: There is no repetition here due to the doubt of the aphorisms on the difference of the individual soul.

analyzed: vākya antara dyotaka tvāt pṛthak iti atra pūrṇa tā
translated: Because it indicates other sentences, it is complete separately here.

original: atra śāstre tatra tatra prakaraṇe hyaikyavivakṣāyāṃ coditāyāṃ tattadgatabhedavākyadyotanena sūtreṣu bhedasamarthanaṃ kriyate /
analyzed: atra śāstre tatra tatra prakaraṇe hi aikya vivakṣāyām coditāyām tad tad gata bheda vākya dyotanena sūtreṣu bheda samarthanam kriyate
translated: Here in this scripture, in that and that section, when the desire for oneness is urged, the establishment of difference is done in the aphorisms by illuminating the sentences on difference contained therein.

analyzed: atas tātparya bhedāt na punarukta tā śaṅkayā
translated: Therefore, due to the difference in purport, there is no need to suspect repetition.

analyzed: tathā hi
translated: To explain:

analyzed: jijñāsā vākyeṣu abheda śaṅkāyām tad gata brahma śabdena eva bheda samarthanam
translated: In the sentences expressing inquiry, if there is doubt of non-difference, the word Brahman itself establishes difference.

original: jijñāsyasya brahmaṇo jīvatve śaṅkite tatpūrvavākyoktalakṣaṇena bhedasādhanamityādi svayamūhyam /🔽evamevabhedavyapadeśāccānyaḥ' /
analyzed: jijñāsyasya brahmaṇaḥ jīva tve śaṅkite tad pūrva vākya ukta lakṣaṇena bheda sādhanam ityādi svayam ūhyam  evam eva bheda vyapadeśāt ca anyaḥ
translated: If there is doubt that Brahman, the object of inquiry, is the individual soul, then the characteristic stated in the previous sentence establishes difference. The rest should be understood by oneself.

analyzed: ityādau api punar ukta doṣaḥ pariharaṇīyaḥ
translated: In the same way, in the statement Therefore, it is different, the fault of repetition should be avoided.

original: nanvevaṃ satyabhedaḥ svarūpeṇa kutrāpi na nirākṛtaḥ syādityata āha pṛthagiti //
analyzed: nanu evam satya bhedaḥ svarūpeṇa kutra api na nirākṛtaḥ syāt iti atas āha pṛthak iti
translated: If it is so, then non-difference would not be refuted anywhere by itself. To this he says: separately, etc.

analyzed: pūrṇa tā pradhāna tā
translated: Fulness is the chief thing.

original: bhedasādhanasya svātantryeṇa vicāritatvāt /🔽yadyapi prakaraṇaviśeṣaviṣayatayābhede nirākṛte 'pi svarūpanirākaraṇamarthātsiddhayati /
analyzed: bheda sādhanasya svātantryeṇa vicārita tvāt  yadi api prakaraṇa viśeṣa viṣaya tayā abhede nirākṛte svarūpa nirākaraṇam arthāt siddhayati
translated: Because the means of establishing difference has been considered independently.🔽Even though, when non-difference is refuted by being the object of a particular context, the refutation of the form is implied,

analyzed: tathā api vastu sthiti kathanam etat iti adoṣaḥ  athavā punarukti parihārasya evaṃjāta tva atata ca upamā
translated: still, this is a statement of the actual state of things, so there is no fault.🔽Or, because the avoidance of repetition is of this kind, therefore, in the aphorisms beginning with like a cow,

analyzed: ityādi sūtrāṇi āpāta pratīta bhāṣya diśā bheda parāṇi iva pratibhānti
translated: they appear as if devoted to difference, according to the commentary that is understood at first sight.

analyzed: tad nirāsa artham idam uktam
translated: This is said to refute that.

analyzed: pṛthak upadeśāt
translated: Because of the separate teaching.

analyzed: iti atra eva bheda samarthanasya pūrṇa tā paryavasānam iti
translated: Here alone the completeness of the establishment of difference ends.

analyzed: yadi api etat kariṣyamāṇa vyākhyānāt eva jñāsyate  tathā api spaṣṭa artham uktam iti adoṣaḥ
translated: Although this will be known from the explanation being given,🔽still it is said for the sake of clarity. There is no fault in this.

original: śarīrādikośā evānnamayādiśabdavācyā iti pakṣo 'pi netaro 'nupapatteriti sādhāraṇadoṣeṇa dūṣita eva /
analyzed: śarīra ādi kośāḥ eva anna maya ādi śabda vācyāḥ iti pakṣaḥ api na itaraḥ nupapatteḥ iti sādhāraṇa doṣeṇa dūṣitaḥ eva
translated: The view that the sheaths beginning with the body are denoted by the words beginning with made of food is also refuted by the general fault stated in not so, because of non-applicability.

original: viśeṣadoṣeṇa dūṣayituṃ sūtram asminnasya ca tadyogaṃ śāstīti /🔽oṃ asminnasya ca tadyogaṃ śāsti oṃ //
analyzed: viśeṣa doṣeṇa dūṣayitum sūtram asmin asya ca tat yogam śāsti iti  om asmin asya ca tat yogam śāsti om
translated: To refute it with a specific fault, the aphorism is: It declares his connection with that in this, and in that.🔽Om. It declares his connection with that in this, and in that.

analyzed: asmin asya ca tad yogam śāsti  /
translated: It declares his connection with that in this, and in that.

analyzed: yogam anna maya ādyaiḥ yat phala tvena asya śaṃsati
translated: Since it declares his connection with the made of food etc. as its fruit,

original: sthānadvaye 'pyataḥ kośā eta ityatisāhasam // / /h //🔽yadyasmādasya sa ya evaṃvidityuktasya brahmavidaḥ phalatvenānnamayādibhiryogaṃ tatprāptiṃ sthānadvaye 'pyanuvākadvaye 'pi /
analyzed: sthāna dvaye kośāḥ ete iti ati sāhasam  yat yasmāt asya sa yaḥ evaṃvid iti uktasya brahma vidaḥ phala tvena annamaya ādibhiḥ yogam tad prāptim sthāna dvaye pi anuvāka dvaye pi
translated: It is extremely rash to say that these are the sheaths in both places.🔽Since, because, it declares, narrates, the scripture, his connection with the made of food etc., his attainment of them, in both places, in both sections,

analyzed: śaṃsati kathayati śrutiḥ
translated: as the fruit of the knower of Brahman, of him who is said he who knows thus.

analyzed: etam anna mayam ātmānam upasaṅkrāmati ityādi
translated: He goes to this made of food Self, etc.

analyzed: etam anna mayam ātmānam upasaṅkramya ityādi ca
translated: And so on, up to 'having approached this self consisting of food'.

analyzed: atas ete nna maya ādayaḥ kośāḥ iti etat vayākhyānam ati sāhasam pūrva uttara a parāmarśa mūlam
translated: Therefore, the explanation that these, the 'sheaths' consisting of food, etc., are so called is extremely rash, based on the non-reference to what precedes and what follows.

analyzed: nahi śarīra ādi kośa prāptiḥ brahma vidyā phalam iti sambhavati
translated: For it is not possible that the attainment of the 'sheaths' beginning with the body is the fruit of the knowledge of Brahman.

analyzed: tarati śokam ātma vid ityādi virodhāt
translated: Because of such passages as 'he who knows the Self crosses over sorrow', etc.

analyzed: śarīra ādeḥ ca śoka rūpa tvāt
translated: And because the body, etc., are of the nature of that which sorrows.

analyzed: syāt etat yat yatra anna maya ādi prāptiḥ ucyeta
translated: This might be so if the attainment of the 'sheaths' beginning with the one consisting of food were mentioned here.

analyzed: na ca etat asti
translated: But that is not the case.

original: upasaṅkramaśabdasyātikramārthatvādityata āha upasaṅkramaṇaṃ ceti // /🔽upasaṅkramaṇaṃ caiva dvitīyoddeśitaṃ prati /
analyzed: upasaṅkrama śabdasya atikrama artha tvāt iti atas āha upasaṅkramaṇam ca iti  upasaṅkramaṇam ca eva dvitīya uddeśitam prati
translated: Because the word 'upasampad' means 'to go beyond'. To this he says: 'And the going beyond' (is to be supplied) 'to what is indicated by the second (word)'.

analyzed: atikramam vadantam tam upaśabdaḥ nivārayet
translated: And the word 'upa' would forbid (the meaning of) 'going beyond' (in the word 'upasampad') to one who speaks of it (as meaning 'going beyond') with reference to what is indicated by the second (word).

analyzed: dvitīya uddeśitam prati
translated: To what is indicated by the second (word).

original: dvitīyayā karmatvenoktamannamayādikaṃ prati yadupasaṅkramaṇamucyate tadatikramaṃ vadantam /
analyzed: dvitīyayā karma tvena uktam anna maya ādikam prati yat upasaṅkramaṇam ucyate tad atikramam vadantam
translated: With reference to the food-sheath, etc., which are mentioned as the object by the second (case-ending), the 'going beyond' that is mentioned would be 'going beyond'.

analyzed: upasaṅkramaṇa pada vāci padam atikrama artham vyākurvantam iti yāvat  upaśabdaḥ nivārayet
translated: That is, to one who explains the word 'upasampad', which means 'going', as meaning 'going beyond'.🔽The word 'upa' would forbid it.

analyzed: tasya upaśabda virodhaḥ syāt
translated: There would be a contradiction with the word 'upa'.

analyzed: upa pūrvasya krameḥ prāpti artha tvāt  doṣa antaram āha aśrutasya iti
translated: Because the prefix upa has the sense of sequence.

analyzed: a śrutasya ati śabdasya sthānam dadyāt katham punar
translated: He states another fault: How can it give a place to the unheard word ati?

analyzed: punar iti doṣa antara samuccaya arthaḥ
translated: Again - the word again is for the purpose of including another fault.

analyzed: śruta aśruta parityāga kalpane vigata hriyām  vākya dvaya tātparyam āha śruta iti
translated: In the assumption of abandoning the heard and unheard, in the absence of shame...🔽He states the purport of the two sentences: By the heard...

original: evaṃ vyākurvāṇena hi śrutamupaśabdaṃ tyaktavā tatsthāne 'śruto 'tiśabdo 'dhyāhāryaḥ /
analyzed: evam vyākurvāṇena hi śrutam upaśabdam tyaktavā tad sthāne tiśabdaḥ dhyā āhāryaḥ
translated: For one who explains thus, having abandoned the heard word upa, the unheard word ati would have to be supplied in its place.

analyzed: tathā ca śruta parityāgaḥ śruta kalpanam ca syāt
translated: And thus there would be the abandonment of the heard and the assumption of the unheard.

analyzed: tat ubhayam ca lajjā hetuḥ iti
translated: And both of those are causes of shame.

original: na vayaṃ śrutaparityāgenāśrutādhyāhāraṃ kurmo yenāyaṃ doṣaḥ syāt /
analyzed: na vayam śruta parityāgena aśruta adhyāhāram kurmaḥ yena ayam doṣaḥ syāt
translated: We do not commit the abandonment of the heard and the assumption of the unheard, by which this fault would occur.

analyzed: kim nāma avyayānām aneka artha tvāt upaśabdaḥ tiśabda arthaḥ vyākhyāyate iti ced na
translated: If it is said that rather the word upa is explained as having the meaning of the word ati because indeclinables have multiple meanings, no.

analyzed: niyāmakena vinā prasiddha artha tyāga aprasiddha artha svīkāra anupapatteḥ
translated: Because without a restriction, the abandonment of the well-known meaning and the acceptance of the unknown meaning are not possible.

analyzed: na hi avyayāni aneka arthāni iti etāvatā antar śabdasya bahis iti arthaḥ gṛhyate
translated: For merely by the indeclinables having multiple meanings, the meaning of the word anta as outside is not grasped.

analyzed: kintu prayoga ādikam anusṛtya evā iti sthite bhyupagamya api doṣam āha mṛtau evā iti
translated: But it is established that it is only in accordance with the performance etc. Having accepted even that, he states the fault in the case of death etc.

analyzed: mṛtau eva parityāgaḥ kṛtaḥ hi anna mayasya ca
translated: But it is established that it is only in accordance with the performance of the rites etc. Having accepted this, he states the fault: He says, The abandonment is indeed made only at death, of the one consisting of food, etc.

original: hi yasmādannamayasya kośasya caśabdātprāṇamayasya ca parityāgo mṛtāveva kṛto bhavati /
analyzed: hi yasmāt anna mayasya kośasya caśabdāt prāṇa mayasya ca parityāgaḥ mṛtau eva kṛtaḥ bhavati
translated: For, since the word 'ca' (and) indicates the abandonment of the sheath consisting of food and also of the one consisting of prāṇa, it is indeed made only at death.

analyzed: mṛteḥ śarīra tyāga rūpa tvāt
translated: Because death is of the nature of abandoning the body.

analyzed: tasmāt asmāt lokāt pretya iti maraṇa uktayā eva anna maya ādi atikramasya ukta tvāt apunar etam anna mayam ātmānam upasaṅkrāmati iti tad atikrama uktau punaruktiḥ prasajyeta iti
translated: Therefore, since the transcendence of the food-based and others is stated by the statement of death itself with the words 'having departed from this world', if the transcendence of that is stated again with the words 'he again approaches this food-based self', there would be the fault of repetition.

original: kiñca brahmavidāpnoti paramityupakramānuguṇyaṃ ca prāptiparatve syāt /
analyzed: kiñca brahma vidā āpnoti param iti upakrama ānuguṇyam ca prāpti paratve syāt
translated: Moreover, in the case of the statement of attainment, there would be conformity with the beginning, which is 'one who knows Brahman attains the supreme'.

analyzed: atas na anna maya ādayaḥ kośāḥ kintu viṣṇuḥ eva
translated: Therefore, the food-based and others are not sheaths, but Viṣṇu alone.

analyzed: śuddhi prārthana liṅgāt vākya antara uktānām kośa tve pi na kaścid virodhaḥ
translated: Or, even if the sheaths are stated in another passage due to the indication of the request for purification, there is no contradiction at all.

analyzed: api ca te n n maya ādayaḥ
translated: Moreover, those food-based and others,

original: ete tvannarasamaya ityupakramādraso vai sa iti vākyaśeṣāccānnarasamayādaya iti śabdāntaranyāyenāpyanye bhaviṣyantīti sarvamanavadyam / /
analyzed: ete tu anna rasa mayaḥ iti upakramāt rasaḥ vai saḥ iti vākyaśeṣāt ca anna rasa maya ādayaḥ iti śabda antara nyāyena api anye bhaviṣyanti iti sarvam anavadyam
translated: But others will be the food-essence, etc., by the method of other words, because of the beginning with these are your food-essences and the conclusion with essence is indeed that. Thus everything is faultless.

original: evamannamayādīnāṃ pañcānāmapi parabrahmatvapratipādanaparatayā sūtrāṇi vyākhyāya pareṣāgamavyākhyāṃ pratyākhyātumuttaro 'yaṃ granthasandarbha 🔽ārabhyate /🔽tatra māyāvādino 'nnamayādayaḥ pañcāpi kośā iti manyamānā brahmapucchaṃ pratiṣṭhetyuktasya brahmaṇaḥ svaprādhānyena jñeyatvapratipādakānyetāni
analyzed: evam anna maya ādīnām pañcānām api para brahma tva pratipādana para tayā sūtrāṇi vyākhyāya pareṣā āgama vyākhyām pratyākhyātum uttaraḥ yam grantha sandarbha  ārabhyate  tatra māyā vādinaḥ nna maya ādayaḥ pañca api kośāḥ iti manyamānāḥ brahma puccham pratiṣṭhā iti uktasya brahmaṇaḥ sva prādhānyena jñeya tva pratipādakāni etāni
translated: Having thus explained the aphorisms as aiming at establishing the true Brahmanhood of all the five, beginning with the food-body, this series of texts is begun in order to refute the explanation of others.

analyzed: sūtrāṇi iti vyācakṣate
translated: There, the Mimamsakas, considering that the five, beginning with the food-body, are all sheaths, explain these aphorisms as teaching the knowability of Brahman, which is stated in the tail of Brahman is the support, with Brahman as the primary subject.

analyzed: tathā hi
translated: For thus:

analyzed: anna maya ādayaḥ catvāraḥ tāvat anna ādi vikārāḥ kośāḥ eva
translated: The four, beginning with the food-body, are indeed sheaths, being modifications of food, etc.

original: tathāca vikārārthe mayaṭpravāhe satyānandamaya evākasmādardhacaratīyanyāyena kathameva mayaṭaḥ prācuryārthatvaṃ brahmaviṣayatvaṃ cāśrīyate
analyzed: tathā ca vikāra arthe mayaṭ pravāhe sati ānanda mayaḥ eva akasmāt ardhacarati iya nyāyena katham eva mayaṭaḥ prācurya artha tvam brahma viṣaya tvam ca āśrīyate
translated: And thus, when the suffix maya is in a series of meanings of modification, how is the meaning of abundance of maya applied only to the bliss-body, and how is it taken as referring to Brahman, by the method of the half-verse that suddenly jumps?

analyzed: māntravarṇika brahma adhikārāt iti ced
translated: If it be said that it is because of the topic of Brahman in the mantra,

analyzed: anna maya ādīnām api tarhi brahmatva prasaṅgaḥ
translated: Then, it follows that the food-made and other sheaths are Brahman.

analyzed: anna maya ādīnām antarasya anyasya śravaṇāt abrahmatvam ānanda mayasya tu tad abhāvāt brahmatvam iti ced na
translated: If it be said that the food-made and other sheaths are not Brahman because something else is heard within them, but the bliss-made is Brahman because that is not so, it is not so.

original: tatrāpi satyaṃ jñānamanantaṃ brahmeti prakṛtasya brahmaṇo brahma pucchaṃ pratiṣṭhetyānandamayāśrayatayoktatvāt /
analyzed: tatra api satyam jñānam anantam brahma iti prakṛtasya brahmaṇaḥ brahma puccham pratiṣṭhā iti ānanda maya āśraya tayā ukta tvāt
translated: Because there also, the bliss-made is said to be the support of Brahman, which is the subject, as Brahman, which is real, knowledge, infinite, is said to be the tail, the support, of Brahman.

analyzed: tad vijijñāpayiṣayā eva anna maya ādayaḥ pañca api kośāḥ kalpyante
translated: The five sheaths beginning with the food-made are postulated only for the purpose of making that known.

original: nanvannamayādīnābhivānandamayasya pucchatvenoktaṃ brahma kathaṃ svapradhānaṃ syāt / na /
analyzed: nanu anna maya ādīnām vā ānanda mayasya puccha tvena uktam brahma katham svapradhānam syāt na
translated: If it be said that Brahman, which is said to be the tail of the bliss-made, which is mentioned along with the food-made and others, how can it be the principal subject? It is not so.

analyzed: sva pradhāna tayā prakṛta tvāt
translated: Because it is the subject as the principal.

original: nacānandamayāvayatvenāpi brahmaṇi jñāyamāne prakṛtatvaṃ na hīyate ānandamayasya brahmatvāditi vācyam /
analyzed: na ca ānanda maya avaya tvena api brahmaṇi jñāyamāne prakṛta tvam na hīyate ānanda mayasya brahma tvāt iti vācyam
translated: And it should not be said that the fact of being the subject is not lost even when Brahman is known as a part of the bliss-made, because the bliss-made is Brahman.

analyzed: tathā sati tat eva avayavi avayavaḥ ca iti asāmañjasya aprasaṅgāt
translated: Because, if that were so, the incongruity of Brahman being both the whole and a part would arise.

analyzed: anyatara parigrahe ca pucchasya eva brahmatvam yuktam
translated: And if one of the two is accepted, it is proper that the tail alone is Brahman.

analyzed: brahma śabda śravaṇāt
translated: Because the word Brahman is heard there.

analyzed: na tu ānanda mayasya tatra brahma śabda aśravaṇāt
translated: But not so of the Self consisting of bliss, because there the word Brahman is not heard.

analyzed: asan eva iti ślokasya brahma puccham iti ukta brahma viṣaya tvāt
translated: For the verse as if non-existent refers to the Brahman spoken of as the tail of the sacrifice.

analyzed: na hi atra ānanda mayaḥ nu ākṛṣṭate
translated: For here the Self consisting of bliss is not superimposed.

analyzed: kintu puccha tayā uktam brahma sva pradhāna tayā  na ca ānanda maya
translated: But Brahman, spoken of as the tail, is stated as the principal.

analyzed: syā anubhava siddhasya bhāva abhāva śaṅkā yujyate
translated: And it is not proper to doubt the existence or non-existence of the Self consisting of bliss, which is established by experience.

analyzed: katham tarhi puccha tva uktiḥ
translated: Then how is the statement of being the tail?

analyzed: pucchavat puccham iti āśraya artha tvāt
translated: Because the word 'tail' is used in the sense of a support, like a tail.

analyzed: kiñca ānanda mayasya priya ādi avayava yoga aśārīra tvābhyām sa viśeṣa ttvāt brahmaṇaḥ api sa viśeṣa tva prasaṅgaḥ
translated: Moreover, since the Self consisting of bliss has the property of having parts like joy etc. and is not the body, Brahman also would have to be admitted as having parts.

analyzed: nirviśeṣam ca brahma
translated: But Brahman is without parts.

analyzed: vāc manasā agocara tva śruteḥ
translated: Because it is declared to be beyond the reach of speech and mind.

analyzed: mayaṭaḥ prācurya artha tve pi ānanda pracuraḥ iti ukte duḥkha alpatvam api gamyate
translated: Even if the suffix maya denotes abundance, when it is said to be abundant in bliss, the presence of little misery is also implied.

analyzed: prācuryasya loke pratiyogi alpatā sāpekṣa tvāt
translated: Because abundance in the world is dependent on the presence of little of its opposite.

analyzed: na ca brahmaṇi duḥkham sambhavati
translated: And misery is not possible in Brahman.

original: kiñca priyādīnāṃ pratiśarīraṃ bhedenānandamayasyāpi bhede brahmaṇo 'pi pratiśarīraṃ bhedaḥ prasajyeta /
analyzed: kiñca priya ādīnām pratiśarīram bhedena ānanda mayasya api bhede brahmaṇaḥ pi pratiśarīram bhedaḥ prasajyeta
translated: Moreover, if the Self consisting of bliss were different, on account of the difference of the dear etc., Brahman also would have to be considered as different with regard to the different individual souls.

analyzed: na ca tat yuktam
translated: But that is not possible,

analyzed: ananta tva śruteḥ
translated: because of the scriptural statement of Brahman being without parts.

analyzed: na ca evam bhāgarvī vāruṇī vidyā viruddhayeta
translated: Nor does the Bṛhadāraṇyaka passage about the Vāruṇī and Bhārgavī knowledge contradict our interpretation,

analyzed: tatra mayaṭaḥ śravaṇena bhinna viṣaya tvāt
translated: because the word consisting is not contained in it, and because it refers to something different.

analyzed: etam ānanda mayam ātmānam iti ca anna maya ādīnām iva ānanda mayasya atikramaṇīya tayā uktasya a brahma tvāt
translated: And the passage, He who consists of bliss, the Self, declares the Self consisting of bliss to be something to be passed over, just as the Self consisting of food etc. are, and thus not to be Brahman.

original: ante mayaṭaḥ śravaṇena pūrvamapi tadadhyāhāre pūrvamapi nānandamayo brahmāstu /
analyzed: ante mayaṭaḥ śravaṇena pūrvam api tad adhyāhāre pūrvam api na ānanda mayaḥ brahma astu
translated: And because the word consisting is found at the end of the passage, it may be supplied also at the beginning, and thus the Self consisting of bliss cannot be Brahman at the beginning of creation either.

analyzed: brahma jñāna arthinaḥ tu tad upadeśaḥ dvāra tayā upapannaḥ bhaviṣyati iti
translated: But the teaching about the Self consisting of bliss may be accepted as a means to the knowledge of Brahman, which is the object of desire of him who is in search of Brahman.

analyzed: nanu evam tarhi katham sūtrāṇi
translated: But if this is so, how are we to understand the Sūtras?

analyzed: ānanda mayasya brahma tā pratipādana para tayā upalambhāt
translated: Because they are found to have for purport the teaching that the Self consisting of bliss is Brahman.

analyzed: mā evam
translated: Not so, we reply.

original: vedasūtrayorvirodhe guṇe tvanyāyyakalpaneti nyāyena sūtrāṇāṃ kathañcidyojyatvāt /
analyzed: veda sūtrayoḥ virodhe guṇe tu anyāyya kalpanā iti nyāyena sūtrāṇām kathañcid yojya tvāt
translated: For, in case of a conflict between the Veda and the Sūtras, the latter are to be interpreted in some way or other, according to the maxim, In doubtful cases we must assume what is not directly stated to be the case

analyzed: tasmāt ānanda maya ādayaḥ pañca api kośāḥ na brahma iti
translated: From all this it follows that the five sheaths consisting of food, &c, are not Brahman.

original: tadetatsūtravyākhyānena nirākṛtamapi śiṣyahitatayā sphuṭaṃ nirākaroti ye 'nnamiti /
analyzed: tat etat sūtra vyākhyānena nirākṛtam api śiṣya hita tayā sphuṭam nirākaroti ye iti
translated: He refutes this clearly for the benefit of the students, even though it has been refuted by the explanation of the sutra, with the words Those who meditate on food as Brahman, etc.

analyzed: ye brahma ityādi upāsām sāmānādhikaraṇyataḥ
translated: Those who meditate on food as Brahman, etc., in the anuvada section,

analyzed: uktavā pañca svarūpāṇām punar tad prāpti vādinī
translated: having stated the five forms, again speak of attaining that.

analyzed: sthāna dvaya gatā veda vāṇī tad apalāpinām
translated: The Vedic statement present in the two sections, for those who deny that,

analyzed: tamasaḥ nyatra saṃsthānam katham eva saheta sā
translated: how can it bear the establishment of darkness elsewhere?

analyzed: ityādi iti kriyāviśeṣaṇam
translated: Etc. is an adverb.

analyzed: viśeṣaṇa samāsaḥ eva ayam na dviguḥ
translated: Of the five forms is a tatpurusa compound, not a dvandva.

analyzed: taddhita artha ādi abhāvāt
translated: Because there is no meaning of the taddhita suffix, etc.

analyzed: tad prāpti vādinī
translated: It speaks of attaining that.

analyzed: jñāna phala tvena iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The meaning is: as the fruit of knowledge.

analyzed: sthāna dvayam anuvāka dvayam
translated: The two sections are the two anuvakas.

analyzed: tad apalāpinām anna maya ādīnām
translated: For those who deny that, i.e., the food-made and others.

original: idamuktaṃ bhavati /🔽annamayādipañcakaṃ yadi na brahma tadānnamayādīnpratyudāhṛtaślokeṣu ye 'nnaṃ brahmopāsata iti prathamānuvāke 'nnaṃ brahmeti vyajānādityuttarānuvāke
analyzed: idam uktam bhavati  anna maya ādi pañcakam yadi na brahma tadā anna maya ādīn pratyudāhṛta ślokeṣu ye nnam brahma upāsate iti prathama anuvāke nnam brahma iti vyajānāt iti uttara anuvāke
translated: This is what is said.🔽If the set of five beginning with the food-made is not Brahman, then there would be a contradiction with the statement in the quoted verses about those who meditate on food as Brahman, and in the second anuvaka,

analyzed: ca brahma tayā ukti virodhaḥ syāt
translated: He knew food to be Brahman in the first anuvaka, and🔽He knew food to be Brahman in the second anuvaka.

analyzed: nahi pucchasya api brahmatve pramāṇam asti anyat atas brahma śabdāt
translated: For there is no other proof that the tail is Brahman except the word Brahman.

analyzed: nanu etat brahma jñāna dvāra tayā upadiṣyam
translated: But it may be said that this is taught as the door to the knowledge of Brahman,

analyzed: na tu brahma tayā upadiṣyam iti ced na
translated: but not as Brahman itself.

analyzed: sāmānādhikaraṇyena ukta tvāt
translated: But this is not so, because it is stated in apposition.

analyzed: na ca sāmānādhikaraṇyam api gauṇam
translated: And the appositional statement is not figurative.

analyzed: tathā sati viduṣaḥ tad prāptiḥ uktā viruddhayā ita
translated: If it were so, the statement of the attainment of that by the knower would be contradicted.

analyzed: na ca tatra atikramaḥ iti uktam
translated: And it has been said that there is no transgression of the meaning there.

original: nacānandamaye brahmaśabdo nāsti ślokasya pucchaviṣayatvāditi vācyam /
analyzed: na ca ānanda maye brahma śabdaḥ na asti ślokasya puccha viṣaya tvāt iti vācyam
translated: And it cannot be said that the word Brahman does not occur in the Ānandamaya, because the verse refers to the tail.

analyzed: tathā sati anna maya ādi ślokānām api tathātva prāpteḥ
translated: For if that were so, the same would follow for the verses on the food-made etc.

analyzed: kiñca bādhaka vaśāt ittham āśrīyate
translated: Moreover, this is accepted because of the contradiction.

analyzed: evam eva vā
translated: Or it is just so.

analyzed: na ādyaḥ
translated: Not the first.

analyzed: bādhakānām parihṛta tvāt
translated: Because the contradictions have been refuted.

original: dvitīye tu nirnimittaṃ vedārthabhūtabrahmāpalāpino bauddhasyeva vedābhimānikopena narakaprāptiḥ syāditi / /
analyzed: dvitīye tu nirnimittam veda artha bhūta brahma apalāpinaḥ bauddhasya iva veda abhimāni kopena naraka prāptiḥ syāt iti
translated: But in the second case, there would be the attainment of hell under the pretext of the Vedas, like that of the Buddhist who, without any reason, denies Brahman which is the meaning of the Vedas.

analyzed: sthāna dvaya gatā iti uktam
translated: It has been said that it occurs in two places.

analyzed: prāk ca bhṛgoḥ ca etat vadiṣyati iti
translated: And before this, it will be said by Bhṛgu.

analyzed: tatra uttara anuvāka uktasya brahma tvam prapañcayati adhīhi iti
translated: There, it elaborates on the Brahmanhood stated in the later anuvāka, with Learn

analyzed: adhīhi bhagavaḥ brahma iti uktaḥ nna prāṇa pūrvakam
translated: When asked, Teach me, revered sir, Brahman, he (Varuna) spoke of food, life, eye, ear, mind, and speech, as preceded by food and life.

analyzed: āha brahma katham tat na
translated: He said, Brahman is that. How is it that?

analyzed: adhīhi adhyāpaya
translated: Teach, teach.

analyzed: ṇi arthasya antar ṇīta tvāt
translated: Because the meaning of the suffix is included.

original: bhagavo bhagavan /🔽matuvaso ruḥ sambuddhau chandasīti vacanāt /
analyzed: bhagavaḥ bhagavan  matu vasoḥ ruḥ sambuddhau chandasi iti vacanāt
translated: Revered sir, revered one.🔽Because of the statement Ru is the vocative in the Vedas, according to the Matubhasha.

analyzed: uktaḥ bhṛguṇā pṛṣṭaḥ varuṇaḥ bhṛguḥ vai vāruṇiḥ
translated: Varuna, when asked by Bhrigu, said: Bhrigu was the son of Varuna.

analyzed: varuṇam pitaram upasasāra
translated: He approached his father Varuna.

analyzed: adhīhi bhagavaḥ brahma iti
translated: Teach me, revered sir, Brahman.

analyzed: tasmai etat provāca
translated: To him he spoke this:

analyzed: annam prāṇam cakṣuḥ śrotram manaḥ vācam
translated: Food, life, eye, ear, mind, and speech.

analyzed: iti evam brahma praśna uttara tvena ukta tvāt anna ādikam brahmā eva bhavitum arhati iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that food and so on must be Brahman itself, because it is stated as the answer to the question about Brahman in this way.

analyzed: nanu tatra mayaṭaḥ śravaṇāt bhinna viṣaya tvam iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that the subject matter is different because the suffix maya is not heard there, it is not so.

analyzed: ukta uttara tvāt
translated: Because the answer has been given.

analyzed: kiñca yathā sati anna maya ādīn pratyudāhṛta ślokeṣu mayaṭaḥ śravaṇāt bhinna viṣaya tvam syāt
translated: Moreover, if the subject matter were different because the suffix maya is not heard in the verses quoted regarding the true food and so on,

analyzed: astu iti ced na
translated: if it is argued that it should be so, it is not so.

analyzed: tathā sati tad udāharaṇasya asaṅgati prasaṅgāt
translated: Because if that were so, the example would be logically incorrect.

analyzed: yasya anna ādeḥ vikārāḥ tad etad praśaṃsā para tayā saṅgatiḥ tu iti ced na
translated: If it be said that there is a connection because of the praise of that which is the source of food, that is not so.

original: manomayaśloke tadayogāt /🔽tarhi tata evānupapatterannādiśabdairannamayādaya evocyata iti kalpyata iti cet /
analyzed: manaḥ maya śloke tad ayogāt  tarhi tatas eva anupapatteḥ anna ādi śabdaiḥ anna maya ādayaḥ eva ucyate iti kalpyate iti ced
translated: Because that is not possible in the verse about the mind-made.🔽If it be said that then it is imagined that the words food etc. refer to the food-made etc. because that is not possible otherwise,

analyzed: tarhi atra api prakaraṇa vaśāt anna maya ādayaḥ eva ucyante iti aṅgīkāryam
translated: then here also it must be accepted that the words food etc. refer to the food-made etc. because of the context.

analyzed: ukte rthe hi saṃvādi tvena iyam ākhyāyikā uktā
translated: For this story is told as corroborating the stated meaning.

analyzed: tasmāt anna maya ādayaḥ eva atra ucyante
translated: Therefore, the food-made etc. are referred to here.

analyzed: te ca brahma praśna uttara tvena uktatva anyathā anupapattyā brahmā eva iti
translated: And because they are stated as the answer to the question about Brahman, they are Brahman by the impossibility of any other explanation.

original: yadyapisaiṣā bhārgavī vāruṇakṣa vidyā parame vyomanpratiṣṭhitā' /
analyzed: yadi api sā eṣā bhārgavī vidyā parame vyoman pratiṣṭhitā
translated: Even though this knowledge of Varuna, belonging to the Bhargava family, is established in the highest heaven,

analyzed: iti sākṣāt brahma vidyā tvam ucyate
translated: it is said to be the direct knowledge of Brahman.

analyzed: tathā api mīmāṃsā artham yuktayā upanyāsaḥ
translated: Nevertheless, arguments are presented for the purpose of investigation.

analyzed: athavā
translated: Or rather,

analyzed: asya api samāna yogakṣema tvāt iti
translated: because it has the same result as that.

analyzed: syāt etat
translated: This may be said:

analyzed: brahma praśna uttara tayā ukti mātreṇa na varuṇa uktānām anna ādīnām brahmatvam
translated: The Brahmanhood of the food etc. mentioned by Varuna is not established merely by their being stated as the answer to a question about Brahman,

analyzed: brahma jñāna upāya tayā api tad upadeśa upapatteḥ
translated: because their teaching is possible even as a means of knowing Brahman.

analyzed: tathā hi
translated: For example,

analyzed: dvitīya ā candra praśne candra rūpā api śākhā candra tayā ucyate candra jñāna upāya tvāt
translated: In the second question about the moon, the branch which is not of the form of the moon is said to be the moon, because it is a means of knowing the moon.

analyzed: yathā vā arundhatī praśne tad samīpa vartinī pṛthulā tārakā arundhatī tvena upadiśyate
translated: Just as in the question about Arundhati, the large star near it is taught as Arundhati,

analyzed: arundhatī jñāna dvāra tvāt
translated: because it is the door to knowing Arundhati.

original: dvāratvaṃ cānnādiśabdoditānāṃ śarīrādīnāṃ bahirvṛttinivāraṇadvārā brahmajñānaṃ pratyupapadyata eveti /
analyzed: dvāra tvam ca anna ādi śabda uditānām śarīra ādīnām bahirvṛtti nivāraṇa dvārā brahma jñānam pratyupapadyate eva iti
translated: And the doorhood of the body etc. indicated by the words anna etc. is indeed appropriate for the knowledge of Brahman through the door of preventing external activities.

analyzed: mā evam
translated: This is not so.

analyzed: kim anena vyabhicāraḥ codyate
translated: Is the fallacy of non-concomitance being urged by this?

analyzed: kiṃvā anyathā asiddhiḥ sambhāvyate
translated: Or is the possibility of being established in another way being imagined?

analyzed: uta sā niścīyate
translated: Or is that being ascertained?

analyzed: pakṣa trayam asambaddham iti āha dvāram iti
translated: The three alternatives are unconnected, he says door etc.

analyzed: dvāram tat iti vādinaḥ
translated: For those who say that is the door.

analyzed: upasattim katham vidyuḥ
translated: How can they know the approach?

analyzed: tat annādikam
translated: That food etc.

analyzed: upapattim brahma jñāna artha upasatti uttara kālīnam guru upadeśa prakāram iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the method of instruction by the teacher after the approach for the purpose of knowing Brahman.

analyzed: katham iti ākṣepe
translated: How is in the sense of objection.

analyzed: na vidyuḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is they do not know.

analyzed: guru upadeśa prakāra ajñāna vijṛmbhitā iyam śaṅkā iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that this doubt arises from the ignorance of the method of instruction by the teacher.

analyzed: tat katham na vidyuḥ iti atas āha aupasannāya iti
translated: How is it that they do not know? To this he says to the one who has approached

analyzed: upasannāya hi triśas
translated: For one who has approached, it should be stated three times.

analyzed: brahma eva vaktavyam
translated: Brahman alone should be stated.

analyzed: na punar yat kiñcid
translated: Not just anything.

original: abodhe 'pi punaḥ punaḥ tadeva śabdāntareṇa vaktavyam /
analyzed: a bodhe pi punar punar tat eva śabda antareṇa vaktavyam
translated: Even if not understood, it should be stated again and again with different words.

analyzed: dvāram ca dvāra tayā eva vaktavyam
translated: And a door should be stated as a door itself.

analyzed: na tu tad ātmaka tvena
translated: But not as having that as its nature.

analyzed: nahi dhūmaḥ gni ātmaka tvena pradaśyarte
translated: For smoke is not indicated as having fire as its nature.

analyzed: candradi udāharaṇam api asiddham eva iti
translated: The example of the moon and lightning is also unestablished.

analyzed: āgamāḥ vedāḥ
translated: The Vedas are the scriptures.

analyzed: sampradāya vidaḥ smṛti itihāsa purāṇa kartāraḥ
translated: The authors of Smriti, Itihasa and Puranas are the knowers of the traditional teachings.

analyzed: api ca au itaretara samuccaya arthau
translated: Moreover, the words api ca (and) have the sense of combining the two.

analyzed: tarhi upadeśa prakāra ajña tayā varuṇaḥ
translated: Then let it be that Varuna, not knowing the method of teaching, teaches something else.

analyzed: mā evam
translated: Not so.

analyzed: lokapālasya etāvat jñāna abhāva sambhavāt iti āśayena dvāra upadeśa śaṅkā nirākaraṇam upasaṃharati tat iti
translated: With the idea that it is possible for the world-protector to lack such knowledge, he concludes the removal of doubt regarding the teaching of the door with the word tat (that).

analyzed: tat yat kiñcid katham brūyāt upasannāya dikpatiḥ
translated: That which the lord of the directions would somehow state to one who has approached,

original: nanvabrahmaiva brahma pṛṣṭavate varuṇenoktaṃ vyāmohanāyeti kiṃ na syādityata āha na vadediti //
analyzed: nanu abrahma eva brahma pṛṣṭavate varuṇena uktam vyāmohanāya iti kim na syāt iti atas āha na vadet iti
translated: Should it not be that Varuna, not knowing Brahman, stated non-Brahman to one who asked about Brahman, for the purpose of confusing him? To this he says na vadet (would not state).

original: na vaded brahma ca kathaṃ māyāvī nahi vārirāṭ // / / //🔽kimākṣepe /🔽brahmaiva vadedityarthaḥ /🔽tatra heturmāyāvī na hīti /🔽āptatvādityarthaḥ /🔽vivakṣitārthatattvajñānaṃ hi varuṇasya dikpateḥ prasiddham /🔽avipralambhakatvaṃ ca pitṛtvāt /🔽bhṛgorbrahmajñānayogyatvāt /🔽upasannāyeti prasaṅgadoṣasya nirastatvāt /🔽vārirāḍiti bhūtābhimānitvenoktasyāpaṭukaraṇatvāsambhavāt /🔽vivakṣāyāścopadeśādeva siddheḥ /🔽ata eva śrutirvāruṇirḥvaruṇaṃ
