analyzed: na vadet brahma ca katham māyāvī nahi  kim ākṣepe  brahmā eva vadet iti arthaḥ  tatra hetuḥ māyāvī na hi iti  āpta tvāt iti arthaḥ  vivakṣita artha tattva jñānam hi varuṇasya dikpateḥ prasiddham  a vipralambhaka tvam ca pitṛ tvāt  bhṛgoḥ brahma jñāna yogya tvāt  upasannāya iti prasaṅga doṣasya nirasta tvāt  vārirāj iti bhūta abhimāni tvena uktasya apaṭu karaṇatva asambhavāt  vivakṣāyāḥ ca upadeśāt eva siddheḥ  atas eva śrutiḥ vāruṇiḥ varuṇam
translated: How can it speak of Brahman? The Lord of the Waters is not an illusionist.

original: pitaramupasasādetyāha /🔽tadanenāptena brahmapraśnottaratvenoktatvamannādīnāṃ brahmatve heturityuktaṃ bhavati / /🔽nanu varuṇenokteṣvannādiṣvannaprāṇamanāṃsi santu brahmasvarūpāṇi /🔽annādiśabdānāmattṛtvādyarthatayānupapattyabhāvāt /🔽cakṣuḥśrotravākśabdaṃ tu kathaṃ brahma syāt /
analyzed: pitaram upasasāda iti āha 🔽tat anena āptena brahma praśna uttara tvena uktatvam anna ādīnām brahmatve hetuḥ iti uktam bhavati 🔽nanu varuṇena ukteṣu anna ādiṣu anna prāṇa manāṃsi santu brahma svarūpāṇi 🔽anna ādi śabdānām attṛ tva ādi artha tayā anupapatti abhāvāt 🔽cakṣuḥ śrotra vāc śabdam tu katham brahma syāt
translated: He approached his father, it is said.🔽By this it is said that the statement of food etc. being Brahman by way of being the answer to the question about Brahman is the reason for food etc. being Brahman.🔽Now, in food etc. stated by Varuna, let food, life and mind be the forms of Brahman.🔽Because the words food etc. are not inconsistent with the meanings of eater etc.🔽But how can the words eye, ear and speech be Brahman?🔽

analyzed: cakṣuḥ ādi śabdānām caṣṭe nena iti cakṣuḥ
translated: And the words 'eye' etc. are derived from the root 'to see' (cakṣate) as 'that by which one sees'.

analyzed: śṛṇoti anena iti śrotram
translated: It is the ear because one hears by it.

analyzed: vadati anayā iti vāc iti karaṇa artha tvāt
translated: It is speech because one speaks by it. Thus they are instruments.

analyzed: brahmaṇaḥ ca karaṇa tva anupapatteḥ iti ced na
translated: If it be said that Brahman cannot be an instrument, it is not so;

analyzed: kartari api tad vyutpatti sambhavāt iti āha caṣṭe iti
translated: because the derivation is possible even in the case of the agent. He says 'it sees' etc.

analyzed: caṣṭe iti eva tat cakṣuḥ śravaṇāt śrotram ucyate
translated: That which sees is indeed the eye. It is called the ear because it hears.

analyzed: vacanāt eva vāc brahma sṛṣṭi sthiti ādi kāraṇam
translated: Speech is Brahman, the cause of creation, sustenance etc.

analyzed: evaśabdena karaṇa sādhanatām nirākaroti
translated: By the word 'eva' (indeed), he rejects the instrumental mode of expression.

analyzed: kiñcayataḥ vai imāni bhūtāni jāyante
translated: Moreover, 'From which are born these beings' (Tai. 2.1).

analyzed: iti sakala bhūtānām sṛṣṭi sthiti saṃhāra kāraṇa tvam ca brahma lakṣaṇam anna ādiṣu upadiṣyam
translated: The characteristic of Brahman as the cause of the creation, sustenance and dissolution of all beings is taught in the food etc.

analyzed: tatas ca etat brahma iti āha sṛṣṭi iti
translated: Therefore, this is Brahman. He says 'creation' etc.

analyzed: yatas sṛṣṭayā ādikāraṇam uktam atas pi brahma iti sambandhaḥ
translated: The connection is: because it is said to be the cause of creation etc., therefore it is Brahman.

analyzed: nanu tathā api na anuvāka dvaya uktam ekam vastu bhavitum arhati
translated: But even so, what is stated in the two Anuvākas cannot be one and the same thing.

analyzed: saṅkhaya abhedāt saṃjñā bhedāt ca
translated: Because of the difference in number and the difference in name.

analyzed: pūrvam khalu anna maya ādayaḥ pañca uktāḥ na cakṣuḥ śrotra vācaḥ
translated: For, indeed, five things beginning with the one consisting of food are stated earlier, not the eye, ear and speech.

original: uttaratra cānnādayaḥ ṣaṭ na vijñānānandāviti tatrāha tacceti //
analyzed: uttaratra ca anna ādayaḥ ṣaṭ na vijñāna ānandau iti tatra āha tat ca iti
translated: And later on, the six beginning with food are not the bliss of consciousness. There he says: That, etc.

analyzed: tat ca vāghūla śākhāyām aṣṭa rūpam udāhṛtam
translated: And that is stated in the Vādhūla branch as having eight forms,

analyzed: vijñāna ānanda sahitam pṛthak sṛṣṭayā ādi lakṣaṇaiḥ
translated: Along with the bliss of consciousness, separately characterized by creation, etc.

analyzed: caśabdaḥ hetvarthaḥ
translated: The word ca (and) has the meaning of reason.

analyzed: yasmāt vādhūlaśākhāyām vijñāna ānanda sahitam tat anna ādi ṣaṭkam iti aṣṭa rūpam brahma tayā udāhṛtam
translated: Because in the Vādhūla branch, that set of six beginning with food, along with the bliss of consciousness, is stated as Brahman having eight forms.

original: tasmāttadanusāreṇa prathamānuvāke cakṣurāditrayasyottaratra vijñānānandayoradhyāhāreṇa saṅkhayāsaṃjñaikyaṃ bhaviṣyatīti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: tasmāt tad anusāreṇa prathama anuvāke cakṣuḥ ādi trayasya uttaratra vijñāna ānandayoḥ adhyāhāreṇa saṅkhayā asaṃjñā aikyam bhaviṣyati iti bhāvaḥ
translated: Therefore, in accordance with that, in the first chapter, by the implication of the triad beginning with the eye, and later of the bliss of consciousness, there will be unity of number and name. This is the idea.

analyzed: hetu anta samuccaye vā caśabdaḥ
translated: Or the word ca (and) is for the collection of other reasons.

analyzed: atra api hi vijñānam brahma iti vyajānāt
translated: For here also, by the consideration of the subsequent statements: He understood that consciousness is Brahman,

analyzed: ānandaḥ brahma iti vyajānāt
translated: He understood that bliss is Brahman.

original: ityuttaravākyaparyālocanayāpi hyatra vijñānānandayoradhyāhāro gamyate /🔽na hyanyadvaruṇenopadiṣyaṃ bhṛgustvanyadvayajānāditi yujyate /
analyzed: iti uttara vākya paryālocanayā api hi atra vijñāna ānandayoḥ adhyāhāraḥ gamyate  na hi anyat varuṇena upadiṣyam bhṛguḥ tu anyat vayajānāt iti yujyate
translated: Even by the consideration of the subsequent statements, the implication of consciousness and bliss is understood here.🔽For it is not proper that Bhṛgu understood something else than what was taught by Varuṇa.

original: nanu vādhūlaśākhoktamapi kuto brahmetyata āha pṛthagiti //
analyzed: nanu vādhūla śākhā uktam api kutas brahma iti atas āha pṛthak iti
translated: But how can what is stated in the Vādhūla branch also be Brahman? To this he says: Separately, etc.

analyzed: aneka śākhā vidām eva atra samyak adhikāra jñāpanāya etat uktam
translated: This is said to indicate that only those who know the many branches are fully qualified here.

analyzed: nanu vādhūla śākhāyām iva atra ubhayatra āṣyakam eva kasmāt na uktam iti atas āha āvāpa iti
translated: But why is it not said here as in the Vādhūla branch that both are to be recited together? To this he says āvāpa etc.

original: āvāpodvāpataṣa śākhā yata āhuḥ paraṃ padam // / / //
analyzed: āvāpa udvāpa taṣa śākhāḥ yatas āhuḥ param padam
translated: The branches are characterized by āvāpa (addition) and udvāpa (omission), since they declare the highest state.

original: kvacidanyatrānuktāvāpena kvacidanyatroktodvāpena kvacidubhayatayā kvacitsāmagṣeṇa parameśvarasvarūpaṃ pratipādayantīti śākhānāṃ svabhāvo yato
analyzed: kvacid anyatra anukta āvāpena kvacid anyatra ukta udvāpena kvacid ubhayatayā kvacid sāmagṣeṇa parameśvara sva rūpam pratipādayanti iti śākhānām svabhāvaḥ yatas
translated: In some places, by adding what is not mentioned elsewhere, in some places, by omitting what is mentioned elsewhere, in some places, by both, and in some places, by the combination, they teach the nature of the Supreme Lord. This is the nature of the branches.

analyzed: na kaścid virodhaḥ iti
translated: Therefore, there is no contradiction at all.

analyzed: nanu tathā api varuṇa upadiṣyānām anna ādīnām brahmatvam na upapadyate
translated: But even so, the Brahmanhood of food etc. taught by Varuṇa is not proper.

analyzed: tat vijñāya punar eva varuṇam pitaram upasasāra
translated: Having known that, he again approached his father Varuṇa.

analyzed: iti labdha upadeśasya api bhṛgoḥ punar upasaraṇa vacanāt
translated: Even though Bhṛgu is said to have received instruction, the statement of his approaching again shows that the Brahman taught earlier is not the same.

original: pūrvoktasyaiva brahmatve adhīhi bhagavo brahmeti punarupasaraṇaṃ vyarthaṃ syāt /
analyzed: pūrva uktasya eva brahmatve adhīhi bhagavaḥ brahma iti punar upasaraṇam vyartham syāt
translated: If the same Brahman taught earlier were to be taught again, his approaching again with Teach me, O revered one, Brahman would be pointless.

original: anena tu jñāyate na pūrvopadiṣyaṃ brahmeti /
analyzed: anena tu jñāyate na pūrva upadiṣyam brahma iti
translated: But this shows that the Brahman taught earlier is not the same.

original: yathā hi kaścitsuvarṇaṃ yācitavate rajataṃ dadāti so 'pi gṛhītvā'locya punaḥpunaḥ
analyzed: yathā hi kaścid suvarṇam yācitavate rajatam dadāti gṛhītvā ālocya punar punar
translated: Just as someone, when asked for gold, gives silver. He, having taken it, looks at it again and again,

analyzed: suvarṇam dehi iti yācate
translated: and asks for gold to be given.

original: tena pārśvastho jānāti prāgdattamanyadeva kiñcinna suvarṇamiti /
analyzed: tena pārśva sthaḥ jānāti prāk dattam anyat eva kiñcid na suvarṇam iti
translated: The one standing by knows that what was given earlier is something else, not gold.

analyzed: tathā iha api iti āśaṅkām pariharati yatas iti
translated: In the same way, here also, he removes the doubt with the words 'because' etc.

original: yato bhūtāni jāyanta ityādyairlakṣaṇaiḥ svayam // / / //🔽lakṣitaṃ guruṇā paścāt tapasaivāparokṣataḥ /
analyzed: yatas bhūtāni jāyante ityādyaiḥ lakṣaṇaiḥ svayam  lakṣitam guruṇā paścāt tapasā eva aparokṣataḥ
translated: Because the Self is characterized by 'from which the beings are born' etc. by the teacher himself,

analyzed: dṛṣṭvā ekaikam sva rūpam tu samasta ukta anudarśanam
translated: having seen each form separately, the vision of the totality is described.

analyzed: icchatā ājñām guroḥ prāpya tapasā eva ārokṣitam
translated: Desiring to obtain the teacher's knowledge, having seen it by austerity alone,

analyzed: abrahma iti eva vadatām śruta hāni a śruta grahau
translated: for those who say 'it is not Brahman', the abandoning of what is heard and the grasping of what is not heard,

analyzed: sākṣāt lakṣaṇa tām prāptau iti lajjā tad uktiṣu
translated: have directly attained the nature of a characteristic, therefore there is shame in their statements.

analyzed: ayam arthaḥ na punar upasaraṇa anyathā anupapattyā pūrva upadiṣyasya abrahmatvam kalpyam
translated: The meaning is: The non-Brahmanhood of what was taught earlier should not be imagined due to the impossibility of the repetition of approach.

analyzed: punar upasaraṇasya anyathā upapatteḥ
translated: Because the repetition of approach is otherwise possible.

analyzed: tathā hi
translated: This is how.

analyzed: varuṇaḥ hi uddeśa lakṣaṇābhyām bhṛgave brahma upadiśya uvāca
translated: Varuṇa, having taught Brahman to Bhṛgu by way of the topic and the characteristic, said:🔽Bhṛgu, having approached Varuṇa, asked about Brahman.

analyzed: na śravaṇa mātreṇa kṛtī bhavān
translated: You are not satisfied merely by hearing.

analyzed: śravaṇa mātrasya brahma sākṣātkāra asādhana tvāt
translated: Because mere hearing is not a means of realizing Brahman.

analyzed: sākṣātkārasya eva mokṣa sādhana tvāt
translated: Because only realization is the means of attaining liberation.

analyzed: atas tvayā manana nididhyāsana rūpam tapaḥ karaṇīyam iti
translated: Therefore, you should perform austerity in the form of reflection and meditation.

analyzed: sa ca evam upadiṣya āṣya rūpaḥ yugapad sarvasya sākṣātkartum aśakya tvāt manana nididhyāsābhyām anna ākhyam
translated: And he, being thus instructed, being unable to realize all at once, by reflection and meditation,🔽the form called food,

original: bhagavadrūpaṃ sākṣātkṛtya guruprasādalabdhamapūrvatamaṃ dhanaṃ tasmai nivedayituṃ
analyzed: bhagavat rūpam sākṣātkṛtya guru prasāda labdham apūrvatamam dhanam tasmai nivedayitum
translated: to offer as a gift the previously unseen wealth obtained through the grace of the guru,

analyzed: prāṇa ākhya rūpa antara sākṣātkārāya manana nididhyāsane cikīrṣuḥ guroḥ anujñām ādātum ca punar gurum upasasāra
translated: and to perform reflection and meditation for the realization of another form called prāṇa, and to obtain the permission of the guru, he approached the guru again.

analyzed: evam rūpa antare pi
translated: And so in other forms as well.

original: tatrānujānīhīti vaktavye yadadhīhi bhagavo brahmeti vadati tadahaṅkāranirāsārthamiti /
analyzed: tatra anujānīhi iti vaktavye yat adhīhi bhagavaḥ brahma iti vadati tat ahaṅkāra nirāsa artham iti
translated: There, when it should be said give permission, that he says teach me, revered one, Brahman is for the purpose of removing the sense of I.

analyzed: nanu evam astu arthāpattiḥ anyathā upapatti upakṣīṇā
translated: Well then, let it be so. Presumption is destroyed by the possibility of another explanation.

analyzed: tathā api kim pūvarsya abrahmatvāt punar upasaraṇam uta ukta rītyā anujñāna artham iti sandihyate
translated: Even so, it is doubted whether the approaching again is due to the previous Brahmanhood or for the sake of permission as explained.

analyzed: sandehe ca anna maya ādīnām na brahmatva avadhāraṇam sambhavati iti
translated: And if there were doubt, it would not be possible to ascertain that the Self consisting of food, etc. are Brahman.

analyzed: mā evam
translated: This is not so.

analyzed: yatas vai imāni bhūtāni jāyante ityādi lakṣara yogāt tapasā eva a parokṣita tva liṅgāt ca uttarapakṣa avadhāraṇa upapatteḥ
translated: Because of the compatibility of the words from which are born these beings and so on, and because of the indicative power of the statement that it is only by austerity that it is seen, the final conclusion is justified.

analyzed: nahi deha ādau idam lakṣaṇam sambhavati iti
translated: For this characteristic is not possible in the case of the body, etc.

analyzed: na ca tasya svabhāva siddha jñānasya sākṣātkārāya tapaḥ upekṣitam
translated: And for the knowledge which is naturally existent, austerity is not required for its realization.

original: kiñca pūrvasyābrahmatvena punarupasaraṇe sa tapastaptvānnaṃ brahmeti vyajānāt /
analyzed: kiñca pūrvasya a brahmatvena punar upasaraṇe sa tapaḥ taptvā annam brahma iti vyajānāt
translated: Moreover, if the previous one were not Brahman, he would again approach it, and having practiced austerity, he would understand that food is Brahman.

analyzed: na annāt hayā iva khalu ityādi brūyāt
translated: He would not say Verily, from food alone, etc.

original: evaṃ brahmatvajñāpakeṣu śruteṣvapyaśrutamabrahmatvaṃ kalpayatāṃ śrutahāniraśrutagrahāpattiśca syādityalaṃ nirdalapakṣapratikṣepe 'smākameva 🔽lajjā jāyata iti /
analyzed: evam brahmatva jñāpakeṣu śruteṣu api aśrutam abrahmatvam kalpayatām śruta hāniḥ aśruta graha āpattiḥ ca syāt iti alam nirdala pakṣa pratikṣepe smākam eva  lajjā jāyate iti
translated: Thus, even when there are scriptural statements indicating Brahmanhood, those who imagine non-Brahmanhood, which is not stated, would incur the fault of rejecting what is stated and accepting what is not stated. Therefore, we are content.🔽Only shame arises for us in refuting such a worthless position.

analyzed: akṣara arthaḥ tu sphuṭaḥ eva
translated: The meaning of the words is clear.

analyzed: sūtra akṣarāṇām anānuguṇyam tu bhagavatā na vyutpāditam
translated: But the non-compatibility of the words of the sutra has not been explained by the Lord.

analyzed: tasya pareṇa svayam eva aṅgīkṛta tvāt
translated: Because that has been accepted by the opponent himself.

analyzed: yaḥ hi svayam eva sva vyākhyānasya asvārasika tvam manyate
translated: For one who himself considers his own explanation to be unjustifiable,

original: taṃ prati tadvyutpādanaṃ mṛtamāraṇamiva nirākartureva lajjākaram /
analyzed: tam prati tat vyutpādanam mṛta māraṇam iva nirākartuḥ eva lajjā karam
translated: to teach that to him would be like killing a dead man, and would only bring shame upon the teacher himself.

analyzed: atas eva āha
translated: For this very reason he says:

original: iti prakāreṇa taduktiṣu viṣayabhūtāsu dūṣaṇābhidhāne 'smākameva lajjeti / /
analyzed: iti prakāreṇa tad uktiṣu viṣaya bhūtāsu dūṣaṇa abhidhāne smākam eva lajjā iti
translated: In this way, when the topics that are the basis for his statements are criticized, it is only we who are ashamed.

original: yacca bhedavyapadeśācceti sūtraṃ vyākhyāyoktaṃ pareṇa mithyābhūtaṃ jīvātmaparamātmabhedamāśritya bhedavyapadeśāccetyuktamiti tadanupapannamiti
analyzed: yat ca bheda vyapadeśāt ca iti sūtram vyākhyāya uktam pareṇa mithyā bhūtam jīvātma paramātma bhedam āśritya bheda vyapadeśāt ca iti uktam iti tat anupapannam iti
translated: And what was said by the opponent after explaining the aphorism because of the teaching of difference, that the difference between the individual soul and the supreme self, which is false, is relied upon, and that because of the teaching of difference is stated, that is not proper.

analyzed: bhāvena āha samīpe iti
translated: With this in mind, he says in the vicinity and so on.

analyzed: samīpe sahabhogasya mukti tvena uktitaḥ sakṛt
translated: Because enjoyment in the vicinity is repeatedly stated to be liberation,

analyzed: bhedaḥ jīva īśayoḥ mithyā iti eva mithyā svayam bhavet
translated: the difference between the individual soul and the Lord would itself be false if it were false.

analyzed: etam ānanda mayam ātmānam upasaṅkramya
translated: Having approached this bliss-filled Self.

analyzed: ityādau parameśvarasya samīpe
translated: In this and other passages, in the vicinity of the supreme Lord.

original: so 'śnute' / ityādau tena saha /🔽nahi sāmīpyaṃ sāhityaṃ ca bhedena vinopapadyate /
analyzed: saḥ u śnute ityādau tena saha  nahi sāmīpyam sāhityam ca bhedena vinā upapadyate
translated: He enjoys. In this and other passages, together with Him.🔽For proximity and togetherness are not possible without difference.

original: naca mokṣe 'pi śiṣyamāṇaṃ mithyā bhavituṃ yuktam /
analyzed: na ca mokṣe śiṣyamāṇam mithyā bhavitum yuktam
translated: And what is taught even in liberation cannot reasonably be false.
Because it would lead to the falsity of the nature of the self itself.

original: athavā bhedavyapadeśādityukte mithyābhedo 'yaṃ kiṃ na syādityākāṅkṣānirāsārthatvenāsminnasya ca tadyogaṃ śāstīti sūtraṃ prakārāntareṇa vyākhyāti
analyzed: athavā bheda vyapadeśāt iti ukte mithyā bhedaḥ yam kim na syāt iti ākāṅkṣā nirāsa artha tvena asmin asya ca tad yogam śāsti iti sūtram prakāra antareṇa vyākhyāti
translated: Or, when it is said because of the designation of difference, the doubt may arise why should not this be a false difference? To remove this doubt, the sutra this is declared to be connected with that is explained in a different way.

analyzed: etena mayaṭaḥ ca eva dvaividhyena artha kalpanāt
translated: By this, and by the assumption of two meanings of the suffix maya,

analyzed: tat anyeṣām matam api sat saṃsatsu na bhāsate
translated: the opinion of others also does not shine in the assemblies of the wise.

original: evaṃ pañcakośavādināṃ māyāvādināṃ vyākhyāṃ nirākṛtya ye tu bhāskarādayo yathāśrutasūtrānusāriṇo 'nnamayādayaścatvāraḥ kośā ānandamayastveka
analyzed: evam pañcakośa vādinām māyā vādinām vyākhyām nirākṛtya ye tu bhāskara ādayaḥ yathāśruta sūtra anusāriṇaḥ nna maya ādayaḥ catvāraḥ kośāḥ ānanda mayaḥ tu eka
translated: Having thus refuted the explanation of the Maya-vadins who accept five sheaths, those who follow the sutra as literally as possible, such as Bhaskara, explain that the four sheaths beginning with food, and the sheath of bliss,

analyzed: eva paramātmā iti vyācakṣate
translated: are the supreme Self.

analyzed: tad matam atideśena nirākaroti etena iti
translated: He refutes their opinion by extension, saying by this.

original: etenaivānnamayādīnāṃ pañcānāmapi brahmatvopapādanena tadanyeṣāṃ pañcakośatvavādibhyo 'nyeṣāṃ catuṣkośavādinām /
analyzed: etena eva anna maya ādīnām pañcānām api brahmatva upapādanena tad anyeṣām pañcakośa tva vādibhyaḥ nyeṣām catuṣkośa vādinām
translated: By this very establishment of the Brahmanhood of all five, beginning with the sheath of food, the opinions of others who accept five sheaths, and of those who accept four sheaths,

analyzed: sat saṃsatsu vidvat sabhāsu
translated: in the assemblies of the wise.

analyzed: adhikam ca atra doṣam āha mayaṭaḥ dvaividhyena artha kalpanāt ca iti
translated: And he states an additional fault here, saying and by the assumption of two meanings of the suffix maya.

original: annamayādiṣu vikārārthatvamānandamaye prācuryārthatvamiti yadatra niyāmakamuktaṃ tatprāgeva nirākṛtamiti /
analyzed: annamaya ādiṣu vikāra artha tvam ānanda maye prācurya artha tvam iti yat atra niyāmakam uktam tat prāk eva nirākṛtam iti
translated: The restriction here that in the case of the 'food-made' etc. it means modification, while in the case of the 'bliss-made' it means abundance, has already been refuted earlier.

analyzed: nanu prāṇa maye eva vikāra prakramaḥ bhagnaḥ
translated: But in the 'life-made' itself, the sequence of modification is broken.

analyzed: tatra tarhi
translated: Then in that case,

analyzed: pratyayasya svāthirka tva kalpanāt adhikaḥ doṣaḥ syāt iti
translated: there would be a fault greater than the assumption of the subjective nature of the cognition.

analyzed: nanu sūtra vyākhyānam upakramya para apavyākhyā nirākaraṇam asaṅgatam iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that, having begun the explanation of the sutra, the refutation of the wrong explanations of others is irrelevant, it is not so.

original: svavyākhyānadarḍhyārthatvāditi bhāvenādhikaraṇārthamupasaṃharati ata iti //🔽ato nārāyaṇo devo niḥśeṣaguṇavācakaiḥ /
analyzed: sva vyākhyāna darḍhyā artha tvāt iti bhāvena adhikaraṇa artham upasaṃharati atas iti  atas nārāyaṇaḥ devaḥ niḥśeṣa guṇa vācakaiḥ
translated: With the intention that it is for the sake of strengthening one's own explanation, he concludes the meaning of the section with the word 'ataḥ' (therefore).

analyzed: guṇi sāmānya vacanaiḥ api mukhya tayā uditaḥ  adhyātma gaiḥ ca prāṇa ādyaiḥ tathā eva hi adhibhūta gaiḥ
translated: Therefore, the god Nārāyaṇa is declared as the primary meaning even by words denoting the general class of possessors and words expressing all good qualities.

analyzed: anna ādi śabdaiḥ bhagavān ekaḥ mukhya tayā uditaḥ
translated: And the one Lord is declared as the primary meaning even by words denoting the life-breaths etc. related to the individual soul and by words denoting food etc. related to the elements.

original: guṇisāmānyavācināṃ guṇavācināṃ ca śabdānāṃ samanvayāya pravṛtte 'pyadhikaraṇe 'dhikaraṇasiddhāntanyāyena siddhamapyarthāntaramupasaṃharati
analyzed: guṇi sāmānya vācinām guṇa vācinām ca śabdānām samanvayāya pravṛtte pi adhikaraṇe dhikaraṇa siddhānta nyāyena siddham api artha antaram upasaṃharati  /
translated: Even though the section has been started for the purpose of establishing the relation of words denoting the general class of possessors and words denoting good qualities, he concludes the secondary meaning also by the principle of the conclusion of the section.

analyzed: adhyātma gaiḥ ca iti
translated: And by those pertaining to the self.

analyzed: atas eva na adhikaraṇa upakrama virodhaḥ iti
translated: For this very reason, there is no contradiction with the beginning of the section.

analyzed: samastaiḥ guṇi sāmānya vācakaiḥ guṇa vācakaiḥ adhyātma viṣayaiḥ ca
translated: The Blessed One is indeed primarily referred to by all words denoting the general qualities of the possessor of qualities, by words denoting qualities, by those pertaining to the self,

analyzed: prāṇa vāc ādibhiḥ adhibhūta viṣayaiḥ ca anna auṣadhī ādibhiḥ śabdaiḥ bhagavān eva mukhya tayā uditaḥ iti upasaṃhāraḥ na upapadyate
translated: by Prana, speech, etc., and by those pertaining to the elements, by words like food, medicine, etc. The conclusion is not appropriate.

analyzed: asya arthasya prāk anukta tvāt
translated: Because this meaning has not been stated before.

analyzed: nanu uktam upalakṣaṇa paraḥ yam ānanda maya śabdaḥ iti
translated: But has it not been said that this word full of bliss is intended to illustrate?

analyzed: satyam
translated: True.

analyzed: upalakṣaṇam hi prakṛta upayuktasya upapanyasya ca arthasya bhavati
translated: For an illustration is of a meaning that is relevant to the context and is being introduced.

analyzed: anyathā atiprasaṅgāt
translated: Otherwise, there would be an absurd consequence.

original: nacaiteṣāṃ sarvaśabdānāṃ mukhyayā vṛttyā bhagavadekavācitvasamarthanaṃ prakṛtopayuktaṃ nāpyupapannam /
analyzed: na ca eteṣām sarva śabdānām mukhyayā vṛttyā bhagavat eka vāci tva samarthanam prakṛta upayuktam na api upapannam
translated: And the establishment that all these words primarily denote only the Blessed One is not relevant to the context nor is it appropriate.

analyzed: tathā hi
translated: To explain:

original: janmādyasya yata iti sūtre jagajjanmādikāraṇatvādīnyaṣṭau lakṣaṇāni brahmaṇo 'bhihitāni /
analyzed: janma ādyasya yatas iti sūtre jagat janma ādi kāraṇa tva ādīni aṣṭau lakṣaṇāni brahmaṇaḥ bhihitāni
translated: In the sutra From which the birth, etc. eight characteristics of Brahman are stated, such as being the cause of the creation, etc. of the world.

analyzed: tatra eva śāstram pramāṇam uktam tṛtīya sūtre
translated: In that very sutra, the sacred teaching is stated to be the means of valid knowledge in the third sutra.

original: samanvayasūtre ca teṣāmeva vākyānāṃ brahmaṇi samanvayaḥ pratijñātaḥ /
analyzed: samanvaya sūtre ca teṣām eva vākyānām brahmaṇi samanvayaḥ pratijñātaḥ
translated: And in the Sūtra on the Connection, the connection of those very passages with Brahman is declared.

original: ato jagajjanmādikāraṇatvaṃ yatrayatra pratīyate teṣāmeva vākyānāṃ parameśvare samanvayasamatharnaṃ prakṛtasaṅgatam /
analyzed: atas jagat janma ādi kāraṇatvam yatra yatra pratīyate teṣām eva vākyānām parameśvare prakṛta saṅgatam
translated: Therefore, the establishment of the connection of those very passages with the Supreme Lord, where the cause of the creation etc. of the world is understood, is relevant to the subject matter.

analyzed: na sarveṣām
translated: Not of all [passages].

analyzed: sarvatra jagat janma ādi kāraṇatva pratipādana abhāvāt
translated: Because the teaching of the cause of the creation etc. of the world is not found everywhere.

original: kiñca yanniṣṭhatayā jagajjanmādikāraṇatvaṃ pratīyate tadvācinaḥ śabdasya yayā kayācana vṛttyā bhagavatparatve samarthite 'pi lakṣaṇasyātivyāptiḥ 🔽patihriyata eva /
analyzed: kiñca yad niṣṭhatayā jagat janma ādi kāraṇatvam pratīyate tad vācinaḥ śabdasya yayā kayācana vṛttyā bhagavat paratve samarthite pi lakṣaṇasya ativyāptiḥ  patihriyate eva
translated: Moreover, even when the word denoting that in which the cause of the creation etc. of the world is understood is established as referring to the Lord by some or other relation, the superimposition [of the word on the Lord] is removed.

original: nahi gaṅgāpadalakṣyasya tīrasya ghoṣāvāsatvaṃ na siddhayati /
analyzed: nahi gaṅgā pada lakṣyasya tīrasya ghoṣa āvāsa tvam na
translated: For the fact that the bank, which is denoted by the word 'Gaṅgā', is not a place where cows low, is not established.

analyzed: atas mukhya vṛtti samarthanasya kva upayogaḥ
translated: So where is the use of establishing the primary relation [of the word with the Lord]?

analyzed: na upapadyate ca sarva śabdānām bhagavati eva mukhya vṛtti samarthanam
translated: And it is not possible to establish the primary relation of all words with the Lord.

analyzed: rūḍhi yogau hi mukhya vṛttī
translated: For the primary relation is either conventional or figurative.

analyzed: tatra api yogāt rūḍhiḥ balavatī
translated: And even there, figurative meaning is stronger than conventional meaning.

analyzed: na ca śabdānām bhagavati rūḍhiḥ asti
translated: And there is no figurative meaning of words with regard to the Lord.

analyzed: kintu tad itaratra eva
translated: But only with regard to something else than Him.

analyzed: yogaḥ tu sambhavati
translated: But yoga is possible.

analyzed: tathā api sa tad itara samānaḥ
translated: Even so, it is the same as that other [yoga].

analyzed: tathā ca artha antare eva mukhya vṛttayaḥ śabdāḥ
translated: And thus, the primary usages of words are indeed in other meanings.

analyzed: rūḍheḥ yogasya ca sattvāt
translated: Because both convention and yoga exist.

analyzed: na īśvare
translated: Not in the Lord.

analyzed: yoga mātrasya kathañcid sambhavāt
translated: Because yoga alone is somehow possible.

original: ataḥ sūtrakārasya sakalaśabdānāṃ mukhyayā vṛttyā bhagavatyeva samanvayasamarthane saṅgatyupapattyorabhāvādapavyākhyānametadityāśaṅkaya saṅgatiṃ
analyzed: atas sūtrakārasya sakala śabdānām mukhyayā vṛttyā bhagavati eva samanvaya samarthane saṅgati upapattyoḥ abhāvāt apavyākhyānam etat iti āśaṅkaya saṅgatim
translated: Therefore, this is a misinterpretation, because there is no coherence or possibility in the author of the aphorisms' demonstration of the complete compatibility of all words only with the Lord by their primary usage.🔽Fearing this, he shows the coherence

analyzed: tāvat darśayati janma ādi iti
translated: first with birth, etc.

analyzed: janma ādyasya iti sūtreṇa guṇa sarva sva siddhaye
translated: By the aphorism The birth, etc. for the sake of establishing the totality of qualities,

analyzed: brahmaṇaḥ lakṣaṇam proktam
translated: the definition of Brahman is stated.

original: athāto brahmajijñāseti prathamasūtre brahmaśabdena jijñāsyasya sakalaguṇapūrṇatvaṃ jīvādivyāvṛttyarthamupāttam /
analyzed: atha atas brahma jijñāsā iti prathama sūtre brahma śabdena jijñāsyasya sakala guṇa pūrṇa tvam jīva ādi vyāvṛtti artham upāttam
translated: After that, the inquiry into Brahman - in the first aphorism, by the word Brahman, the completeness of all qualities of what is to be inquired into is stated for the purpose of excluding the individual soul and others.

original: janmādyasya yata iti dvitīyasūtreṇa tatsiddhaye jagajjanmādikāraṇatvaṃ brahmaṇo lakṣaṇaṃ proktam /
analyzed: janma ādyasya yatas iti dvitīya sūtreṇa tad siddhaye jagat janma ādi kāraṇa tvam brahmaṇaḥ lakṣaṇam proktam
translated: By the second aphorism From which the birth, etc., for the sake of establishing that, the cause of the birth, etc. of the world is stated as the definition of Brahman.

original: ataḥ sūtradvayena sādhyatayā sādhakatayā cānandādisakalaguṇapūrṇatvaṃ jagajjanmādikāraṇatvaṃ ca prakṛtamiti /
analyzed: atas sūtra dvayena sādhyatayā sādhaka tayā ca ānanda ādi sakala guṇa pūrṇa tvam jagat janma ādi kāraṇatvam ca prakṛtam iti
translated: Therefore, by the two sutras, the perfection of all qualities such as bliss and the being the cause of the creation etc. of the world are being established as the probandum and as the probans respectively.

analyzed: vivṛtam ca etat pūrvam asmābhiḥ  kim atas yadi evam iti atas āha śāstra mūlam iti
translated: And this has been explained by us before.🔽What follows from this if it is so? To this he says the scripture is the basis etc.

analyzed: śāstra mūlam yatas tatas
translated: Since the scripture is the basis, therefore...

original: tadubhayaṃ pradhānamapradhānaṃ ca lakṣaṇamanumānādinātivyāptau śaṅkitāyāṃ tannivṛttyarthaṃ
analyzed: tat ubhayam pradhānam apradhānam ca lakṣaṇam anumāna ādinā ativyāptau śaṅkitāyām tad nivṛtti artham
translated: When both of those characteristics are suspected of over-extension by inference etc., in order to remove that,

original: tṛtīyasūtre śāstramūlaṃ śāstraikapramāṇamuktaṃ yatastataścaturthe sūtre śāstrasyānyaparatvaśaṅkāyāṃ
analyzed: tṛtīya sūtre śāstra mūlam śāstra eka pramāṇam uktam yatas tatas caturthe sūtre śāstrasya anya para tva śaṅkāyām
translated: in the third sutra, the scripture is said to be the basis, having only the scripture as the means of knowledge. Since that is so, in the fourth sutra, when there is a doubt that the scripture has another purport,

original: sarvaśabdānāṃ bhagavatyanvayaḥ pratijñātumucito na katipayaśabdānāmiti śeṣaḥ /
analyzed: sarva śabdānām bhagavati anvayaḥ pratijñātum ucitaḥ na katipaya śabdānām iti śeṣaḥ
translated: it is proper to affirm the inclusion of all words in the Lord, not of a few words. This is the remainder.

original: sarvaguṇapūrṇatve śāstrasya pramāṇatayābhidhāne 'pi kutaḥ sarvaśabdasamanvayaḥ pratijñātavya ityata āha anvaya iti //
analyzed: sarva guṇa pūrṇa tve śāstrasya pramāṇa tayā abhidhāne kutas sarva śabda samanvayaḥ pratijñātavyaḥ iti atas āha anvayaḥ iti
translated: Even though the perfection of all qualities is affirmed as the means of knowledge of the scripture, why is the inclusion of all words to be affirmed? To this he says the inclusion etc.

analyzed: anvayaḥ sarva śabdānām guṇa sarva sva vedakaḥ
translated: The inclusion of all words reveals the totality of qualities.🔽...

original: yataḥ sarvaśabdānāmanvaya eva guṇasarvasvavedako na katipayaśabdānām /
analyzed: yatas sarva śabdānām anvayaḥ eva guṇa sarva sva vedakaḥ na katipaya śabdānām
translated: Because the connection of all words reveals the totality of qualities, not just a few words.

original: ataḥ sarvaśāstrād guṇasarvasvasiddhaye sa eva pratijñātavya iti sambandhaḥ /
analyzed: atas sarva śāstrāt guṇa sarva sva siddhaye saḥ eva pratijñātavyaḥ iti sambandhaḥ
translated: Therefore, the connection is that he alone should be asserted for the purpose of establishing the totality of qualities from all scriptures.

original: anyathā yasyaiva śabdasya samanvayo na pratijñāyate tadartho guṇo bhagavati na siddhayedativyāptiśca syāt /
analyzed: anyathā yasya eva śabdasya samanvayaḥ na pratijñāyate tad arthaḥ guṇaḥ bhagavati na siddhayet ativyāptiḥ ca syāt
translated: Otherwise, if the connection of a particular word is not asserted, the quality of its meaning would not be established in the Lord, and there would be over-extension.

original: pratijñāte ca samanvayasūtreṇa sakalaśabdasamanvaye tatprapañcanaṃ sūtrakārasya kathamasaṅgataṃ bhavatīti /
analyzed: pratijñāte ca samanvaya sūtreṇa sakala śabda samanvaye tad prapañcanam sūtrakārasya katham asaṅga tam bhavati iti
translated: And when the connection of all words is asserted by the Sūtra on Connection, how can it be irrelevant for the author of the Sūtras to elaborate on that?

analyzed: etena mukhya vṛttiḥ api saṅga tā draṣṭavyā
translated: By this, the primary usage should also be seen as connected.

analyzed: tasyāḥ api samanvaya sūtre pratijñātavya tvāt
translated: Because that too should be asserted in the Sūtra on Connection.

analyzed: amukhya vṛttau tad abhidheya guṇa alābha prasaṅgāt
translated: Because if it were not the primary usage, the qualities denoted by it would not be obtained,

analyzed: abhidheye tivyāpti prasaṅgāt ca iti
translated: and there would be the logical fault of over-extension in the denoted meaning.

original: evamasaṅgatiṃ parihṛtya yaduktaṃ pareṇa na parameśvarasyaiva sarvaśabdamukhyārthatvaṃ yuktam /
analyzed: evam asaṅgatim parihṛtya yat uktam pareṇa na parameśvarasya eva sarva śabda mukhya artha tvam yuktam
translated: Having thus refuted the irrelevance, it is said by the opponent that it is not proper that the Supreme Lord alone is the primary meaning of all words.

analyzed: yogasya parameśvaraḥ iva anyatra api sambhavāt
translated: Because yoga is possible in other things also, like the Supreme Lord.

analyzed: īśvare rūḍheḥ abhāvena anyatra tad ādhikyāt iti
translated: Because there is no adherence to God, and because of the superiority of other deities.

analyzed: tatra yogasya ubhayatra sāmyam tāvat nirākaroti śabda iti
translated: There, he first refutes the equality of Yoga in both cases, with the word sound.

analyzed: śabda pravṛtti hetūnām tasmin mukhya samanvayāt
translated: Because the causes of the application of words are primarily connected with Him.

analyzed: indra ādi śabda pravṛtti hetūnām parama aiśvarya ādīnām tasmin parameśvare mukhya sambandhāt indra ādi śabdānām tad vācaka tvam eva
translated: Because the causes of the application of words like Indra and so on, such as supreme lordship and so on, are primarily related to that Supreme Lord, the words Indra and so on denote Him alone.

analyzed: tasya eva hi parama aiśvaryam anavadhikam svatantram ca
translated: For only He has unlimited and independent supreme lordship.

original: anyatrāpi tathā cetko viśeṣa iti tatroktam anyārtheṣviti //
analyzed: anyatra api tathā ced kaḥ viśeṣaḥ iti tatra uktam anya artheṣu iti
translated: If it is so in other cases as well, what is the difference? In that case, it is said: In other meanings and so on.

analyzed: anya artheṣu alpa tā hetoḥ tad nimitta tvataḥ tathā
translated: In other meanings, due to the cause of smallness, it is the cause of that, and so it is.

analyzed: tad vācaka tvam śabdānām
translated: The denotation of words is...

analyzed: yatas purandara ādiṣu hetoḥ śabda pravṛtti hetoḥ aiśvarya ādeḥ alpa tā
translated: Because in other meanings, in Purandara and so on, the cause of the application of words, such as lordship and so on, is small.

analyzed: deśataḥ kālataḥ svarūpataḥ ca sa avadhika tvāt
translated: Because it is limited in space, time, and form.

analyzed: alpasya api bhagavat nimitta tvāt ca iti
translated: And because even the small is the cause of the Lord.

analyzed: etat uktam bhavati
translated: This is what is said.

analyzed: avayava artham anusṛtya vṛttiḥ hi yogaḥ
translated: For Yoga is the application that follows the meaning of the parts.

original: avayavārthaśca yathā yathotkṛṣṭate tathātathā yogavṛtterapyutkarṣeṇa bhāvyam /
analyzed: avayava arthaḥ ca yathā yathā utkṛṣṭate tathā tathā yoga vṛtteḥ api utkarṣeṇa bhāvyam
translated: And the meaning of the parts should be as excellent as it is, so also the excellence of the function of yoga should be expected by the excellence of that.

analyzed: nimitta vaicitṛye naimittika avaicitṛyasya anupapatteḥ
translated: Because the diversity of the effect is not possible without the diversity of the cause.

analyzed: avayava arthaḥ ca parameśvare na vadhikaḥ svatantraḥ ca
translated: And the meaning of the parts is unlimited and independent in the Supreme Lord.

analyzed: artha antare lpaḥ para adhīnaḥ ca
translated: In other meanings, it is limited and dependent on others.

analyzed: atas katham yogasya ubhayatra sāmyam
translated: Therefore, how can yoga be the same in both cases?

original: kintvīśvare mahāyogo 'nyatra yogamātramiti sa eva śabdamukhyārtha iti /🔽yaduktamīśvare śabdānāṃ rūḍhirnāstīti tannirākaroti bahuleti //
analyzed: kintu īśvare mahā yogaḥ nyatra yoga mātram iti saḥ eva śabda mukhya arthaḥ iti  yat uktam īśvare śabdānām rūḍhiḥ na asti iti tat nirākaroti bahulā iti
translated: But in the Lord, there is great yoga, and in others, mere yoga. Thus, He alone is the primary meaning of the word.🔽What was said, that there is no conventional usage of words in the Lord, he refutes with bahula etc.

analyzed: bahula atiprayogataḥ
translated: Due to the usage of many words,

analyzed: rūḍham iti eva sādhyam syāt
translated: it would be established that there is conventional usage.

original: bahulātiprayogato hetoḥ śabdajātaṃ harau rūḍhameveti sādhyaṃ syāt /
analyzed: bahula atiprayogataḥ hetoḥ śabda jātam harau rūḍham evā iti sādhyam syāt
translated: Due to the reason of the usage of many words, it would be established that the class of words has conventional usage in Hari alone.

analyzed: ayam prayogaḥ
translated: This is the argument.

analyzed: vimatāḥ śabdāḥ harau rūḍhāḥ
translated: The words in question have conventional usage in Hari.

analyzed: bahula atiprayogavat tvāt
translated: Because they are used many times.

analyzed: nārāyaṇa ādi śabda vat iti
translated: Like the words Nārāyaṇa etc.

analyzed: prayogavat tvam ca yaugikeṣu amukhyeṣu ca asti iti atas bahulā iti uktam
translated: And usage exists in etymological and secondary meanings. Therefore, bahula is said.

analyzed: ajñāta mukhyeṣu amukhyeṣu api sti iti atas ti prayogataḥ iti uktam
translated: In the case of unknown primary meanings and non-primary meanings, there is also abundant usage, hence it is said 'due to excessive usage'.

analyzed: pūjya prayogaḥ hi atiprayogaḥ
translated: For excessive usage is usage with respect to what is venerable.

analyzed: pūjya tā ca aviveka pūrvaka tva abhāvaḥ
translated: And venerability is the absence of being preceded by non-discrimination.

analyzed: na ca rūḍha yoge rūḍha upacāre rūḍha lakṣaṇāyām vyabhicāraḥ
translated: And there is no deviation in the case of conventional usage, conventional reference, or conventional indication.

analyzed: tatra api rūḍhi sadbhāvena sapakṣa tvāt
translated: Because even there, due to the presence of convention, it is a similar instance.

analyzed: samāhāra vṛttayaḥ hi tāḥ
translated: For they occur in a combination.

analyzed: nanu asiddhaḥ yam hetuḥ
translated: But this reason is unestablished,

analyzed: indra ādi śabdānām parameśvare prayogasya eva abhāvāt iti atas āha rūḍhiḥ iti
translated: because there is no usage at all of words like Indra for the Supreme Lord. To this he says 'convention'.

analyzed: rūḍhiḥ hi dvividhā matā
translated: For convention is considered twofold,

analyzed: a vidvat vidvat āptyā eva
translated: by the attainment of the ignorant and the learned.

analyzed: atra rūḍhiḥ iti rūḍhi jñāpakaḥ bahula atiprayogaḥ lakṣyate
translated: Here, 'convention' indicates the conventional usage that is abundant and excessive.

analyzed: āptiḥ sambandhaḥ
translated: 'Attainment' is connection.

analyzed: tatra avidvas sambandhinaḥ bahula atiprayogasya abhāve vidvas sambandhine bhāvāt na asiddhiḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The meaning is that even though the abundant and excessive usage connected with the ignorant is absent, it is not unestablished because of the presence of that connected with the learned.

analyzed: astu evam īśvare pi
translated: Let it be so, even with respect to God,

analyzed: rūḍhiḥ śabdānām
translated: there is convention of words.

analyzed: tathā api loke tad bhāvāt sāmyam eva
translated: Even so, there is equality because of its existence in the world too.

original: tataśca harireva mukhyavācya iti nopapadyata ityata āha mukhyeti // /🔽mukhyā hi viduṣāṃ tu sā // / / //
analyzed: tatas ca hariḥ eva mukhya vācyaḥ iti na upapadyate iti atas āha mukhya iti  mukhyā hi viduṣām tu sā
translated: And therefore it is not proper that Hari alone is the primary denoted. To this he says 'muhkyêti'.

original: viduṣāṃ bahulātiprayogānumitā sā rūḍhirmukhyā hi yasmāttasmānna sāmyamiti śeṣaḥ /
analyzed: viduṣām bahula atiprayoga anumitā sā rūḍhiḥ mukhyā hi yasmāt tasmāt na sāmyam iti śeṣaḥ
translated: For that conventional usage inferred from the abundant usage of the learned is indeed primary. Therefore, the remainder is: there is no equality.

analyzed: katham mukhya tvam iti atas āha vidvas iti
translated: How is it primary? To this he says 'vidvadêti'.

analyzed: vidvat rūḍhiḥ vaidikā syāt sā yogāt eva labhyate
translated: That conventional usage of the learned should be Vedic, it is obtained only from yoga.

analyzed: vaidika bahula prayoga anumitā hi vidvat rūḍhiḥ iti ucyate
translated: For it is said that the conventional usage of the learned is inferred from the abundant usage in the Vedas.

analyzed: sā ca laukika mātra prayoga anumitāyāḥ mukhyā iti sphuṭam eva iti
translated: And that is clearly primary compared to that inferred from mere worldly usage.

analyzed: nanu vaidikā iti katham
translated: But how is it Vedic?

analyzed: ityādinā ṅīpā bhavitavyam
translated: By the rule 'ṭiḍḍhāṇañ' etc., it should be in the feminine form.

analyzed: mā evam
translated: Not so.

analyzed: parama vaidika tva khyāpana artha tvāt
translated: Because it is for the purpose of proclaiming the highest Vedic nature.

original: athavā vaidikāḥ prayogā asyāṃ santi jñāpakā itiarśādibhyo 'c' /
analyzed: athavā vaidikāḥ prayogāḥ asyām santi jñāpakāḥ iti arśa ādibhyaḥ c
translated: Or, the Vedic usages are found in it as indicators.🔽By adding the nominal affix 'ac' as per the rule 'arṣādi-bhyo 'ac'

analyzed: iti a ci kṛte vaidika iti bhavati
translated: when added, it becomes 'Vedic'.

analyzed: yat vā vaidikānām puruṣāṇām āsyāt iti tad prayogāt siddhā iti
translated: Or, it is established by the usage of the Vedic people in it.

analyzed: hetu antaram āha sā iti
translated: He states another reason with 'sa'.

analyzed: lyap lopa nimittā pañcamī
translated: The fifth case is due to the elision of the nominal affix.

analyzed: yatas sā vidvat rūḍhiḥ yogam a vihāya evā upalabhyate
translated: Because that usage of the learned is found even without yoga,

analyzed: na tu avidvas rūḍhi vat saṅketa tulyā atas sā mukhyā iti
translated: but not like the usage of the ignorant, nor like convention, it is primary.

analyzed: tatas kim iti atas āha tasmāt iti
translated: What then? Therefore, it is said.

analyzed: tasmāt mukhya artha tā viṣṇoḥ
translated: Therefore, the primary meaning is of Vishnu.

original: yasmādevaṃ viṣṇau mahāyogo mukhyā ca rūḍhiḥ /
analyzed: yasmāt evam viṣṇau mahā yogaḥ mukhyā ca rūḍhiḥ
translated: Because the great yoga and primary usage are thus in Vishnu,

analyzed: anyatra yoga mātram amukhya rūḍhiḥ ca tasmāt sarva śabda mukhya artha tā viṣṇoḥ upapannā iti
translated: and elsewhere there is only yoga and secondary usage, therefore it is proper that all words have Vishnu as their primary meaning.

analyzed: upasaṃharati iti kṛtvā iti
translated: He concludes with thus.

analyzed: kṛtvā hṛdi prabhuḥ
translated: Having placed in the heart, the Lord...

analyzed: samanvayam sādhayati
translated: ...establishes the connection.

original: etāṃ saṅgatimetāṃ copapattiṃ hṛdi kṛtvā sūtrakṛdānandamayo 'bhyāsādityaśeṣaguṇisāmānyavācakādiśabdānāṃ mukhyayā vṛttyā harau samanvayaṃ sādhayati
analyzed: etām saṅgatim etām ca upapattim hṛdi kṛtvā sūtrakṛt ānanda mayaḥ bhyāsāt iti aśeṣa guṇi sāmānya vācaka ādi śabdānām mukhyayā vṛttyā harau samanvayam sādhayati
translated: Having placed in the heart this connection and this reason, the author of the aphorisms establishes the connection of all words such as full of bliss, which denote the general qualities, primarily in Hari, by the repetition of full of bliss.

analyzed: atas yuktam eva etat vayākhyānam iti
translated: Therefore, this explanation is proper.

analyzed: iti śrīmat nyāyasudhāyām ānanda maya adhikaṇam
translated: Thus ends the section on full of bliss in the auspicious Naya-sudha.
Chapter on Being Within

analyzed: atha antaḥsthatva adhikaraṇam
translated: Now, the section on Being Within

analyzed: om antar tad dharma upadeśāt om
translated: Om. He is within, because of the teaching of His attributes.

analyzed: antar tad dharma upadeśāt
translated: The inner (Self) is indicated by the teaching of its attributes.

analyzed: syāt etat
translated: This may be said:

original: yadyānandamayo 'bhyāsāditi vadataḥ sūtrakārasyaitāvānartho 'bhimato bhavettarhi tata eva gatārthatvādantastaddharmopadeśādityādyadhikaraṇānāmanutthānameva 🔽syāt /
analyzed: yadi ānanda mayaḥ bhyāsāt iti vadataḥ sūtrakārasya etāvān arthaḥ bhimataḥ bhavet tarhi tatas eva gatārtha tvāt antar tad dharma upadeśāt ityādi adhikaraṇānām anutthānam eva  syāt
translated: If this much were the intended meaning of the aphorism of the author, who says the Self consisting of bliss is the object of meditation because of repetition, then the very fact that it has been stated would make the raising of the topics beginning with the inner (Self) is indicated by the teaching of its attributes unnecessary.

analyzed: padārtha antara viṣayau hi rūḍhi yogau āśritya eva tatra pūrvapakṣa pravṛttiḥ
translated: For the discussion in those (topics) is based on the assumption of the primary meaning and the secondary meaning as having different objects.

analyzed: yathā uktam bhāṣye
translated: As it has been said in the Bhāṣya (commentary).

analyzed: tatra anya viṣayāyāḥ rūḍheḥ avidvat rūḍhi tvena bhagavat viṣayāyāḥ vidvat rūḍhitaḥ
translated: There, the primary meaning having a different object is weaker than the primary meaning of the ignorant, and the secondary meaning having the Lord as its object is weaker than the primary meaning of the learned.

analyzed: yogasya ca alpa bhagavat adhīna pravṛtti nimitta sāpekṣasya niravadhika aparatantra pravṛtti nimitta apekṣāt mahāyogāt upapāditam eva durbala tvam iti kutas dhikaraṇa antarasya avakāśaḥ
translated: And the secondary meaning, which depends on a limited cause of application dependent on the Lord, is established as weaker than the great secondary meaning, which depends on a cause of application that is unlimited and independent. So where is there room for another topic?

analyzed: satyam 🔽tathā api abhyadhika āśaṅkā sadbhāvena adhikaraṇa antara ārambha upapattiḥ iti āśayavān stāvat adhika āśaṅkā pravartana pūrvakam antar tad dharma upadeśāt ityādi adhikaraṇa tātparyam
translated: True.🔽Nevertheless, the idea being that the beginning of another topic is justified by the presence of a greater doubt, he (Śrī Śaṅkara) first raises the greater doubt and then states the purport of the topics beginning with the inner (Self) is indicated by the teaching of its attributes.

analyzed: darśayati devānām iti
translated: He shows that it is the gods.

analyzed: om antar tad dharma upadeśāt om
translated: Om. It is within, because of the teaching of its attributes. Om.

analyzed: devānām tatra
translated: The capability of the gods there,

analyzed: āśaṅkaya
translated: Suspecting...

analyzed: taittirīyāḥ paṭhanti
translated: The Taittiriyas recite:

analyzed: antaḥpraviṣyam kartāram etam antar candramasi manasā carantam
translated: Him who has entered within, the maker, moving with the mind within the moon,

original: sahaiva santaṃ na vijānanti devā iti /
analyzed: saha eva santam na vijānanti devāḥ iti
translated: The gods do not know him who is present with them.

analyzed: tatra saṃśayaḥ
translated: There is doubt about this.

analyzed: kim ayam antar praviṣyaḥ paramātmā uta anyaḥ iti
translated: Is this one who has entered within the supreme self or another?

analyzed: anyaḥ iti tāvat prāptam
translated: First it is obtained that he is another.

analyzed: kutas
translated: Why?

analyzed: indraḥ rājā jagataḥ yaḥ īśe
translated: He who is the king and lord of the world,

original: tvaṣṭāraṃ rūpāṇi vikurvantaṃ vipaścitaṃ brahmendramagniṃ jagataḥ pratiṣṭhām /
analyzed: tvaṣṭāram rūpāṇi vikurvantam vipaścitam brahma indram agnim jagataḥ pratiṣṭhām
translated: Tvastr who transforms forms, the wise one, Brahman, Indra, Agni, the support of the world,

analyzed: divaḥ ātmānam savitāram bṛhaspatim iti indra ādi śruteḥ
translated: The self in heaven, Savita, Brihaspati, because of the mention of Indra and others.

analyzed: sapta yuñjanti ratham eka cakram iti aditya liṅgāt ca
translated: Seven yoke the chariot with one wheel, and because of the indication of Aditya.

original: annaṃ brahmetyādiśrutyā taddhetuvyapadeśādiliṅgena cātītādhikaraṇena nirṇayaḥ kṛtaḥ /
analyzed: annam brahma ityādi śrutyā tad hetu vyapadeśa ādi liṅgena ca atīta adhikaraṇena nirṇayaḥ kṛtaḥ
translated: And the decision has been made in the previous section by the scriptural statement food is Brahman and by the indication of the designation of its cause and other things.

analyzed: na ca indra ādi śrutiḥ anyatra netum śakyate
translated: And the mention of Indra and others cannot be taken elsewhere.

analyzed: purandara ādiṣu rūḍha tvāt yaugika tvāt ca
translated: Because of the established usage in Purandara and others, and because of the etymological derivation.

analyzed: nanu uktam atra anyatra rūḍheḥ avidvas sambandhi tvāt yogasya ca parameśvara āyatta alpa nimitta tvāt amukhya tā iti
translated: But it has been said that in other cases, because of the established usage elsewhere, and because the secondary meaning of the word is dependent on the Supreme Lord for its limited purpose, it is not primary.

analyzed: satyam
translated: True.

analyzed: tad anna auṣadhī ādi padārtheṣu syāt
translated: That may be so in the case of things like food and medicine.

analyzed: na tu purandara ādiṣu
translated: But not in the case of Purandara and others.

analyzed: tatra indra ādi śabda pravṛtti nimittasya parama aiśvarya ādeḥ anavadhikasya apara āyattasya vidyamāna tvena mukhya yoga upapatteḥ
translated: Because in that case, the primary meaning is possible, as the basis for the use of the words Indra and others, such as supreme lordship, etc., is present without limit and without dependence on anything else.

original: aśakteṣu khalu sāmantādiṣvaiśvaryādikamalpaṃ parāyattaṃ ca bhavati /
analyzed: aśakteṣu khalu sāmanta ādiṣu aiśvarya ādikam alpam parāyattam ca bhavati
translated: In the case of those who are powerless, such as local chiefs, etc., lordship, etc., are limited and dependent on others.

analyzed: devāḥ tu apratihata śaktayaḥ katham evam bhaveyuḥ
translated: But how can the gods, who are of unobstructed power, be so?

analyzed: tathā ca śrutiḥ
translated: And thus the Śruti:

analyzed: indraḥ vai devānām ojiṣṭhaḥ iti evaṃjātīyakā
translated: Indra is indeed the strongest among the gods. Such are the statements.

original: tatra rūḍhiṃ ca tacchabdānāmapi svayam // / / //🔽rūḍhirapi purandarādiṣvindrādiśabdānāṃindrasya nu vīryāṇi pravocam' /
analyzed: tatra rūḍhim ca tad śabdānām api svayam  rūḍhiḥ api purandara ādiṣu indra ādi śabdānām indrasya nu vīryāṇi pravocam
translated: There, the established usage of those words is also by themselves.

analyzed: ityādi mantreṣu bahula prayoga darśanena vidvat sambandhinī mukhyā eva
translated: The established usage of the words Indra, etc., in Purandara and others is also primary, being related to the learned, as seen from the frequent use in mantras such as I proclaim the heroic deeds of Indra.

analyzed: teṣām atatpara tve tad yajana ādau viniyoga anupapatteḥ
translated: Because if they were not directed towards that, their application in the worship of that, etc., would be impossible.

analyzed: na ca svatantra anavadhika aiśvarya ādikam anekeṣām viruddham iti vācyam
translated: And it should not be said that the independent, unlimited lordship, etc. of many are contradictory.

analyzed: indra ādīnām parameśvara ātmaka tvāt
translated: Because Indra and others are of the nature of the Supreme Lord.

original: sa eva hi kāyarvaśāttattadupādhibhedabhinnastāstāḥ saṃjñā labhate /🔽kuta etaditi cet /
analyzed: saḥ eva hi kāya rvaśāt tad tad upādhi bheda bhinnaḥ tāḥ tāḥ saṃjñāḥ labhate  kutas etat iti ced
translated: He alone, due to the power of His own actions, being differentiated by the various limiting adjuncts, obtains those and those designations.

analyzed: etat prakaraṇa gata vākya śābalya anyathā anupapattyā iti tāvat brūmaḥ
translated: If it is asked from where this is known, we say that it is known from the impossibility of explaining otherwise the mutual inconsistency of the statements in this section.

analyzed: tathā hi
translated: To explain:

analyzed: adṛśye na ātmye iti ānanda maya lakṣaṇa tvena uktam adṛśya tvam iha na vijānanti devāḥ iti ucyate
translated: The invisibility mentioned here as the definition of the Bliss-Body is said to be what the gods do not know.

analyzed: samāna adhikaraṇāni ca indra ādi śruti liṅgāni  na ca ekam vākyam aneka viṣayam sam
translated: And the references to Indra and others are in the same context.

analyzed: bhavati vyāghātāt
translated: And a single sentence cannot have many meanings, because of contradiction.

analyzed: yathā uktam
translated: As it is said:

analyzed: artha eka tvāt ekam vākyam sākāṅkṣam ced vibhāge syāt iti
translated: A sentence is one because of the unity of meaning. If there is a desire for more, there would be a division.

analyzed: na ca atra eka upādānena apara parityāge kāraṇam asti
translated: And there is no reason here for abandoning one by adopting another.

analyzed: tathā ca purāṇa vākyam
translated: And so is the statement of the Puranas:

original: ahaṃ bhavo bhavantaśca sarvaṃ nārāyaṇātmakam' / ityādi /
analyzed: aham bhavaḥ bhavantaḥ ca sarvam nārāyaṇa ātmakam ityādi
translated: I, Bhava, and you all are of the nature of Narayana.

analyzed: atas eva bheda vyapadeśaḥ tad itara viṣayaḥ vyākhyeyaḥ
translated: And for this very reason, the statement of difference should be explained as referring to something else.

analyzed: na ca evam sati vinigamane kāraṇa abhāvaḥ
translated: And in this case, there is no reason for a restriction.

analyzed: anupahita dharmāṇām upahite sambhavāt vaiparītyasya asambhavāt
translated: Because the qualities of the unconditioned can be present in the conditioned, but the reverse is not possible.

analyzed: tasmāt indra ādayaḥ eva antar praviṣṭa tvena pratipādyante iti
translated: Therefore, Indra and others are taught as being within.

analyzed: evam devānām indra ādīnām tatra svatantra anavadhika indra ādi śabda pravṛtti nimittavat tāyām śakta tām
translated: Thus, the gods like Indra have the ability to be the basis for the application of the words Indra etc. independently and without limit there.

analyzed: tatas ca indra ādi śabdānām tatra mahā yoga vṛttim iti śeṣaḥ
translated: And therefore, the words Indra etc. have the function of great yoga there, this is the remainder.

analyzed: tathā tad śabdānām indra di śabdānām tatra purandara ādiṣu
translated: Similarly, the words like Indra have a conventional meaning in the gods like Purandara.

analyzed: deveṣu svayam api sākṣāt api vidvas sambandhinīm api iti yāvat
translated: Even themselves, directly, and also in relation to the learned, this is the extent.

analyzed: rūḍhim ca abhyadhikām āśaṅkaya
translated: And suspecting that the conventional meaning is excessive,

analyzed: samudra anta sthita tva ādyaiḥ tad dharmaiḥ viṣṇu rūḍha tām
translated: having established that Vishnu has the conventional meaning of being within the ocean etc. by those qualities of Him,

analyzed: sādhayitvā
translated: having established that...

analyzed: svayam sūtra kāraḥ ntar tad dharma upadeśāt iti sūtreṇa antar praviṣyaḥ viṣṇuḥ eva
translated: The author of the sutra himself establishes that Vishnu alone is within by the sutra antar tatdharmopadeśāt, that Vishnu alone is within.

analyzed: samudre ntar kavayaḥ 🔽yasya aṇḍakośam śuṣmam āhuḥ
translated: The wise ones are within the ocean.🔽They call the embryo of the universe His essence.

analyzed: brahmā tapasā anvavindat iti samudra antar sthita tva brahmāṇḍa vīrya tva brahma tāpaḥ labhya tva ādi dharma upadeśāt
translated: And because it teaches the attributes of being located within the ocean, being the semen of the universe, and being attained through the heat of Brahman, as in the statement Brahman found it through austerities.

analyzed: teṣām ca viṣṇu dharma tvena śruti smṛti siddha tvāt
translated: And because it is established by scripture and smrti that those attributes belong to Vishnu.

analyzed: na ca indra ādi śruti liṅga virodhaḥ
translated: And there is no contradiction with the scriptures and inferences about Indra and others.

analyzed: niravakāśa liṅga balena tad bādhā upapatteḥ
translated: Because it is possible to negate them by the power of the non-contingent inferences.

analyzed: na ca teṣām api niravakāśa tvam
translated: And those are not non-contingent.

original: indraṃ mitraṃ varuṇamagnimāhurityādinā teṣāṃ bhagavati vidvadrūḍhisadbhāvasya siddhatvāt /
analyzed: indram mitram varuṇam agnim āhuḥ ityādinā teṣām bhagavati vidvat rūḍhi sadbhāvasya siddha tvāt
translated: Because it is established by statements like They call Indra, Mitra, Varuna, Agni, etc. that the learned have established the existence of the supreme Lord in them.

analyzed: mahā yogasya ca su prasiddha tvāt
translated: And because the great yoga is well-known.

analyzed: indra ādi gatasya parama aiśvarya ādeḥ alpa tā parameśvara adhīna tā ca śruti purāṇa ādi prasiddhā
translated: The inferiority and dependence on the supreme Lord of the supreme lordship etc. of Indra and others is well-known in the scriptures, Puranas etc.

analyzed: śakteḥ api asmat ādi apekṣayā ādhikya mātram eva na tu nirargala tvam api
translated: And the power also has only a greater degree in relation to us, not even unrestrictedness.

analyzed: anyathā aneka īśvara virodhaḥ ca
translated: Otherwise, there would be contradiction with many lords.

analyzed: vidvas rūḍhiḥ api īśvara sannidhāna nimittā eva
translated: And the learned usage also is due only to the presence of the Lord.

analyzed: iti evam samudra antar sthita tva ādyaiḥ viṣṇu dharmaiḥ antar praviṣṭa tvasya viṣṇu niṣṭha tām tathā tad śabdānām indra ādi śabdānām api viṣṇu rūḍha tām
translated: Thus, by these characteristics of Vishnu, such as being situated within the ocean, the identity of being within with Vishnu, and the fact that words like Indra are based on Vishnu,

analyzed: upalakṣaṇam etat
translated: this is an indication.

analyzed: tatra yaugika tvam ca sādhayitvā
translated: Having established the etymological meaning there,

analyzed: bheda vyapadeśāt ca anyaḥ
translated: and because of the designation of difference, He is different...

analyzed: abhidām taiḥ ca punar eva nyavārayat
translated: and again He refuted the assertion by them...

analyzed: nanu ukta rītyā devānām parameśvara ātmaka tvena samudra antar sthita tva ādikam sarvam
translated: But by the stated method, all the being situated within the ocean and so on of the gods as having the nature of the Supreme Lord

analyzed: sambhavati iti evam taiḥ devaiḥ everī
translated: is possible. Thus, by those very gods,

original: śvarasyābhidāṃ ca punarāśaṅkaya bhedavyapadeśāccānya iti sūtreṇa /
analyzed: śvarasya abhidām ca punar āśaṅkaya bheda vyapadeśāt ca anyaḥ iti sūtreṇa
translated: suspecting again the assertion of the Supreme Lord, with the sutra And He is different because of the designation of difference,

analyzed: anyaḥ ca asau indra ādidevebhyaḥ ntar praviṣyaḥ
translated: and He who enters within is different from the gods like Indra.

analyzed: indrasya ātmā ityādi viśeṣa viṣaya bheda vyapadeśāt abhede pramāṇa abhāvāt ca
translated: Because of the designation of difference with respect to specific things like the Self of Indra and so on, and because there is no evidence for non-difference.

analyzed: na ca vākya śābalyam
translated: And there is no deficiency in the sentence.

analyzed: sarvasya īśvara para tāyāḥ ukta tvāt
translated: Because it has been said that everything is about the Lord.

analyzed: purāṇa stha īśvara sannidhāna atiśaya viṣaya tvāt iti evam nyavārayat iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that He refuted again, considering that it refers to the excess of the proximity of the Lord in the Puranas.

analyzed: atra punar iti āśaṅkā vṛtti mātram ācaṣṭe
translated: Here, the word again merely indicates the repetition of the doubt.

original: tairevetyavadhārayatā prakārāntareṇa bhedasūtrasya punaruktatā nirastā bhavati /
analyzed: taiḥ eva iti avadhārayatā prakāra antareṇa bheda sūtrasya punarukta tā nirastā bhavati
translated: By determining that it is by those very [means], the repetition of the Sūtra on difference by another method is refuted.

analyzed: yadi api ayam liṅgātamakaḥ śabdaḥ tathā api indra ādi aneka nāma samanvaya lābhāt atra nirṇītaḥ iti adoṣaḥ
translated: Although this word is of the Linga class, there is no fault because it is determined here by the gain of the correspondence of many names such as Indra and so on.

original: kecidetatsūtradvayaṃatha ya eṣo 'ntarāditye hiraṇmayaḥ puruṣo dṛśyate /
analyzed: kecid etat sūtra dvayam atha yaḥ eṣaḥ ntar āditye hiraṇmayaḥ puruṣaḥ dṛśyate
translated: Some explain these two Sūtras as being for the purpose of establishing the lordship of the person dwelling in the eye and sun mentioned in the Chāndogya Upaniṣad: That golden person is seen within the sun,

analyzed: yaḥ eṣaḥ ntarakṣiṇi puruṣaḥ dṛśyate  iti chāndogya ukta akṣi āditya anta stha puruṣasya īśvara tva samarthana paratvena vyācakṣate
translated: That person is seen within the eye.

analyzed: tat vā nira kartum eva iti uktam
translated: But that has been stated to be rejected.

analyzed: tathātve hi antare upapatteḥ iti asya anārambha prasaṅgaḥ
translated: For if that were so, then because of the possibility within would be meaningless.

original: ya eṣo 'ntarakṣiṇi puruṣo dṛśyata eṣa ātmeti hovācetyetadvākyamadhikṛtya tatpravṛttamiti cenna /
analyzed: yaḥ eṣaḥ ntar akṣiṇi puruṣaḥ dṛśyate eṣaḥ ātmā iti ha uvāca iti etat vākyam adhikṛtya tat pravṛttam iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that it is begun with reference to the statement The person who is seen within the eye, he is the Self, that is not so.

analyzed: vākya bhedena adhikaraṇa bhede śāstra aparyavasāna prasaṅgāt
translated: For if there were a difference in statements and a difference in sections, it would follow that the scriptures would not be complete.

analyzed: santi ca tatra api amṛta tva ādayaḥ brahma dharmāḥ
translated: And there are also the qualities of Brahman such as immortality in that [Chāndogya Upaniṣad].

analyzed: nanu adhika āśaṅkayā tad ārambhaḥ bhaviṣyati
translated: But it will be begun with an additional doubt.

analyzed: tathā hi
translated: For thus:

analyzed: eṣa dṛśyate iti tāvat pratyakṣe rthe prayujyate
translated: This is seen is used only in regard to an object that is directly perceived.

original: brahma tu parokṣaṃ na tathā nirdeśaviṣayo bhavitumarhati /
analyzed: brahma tu parokṣam na tathā nirdeśa viṣayaḥ bhavitum arhati
translated: But Brahman is transcendent and cannot properly be the object of such an instruction.

analyzed: yujyate ca etat pratibimbe
translated: And this is appropriate in the case of a reflection.

original: prathamāvagatātpratyakṣābhidhānācchāyāpuruṣe 'dhigate taduparaktāyāṃ buddhau pratīyamānāṃ amṛtatvādayaḥ stutyā kathañcid vyākhyeyā iti /
analyzed: prathama avagatāt pratyakṣa abhidhānāt chāyā puruṣe dhigate tad uparaktāyām buddhau pratīyamānām amṛta tva ādayaḥ stutyā kathañcid vyākhyeyāḥ iti
translated: When the person in the eye is understood from the first-person pronoun, which refers to a directly perceived object, immortality and so on, which are cognized in the cognition colored by that, can be somehow explained as praise.

analyzed: tat idam punarukti bhaya sambhrāntena bhāṣitam
translated: This was said by one alarmed by the fear of repetition.

original: yato atrāpi ya eṣo 'ntarakṣiṇi puruṣo dṛśyata iti pratyakṣābhidhānamasti /
analyzed: yatas atra api yaḥ eṣaḥ ntarakṣiṇi puruṣaḥ dṛśyate iti pratyakṣa abhidhānam asti
translated: For here too there is the use of the first-person pronoun, This person is seen within the eye.

original: tadatra yathā paramātmani sāvakāśitaṃ tathā tadapi bhaviṣyatīti kā tatrāpyadhikāśaṅkā /
analyzed: tat atra yathā paramātmani sāvakāśitam tathā tat api bhaviṣyati iti kā tatra api adhikā āśaṅkā
translated: So just as the person in the eye is referred to as the supreme self, so it will be in that case as well. What is the excessive doubt there?

analyzed: tarhi atra para udāhṛtam evā astu viṣaya vākyam
translated: Then let the subject sentence quoted by the opponent be the same here.

analyzed: tatra antar praviṣyam iti ādi antat bhaviṣyati iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that the person in the eye is the supreme self because it is said to enter there, that is not so.

analyzed: sthāna ādi bheda vyapadeśa ādinā tatra tasya eva udāharaṇa tva pratibhāsanāt
translated: Because it appears as an example of that very [supreme self] by the teaching of difference in location and so on.

analyzed: tasmāt vākya jñāna daridrāṇām vyākhyānam upekṣaṇīyam iti
translated: Therefore, the explanation of those poor in knowledge of the sentence should be ignored.

analyzed: iti śrīmat nyāyasudhāyām antaḥsthatva adhikaraṇam
translated: Thus ends the chapter on the internal existence in the commentary called Nyāyasudhā.

analyzed: ākāśa adhikaraṇam
translated: VI. The chapter on Ākāśa.

analyzed: atha śrīmat nyāsudhāyām ākāśa adhikaraṇam  evam adhidaiva viṣaya śabda samanvayam abhidhāya adhunā adhibhūta viṣaya śabda samanvayam pratipipādayiṣuḥ ākāśasya
translated: Now, in the commentary called Nyāyasudhā, the chapter on Ākāśa.

analyzed: bhūteṣu prādhānyāt tad śabda samanvayam sūtrakāraḥ ākāśaḥ tad liṅgāt iti
translated: Having thus explained the harmony of words referring to the deities, now, wishing to establish the harmony of words referring to the elements, the author of the aphorisms states the harmony of the word with Ākāśa, because it is the most important among the elements. Ākāśa, because of its indicative mark.

analyzed: ākāśaḥ tad liṅgāt  /
translated: Ākāśa, because of its indicative mark.

analyzed: chandogāḥ paṭhanti
translated: The Chandogas recite:

original: asya lokasya kā gatirityākāśa iti hovāca /
analyzed: asya lokasya kā gatiḥ iti ākāśaḥ iti ha uvāca
translated: What is the goal of this world? He said, Ākāśa.

original: sarvāṇi ha vā imāni bhūtānyākāśādeva samutpadyante /
analyzed: sarvāṇi ha vai imāni bhūtāni ākāśāt eva samutpadyante
translated: Verily, all these beings originate from Ākāśa,

original: ākāśaṃ pratyastaṃ yantyākāśo hyevaibhyo jyāyānākāśaḥ parāyaṇaṃ sa eṣa parovarīyānudgīthaḥ sa eṣo 'nanta iti /
analyzed: ākāśam pratyastam yanti ākāśaḥ hi eva ebhyaḥ jyāyān ākāśaḥ parāyaṇam saḥ eṣa paras varīyān udgīthaḥ saḥ eṣaḥ nantaḥ iti
translated: and they dissolve into Ākāśa, for Ākāśa is indeed greater than they. Ākāśa is the highest support. It is the highest Udgītha. It is the endless.

analyzed: tatra saṃśayaḥ
translated: Regarding this, there is doubt.

analyzed: kim ayam ākāśaḥ paramātmā uta bhūtam iti
translated: Is this Ākāśa the supreme self or an element?

analyzed: bhūtam iti tāvat prāptam
translated: First, it is obtained as an element.

analyzed: kutas
translated: Why?

analyzed: ākāśa śabdasya yoga rūḍhibhyām bhūte prasiddha tvāt
translated: Because the word Ākāśa is well-known in the element by both derivation and conventional usage.

analyzed: khalu ākāśa śabda nirvacana labdham
translated: Space is well known to be the mere absence of contact, as is understood from the etymological explanation of the word 'ākāśa' (space).

analyzed: tat ca bhūte su prasiddham
translated: And that is well known in the element (ether).

analyzed: prayogaḥ ca loka vedayoḥ ākāśa śabdasya bhūta viṣayaḥ bahulaḥ
translated: And the usage of the word 'ākāśa' in the world and the Vedas is mostly with reference to the element (ether).

original: nanu ca sarvāṇi ha vetyādyuktaliṅgabalātparamātmā kiṃ na syāt /
analyzed: nanu ca sarvāṇi ha vā ityādi ukta liṅga balāt paramātmā kim na syāt
translated: But is it not the Supreme Self, because of the indicative power stated by the words 'all this'?

analyzed: liṅgāt śruteḥ balavat tvāt iti brūmaḥ
translated: We say that the indicative power is stronger than the direct statement.

analyzed: na ca bahu tvena liṅgānām prābalyam
translated: And the indicative power is not stronger because of its multiplicity.

analyzed: tathā api sāmyena anirṇayāt
translated: Even so, there is no determination because of equality.

analyzed: na ca sāmyam api
translated: And there is no equality either.

analyzed: yathā āhuḥ  dvividham balavat tvam ca bahu tvāt ca svabhāvataḥ
translated: As they say:🔽Strength is of two kinds: by multiplicity and by nature.

analyzed: tayoḥ svabhāvaḥ balavān upajīvya ādikaḥ ca saḥ iti
translated: Of those two, that which is based on dependence and so on is stronger by nature.

analyzed: kutrima akṛtrimayoḥ akṛtrimam hi jyāyaḥ  atas prathama avagata svabhāva balavat śruti anurodhena liṅgāni kathañcid yojyāni iti
translated: Between what is artificial and what is not artificial, what is not artificial is greater.

analyzed: nanu antar tad dharma upadeśāt iti anena eva parihṛtam etat
translated: Therefore, the indicative power should be somehow connected in accordance with the direct statement, which is stronger by nature, as understood from the first.

original: indrādiśabdavadākāśaśabdasyāpi bhūte 'mukhyayā vṛttyā pravṛttasya mahāyogavidvadrūḍhibhyāmīśvaravācinastadbuddhayādhāyakatvameva hi nyāyyam
analyzed: indra ādi śabda vat ākāśa śabdasya api bhūte mukhyayā vṛttyā pravṛttasya mahā yoga vidvas rūḍhibhyām īśvara vācinaḥ tad buddhayā ādhāyaka tvam eva hi nyāyyam
translated: Just as the word Indra etc. is applied to the element ether in a secondary sense, it is proper that the word ether also, which is applied to God by the great yoga and the learned, should indicate Him by the intellect.

analyzed: sutarām ca niravakāśa liṅga balāt iti
translated: And all the more so by the force of the non-discrepant indicative power.

analyzed: na ca kācid abhyadhikā śaṅkā asti iti atas na ārambhaṇīyam idam sūtram iti
translated: And there is no greater doubt. Therefore, this aphorism is not to be commenced.

analyzed: tatra abhyadhikām śaṅkām darśayati ceṣyāḥ hi iti
translated: There, he shows the greater doubt in But motion, etc.

original: ceṣṭā hi cetanānāṃ yā sā bhavet tatprasādataḥ /
analyzed: ceṣṭāḥ hi cetanānām yā sā bhavet tad prasādataḥ
translated: For, the motion of conscious beings would be due to His grace.

analyzed: acetana svabhāvaḥ tu vivara ādiḥ katham tatas
translated: But how can the inert nature, such as space, etc., be from Him?

analyzed: iti śaṅkā nivṛtti artham
translated: Thus, for the purpose of removing doubt, etc.

analyzed: yuktam indra ādi śabdānām purandara ādiṣu amukhya tvam
translated: It is proper that the words Indra etc. are secondary in relation to Purandara etc.

analyzed: niravadhikasya pravṛtti nimittasya aiśvarya ādeḥ asambhavāt
translated: Because the cause of application without limit, such as sovereignty, etc., is impossible.

analyzed: alpasya api parameśvara āyatta tvāt
translated: Even a little is dependent on the Supreme Lord.

analyzed: yuktam ca svatantra anavadhika aiśvarya ādimati parameśvare mukhya tvam
translated: And it is proper that the word ether is primary in relation to the Supreme Lord, who is independent and unlimited in sovereignty, etc.

analyzed: na ca evam ākāśa śabda pravṛtti nimittam avakāśa tvam bhūte niravadhikam na sambhavati
translated: And in the same way, the cause of the application of the word ether, namely, space, is not impossible without limit in the element.

analyzed: kvacid kadācid api abhāva abhāvāt
translated: Because of the absence of absence at some place and at some time.

analyzed: na api īśvara āyattam
translated: Nor is it dependent on God.

analyzed: aiśvaryam hi varṣaṇa śāsana pālana ādi rūpā cetana sambandhinī ceṣyā
translated: For sovereignty, which is of the form of raining, ruling, protecting, etc., is accepted as connected with a conscious being.

analyzed: sā ca āgantuka jñāna icchā ādi kāraṇa vyapekṣa tvāt svayam āgantuka tvāt ca kāraṇa dvārā svarūpataḥ ca parameśvara prasāda āyattā iti yujyate
translated: And that is dependent on the grace of the Supreme Lord through causes such as adventitious knowledge, desire, etc., and through its own nature, because it is adventitious.

original: ākāśādiśabdapravṛttinimittaṃ tu vivaratvādikaṃ na tāvadāgantukajñānādikāraṇadvārā parameśvarāyattam /
analyzed: ākāśa ādi śabda pravṛtti nimittam tu vivara tva ādikam na tāvat āgantuka jñāna ādi kāraṇa dvārā parameśvara āyattam
translated: But the reason for the application of words like space, such as being a cavity, etc., is not dependent on the Supreme Lord through adventitious causes such as knowledge, etc.

analyzed: acetana āśrita tvāt
translated: Because it is based on non-sentient beings.

analyzed: na api svarūpataḥ
translated: Nor is it through its own nature.

analyzed: svabhāva tvāt anāgantuka tvāt
translated: Because it is natural and not adventitious.

analyzed: na ca ākāśa śabdasya īśvare yogaḥ sambhavati
translated: And the word space cannot be applied to God.

analyzed: tasya manāk api avakāśa tva abhāvāt  tasmāt ākāśa śabdam bhūtam eva iti abhyadhika āśaṅkā nivṛtti artham sūtritam iti śeṣaḥ
translated: Because it does not have even the slightest space.🔽Therefore, the aphorism was formulated to remove the doubt that the word space refers only to the element.🔽The expression cavity, etc. is significant.

analyzed: vivara ādiḥ iti bhāva pradhānaḥ nirdeśaḥ  ādi grahaṇena ākāśa grahaṇam upalakṣaṇam iti sūcayati
translated: By the word etc., it indicates that the word space is a synecdoche.

analyzed: tatas parameśvarāt
translated: From that, from the Supreme Lord.

analyzed: tad āyattaḥ iti yāvat
translated: It is dependent on that, that is, on Him, only.

analyzed: katham iti ākṣepe
translated: How? This is a rhetorical question.

analyzed: nanu atra ākāśaḥ paramātmā tad liṅgāt iti etāvat ucyate
translated: But here it is said only this much: ākāśa is the supreme self, because of that indication.

original: na punaruktapūrvapakṣācchādakaṃ kiñcidityataḥ sūtrasyārthāntaramāha ākāśa iti //
analyzed: na punar ukta pūrvapakṣa ācchādakam kiñcid iti atas sūtrasya artha antaram āha ākāśe iti
translated: And nothing is said to cover the previously stated position. Therefore, the meaning of the sūtra is stated to be different, beginning with ākāśa.

analyzed: ākāśaḥ iti nāma ca
translated: And the name ākāśa

analyzed: pivarīyaḥ tva pūrvāt liṅgāt hareḥ bhavet
translated: would be of Hari, because of the indication of being greater than the greatest, even from elsewhere.

analyzed: ākāśa nāma balāt khalu pareṇa bhūtam āśaṅkitam
translated: Indeed, the opponent has suspected the element to be ākāśa on the strength of the name ākāśa.

analyzed: na ca tat yuktam
translated: And that is not proper.

analyzed: yatas niravakāśāt paras varīyaḥ tva ādeḥ anekasmāt liṅgāt ākāśaḥ iti nāma ca hareḥ bhavet
translated: Because the name ākāśa and the indication of being greater than the greatest, which is not subject to any other interpretation, would be of Hari.

analyzed: vācakam iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The rest is that which denotes.

original: atropasarjanatayā samāse nirdiṣyenāpi varīyastvena buddhayā viviktena parato 'pītyasya sambandho nānupapannaḥ /
analyzed: atra upasarjana tayā samāse varīyas tvena buddhayā viviktena paratas pi iti asya sambandhaḥ na anupapannaḥ
translated: Here, even though greater than the greatest is indicated in the compound as a subordinate element, its connection with even from elsewhere is not impossible when distinguished by the intellect.

analyzed: sarva bhūta utpatti kāraṇa tva pūrvāt iti vaktavye paraḥ varīyaḥ tva pūrvāt iti uktam
translated: When it should be said because of being the cause of the origin of all beings, it is said because of being greater than the greatest.

analyzed: prathama pratītasya api sarva bhūta kāraṇa tva ādeḥ bhūte kathañcid vayākhyātum śakya tvāt
translated: Because even though being the cause of all beings is understood first, it can somehow be explained even in the case of the element.

analyzed: paraḥ varīyaḥ tva ādeḥ sarvathā api tatra netum aśakya tvāt
translated: But being greater than the greatest cannot be brought about in that at all.

analyzed: tathā hi
translated: For thus:

original: asya lokasya kā gatiriti pṛthivīgatipraśnasyākāśa ityuttaramabhidhāya kathametat /
analyzed: asya lokasya kā gatiḥ iti pṛthivī gati praśnasya ākāśaḥ iti uttaram abhidhāya katham etat
translated: To the question What is the goal of this world? the answer space is given. How is this?

analyzed: apām kāryam hi pṛthivī
translated: Earth is the effect of water.

analyzed: tatra eva ca
translated: And it dissolves into that.
