analyzed: līyate iti tāsām eva pṛthivī gati tva upapatteḥ iti āśaṅkaya mā evam
translated: Therefore, it is proper that water is the goal of earth.🔽Fearing this, he says No,

analyzed: mūla kāraṇa tvāt iti āha sarvāṇi iti
translated: because it is the primary cause.

original: naca tarhyātmana ākāśaḥ sambhūta iti śruterātmā vaktavya iti vācyam /
analyzed: na ca tarhi ātmanaḥ ākāśaḥ sambhūtaḥ iti śruteḥ ātmā vaktavyaḥ iti vācyam
translated: And it should not be argued that since the scripture says space is born from the self, the self should be mentioned.

original: bhūtaviṣayavicāre viyata eva vaktavyatvāt /🔽naca ākāśasyāpi bhūtatvātsarvāṇīti viruddham /
analyzed: bhūta viṣaya vicāre viyataḥ eva vaktavya tvāt  na ca ākāśasya api bhūta tvāt sarvāṇi iti viruddham
translated: Because it should be mentioned only in the consideration of the elements, not in the consideration of space.

analyzed: idam sarvam asṛjata iti vat tad vayatirikta grahaṇa īpapatteḥ
translated: And it is not contradictory that space is also an element, because the word all is applicable to what is other than that, just as in the statement He created all this.

analyzed: na ca avadhāraṇa anupapattiḥ
translated: And there is no inappropriateness of determination.

analyzed: paramparayā
translated: Because there is no other [element] that is produced by the elements indirectly.

analyzed: katham asya bhūta utpatti ādi hetu tvam
translated: How is it the cause of the origination of the elements and so on?

original: bhūteṣu jyeṣṭhatvādityāha ākāśo hyebhyaścaturbhyo bhūtebhyo jyāyāniti //
analyzed: bhūteṣu jyeṣṭha tvāt iti āha ākāśaḥ hi ebhyaḥ caturbhyaḥ bhūtebhyaḥ jyāyān iti
translated: He says it is because it is the eldest of the elements, that space is greater than these four elements.

analyzed: na kevalam utpatti laya kāraṇa tvāt gatiḥ
translated: And the goal is not only because it is the cause of origination and dissolution,

original: kiṃ nāma kāraṇeṣu sthitaṃ kāryamiti śruterāśrayatvādapītyāhaākāśaḥ parāyaṇamiti //
analyzed: kim nāma kāraṇeṣu sthitam kāryam iti śruteḥ āśraya tvāt api iti āha ākāśaḥ parāyaṇam iti
translated: What is meant by the statement that the effect is dependent on the cause? The answer is: Ākāśa is the highest resort.

analyzed: na ca asya lokasya iti prāṇi nikāya abhidhānam
translated: And this world, the term ‘loka’ here standing for the aggregate of living beings.

analyzed: yena sarva bhūta śabdaḥ u pi tad paraḥ syāt
translated: By this explanation, the term ‘sarva-bhūta’ also would be applicable to the said Ākāśa.

analyzed: na pratiṣṭhām lokam atinayet iti pṛthivyāḥ prakṛta tvāt
translated: The world would not attain the support, because the Earth has been already mentioned as the support.

analyzed: na ca paraḥ varīyaḥ tva ādikam śakyam evam kathañcid vayakhyātum
translated: Nor is it possible to explain the term ‘parāvarīyaḥ’ and the rest in any such way.

analyzed: nirupacaritam sarva uttama tvam hi paras varīyaḥ tvam
translated: For ‘parāvarīyaḥ’ means that which is the highest of all, in the highest degree;

original: anyathā jyāyānityanenaiva gatāthartvaprasaṅgāt /🔽udgīthatvaṃ comityetadakṣaramudgīthamityuktatvānna kathañcidanyatra netuṃ śakyate /
analyzed: anyathā jyāyān iti anena eva gatāthartva prasaṅgāt  udgītha tvam ca ūm iti etat akṣaram udgītham iti ukta tvāt na kathañcid anyatra netum śakyate
translated: otherwise, the term ‘jyayā’ itself would have served the purpose, and there would have been no point in adding the term ‘parāvarīyaḥ’.🔽As for the term ‘udgītha’, it has been already explained that it stands for the syllable ‘Om’, and hence it cannot be taken in any other sense.

analyzed: āropaḥ yam iti ced na
translated: If it be argued that “the said explanation is only an imposition”, that cannot be right;

analyzed: bāla līlā atha ṛtu a prasaṅgāt upaniṣadām
translated: because such an imposition would make the Upaniṣad a mere childish play.

analyzed: ananta tvam ca ākāśasya deśa kāla dharmaiḥ antavataḥ na sambhavati eva
translated: As regards the term ‘ananta’, ‘infinite’, it can apply to Ākāśa only if it is something that has limits in the shape of space, time and properties;

analyzed: āpekṣikam tu prakṛta viruddham
translated: and if it is applied figuratively, it would be contrary to the context.

original: pṛthivyāḥ sāmagatitvamantavadvai khalu saumya te sāma' /
analyzed: pṛthivyāḥ sāma gati tvam antavat vai khalu saumya te sāma
translated: For instance, the Earth has been spoken of as ‘sāman’ in the text ‘O gentle one, the Earth, indeed, is your Sāman, which is limited, etc.’ (Chā.

analyzed: iti nirākṛtya svayam api antavantam ākāśam abhidadhatā kim adhikam ācaritam syāt
translated: Thus, having refuted [the idea of space being the supreme Brahman], what more could be done by one who asserts space itself to be finite?

analyzed: atas nanta tvam api nirupacaritam eva iti
translated: Therefore, infinity also is [to be understood] in its primary sense only.

analyzed: nanu ākāśa śrutiḥ api niravakāśā iti uktam
translated: But it has been said that the mention of space also is not open to any other interpretation.

analyzed: satyam
translated: True.

analyzed: duruktam tat
translated: That [statement] is ill-spoken.

analyzed: nahi deśa kālābhyām paricchinnasya ākāśasya avakāśa dātṛ tvam niravadhikam sambhavati
translated: For the giving of space by space, which is limited by place and time, cannot be unlimited.

analyzed: nā api svatantram parameśvara āyattatvāt
translated: Nor is it independent, because it depends on the supreme Lord.

analyzed: tat kutas iti atas āha nabhaḥ iti
translated: How is that? To this he says 'in the sky' [means].

analyzed: nabhaḥ dadāti śvasatām mārgam yat niyamāt adaḥ  ityādi vākyaiḥ
translated: The sky gives way for the breathers, because of its restriction.

analyzed: ādi grahaṇena sarva bhūta guṇaiḥ yuktam iti ādeḥ saṅgrahaḥ
translated: By the word 'etc.' [is included] the statement 'endowed with all the qualities of beings' and so on.

original: tena yaduktaṃ parameśvare yogānupapattiriti tadapi samāhitaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: tena yat uktam parameśvare yoga anupapattiḥ iti tat api samāhitam bhavati
translated: Therefore, what was said, that there is no possibility of yoga in the supreme Lord, that also is answered.

analyzed: ākāśe vakāśa dātṛ tvam īśvarasya api pṛthak tadvattvam ca avagamyate iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The meaning is that in space, the giving of space and the separateness of God from it are understood.

analyzed: upapattim tu vakṣyāmaḥ
translated: But the reason we will state.

analyzed: tasmāt ākāśa upalakṣita sakala adhibhūta śabda parama mukhya vācyaḥ bhagavān hariḥ iti siddham
translated: Therefore, it is established that Lord Hari is the primary and principal referent of all the words denoting the elements, exemplified by space.

analyzed: iti śrīmat nyāyasudhāyām ākāśa adhikaraṇam
translated: Thus ends the chapter on Ākāśa in the commentary of Śrī Nāya­su­dhā.
VII. The Chapter on Prāṇa.

analyzed: atha prāṇa adhikaraṇam
translated: Now begins the chapter on Prāṇa.

original: idānīmādhyātmikaśabdasamanvayaṃ siṣādhayiṣuḥ pradhānatvātprāṇaśabdasamanvayārthaṃ sūtrayāmāsa ata eva prāṇa iti //
analyzed: idānīm ādhyātmika śabda samanvayam siṣādhayiṣuḥ pradhāna tvāt prāṇa śabda samanvaya artham sūtrayāmāsa atas eva prāṇaḥ iti
translated: Now, wishing to establish the identity of the internal word, for the sake of establishing the identity of the word Prāṇa, which is primary, he has formulated the sūtra Therefore, Prāṇa.

analyzed: om atas eva prāṇaḥ om
translated: Om. Therefore, Prāṇa.

analyzed: atas eva prāṇaḥ
translated: Therefore, Prāṇa.

analyzed: taittirīyake śrūyate
translated: It is heard in the Taittirīya Upaniṣad:

analyzed: tat vai tvam prāṇaḥ bhavaḥ
translated: You have become Prāṇa,

analyzed: mahān bhogaḥ prajāpateḥ
translated: the great enjoyment of Prajāpati,

analyzed: bhujaḥ kariṣyamāṇaḥ yat devān prāṇayaḥ na vā iti
translated: when you were about to enjoy, whether you know the gods or not.

analyzed: tatra saṃśayaḥ
translated: There is a doubt there.

analyzed: kim ayam prāṇaḥ paramātmā uta mukhyaḥ iti
translated: Is this Prāṇa the supreme self or the primary one?

analyzed: vāyu vṛtti ādeḥ prāṇa śabda pravṛttau api vākya arthasya sarvathā api anupapatteḥ na saṃśaya viṣaya tvam
translated: Even though the term Prāṇa is used for the function of air, etc., the meaning of the sentence is not at all possible, so it is not the subject of doubt.

original: na hyacetanaṃ prati tvamevamabhava iti buddhimatocyate /
analyzed: na hi acetanam prati tvam evam abhavaḥ iti buddhimatā ucyate
translated: For it is not said to an insentient thing: You have become thus.

analyzed: kim tāvat prāptam
translated: What is the prima facie view?

analyzed: mukhyaḥ iti
translated: The primary one.

analyzed: kasmāt
translated: Why?

analyzed: prāṇa śabdasya loka vedayoḥ mukhya prāṇe prayoga prācuryāt prāṇanti anena iti nirukti sambhavāt ca
translated: Because the term Prāṇa is used primarily for the primary Prāṇa in the world and the Vedas, and because the derivation as that by which they breathe is possible.

original: nanvetadapi pūrvanyāyena parihṛtaṃ na sūtrārambhaṃ prayojayatīti /
analyzed: nanu etat api pūrva nyāyena parihṛtam na sūtra ārambham prayojayati iti
translated: But this also, by the same reasoning as before, is set aside, and does not justify the beginning of the Sūtra.

analyzed: atas bhyadhikā āśaṅkā darśayati adhyātmam iti
translated: Therefore he shows a more probable doubt, saying in the individual soul, etc.

analyzed: adhyātmam anvaya vyatirekataḥ
translated: In the individual soul, by positive and negative concomitance.

analyzed: prāṇa ādi hetutā dṛṣṭeḥ
translated: Because the causality of the vital airs, etc., is seen.

original: ātmānamadhikṛtya tasya bhogāyatanatvena vartata ityadhyātmaṃ śarīraṃ tasminprāṇaḥ prāṇanaṃ jīvanam /
analyzed: ātmānam adhikṛtya tasya bhoga āyatana tvena vartate iti adhyātmam śarīram tasmin prāṇaḥ prāṇanam jīvanam
translated: The body exists as the abode of enjoyment for that [soul], with reference to the self. The vital airs are the vitalizing, the living.

analyzed: ādi grahaṇāt ca iṣyā upādīyate
translated: And by the word etc., the rest is included.

analyzed: mukhyasya iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The remainder is of the primary.

analyzed: mukhyaḥ eva atra prāṇaḥ bhavitum arhati iti vākya śeṣaḥ tra adhyāhāryaḥ
translated: The remainder of the sentence should be supplied here as the primary alone should be here.

analyzed: tatas ca ayam arthaḥ
translated: And from that, this is the meaning.

analyzed: upapadyate tatra indra ādi śruteḥ ākāśa ādi śruteḥ vā apahāraḥ
translated: There, the mention of Indra, etc., or the mention of space, etc., can be set aside.

analyzed: pravṛtti nimittasya anyatra mukhyasya asambhavāt
translated: Because the reason for the occurrence is not possible elsewhere in the primary,

analyzed: paramātmani ca sambhavāt
translated: but is possible in the supreme self.

analyzed: na ca evam prakṛte
translated: And it is not so in the present case.

analyzed: jīvana ceṣyā hetu tvam
translated: The cause of the desire to live,

analyzed: tāḥ hi prāṇa śabda pravṛtti nimittam
translated: that is the reason for the occurrence of the word vital airs.

analyzed: tat ca mukhye sambhavati
translated: And that is possible in the primary.

analyzed: śarīre sati mukhye
translated: In the body, when the primary exists,

analyzed: jīvana ādikam bhavati
translated: the living, etc., occur.

analyzed: na asati iti anvaya vyatirekābhyām mukhyasya jīvana ādi hetutā dṛṣṭeḥ
translated: Because the existence of the principal [soul] is seen through positive and negative concomitance as the cause of life, etc.
But it is understood that life, etc. are concomitant with the modifications of air.

original: mukhyasya tu taddhetutā sādhyata iti kiṃ kena saṅgatam /
analyzed: mukhyasya tu tad hetutā sādhyate iti kim kena saṅgatam
translated: How can the causality of the principal [soul] be established?

analyzed: mā evam
translated: This is not so.

analyzed: vāyu vikāra śarīra tvāt mukhyasya iti
translated: Because the principal [soul] has a body that is a modification of air.

analyzed: athavā prāṇa ādi hetutāyāḥ adṛṣṭeḥ iti vyākhyeyam
translated: Or it should be explained as because the causality of life, etc. is not seen.

analyzed: paramātmanaḥ iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The supreme self is implied.

analyzed: anvaya vyatirekābhyām hi hetu tā kalpyā
translated: For causality is to be imagined through positive and negative concomitance.

analyzed: na ca paramātmanaḥ prāṇa śabda pravṛtti nimitta jīvana ādi hetutā avagamaka anvaya vyatirekau paśyāmaḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: And we do not see the positive and negative concomitance that would indicate the supreme self as the cause of life, etc., which is the basis for the application of the word prāṇa [to the self].

analyzed: yat vā yat atra vākye devān prāṇaye iti indriya prāṇanam uktam
translated: Or, what is stated here in this sentence, I breathe the gods, is the breathing of the senses.

analyzed: yat ca prajāpati upalakṣitānām sakala jīvānām bhoga kāraṇa tvam
translated: And the cause of the enjoyment of all living beings indicated by Prajāpati.

analyzed: tat ubhayam api adhyātmam anvaya vyatirekābhyām mukhyasya dṛśyate na paramātmanaḥ
translated: Both of these are seen in the principal [soul] through positive and negative concomitance in the internal [world], not in the supreme self.

analyzed: atas yukti saṃvādāt mukhya viṣayam eva idam vākyam iti
translated: Therefore, because of agreement with reason, this sentence refers only to the principal [soul].

analyzed: na ca atra pūrvavat ananyathā asiddham kim api īśvara liṅgam asti
translated: And here there is no mark of God, as before, which is not otherwise established.

analyzed: yena śruti bādham pratyeṣyāmaḥ iti pūrvapakṣa śeṣaḥ
translated: By which we would accept the contradiction of the Veda. This is the remainder of the prima facie view.

original: nanvevaṃ cenna sūtrametadācchādakamityatastasya tātparyamāha atideśo hīti //
analyzed: nanu evam ced na sūtram etat ācchādakam iti atas tasya tātparyam āha atideśaḥ hi iti
translated: If it is so, then this aphorism does not cover it. Therefore, its purport is stated: For it is a restatement of that kind.

analyzed: atideśaḥ hi tādṛśaḥ
translated: For it is a restatement of that kind.

analyzed: hi śabdaḥ hetau
translated: The word hi (for) is a reason.

original: evamadhikāśaṅkayā pūrvapakṣe prāpte sūtrakṛtā tādṛśaḥ pūrvoktasamānasya parihāranyāyasyātideśaḥ kṛto yasmāttasmāduktāśaṅkācchādakaṃ bhavatyevedaṃ 🔽sūtramiti yojyam /
analyzed: evam adhika āśaṅkayā pūrvapakṣe prāpte sūtrakṛtā tādṛśaḥ pūrva ukta samānasya parihāra nyāyasya atideśaḥ kṛtaḥ yasmāt tasmāt ukta āśaṅkā ācchādakam bhavati eva idam  sūtram iti yojyam
translated: When the prima facie view is thus presented with an additional doubt, the author of the aphorisms has made a restatement of the same method of solution as before, because of which this aphorism certainly covers the stated doubt. This is to be connected.

analyzed: yat vā kim anena adhika āśaṅkā vyutpādanena
translated: Or, what is the use of producing this additional doubt?

analyzed: yathābhāṣyam eva pūrvapakṣaḥ kim na syāt iti atra idam uktam
translated: Why should not the prima facie view be just as it is stated in the commentary? Here this is said.

original: tādṛśo hyatideśo yat āśaṅkāyā ādhikye sati parihārasya samānatvam /🔽yadyāśaṅkāyāṃ na viśeṣastarhi pūrveṇaiva parihṛtatvātprācīnanyāyātideśanamanarthakaṃ syāt /
analyzed: tādṛśaḥ hi atideśaḥ yat āśaṅkāyāḥ ādhikye sati parihārasya samāna tvam  yadi āśaṅkāyām na viśeṣaḥ tarhi pūrveṇa eva parihṛta tvāt prācīna nyāya atideśanam anarthakam syāt
translated: For it is a restatement of that kind, where, when there is an increase in doubt, the solution is the same.🔽If there is no difference in the doubt, then, since it has already been refuted by the previous [solution], the restatement of the old method would be pointless.

analyzed: pratyudāharaṇam śaṅkā parihāre śāstra aparyavasāna prasaṅgāt
translated: Because, in the case of doubt and solution by way of counterexample, there would be the undesirable consequence of the impossibility of the conclusion of the scripture.

original: yadi ca parihāro 'viśeṣito na syātkathaṃ tarhyata evetyatideśa iti mandavyutpādanārthamidamuktam /
analyzed: yadi ca parihāraḥ viśeṣitaḥ na syāt katham tarhi atas eva iti atideśaḥ iti manda vyutpādana artham idam uktam
translated: And if the answer were not to be stated without distinction, then how could there be the extension from this very [reason]? This is said for the purpose of instructing the slow-witted.

analyzed: bhāṣye pi asya sarvasya api svīkāra artham prasiddheḥ iti āha
translated: In the commentary also, for the purpose of accepting all of this, it is said because of the well-known meaning.

analyzed: liṅgam iti
translated: He says the mark for the purpose of extension.

analyzed: liṅgam balavat eva syāt
translated: The mark would be strong indeed.

analyzed: hariḥ iti vakṣyamāṇam siṃhāvalokana nyāyena atra api sambaddhyate
translated: Hari is to be stated, and is connected here also by the method of the lion's gaze.

analyzed: tena eva śabdasya sambandhaḥ
translated: By that, the word eva (only) is connected.

analyzed: athavā sautrasya eva śabdasya anuvādena balavat iti vyākhyānam
translated: Or, by way of restating the word eva (only) in the sutra, the explanation is strong.🔽Understood from the word itself.

analyzed: śabdāt eva pramitaḥ iti yathā
translated: Like that.

analyzed: yatas tasmāt iti adhyāhāryam
translated: Yataḥ (from which) is to be supplied.

analyzed: tatas ca ayam arthaḥ
translated: And then this is the meaning.

analyzed: hariḥ eva atra prāṇaḥ syāt
translated: Hari alone should be the prāṇa here.

original: kutaḥ / yato 'tra vaiṣṇavaṃ liṅgaṃ śrūyate tasmāt /
analyzed: kutas yatas tra vaiṣṇavam liṅgam śrūyate tasmāt
translated: Why? Because here the mark of Viṣṇu is heard, therefore.

analyzed: śrīḥ ca te lakṣmīḥ ca patnī nayau
translated: And Śrī and Lakṣmī are your two wives.

original: iti sannihitavākye śrūyamāṇasya śrīlakṣmīpatitvasya manasāpyanyatrāśakyacintanasya balavattvāditi /🔽nanūktaṃ prāṇaśrutirapi niravakāśā /
analyzed: iti sannihita vākye śrūyamāṇasya śrī lakṣmīpati tvasya manasā api anyatra aśakya cintanasya balavat tvāt iti 🔽nanu uktam prāṇa śrutiḥ api niravakāśā
translated: Because the being the lord of Śrī and Lakṣmī, which is heard in the nearby sentence, which cannot be thought of anywhere else even mentally, is strong.

analyzed: śabda pravṛtti nimittasya prāṇana ādi hetu tvasya anvaya vyatirekābhyām mukhye dṛṣṭa tvāt parameśvare tad abhāvāt iti atra api etat eva uttaram
translated: The same answer applies here also, that the reason for the application of the word is seen primarily in the cause of breathing, etc., by concomitance and non-concomitance, and that is absent in the Supreme Lord.

analyzed: prāṇana ādi hetutva liṅgam prāṇa śabda pravṛtti nimittaḥ dharmaḥ iti yāvat
translated: The reason of being the cause of breathing, etc., is the quality that is the reason for the application of the word breath, that is all.

original: harāveva mukhyaṃ syānna mukhya iti / /🔽kuto jīvanādihetutvaṃ harau mukhyam /
analyzed: harau eva mukhyam syāt na mukhye iti  kutas jīvana ādi hetu tvam harau mukhyam
translated: It would be primary only in Hari, not primary.

analyzed: anvaya vyatirekayoḥ abhāvāt iti atas āha prerakaḥ iti
translated: How is the being the cause of living, etc. primary in Hari? Because of the absence of concomitance and non-concomitance. To this he says the impeller.

analyzed: sya api yat hariḥ
translated: Hari is the impeller of this also.

analyzed: asya jīvana ādeḥ mukhya adhīna tayā pratītasya api iti apeḥ arthaḥ
translated: The word api means that even this living, etc., is known to be dependent on the primary.

analyzed: yat yasmāt śrutaḥ iti śeṣaḥ
translated: Yat means because, this is the remainder.

analyzed: ayam arthaḥ
translated: This is the meaning.

analyzed: mā bhūtām anvaya vyatirekau īśvarasya jīvana ādi hetutā sādhakau
translated: Let there be no concomitance and non-concomitance to prove the Supreme Lord as the cause of living, etc.

analyzed: tathā api śruti balāt setsyati
translated: Nevertheless, it will be established by the power of the śruti.

analyzed: na hi anvaya vyatirekau eva kāraṇa tāyām pramāṇam
translated: For concomitance and non-concomitance are not the only means of knowing causality.

original: tathā sati svargādāvagnihotrādeḥ kāraṇatā na syāditi /
analyzed: tathā sati svarga ādau agnihotra ādeḥ kāraṇatā na syāt iti
translated: If that were so, the agnihotra, etc. would not be the cause of heaven, etc.

original: tarhi pramāṇadvayabalād dvayorapi jīvanādihetutvena kuto harāveva tanmukhyamiti ca na vācyam /
analyzed: tarhi pramāṇa dvaya balāt dvayoḥ api jīvana ādi hetutvena kutas harau eva tat mukhyam iti ca na vācyam
translated: Then, it should not be said that, since both are the cause of life, etc. by the power of the two means of knowledge, how is that primary only in Hari?

original: yato 'sya mukhyasyāpi hariḥ prerakaḥ śrūyata iti /
analyzed: yatas sya mukhyasya api hariḥ prerakaḥ śrūyate iti
translated: Because it is heard that Hari is the impeller of this primary one also.

analyzed: mukhye katham na mukhyam jīvana ādi hetu tvam iti asya api etat eva uttaram
translated: This is the very answer to the question: How is the being the cause of life, etc. not primary in the primary one?

analyzed: nahi para preraṇayā bhavat tasmin mukhyam iti sambhavati iti
translated: For it is not possible that what is done by the prompting of another is primary in that.

original: athavā jīvanādihetutāsādhanāya yadanvayavyatirekānuvidhāyitvaṃ liṅgamuktaṃ tadviṣṇupakṣa eva mukhyaṃ syāt /
analyzed: athavā jīvana ādi hetutā sādhanāya yat anvaya vyatireka anuvidhāyi tvam liṅgam uktam tat viṣṇu pakṣe eva mukhyam syāt
translated: Or else, the reason stated, namely, being in conformity with positive and negative concomitance, for proving the being the cause of life, etc., would be primary only in the case of Vishnu.

analyzed: na mukhya pakṣe iti yojyam
translated: It should be connected as: not in the primary case.

analyzed: ubhayatra hetum āha prerakaḥ iti
translated: He states the reason in both cases with the impeller etc.

analyzed: yathā vāyu vikāra niṣṭhā anvaya vyatirekau tasya mukhya śarīra tvāt mukhya viṣayau aṅgīkriyete
translated: Just as positive and negative concomitance, which are based on the modifications of air, are accepted as having the primary body as their primary object,

original: tathāsya mukhyasyāpi hariḥ preraka iti tadviṣayāviti /
analyzed: tathā asya mukhyasya api hariḥ prerakaḥ iti tad viṣayau iti
translated: in the same way, Hari is the impeller of this primary one also. Therefore, they have that as their object.

analyzed: mukhye na mukhyam liṅgam iti asya api etat upapādakam
translated: This is the explanation of the statement: The reason is not primary in the primary one.

analyzed: ananyathā asiddha anvaya vyatirekau hi kāraṇa kḷptim kurvate
translated: For positive and negative concomitance, which are not otherwise established, bring about the establishment of the cause.

analyzed: na ca iha tathā asti
translated: And that is not so here.

analyzed: yatas parameśvara avasthānam eva jīvana kāraṇam
translated: For the existence of the Supreme Lord is the cause of life.

analyzed: mukhyaḥ tu tad āyattaḥ tad śarīra rūpaḥ tasmin avasthite vatiṣṭhate nirgate nirgacchati iti
translated: The primary one, however, depends on that, is of the form of His body. When He abides, it abides. When He departs, it departs.

analyzed: saṃvadati imam sarvam api artham śrutiḥ
translated: The Veda declares all this meaning.

original: na prāṇena nāpānena martyo jīvati kaścana /
analyzed: na prāṇena na apānena martyaḥ jīvati kaścana
translated: No mortal lives by the outgoing breath or the ingoing breath,

analyzed: itareṇa tu jīvanti yasmin etau upāśritau
translated: but by the other one in whom these two rest.

analyzed: iti evaṃjātīyakā  evam eva yuktayā ānukūlya parihārāya api liṅgam
translated: Such are the statements.

analyzed: ityādikam eva yojanīyam iti
translated: In the same way, the indicative power should be connected with the avoidance of contradiction with the reasoning.🔽Thus, statements beginning with Therefore, the Self is to be realized through the scriptures should be connected in this way.

analyzed: atra kecid
translated: Here some quote:

original: prāṇasya prāṇaṃ prāṇabandhanaṃ hi somya manaḥ' /🔽iti codāharanti /
analyzed: prāṇasya prāṇam prāṇa bandhanam hi somya manaḥ  iti ca udāharanti
translated: The life of the life of the breath is the mind, my dear.

analyzed: tat ayuktam iti apare
translated: Others say that is not correct.

analyzed: śabda bhedāt prakaraṇa vaśāt ca saṃśaya anupapatteḥ
translated: Because of the difference in words and the context, doubt is not possible.

original: yathā pituḥ piteti prayoge 'nyaḥ pitā ṣaṣṭhīnirdiṣyo 'nyaḥ prathamānirdiṣyaḥ pitāmaha iti gamyate /
analyzed: yathā pituḥ pitā iti prayoge nyaḥ pitā ṣaṣṭhī nirdiṣyaḥ nyaḥ prathamā nirdiṣyaḥ pitāmahaḥ iti gamyate
translated: Just as in the usage father of the father, another father is indicated by the sixth case, and another indicated by the first case is the grandfather,

original: tadvatprāṇasya prāṇamiti śabdabhedātprāṇādanyaḥ prāṇasya prāṇa iti niścīyate /
analyzed: tadvat prāṇasya prāṇam iti śabda bhedāt prāṇāt anyaḥ prāṇasya prāṇaḥ iti niścīyate
translated: so because of the difference in words in the life of the life of the breath, it is ascertained that the life of the breath is different from the breath.

original: nahi sa eva tasyeti bhedanirdeśo bhavati /
analyzed: nahi saḥ eva tasya iti bheda nirdeśaḥ bhavati
translated: For it is not that the same thing is indicated by a different name.

original: yasya ca prakaraṇe yo nirdiśyate nāmāntareṇāpi sa eva tatprakaraṇanirdiṣya iti gamyate /
analyzed: yasya ca prakaraṇe yaḥ nirdiśyate nāma antareṇa api saḥ eva tad prakaraṇa nirdiṣyaḥ iti gamyate
translated: And that which is indicated by a different name in the context of something, it is understood that it is to be indicated in that context.

analyzed: yathā jyotiṣyoma adhikāre vasante vasante jyotiṣā yajeta
translated: Just as in the context of the Jyotiṣṭoma, in the statement 'One should sacrifice with the Jyotiṣ compound in spring',

analyzed: iti atra jyotiḥ śabdaḥ jyotiṣyoma viṣayaḥ bhavati
translated: the word 'jyotiḥ' refers to the Jyotiṣṭoma.

original: tathā parasya brahmaṇaḥ prakaraṇeprāṇabandhanaṃ hi somya manaḥ' /
analyzed: tathā parasya brahmaṇaḥ prakaraṇe prāṇa bandhanam hi somya manaḥ
translated: Similarly, in the context of the supreme Brahman, in the statement 'The mind is indeed bound by the vital breath, O dear one',

analyzed: iti śrutaḥ prāṇa śabdaḥ vāyu vikāra mātram katham avagamayet
translated: how could the word 'prāṇa' heard here convey just the modification of air?

analyzed: atas saṃśaya aviṣaya tvāt na etat udāharaṇam yuktam
translated: Therefore, because it is not the object of doubt, this is not a proper example.🔽But in the statement beginning 'O Prastārin, which deity is connected with the Prastāva?', it is heard:

original: kintuprastotaryā devatā prastāvamanvāyattetyupakramya śrūyatekatamā sā devatā' / iti /
analyzed: kintu prastotar yā devatā prastāvam anvāyattā iti upakramya śrūyate katamā sā devatā iti
translated: 'Which is that deity?'

analyzed: prāṇaḥ iti ha uvāca
translated: He said: 'Prāṇa.'

original: sarvāṇi ha vā imāni bhūtāni prāṇamevābhisaṃviśanti /
analyzed: sarvāṇi ha vai imāni bhūtāni prāṇam eva abhisaṃviśanti
translated: For all these beings enter into Prāṇa itself,

analyzed: prāṇam abhyujjihate sā eṣā devatā prastāvam anvāyattā
translated: and rise up from Prāṇa. This deity is connected with the Prastāva.

analyzed: iti etat udāharaṇa vākyam iti
translated: This is the exemplifying statement.

analyzed: etat api ayuktam
translated: This is also improper.

analyzed: saṃśaya pūrvapakṣayoḥ anutthānāt
translated: Because doubt and the prima facie view do not arise.

original: nanu prāṇabandhanaṃ hi somya manaḥ'prāṇasya prāṇam' /
analyzed: nanu prāṇa bandhanam hi somya manaḥ prāṇasya prāṇam
translated: ‘Verily, the mind, my dear, is bound by the lifebreath; the lifebreath is the life of the lifebreath’ (Ch .🔽

analyzed: iti ca evamādau brahma viṣayaḥ prāṇa śabdaḥ dṛśyate
translated: But in such passages as, ‘Verily, the mind, my dear, is bound by the vital breath,’ and ‘The vital breath of the vital breath,’ the word ‘vital breath’ is seen to refer to Brahman.

analyzed: vāyu vikāre tu prasiddhaḥ loka vedayoḥ
translated: But in the modifications of the vital air, it is well known in the Veda and in ordinary speech.

analyzed: atas prāṇa śabdena katarasya upādānam iti bhavati saṃśayaḥ
translated: Therefore, there arises the doubt as to which is meant by the word ‘vital breath.’

analyzed: mā evam
translated: This is not so.

analyzed: vāyu vikāre devatā śabdasya prastāva mantra āyatta tvasya ca asambhavāt
translated: Because the word ‘deity’ and the dependence on the Prastāva-hymn are impossible in the modification of the vital air.

analyzed: cetanasya hi devatā śabdaḥ mantra adhiṣṭhānam
translated: For the word ‘deity’ is appropriate for the conscious, and the basis of the mantra is not the modification of the vital air.

analyzed: ca upapannam
translated: This is proper.

original: kiñcātra bhūtānāṃ saṃveśanamudgamanaṃ ca pārameśvaraṃ karma pratīyate /
analyzed: kiñca atra bhūtānām saṃveśanam udgamanam ca pārameśvaram karma pratīyate
translated: Moreover, here the entering into and coming out of the beings is understood to be the supreme Lord’s action.

analyzed: tena pūrvavat tad grahaṇam eva yuktam
translated: Therefore, as before, it is proper to take it as referring to Him.

analyzed: kutas pūrvapakṣasya avakāśaḥ
translated: How then is there room for the prima facie view?

original: yato vā imāni bhūtānīti hi sarvaprāṇinikāyasya brahmaṇyeva saṃveśanaṃ tata evodgamanaṃ ca śrāvayati /
analyzed: yatas vai imāni bhūtāni iti hi sarva prāṇi nikāyasya brahmaṇi eva saṃveśanam tatas eva udgamanam ca śrāvayati
translated: Because it declares that the entire group of living beings enters into Brahman itself and comes out of Him alone.

original: suptijāgarayorapi satā somya tadā sampanno bhavati' / ityādi / /
analyzed: supti jāgarayoḥ api satā somya tadā sampannaḥ bhavati ityādi
translated: ‘When he is asleep, my dear, then he becomes united with the Sat.’ Thus, etc.

analyzed: nanu mukhye pi prāṇe saṃveśana udgamane dṛśyete
translated: But are not entering into and coming out of seen even in the principal vital air?

original: yadā vai puruṣaḥ svapiti prāṇaṃ tarhi vāgapyeti prāṇaṃ cakṣuḥ prāṇaṃ manaḥ prāṇaṃ śrotram /
analyzed: yadā vai puruṣaḥ svapiti prāṇam tarhi vāc apyeti prāṇam cakṣuḥ prāṇam manaḥ prāṇam śrotram
translated: When a man sleeps, then speech goes to the breath, the eye to the breath, the mind to the breath, the ear to the breath.

analyzed: yadā pratibuddhayate prāṇāt eva adhi punar jāyante iti
translated: When he awakes, they are born again from the breath alone.

analyzed: evam tarhi saṃśayaḥ syāt na pūrvapakṣaḥ
translated: If so, then there would be doubt, not the prima facie view.

analyzed: sama bala tvāt
translated: Because they are of equal strength.

analyzed: kiñcayadāḥ vai puruṣaḥ
translated: Moreover, when a man sleeps.

analyzed: iti śrutiḥ api mukhya prāṇa viṣayā iti kutas vagatam
translated: How is it known that even the Vedic text is about the primary breath?

analyzed: svāpa kāle prāṇa vṛttau a parilupyamānāyām indriya vṛttayaḥ parilupyante
translated: When a man sleeps, the functions of the senses cease when the activity of the primary breath is about to cease.

original: prabodhakāle ca prādurbhavantīti pratyakṣānuguṇyānmukhyaprāṇaviṣayatvaṃ prābalyaṃ ca niścīyata iti cenna /
analyzed: prabodha kāle ca prādurbhavanti iti pratyakṣa ānuguṇyāt mukhya prāṇa viṣaya tvam prābalyam ca niścīyate iti ced na
translated: And they appear when he awakes. The fact that it is about the primary breath and its strength is ascertained because it is in accordance with perception. If this is argued, it is not so.

analyzed: indriyāṇām atīndriyāṇām mukhyaprāṇe saṃveśāt gamanayoḥ apratyakṣa tvāt
translated: Because the movement of the senses, which are beyond the senses, into the primary breath is not perceptible.

analyzed: anumānam astu iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that there may be inference, it is not so.

analyzed: paramātmanaḥ u pi a parilupyamānasya vidyamāna tvena avadāraṇa anupapatteḥ
translated: Because it is not possible to cite an example when the supreme self, which is not about to cease, is present.

original: kiñcendriyāṇāṃ mukhyaprāṇe saṃveśodgamanayoḥ śrutyanumānasiddhatve 'pi kimāyātaṃ savarbhūtasambandhinostayoḥ indriyasāratvāt bhūtānāṃ nāsaṅgatiriti 🔽cet /
analyzed: kiñca indriyāṇām mukhyaprāṇe saṃveśa udgamanayoḥ śruti anumāna siddha tve pi kim āyātam savar bhūta sambandhinoḥ tayoḥ indriya sāra tvāt bhūtānām nā asaṅgatiḥ iti  ced
translated: Moreover, even if the entering into and coming out of the senses from the chief vital air are established by scriptural inference, what has that to do with those two which belong to all the elements? If it be said that there is no incoherence because the elements are the essence of the senses,

analyzed: kim etat anumānam sambhāvānā vā
translated: what is this, inference or possibility?

analyzed: na ādyaḥ
translated: Not the first,

analyzed: vyāpti abhāvāt
translated: because there is no pervasion.

original: dvitīye tu śrutyanumābhāsamūlasambhāvanāmātreṇa śrutibādhayā pūrvapakṣa iti subhāṣitam /🔽nanvādityo 'nnaṃ codgīthapratihāradevate tāvadbrahmaṇo 'nye /
analyzed: dvitīye tu śruti anumā ābhāsa mūla sambhāvanā mātreṇa śruti bādhayā pūrvapakṣaḥ iti subhāṣitam  nanu ādityaḥ annam ca udgītha pratihāra devate tāvat brahmaṇaḥ nye
translated: But in the second case, it is well said that the prima facie view is based on the contradiction of the scriptural text by the mere possibility based on the fallacious scriptural inference.🔽But it may be argued that the sun and food, which are the deities of the Udgītha and Pratihāra, are certainly different from Brahman,

original: tatsāmyāmānyāt prāṇasyāpi na brahmatvamiti pūrvapakṣo 'stviti cenna /
analyzed: tad sāmya āmānyāt prāṇasya api na brahmatvam iti pūrvapakṣaḥ stu iti ced na
translated: and therefore, on account of their similarity, the vital air also is not Brahman. But this is not so.

analyzed: nirṇāyaka abhāve eva prāya pāṭhasya anusaraṇīya tvāt
translated: For the mere fact that the general statement is to be followed is due to the absence of a decisive factor.

analyzed: spaṣṭam ca atra pārameśvaram karma iti uktam
translated: And it has been clearly stated here that this is the work of the Supreme Lord.

original: anyathā chatracāmarādyasādhāraṇaliṅgasadbhāve 'pi samāntasannidhimātreṇa rājā na rājā syāt /
analyzed: anyathā chatra cāmara ādi asādhāraṇa liṅga sadbhāve samā anta sannidhi mātreṇa rājā na rājā syāt
translated: Otherwise, even if there were the presence of such uncommon marks as the umbrella, the chowrie, etc., the king would not be a king merely by the proximity of the attendant.

analyzed: katham ca avadhāritam ādityaḥ nnam ca na brahma iti
translated: And how is it ascertained that the sun and food are not Brahman?

original: śrūyate hi tatrāpisarvāṇi ha vā imāni bhūtānyādityamuccaiḥ santaṃ gāyanti' /
analyzed: śrūyate hi tatra api sarvāṇi ha vai imāni bhūtāni ādityam uccais santam gāyanti
translated: For it is heard there also: 'All these beings sing the praises of the sun as the highest.'

analyzed: ityādi brahma liṅgam  annam eva pratiharamāṇāni
translated: This is a mark of Brahman.🔽'Taking food itself as the oblation.'

analyzed: iti tu prāya pāṭhāt upajīvana artham grāhyam
translated: But this should be accepted for the sake of sustenance due to the general rule.

analyzed: tasmāt saṃśaya pūrvapakṣayoḥ asambhavāt na idam udāharaṇam
translated: Therefore, this is not an example due to the impossibility of doubt and prima facie view.

analyzed: kintu nyāya vidām agresareṇa ananta veda vidā bhāṣyakṛtā upāttam eva iti siddham
translated: But it is established that it was only taken up by the author of the commentary, who was a leader among the knowers of logic and an infinite knower of the Vedas.
VIII. The section on the light.

analyzed: jyotiḥ caraṇa abhidhānāt
translated: And the light, because of the mention of the feet.

analyzed: jyotiścaraṇa abhidhānāt iti atra adhikā āśaṅkā bhāṣye eva darśitā
translated: In the passage 'And the light, because of the mention of the feet,' an additional doubt is shown in the commentary itself.

analyzed: yat āha agni sūkta tvāt iti
translated: When he says 'because of being a hymn to Agni.'

analyzed: iti śrīmat nyāyasudhāyām prāṇa adhikaraṇam
translated: Thus ends the chapter on the vital breaths in the commentary called 'Naya-sudha.'
IX. The section on the Gayatri.

analyzed: atha śrīmat nyāyasudhāyām gāyatṛyadhikaraṇam
translated: Now, in the commentary called 'Naya-sudha,' the section on the Gayatri.

analyzed: tena vaktavya abhāvāt uttaram gāyatṛya dhikaraṇam eva vivriyate
translated: Since there is nothing to be said after that, the section on the Gayatri is being explained.

analyzed: adhiveda gata aśeṣa nāmnām upalakṣaṇasya vedamātuḥ traivarṇika dvitīya janmani jananyāḥ gāyatṛyāḥ
translated: The Gayatri, the mother of the Vedas, is the designation of all the names found in the Vedas, and is the mother of the second birth of the three varnas,

original: prādhānyena tannāmnaḥ samanvayaṃ pratipādayituṃ sūtram chandobhidhānaśceti cenna
analyzed: prādhānyena tad nāmnaḥ samanvayam pratipādayitum sūtram chandaḥ abhidhānaḥ ca iti ced na
translated: In order to primarily establish the connection of that name, the sutra is: And because of the mention of the meter, if it is said no, then not.

original: tathā cetorpaṇanigadāttathā hi daśarnamiti //🔽oṃ chandobhidhānānneti cenna tathā cetorpaṇanigadāttathā hi darśanāt oṃ //
analyzed: tathā ca itas ūrpaṇa nigadāt tathā hi daśarnam iti  om chandaḥ abhidhānāt na iti ced na tathā cetas arpaṇa nigadāt tathā hi darśanāt om
translated: Because of the statement of the fixing of the mind in that way, it is seen thus.

original: chando 'bhidhānān neti cen na tathā ceto'rpaṇanigadāt tathā hi darśanam / / / /
analyzed: chandaḥ abhidhānāt na iti ced na tathā cetaḥ ūrpaṇa nigadāt tathā hi darśanam
translated: If it is said that it is not because of the mention of the meter, it is not so, because of the statement of the fixing of the mind in that way, it is seen thus.

analyzed: chandogāḥ paṭhanti
translated: The Chandogas recite:

analyzed: gāyatrī vai idam bhūtam ityādi
translated: This world is indeed the Gayatri, and so on.

analyzed: tatra saṃśayaḥ
translated: There is a doubt there.

analyzed: kim gāyatrī brahma kiṃvā
translated: Is the Gayatri Brahman or

analyzed: idam bhūtam ityādi
translated: This world, and so on?

analyzed: tatra saṃśayaḥ
translated: There is a doubt there.

analyzed: kim gāyatrī brahma kim vā
translated: Is the Gayatri Brahman or

analyzed: varṇa samāveśa lakṣaṇaḥ mantraḥ iti
translated: a mantra characterized by the inclusion of syllables?

analyzed: mantraḥ eva iti tāvat prāptam
translated: It is first established that it is a mantra.

analyzed: kutas
translated: Why is that?

analyzed: gāyatrī śabdasya chandaḥ viśeṣe prasiddha tvāt
translated: Because the word Gayatri is well-known in the sense of a particular meter.

analyzed: nanu etat api pūrva nyāyena eva parihṛtam iti atas bhyadhika āśaṅkayā pūrvapakṣayati nitya tvāt iti
translated: But this too has been refuted by the same reasoning as before. Therefore, with an additional doubt, he presents the prima facie view with nityatvāt (because of eternality).

analyzed: nitya tvāt eva śabdasya tad svabhāvaḥ katham hareḥ
translated: How can that be the nature of Hari just because of the eternality of the word?

analyzed: bhavet ākāśa ādi śabdānām paramātma para tvam
translated: The words ākāśa (space), etc., may refer to the Supreme Self.

analyzed: anya gatasya śabda pravṛtti nimittasya īśvara paratantra tvena tatra mukhya vṛtti ayogāt
translated: Because the reason for the application of the word to something else is subordinate to God, so it is not proper for it to be used primarily in that sense.

analyzed: yadi api vivara tva ādikam kāraṇataḥ svarūpataḥ pi anāgantukam
translated: Although spaciousness, etc., are not adventitious either by cause or by nature,

original: tathāpi dharmiṇa evākāśāderutpattivināśavato janmasthitilayeṣvīśvarādhīnatve dharmasyāpi tathābhāvo 'varjanīyaḥ /
analyzed: tathā api dharmiṇaḥ eva ākāśa ādeḥ utpatti vināśavataḥ janma sthiti layeṣu īśvara adhīna tve dharmasya api tathābhāvaḥ varjanīyaḥ
translated: still, when the substratum, space, etc., which have origination and destruction, are dependent on God for birth, continuance, and dissolution, it is unavoidable that the attribute also should be so.

analyzed: na ca ākāśaḥ na ādi nityaḥ iti yuktam
translated: And it is not proper to say that space is beginningless and eternal.

analyzed: ātmanaḥ ākāśaḥ sambhūtaḥ ityādi śruti virodhāt  yaḥ tu anādiḥ vā ayam ākāśaḥ
translated: Because that is contradicted by the Vedic text, Space was born from the Self, etc.

original: ityukto 'vyākṛtākāśaḥ so 'nādinityo 'pi na tatra pūrvapakṣiṇo vivakṣitaḥ /
analyzed: iti uktaḥ vyākṛta ākāśaḥ saḥ na ādi nityaḥ na tatra pūrvapakṣiṇaḥ vivakṣitaḥ
translated: But that unmanifested space which is said to be beginningless and eternal is not intended by the pūrvapakṣin (in the Sūtra).

analyzed: bhūta prakaraṇa tvāt
translated: Because the topic is about the elements.

analyzed: na ca evam prakṛte sambhavati
translated: And it is not possible in the present case.

analyzed: gāyatrī śabda pravṛtti nimittam hi gāna trāṇa kartṛ tvam
translated: For the reason for the application of the word gāyatrī is the quality of being the doer of singing and protecting.

analyzed: yathā āha śrutiḥ
translated: As the Śruti says:

original: gāyati ca trāyate ca tasmādgāyatrīti tatra gānakartṛtvaṃ nāma arthapratipādakatvam /
analyzed: gāyati ca trāyate ca tasmāt gāyatrī iti tatra gāna kartṛ tvam nāma artha pratipādaka tvam
translated: It sings and protects, therefore it is gāyatrī. There, the quality of being the doer of singing is the quality of conveying the meaning.

analyzed: trāṇa kartṛ tvam ca adhyetṛṇām pāpāt rakṣaṇa śaktiḥ
translated: And the quality of being the protector of the students is the power to save them from sin.

original: tadubhayamapi kathaṃ kena prakāreṇa hareḥ adhīnaṃ syāt /
analyzed: tat ubhayam api katham kena prakāreṇa hareḥ adhīnam syāt
translated: In what way, by what means, are both of these dependent on Hari?

analyzed: na kena api
translated: Not by any means.

original: tathā hi /🔽vivaratvādivaddharmiṇā sahaiva tadadhīnaṃ vā syāt /
analyzed: tathā hi  vivara tva ādi vat dharmiṇā saha eva tad adhīnam vā syāt
translated: Because it is like this.🔽It would be dependent on that either along with the substratum like the quality of being a hole,

analyzed: dhvani vat svayam eva vā
translated: or by itself like sound.

analyzed: na ādyaḥ
translated: Not the first.

analyzed: dharmiṇaḥ śabdasya vedasya nitya tvāt anādi tvāt ca
translated: Because the substratum, the word, the Veda, is eternal and beginningless.

original: dharmiṇa eva nityatve tena saha parādhīnatvaṃ kuta iti evārthaḥ /
analyzed: dharmiṇaḥ eva nitya tve tena saha para adhīna tvam kutas iti eva arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: if the substratum itself is eternal, how can it be dependent on another?

analyzed: na dvitīyaḥ
translated: Not the second.

analyzed: artha pratipādāna ādi śakteḥ tad svabhāva tvāt
translated: Because the power to convey meaning and so on is the nature of that.

analyzed: katham prasiddha bahula śabdānām ayathārtha tā
translated: How can words that are well-known in many ways be contrary to the true meaning?

original: kiñcākāśādivākye santi pārameśvarāṇi liṅgānīti yuktaṃ tatra tadāśrayaṇam /
analyzed: kiñca ākāśa ādi vākye santi pārameśvarāṇi liṅgāni iti yuktam tatra tad āśrayaṇam
translated: Moreover, in the statements about space etc. there are indications of the Supreme Lord, so it is proper to rely on them there.

original: nacātra tathāvidhaṃ kimapi paśyāmaḥ /🔽pratyutagāyatrī vā idaṃ sarvaṃ'vāgvai gāyatri' /
analyzed: na ca atra tathāvidham kim api paśyāmaḥ  pratyuta gāyatrī vai idam sarvam vāc vai gāyatri
translated: But we do not see anything of that kind here.

original: ityādayaḥ śabda eva prasiddhā bahavaḥ śabdāḥ śrūyante /🔽kathaṃ ca teṣāṃ /
analyzed: ityādayaḥ śabdaḥ eva prasiddhāḥ bahavaḥ śabdāḥ śrūyante  katham ca teṣām
translated: On the contrary, many well-known words are heard, such as This whole (universe) is indeed the Gāyatrī, Speech indeed is the Gāyatrī.🔽And how can their meaning be otherwise

analyzed: vinā balavat bādhaka upanipātena anyathārtha tā
translated: without the occurrence of a strong contradiction?

analyzed: anya artha tā kalpayitum yuktā
translated: It is proper to assume that it has another meaning.

analyzed: avyavasthā prasaṅgāt
translated: Because it would lead to the undesirable consequence of lack of system.

analyzed: na ca chandasaḥ sarva ātmaka tva anupapattiḥ
translated: And it is not impossible for the Chandas to be all-pervading.

original: brahmaṇo 'pi sāmyāt / /🔽nanviyameva gāyatrī vākyaśeṣe jyotiṣṭvena paṭhyate /
analyzed: brahmaṇaḥ pi sāmyāt  nanu iyam eva gāyatrī vākya śeṣe jyotiṣṭvena paṭhyate
translated: Because it is equally so for Brahman.🔽But this very Gāyatrī is recited as the light in the remainder of the sentence:

analyzed: atha yat atas parodivaḥ jyodiḥ dīpyate ityādinā
translated: That light which shines beyond this heaven, and so on.

analyzed: jyotiḥ ca pūrva adhikaraṇe brahma iti nirṇītam
translated: And light has been determined as Brahman in the previous section.

analyzed: mā evam
translated: Not so.

analyzed: pūrva adhikaraṇa udāhṛta vākya uktasya jyotiṣaḥ brahma tve pi atra tad anupapatteḥ
translated: Even if the light mentioned in the passage quoted in the previous section is Brahman, it is not possible here.

analyzed: tatra hi karṇa ādi vidūra tvam uktam
translated: For there it is said to be far away from the ears and so on.

original: atra punastadetaddṛṣṭaṃ ca śrutaṃ ceti tadviparītam /
analyzed: atra punar tat etat dṛṣṭam ca śrutam ca iti tad viparītam
translated: But here it is the opposite: This has been seen and heard.

original: yujyate ca jyotiriti padaṃ chandasi /🔽tatparyāyasyatejo vai brahmavarcasaṃ gāyatri' /🔽iti tejaḥśabdasya tatra darśanāt /🔽astu vāatha yadataḥparodivo jyotiḥ' /
analyzed: yujyate ca jyotiḥ iti padam chandasi  tat paryāyasya tejaḥ vai brahmavarcasam gāyatri  iti tejaḥ śabdasya tatra darśanāt  astu vā atha yat atas parā udivaḥ jyotiḥ
translated: And the word jyotiḥ (light) is appropriate in the Chandas.🔽Because the word tejas (light) is seen there as a synonym, as in Tejas indeed is Brahman-splendor, the Gāyatrī.

analyzed: iti uktam jyotiḥ brahma
translated: Or let it be that the light mentioned as That light which shines beyond this heaven is Brahman.

analyzed: tathā api gāyatrī chandaḥ eva
translated: Even so, Gāyatrī is only the Chandas.

analyzed: upadeśa bhedena bhinna prakaraṇa tvāt iti
translated: Because it has a different topic due to the difference in instruction.

original: athavātrāpyatha yadataḥparo diva iti vākyokte jyotiṣi sandehaḥ /
analyzed: athavā atra api atha yat atas paras divaḥ iti vākya ukte jyotiṣi sandehaḥ
translated: Or, even here, there is doubt regarding the light mentioned in the sentence beginning with What is beyond that, above this heaven?

analyzed: kim brahma uta anyat iti
translated: Is it Brahman or something else?

analyzed: upakrame gāyatrī śabda śravaṇāt anyat iti prāptam
translated: Since the word Gāyatrī is heard in the beginning, it is concluded to be something else.

analyzed: nanu gāyatrī śabdasya ākāśa ādi śabda vat īśvara paratva upapatteḥ kim anena iti atas nitya tvāt ityādinā abhyadhikā āśaṅkā iyam uktā iti
translated: But since the word Gāyatrī can be understood to refer to God, like the words space etc., what is the use of this? Therefore, the additional doubt expressed by because of eternality etc. is said to be stated.

analyzed: etad ācchādaka tvena adhikaraṇa tātparyam āha iti ced iti
translated: As a covering of this, the purport of the topic is stated as If this is said.

analyzed: iti ced tat hareḥ eva bāhulyāt śruti liṅgayoḥ
translated: If this is said, then that is of Hari alone, due to the abundance of Śruti and Liṅga.

analyzed: tatra brūmaḥ iti adhyāhāryam
translated: There, the sentence we say should be supplied.

original: tat jyotiḥprakaraṇaṃ gāyatrīprakaraṇaṃ ca harereva pratipādakam /
analyzed: tat jyotiḥ prakaraṇam gāyatrī prakaraṇam ca hareḥ eva pratipādakam
translated: That section on light and that section on Gāyatrī are the expounders of Hari alone.

analyzed: na ca gāyatrī pada virodhaḥ
translated: And there is no contradiction with the word Gāyatrī.

analyzed: yatas tat hareḥ eva vācakam
translated: Because that is the denoter of Hari alone.

analyzed: katham  yasmāt tat gāyatrī pada pravṛtti nimittam mukhyataḥ hareḥ eva
translated: How?🔽Because that is the primary reason for the application of the word Gāyatrī to Hari alone.

analyzed: anya gatam ca hareḥ eva adhīnam
translated: And that which is in others is dependent on Hari alone.

analyzed: na ca jyotiṣaḥ brahma tve dṛṣṭa tva ādi anupapattiḥ
translated: And in the case of light being Brahman, the non-applicability of being seen etc. is not so.

analyzed: yatas tat adhiṣṭhāna ādi dvārā karṇa ādi vidūrasya eva hareḥ upapadyate
translated: Because that is possible only for Hari who is far away from the ears etc. through the medium of His abode etc.

analyzed: na ca upadeśa bheda anupapattiḥ
translated: And there is no inconsistency in the difference of teachings.

original: yatastaddivaḥ paratvaṃ divi sthitatvaṃ ca vivakṣābhedāddherereva yujyate /
analyzed: yatas tat divaḥ paratvam divi sthita tvam ca vivakṣā bhedāt hereḥ eva yujyate
translated: Because that being beyond heaven and being situated in heaven are possible only for Hari Himself due to the difference of intention.

analyzed: kutas etat
translated: Where is this from?

analyzed: śruti liṅgayoḥ bāhulyāt
translated: From the abundance of Vedic texts and indications.

analyzed: tathā hitataḥ jyāyān ca pūruṣaḥ
translated: Thus, The Person is greater than heaven and greater than that.

analyzed: yat vā etat brahmayaḥ etām eva brahma upaniṣadam veda
translated: That which is Brahman and One who knows this Upanishad of Brahman.

analyzed: iti śrutayaḥ  liṅgāni ca gāna trāṇa kartṛ tvam
translated: These are the Vedic texts.🔽And the indications are: being the agent of singing and protecting,

analyzed: bhūta ādi pāda tvam
translated: being the foot of the elements etc.,

analyzed: etām eva na atiśīyante
translated: They do not go beyond this.

analyzed: iti sarva uttama tvam ityādīni
translated: These and other indications of being the highest of all.

analyzed: atas eva śruti liṅga bāhulyāt tat prasiddha bahula śabda jātam api
translated: For this very reason, even the multitude of words well-known as belonging to that (Upanishad),

analyzed: hareḥ eva iti
translated: belong to Hari alone.

original: nanūktamatra nityā gāyatrī pravṛttinimittaṃ ca tatsvabhāvaḥ /🔽tatkathaṃ hareradhīnamityata āha tādṛśatvācceti //
analyzed: nanu uktam atra nityā gāyatrī pravṛtti nimittam ca tad svabhāvaḥ  tat katham hareḥ adhīnam iti atas āha tādṛśa tvāt ca iti
translated: But it has been said here that the eternal Gayatri is the cause of engagement and that is of its own nature.🔽How then is it dependent on Hari? To this he says and because of being of that nature.

analyzed: tādṛśa tvāt ca tad śakteḥ
translated: And because of being of that nature, of that power...

analyzed: pūrveṇa sambandhaḥ
translated: The connection is with the previous (verse).

analyzed: hetu samuccaye caśabdaḥ
translated: The word ca (and) is for the cumulative force of the reason.

analyzed: tādṛśī khalu īśvara śaktiḥ
translated: For such indeed is the power of the Lord.

analyzed: yad nitya anitya svabhāva asvabhāva sarva viṣayā
translated: Which has as its object the eternal, the non-eternal, the nature, and the natureless.

analyzed: anyathā sarva īśvara tva hāneḥ
translated: Otherwise, because of the loss of being the Lord of all.

original: atha tasyāḥ śakteḥ kiṃ śakyamiti cet /
analyzed: atha tasyāḥ śakteḥ kim śakyam iti ced
translated: If it is asked what is possible for that power,

analyzed: tad svarūpa sattā eva
translated: its own existence is that.

analyzed: anādi siddhā sā iti ced
translated: If it is said that it is established from beginningless time,

analyzed: satyam
translated: it is true.

analyzed: anādi īśvara śaktayā eva iti vadāmaḥ
translated: We say it is only by the beginningless power of God.

analyzed: uktam ca atra pramāṇam iti
translated: And the proof has been stated here.

analyzed: apare tu jyotiḥ caraṇa abhidhānāt ityādi ekam eva adhikaraṇam vyācakṣate
translated: But others explain only one section beginning with because of the mention of the feet of the light and so on.

analyzed: tat ayuktam
translated: That is incorrect.

original: atha yadataḥ paro divo jyotiriti vākye caraṇābhidhānābhāvāt /
analyzed: atha yat atas paras divaḥ jyotiḥ iti vākye caraṇa abhidhāna abhāvāt
translated: Because in the sentence That light which is beyond this heaven there is no mention of feet.

analyzed: caraṇa abhidhānāt ityasya pāda abhidhānāt iti arthaḥ iti ced
translated: If it is argued that because of the mention of the feet means because of the mention of the feet,

analyzed: bhūta ādi pāda vyapadeśa upapatteḥ ca evam
translated: and because the designation of the feet of beings and so on is appropriate in this way.

original: upadeśabhedān neti cen nobhayasminn apy avirodhāt / / / /
analyzed: upadeśa bhedāt na iti ced na ubhayasmin api avirodhāt
translated: If it is argued that it is not so because of the difference in instruction, it is not so, because there is no contradiction in both.

analyzed: evam tarhi bhūta ādi pāda vyapadeśa upapatteḥ ca evam iti punar uktam syāt
translated: If it is so, then it would be a repetition to say because the designation of the feet of beings and so on is appropriate in this way.

analyzed: na syāt
translated: It would not be so.

analyzed: tātparya bhedāt
translated: Because of the difference in purport.

analyzed: tathā hi
translated: For example,

analyzed: pūrvasmin vākye tāvān asya mahimā iti catuṣpād brahma nirdiṣyam
translated: in the previous sentence, the four-footed Brahman is indicated as His greatness is so much.

original: tatra yaccatuṣpado brahmaṇastripādasyāmṛtaṃ divīti dyusambandhirūpaṃ nirdiṣyam tadeveha dyusambandhātpratyabhijñāyate /
analyzed: tatra yat catuṣpadaḥ brahmaṇaḥ tri pādasya amṛtam divi iti dyu sambandhi rūpam nirdiṣyam tat eva iha dyu sambandhāt pratyabhijñāyate
translated: There, the Brahman which has four feet, and of which the immortal part is in heaven, which is to be indicated as connected with heaven, is recognized here as the same, because of its connection with heaven.

original: tatparityajya prākṛtaṃ jyotiḥ kalpayataḥ prakṛtahānāprakṛtaprakriye prasajyetāmityatrābhipreyate /
analyzed: tat parityajya prākṛtam jyotiḥ kalpayataḥ prakṛta hāna aprakṛta prakriye prasajyetām iti atra abhipreyate
translated: It is intended that if one were to abandon that and imagine an ordinary light, there would be the fault of abandoning the original and positing what is not original.

analyzed: tatra tu bhūta ādi pāda vyapadeśa balena prakṛtasya brahma tva upapādanam iti
translated: But there, the establishment of Brahman as the original is done by the force of the designation of the part beginning with bhūta.

analyzed: ucyate
translated: It is said:

original: evaṃ hi vyākuvartā prakṛtapratyabhijñānaṃ jyotiṣo brahmatve hetuḥ uttarā tu trisūtrī prakṛtasya brahmatvopapādiketyuktaṃ syāt /
analyzed: evam hi vyākuvartā prakṛta pratyabhijñānam jyotiṣaḥ brahma tve hetuḥ uttarā tu tri sūtrī prakṛtasya brahma tva upapādikā iti uktam syāt
translated: Thus, the recognition of the original would be stated as the reason for the light being Brahman, and the next three aphorisms would be stated as establishing the light as Brahman.

analyzed: tathā ca śruta hāna aśruta kalpane syātām
translated: And thus there would be the faults of abandoning what is directly stated and positing what is not directly stated.

analyzed: anyathā jyotiḥ pratyabhijñānāt iti eva brūyāt
translated: Otherwise, he would have simply said because of the recognition of the light.

original: laghu caivaṃ spaṣṭaṃ ca sūtraṃ syāt /
analyzed: laghu ca evam spaṣṭam ca sūtram syāt
translated: And thus the aphorism would be brief and clear.

analyzed: pāda abhidhānāt iti eva vā vadet
translated: Or he would have simply said because of the mention of the part.

analyzed: śruti anugamaḥ hi evam sati syāt iti uktam eva upapannam iti
translated: For in that case there would be conformity with the śruti. Thus what has been stated is reasonable.

analyzed: iti śrīmat nyāyasudhāyām gāyatṛyadhikaraṇam
translated: Thus ends the chapter on the Gāyatrī in the commentary Nyāyasudhā.

analyzed: atha śrīmat nyāyasudhāyām pāda antya prāṇa adhikaraṇam
translated: Now, in the glorious Nyāyasudhā, the last topic of the feet is the topic on the vital breath.

original: oṃ prāṇastathānugamāt oṃ //🔽nanvata eva prāṇa ityanenaivaitadgatārtham /
analyzed: om prāṇaḥ tathā anugamāt om  nanu atas eva prāṇe iti anena eva etat gatārtham
translated: Om. The vital breath, because of the subsequent cognition.🔽But isn't this already dealt with by the very statement it is the vital breath itself?

original: tā etāḥ śīrṣaṃcchriyaḥ śritā ityādivākyāntaraviṣayatvānneti cenna /
analyzed: tāḥ etāḥ śīrṣaṃ śriyaḥ śritāḥ ityādi vākya antara viṣaya tvāt na iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that it is not so because it is the subject of other statements beginning with these are the glories resting on the head, that is not so.

analyzed: ukta uttara tvāt
translated: Because the answer has already been given.

analyzed: abhyadhika āśaṅkā sadbhāvāt na iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that it is not so because there is a greater doubt, that is not so.

analyzed: a darśanāt
translated: Because it is not seen.

original: sadbhāve vā tadanantaramevārambhaṇīyatvādityato nirantarādhikaraṇasiddhāntanyāyopajīvyadhikāśaṅkayā pūrvapakṣamāha bāhulya iti //
analyzed: sadbhāve vā tad anantaram eva ārambhaṇīya tvāt iti atas nirantara adhikaraṇa siddhānta nyāya upajīvi adhika āśaṅkayā pūrvapakṣam āha bāhulye iti
translated: If it exists, then it should have been started immediately after that. Therefore, with a greater doubt that depends on the established reasoning of the immediately preceding topic, he presents the prima facie view with bahulye (in the abundance of scriptural statements and indications).

analyzed: bāhulye śruti liṅgayoḥ
translated: In the abundance of scriptural statements and indications,

analyzed: anyasya mukhya vācya tvam iti
translated: the other is the primary meaning.

original: pūrvādhikaraṇe hi gāyatṛyādyanyavāciśabdabāhulyasadbhāve 'pi śrutiliṅgabāhulyāśrayaṇena gāyatrī paramātmaiveti nirṇītam /
analyzed: pūrva adhikaraṇe hi gāyatṛ ya ādi anya vāci śabda bāhulya sadbhāve pi śruti liṅga bāhulya āśrayaṇena gāyatrī paramātmā eva iti nirṇītam
translated: In the previous topic, even though there is an abundance of words denoting other than the Gāyatrī, by relying on the abundance of scriptural statements and indications, it was determined that the Gāyatrī is the supreme self.

analyzed: asti ca atra api parakīya śruti liṅga bāhulyam
translated: And here too there is an abundance of scriptural statements and indications belonging to others.

analyzed: tathā hi
translated: To explain:

analyzed: cakṣuḥ ādibhiḥ saha pāṭhaḥ tāvat pradhānasya brahmaṇaḥ na upapadyate
translated: The simultaneous mention with the eyes etc. is not possible for the primary Brahman.

analyzed: na ca kiñcid atra brahmaṇaḥ jñāpakam asti
translated: And there is nothing here that indicates Brahman.

analyzed: yena a pradhāna prāya pāṭhasya apavādaḥ syāt
translated: By which there would be an exception to the recitation primarily of what is not primary.

analyzed: yujyate
translated: It is appropriate.

analyzed: ca indrajīva mukhya prāṇānām
translated: Of Indra, Jiva, and the principal life breaths.

analyzed: indrasya hasta adhiṣṭhātuḥ indriya tvāt
translated: Because Indra, the presiding deity of the hands, is a sense organ.

analyzed: jīvasya indriya janya phala āśraya tvāt
translated: Because Jiva is the abode of the fruits produced by the sense organs.

analyzed: mukhyasya ca sarva indriya svāmi tvāt
translated: And because the principal one is the lord of all the sense organs.

original: prāṇo vā ahamasmyaṣa itīndraśrutiḥ /🔽tā ahiṃsantetyādinoktāni prāṇavivādo /
analyzed: prāṇaḥ vai aham asmi aṣaḥ iti indra śrutiḥ  tāḥ ahiṃsanta ityādinā uktāni
translated: The Vedic text about Indra says I am the breath.🔽The dispute about the life breaths mentioned in the text beginning with They do not harm each other,

analyzed: dehāt utkramaṇa praveśau
translated: The going out and entering from the body,

analyzed: tatas dehapāta utthāne
translated: Then the rising up and falling down of the body,

analyzed: prāṇa saṃvādaḥ ca iti mukhya prāṇa liṅgāni
translated: And the dialogue of the life breaths - these are the indications of the principal life breath.

original: tathā taṃ śataṃ varṣāṇyabhyārcaditi śatāyuṣṭvaṃ prāṇo vaṃśa iti cakṣurādīnprati vaṃśatvamiti jīvaliṅgāni /🔽sati caivamanyadīyayoḥ
analyzed: tathā tam śatam varṣāṇi abhyārcat iti śata āyuḥ tvam prāṇaḥ vaṃśaḥ iti cakṣuḥ ādīn prati vaṃśa tvam iti jīva liṅgāni  sati ca evam anyadīyayoḥ
translated: Similarly, the indications of Jiva are: the statement He worshipped him for a hundred years indicates having a life span of a hundred years, and the statement The life breath is the lineage indicates being the lineage to the eyes and so on.🔽And when there is this abundance of Vedic texts and indications belonging to others,

analyzed: śruti liṅgayoḥ bāhulye nyasya indra ādeḥ prāṇa śabda vācya tvam yuktam  anyathā ukta nyāyasya anaikāntya āpātāt
translated: It is proper that someone else, Indra and so on, is denoted by the word life breath.🔽Otherwise, the stated reasoning would be inconclusive.

analyzed: na ca vākya bhedaḥ doṣaḥ ananyagatikatayā prāptatvāt iti
translated: And the fault of textual division is not, because it is obtained by being the only alternative.

original: amukhyayā vṛttyātra mukhyaprāṇasya vācyatvaṃ siddhāntināpyabhyupagamyata ityato mukhyetyuktam /
analyzed: amukhyayā vṛttyā atra mukhya prāṇasya vācya tvam siddhāntinā api abhyupagamyate iti atas mukhyā iti uktam
translated: The fact that the chief vital air is to be spoken of here by a secondary meaning is admitted even by the Siddhantin. Hence the word 'chief' is used.

analyzed: iti śabdaḥ śaṅkā samāpti dyotakaḥ
translated: The word 'iti' indicates the end of the doubt.
X. The section on the final vital air.

analyzed: siddhāntayat sūtram vyākhyāti tat na iti  om prāṇaḥ tathā anugamāt om
translated: The Sutra establishing the conclusion is explained as 'not so'.🔽Om. The vital air, because of the subsequent connection.

analyzed: prāṇaḥ tathā anugamāt
translated: The vital air, because of the subsequent connection.

analyzed: tat na atragasya hi
translated: For that is not here.

original: viṣṇoreva tu liṅgāni prāṇasthāni tu sarvaśaḥ // / /d //🔽prāṇasaṃvādapūrvāṇi mukhyato jīvagāni ca /
analyzed: viṣṇoḥ eva tu liṅgāni prāṇa sthāni tu sarvaśas  prāṇa saṃvāda pūrvāṇi mukhyatas jīva gāni ca
translated: But all the indications of Vishnu are indeed in the vital air.🔽And those beginning with the dialogue of the vital airs are primarily about the individual soul.

analyzed: abhyārcat śata varṣāṇi prāṇa vaṃśa tvam iti api
translated: He worshipped for a hundred years, and also that it is the lineage of the vital airs.

analyzed: kintu brahmaṇaḥ eva prāṇa śabda mukhya vācya tvam iti śeṣaḥ
translated: But the remainder is that the vital air is indeed the primary object of the word of Brahman.

analyzed: kutas
translated: Why?

analyzed: brahma śabda anugamāt
translated: Because of the connection with the word Brahman.

analyzed: pārameśvara liṅga anugamāt ca iti bhāvaḥ
translated: And because of the connection with the indications of the supreme Lord, this is the idea.

analyzed: athavā bāhulye ityādikam eva siddhānta vākyam
translated: Or else, the statement of the conclusion itself is 'because of abundance' and so on.

original: brahmaviṣayayoḥ śrutiliṅgayorbāhulye vidyamāne yadanyasyendrādeḥ prāṇaśabdamukhyavācyatvaṃ pūrvavādinoktam tanneti //
analyzed: brahma viṣayayoḥ śruti liṅgayoḥ bāhulye vidyamāne yat anyasya indra ādeḥ prāṇa śabda mukhya vācyatvam pūrvavādinā uktam tat na iti
translated: When there is abundance of the Vedic text and indications pertaining to Brahman, the statement by the opponent that something else, Indra and so on, is the primary object of the word 'vital air', that is not so.

analyzed: nanu ca śruti liṅga bāhulyāt eva anyasya mukhya vācya tvam iti uktam
translated: But it has been said that the other is the primary meaning because of the abundance of Vedic statements and indications.

analyzed: satyam
translated: True.

analyzed: tathā api asti atra vaiṣamyam
translated: Nevertheless, there is inequality here.

original: niravakāśaśrutiliṅgabāhulyena hi prāgatra ca nirṇayaḥ kṛtaḥ /
analyzed: niravakāśa śruti liṅga bāhulyena hi prāk atra ca nirṇayaḥ kṛtaḥ
translated: For the decision was made here earlier by the abundance of non-contradictory Vedic statements and indications.

analyzed: etāni tu sa avakāśāni iti āha atragasya iti
translated: But these are capable of other interpretations. Thus he says 'of the one who is here'.

analyzed: indra ādi gatasya
translated: Of the one who is Indra and so on.

analyzed: hi śabdaḥ hetvarthaḥ
translated: The word 'hi' means 'for'.

analyzed: tasmāt na iti pūrveṇa sambandhaḥ
translated: Therefore, 'not' is connected with the previous.

analyzed: pramāṇa prasiddhi dyotakaḥ vā
translated: Or it illuminates the well-known means of knowledge.

analyzed: ādyaḥ tuśabdaḥ nyāya viśeṣa sūcakaḥ
translated: The first 'tu' word indicates a special reasoning.

analyzed: prāṇa sthāni prāṇa sambandhi tayā pratītāni
translated: The ones located in the vital breaths are understood to be related to the vital breaths.

analyzed: punar tuśabdaḥ pi arthe
translated: Again, the word 'tu' means 'also'.

analyzed: indriya viṣayāṇi api iti śrutiḥ api iti vā
translated: Or 'the Vedic statements also' means 'the Vedic statements also'.

original: naca mañceṣu puruṣasambandhanibandhanaṃ krośanamivāmukhyānīśvare liṅgānīti śaṅkanīyam /
analyzed: na ca mañceṣu puruṣa sambandha nibandhanam krośanam iva amukhyāni īśvare liṅgāni iti śaṅkanīyam
translated: And it should not be suspected that the indications in the Lord are not primary, like the crying in the benches being based on the connection with men.

analyzed: antargatasya tasya eva tad tad kartṛ tvāt iti āśayena mukhyatas iti uktam
translated: With the idea that He Himself is the agent of each of those, it is said 'primarily'.

analyzed: śatam varṣāṇi iti atas parastāt iti śabdaḥ yojyaḥ
translated: The word 'tatah' should be connected as 'after that' also from 'for a hundred years'.

analyzed: prāṇa vaṃśa tvam prāṇān cakṣuḥ ādīn prati vaṃśa tvam
translated: Being the family of the vital breaths means being the family of the vital breaths, the eyes and so on, in relation to them.

analyzed: etena na vaktuḥ ityādi sūtra tātparyam uktam bhavati
translated: By this, the purport of the sutra beginning with not of the speaker is stated.

original: na vaktur ātmopadeśād iti ced adhyātmasaṃbandhabhūmā hy asmin / / / / /
analyzed: na vaktuḥ ātma upadeśāt iti ced adhyātma saṃbandha bhūmā hi asmin
translated: If it be said that it is not so, because of the teaching of the Self by the speaker, then it is said that in this (Upanisad) there is a basis for the connection with the Self.

analyzed: kecid atra kauṣītaki brāhmaṇa upaniṣadi indrapratardana ākhyāyikāyām śrutaṃprāṇaḥ smi prajñā ātmā  ityādi vākyam udāharanti
translated: Some quote here the passage beginning with I am the life-breath, the intelligent Self, from the story of Indra and Pratardana in the Koushithaki Brahmana Upanishad.

analyzed: teṣām vaktuḥ iti na śruti anugatam
translated: They say that the word speaker does not accord with the Vedic text.

analyzed: vaktṛ tvam hi indrasya ātma upadeśāt iti anena eva labdham
translated: For the fact that Indra is the speaker is already established by the argument because of the teaching of the Self by the speaker.

analyzed: na ca vaktuḥ iti indra pratipatti artham
translated: And the word speaker is not for the purpose of understanding Indra.

analyzed: tasya tad apratyāyaka tvāt
translated: Because that (story) does not convey him (Indra).

original: asmākaṃ tu viśiṣṭaṃ śastraṃ śaṃsiturviśvāmitrasya nendro 'nyathopadeṣyumarhatīti yuktidyotanāya sārthakamiti / /
analyzed: asmākam tu viśiṣṭam śastram śaṃsituḥ viśvāmitrasya na indraḥ nyathā upadeṣyum arhati iti yukti dyotanāya sārthakam iti
translated: But for us, it is meaningful for the purpose of illuminating the reasoning that Indra is not fit to teach otherwise to Vishvamitra, the chanter of the distinguished hymn.

analyzed: pāda artham upasaṃharati tasmāt iti
translated: He concludes the meaning of the chapter with tasmat (therefore).

analyzed: tasmāt anyatragaiḥ śabdaiḥ ukta nyāyaiḥ samantataḥ
translated: Therefore, by words that go to other things, by reasonings stated all around,

original: eko nārāyaṇo devo bhaṇyate nātra saṃśayaḥ // / / //
analyzed: ekaḥ nārāyaṇaḥ devaḥ bhaṇyate na atra saṃśayaḥ
translated: the one god Narayana is spoken of, there is no doubt about it.

analyzed: anyatragaiḥ nāma ātmakaiḥ iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The rest is that they are named.

analyzed: tasmāt ityasya eva vivaraṇam ukta nyāyaiḥ iti
translated: The explanation of tasmat (therefore) is by reasonings stated.

analyzed: uktaḥ nyāyaḥ yeṣu te tathā uktāḥ
translated: Those in which the principle has been stated are called thus.

analyzed: samantataḥ sarva veda gataiḥ
translated: On all sides, with all the Vedas.

analyzed: ekaḥ mukhya arthaḥ
translated: One is the primary meaning.

analyzed: na atra saṃśayaḥ iti
translated: There is no doubt here.

original: lakṣaṇayāyaṃ samanvayo 'bhidhīyata iti keṣāñcinmataṃ mukhyavṛttyeti siddhāntaḥ /
analyzed: lakṣaṇayā ayam samanvayaḥ bhidhīyate iti keṣāñcid matam mukhya vṛttyā iti siddhāntaḥ
translated: The opinion of some is that this relation is stated by secondary meaning, the conclusion is that it is by primary meaning.

original: ato vipratipatteratra saṃśayo na kāryo nirṇāyakasyoktatvādityarthaḥ /
analyzed: atas vipratipatteḥ atra saṃśayaḥ na kāryaḥ nirṇāyakasya ukta tvāt iti arthaḥ
translated: Therefore, due to disagreement, doubt should not be entertained here, as the determiner has been stated. This is the meaning.

original: athavokte 'pi nyāye 'nādivāsanānimitto 'nyasya mukhyavācyatvaviṣayaḥ saṃśayo na kārya ityanenācaṣṭe / /
analyzed: athavā ukte pi nyāye na ādi vāsanā nimittaḥ nyasya mukhya vācya tva viṣayaḥ saṃśayaḥ na kāryaḥ iti anena ācaṣṭe
translated: Or, even when the principle has been stated, doubt regarding the primary denotability of another, caused by beginningless impressions, should not be entertained. This is what is being said.

original: sarvajñakalpena tattvopadeśāya pravṛvena bhagavatā'cāryeṇaivaṃ sūtreṣu vyākhyāteṣu śiṣyāṇāmetāvanmātrārthānyetānīti pratītiḥ syāt /
analyzed: sarvajña kalpena tattva upadeśāya bhagavatā ācāryeṇa evam sūtreṣu vyākhyāteṣu śiṣyāṇām etāvat mātra arthāni etāni iti pratītiḥ syāt
translated: When the sutras have been explained by the revered teacher, who has engaged in teaching the truth through the imagination of the omniscient one, the disciples would think that they have meanings only up to that extent.

analyzed: tām nirākartum āha vāsudeva ādi iti
translated: To refute that, he says Vasudeva and so on.

analyzed: vāsudeva ādi rūpeṇa catur mūrtiḥ ca sarvaśas
translated: And in every way, he is the four forms of Vasudeva and so on.

analyzed: athavā pañcamūrtiḥ sa proktaḥ dhikaraṇam prati
translated: Or, he is said to be the fifth form, in every section.

analyzed: pratisūtram pratipadam pratyakṣaram atha api vā
translated: In every sutra, in every word, or even in every syllable.

analyzed: vāsudeva ādi tvena iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that he is Vasudeva and so on.
The word 'ca' (and) is for the purpose of including the alternative views that will be stated.

original: prathamapādānte kathanādasminneva pāda iti bhāti /🔽tannirāsāyoktam sarvaśaḥ //
analyzed: prathama pāda ante kathanāt asmin eva pāde iti bhāti  tad nirāsāya uktam sarvaśas
translated: Since it is mentioned at the end of the first quarter, it appears to be in this very quarter.🔽In order to refute that, it is said 'sarvaśaḥ' (in every way).

analyzed: sarveṣu api pādeṣu athavā iti nipāta samudāyaḥ pakṣa antare
translated: The group of particles 'athāpi vā' (or) is for another alternative.

analyzed: pañca mūrtiḥ nārāyaṇa ādi tvena
translated: The five forms are as Nārāyaṇa and others.

analyzed: pratiśabdaḥ vīpsāyām karmapravacanīyaḥ
translated: The word 'prati' is a karmapravacanīya (verbal affix) in the sense of repetition.

original: athāpi veti trayo nipātā yathākramaṃ pratisūtramityādibhistribhiḥ sambaddhayate /
analyzed: atha api vā iti trayaḥ nipātāḥ yathākramam pratisūtram ityādibhiḥ tribhiḥ sambaddhayate
translated: The three particles 'athāpi vā' (or) are connected respectively with the three beginning with 'prati sūtram' (for each aphorism) and so on.

original: atreyaṃ mūrtiḥ pratipādyata iti kathaṃ jñāyata ityata āha tairiti // /
analyzed: atra iyam mūrtiḥ pratipādyate iti katham jñāyate iti atas āha taiḥ iti
translated: How is it known that this form is being taught here? Therefore it is said 'taiḥ' (by them).

analyzed: taiḥ taiḥ yukti śruti nyāya viśeṣaiḥ
translated: By those various reasons, scriptures, and principles.

analyzed: nyāya śabdaḥ prakāra vacanaḥ
translated: The word 'nyāya' (principle) denotes a mode.

analyzed: śruti liṅga vyatirikta nyāya arthaḥ vā
translated: Or it means the purpose of reasoning other than scriptural evidence and indicative power.

original: tasyāṃ tasyāṃ mūrtau prasiddhairliṅgaiḥ śrutisamākhyādivyāvartakaivirveko jñātavya iti śeṣaḥ /
analyzed: tasyām tasyām mūrtau prasiddhaiḥ liṅgaiḥ śruti samākhyā ādi vyāvartaka virvekaḥ jñātavyaḥ iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The distinction should be known by the well-known indicative powers in that and that form, which avert scriptural evidence and synonyms. This is the remainder.

original: nanu caturmūrtiḥ pañcamūrtirveti pratyadhikaraṇaṃ pratisūtraṃ vā pratyakṣaraṃ veti ca vastuvikalpaḥ kathamityata āha yogyateti //
analyzed: nanu catur mūrtiḥ pañca mūrtiḥ vā iti pratyadhikaraṇam pratisūtram vā pratyakṣaram vā iti ca vastu vikalpaḥ katham iti atas āha yogyatā iti
translated: But how is it possible to have alternatives regarding the subject, each sūtra, or each letter, such as four-formed or five-formed? To this he says according to fitness, etc.

analyzed: yogyatā yathā
translated: Fitness is as follows...

analyzed: sarve pi pakṣāḥ sūtra kṛtaḥ vivakṣitāḥ
translated: All the positions are intended by the author of the sūtras.

analyzed: puruṣāṇām yogyatā anatikrameṇa pratīyante
translated: They are understood without transgressing the fitness of the people.

analyzed: tad apekṣayā vikalpaḥ yujyate iti yojyam
translated: It should be connected that the alternative is proper according to that.

analyzed: evam alaukika artha tvam kutas sūtrāṇām iti atas āha bṛhat tantra iti
translated: Thus, why are the sūtras not of a non-worldly meaning? To this he says in the Brihat Tantra, etc.

analyzed: bṛhat tantra pramāṇena
translated: By the authority of the Brihat Tantra...

analyzed: evam artha tvam sūtrāṇām jñeyam iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The remainder is that the meaning of the sūtras should be known.

analyzed: bahu arthaḥ iti vakṣyamāṇam
translated: And what is going to be said as having many meanings is also

analyzed: tra sambaddhayate
translated: connected here.

original: tarhi kasmāttathā na vyākhyāyata ityata āha bahvarthamapīti //
analyzed: tarhi kasmāt tathā na vyākhyāyate iti atas āha bahu artham api iti
translated: Then why is it not explained in that way? To this he says even though having many meanings, etc.

analyzed: bahu artham api saṅgrahāt
translated: Even though having many meanings, it is stated from the summary.

analyzed: ucyate nara buddhīnām api kiñcid graha arthataḥ
translated: It is said for the sake of grasping something of the human intellects...

analyzed: sūtra jātam iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The remainder is the collection of sūtras.

analyzed: ucyate vyākhyāyate
translated: It is said, it is explained.

original: buddhiśabdasya jñānārthatve graho grāhyaṃ bhāvapradhāno nirdeśaḥ /
analyzed: buddhi śabdasya jñāna artha tve grahaḥ grāhyam bhāva pradhānaḥ nirdeśaḥ
translated: When the word intellect means knowledge, grasp is what is to be grasped, the direction is predominant in the noun.

analyzed: grāhya tvam eva arthaḥ prayojanam tasmai
translated: The object is the purpose for which it is to be grasped.

analyzed: manaḥ ṛtha tve grahaṇam grahaḥ
translated: And grasping is the apprehension of the object of the mind.

original: na caivaṃ sūtrārthaleśavyākhyānaparo 'yaṃ grantha ityanādaraṇīya ityāśayenāha grantha iti //
analyzed: na ca evam sūtra artha leśa vyākhyāna paraḥ yam granthaḥ iti anādaraṇīyaḥ iti āśayena āha granthaḥ iti
translated: And with this intention, he says this treatise in the sense that this text is not to be disregarded as being devoted to explaining only a part of the meaning of the sutra.

analyzed: granthaḥ yam api
translated: This treatise also has many meanings.

analyzed: samagra artha vyākhyānam akurvan api
translated: Even without explaining the entire meaning.

original: ayamityuktatvātsatyapi tasminpunarasya viracanādbhāṣyamalpārthamiti nāśaṅkanīyamityāha bhāṣyaṃ ceti //
analyzed: ayam iti ukta tvāt sati api tasmin punar asya viracanāt bhāṣyam alpa artham iti na āśaṅkanīyam iti āha bhāṣyam ca iti
translated: Since it is said this, even if it exists, it should not be suspected that the commentary has little meaning due to its composition again. Therefore, he says and the commentary etc.

analyzed: bhāṣyam ca atyartha vistaram
translated: And the commentary is extremely extensive.

analyzed: atiśayitena arthena vistaraḥ yasya iti vyadhikaraṇa bahuvrīhi garmaka tvāt  bahvartha tvam anayoḥ anupalambha bādhitam iti ced na
translated: Because of the compound vyadhikaraṇabahuvrīhi (having a different substratum), which means that which has extension with an excessive meaning.🔽If it is argued that the fact of these two having many meanings is contradicted by non-apprehension, it is not so.

analyzed: vyākhyāna sāmagrī vaikalya nimitta tvāt tad anupalambhasya iti āśayena āha bahu jñāḥ eva iti
translated: Because non-apprehension is due to the deficiency of the collection of explanations. With this intention, he says only the very learned etc.

analyzed: bahu jñāḥ eva jānanti viśeṣaṇa artham etayoḥ
translated: Only the very learned know the specific meanings of these two.
