analyzed: evam phalam lakṣaṇa siddhim upasaṃharati tasmāt iti
translated: Having thus stated the incidental matter, he concludes the establishment of the definition by the result of the establishment of the application of the names well-known elsewhere:

analyzed: tasmāt mahā guṇaḥ viṣṇuḥ nāmnā aya punaruktitaḥ
translated: Therefore, by the non-redundancy of names, Vishnu has great qualities.

analyzed: sakala veda gata samasta nāma vācyatvāt iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: because he is denoted by all the names found in all the Vedas.

analyzed: katham tanmātreṇa mahā guṇa tvam
translated: How is it that he has great qualities merely by that?

original: nāmnāṃ yaugikatvādapunaruktitaśceti /🔽iti śrīmatpūrṇapramatibhagavatpādasukṛteranuvyākhyānasya praguṇajayatīrthākhyayatinā /🔽kṛtāyāṃ ṭīkāyāṃ viṣamapadavākyārthavivṛtāvayaṃ pūrve 'rvā
analyzed: nāmnām yaugika tvāt apunaruktitaḥ ca iti  iti śrīmat pūrṇapramati bhagavat pāda su kṛteḥ anuvyākhyānasya praguṇa jayatīrtha ākhya yatinā  kṛtāyām ṭīkāyām viṣama pada vākya artha vivṛtau ayam pūrve r vā
translated: By the etymological correctness of the names and by the non-redundancy.🔽Thus ends the first quarter of the first chapter in the commentary written by the ascetic named Praguṇajayatīrtha,

analyzed: dhyāye prathama caraṇaḥ paryavasitaḥ
translated: who is the disciple of the illustrious and fully wise Lord Padmasambhava, on the difficult words and meanings of the Anuvyākhyā.

analyzed: adhyaya pada
translated: Chapter. Word.

analyzed: atha prathama adhyāyasya dvitīyaḥ pādaḥ
translated: Now, the second quarter of the first chapter.
I. The section on omnipresence.

original: dvitīyapādasya pūrvottarapādabhedasya svasminnekavākyatāyāśca siddhaye pratipādyamarthaṃ darśayati liṅgātmakānāmiti //
analyzed: dvitīya pādasya pūrva uttara pāda bhedasya svasmin ekavākyatāyāḥ ca siddhaye pratipādyam artham darśayati liṅga ātmakānām iti
translated: To establish the distinction between the previous and subsequent quarters of the second quarter and their unity in itself, he shows the subject matter to be taught:

analyzed: liṅga ātmakānām śabdānām vṛttiḥ nārāyaṇe pare
translated: The application of words having the nature of gender is in the supreme Narayana.

analyzed: cintyate
translated: is being considered.

original: liṅgaṃ dharmaḥ sa ātmevātmā pravṛttinimittaṃ yeṣāṃ te liṅgātmakāḥ /
analyzed: liṅgam dharmaḥ saḥ ātmā iva ātmā pravṛtti nimittam yeṣām te liṅga ātmakāḥ
translated: Those for whom the mark, which is the property, is the very self are of the nature of the mark.

analyzed: svarūpa arthaḥ vā ātma śabdaḥ
translated: Or the word 'self' has the meaning of own nature.

analyzed: nimitta nimittinoḥ abheda upacārāt
translated: Because there is figurative identification of the cause and the caused.

analyzed: sakala veda gatānām anyatra prasiddhānām iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The remainder is: of those well-known elsewhere in the entire Veda.

analyzed: nanu atīta pāde samanvitāḥ api liṅga ātmakāḥ eva
translated: But in the previous section, even the connected ones are of the nature of the mark.

analyzed: yaugika tvāt  anyathā guṇa pūrti alābhena samanvaya samarthana vaiyarthyāt
translated: Because they are etymological.🔽Otherwise, because there would be no gain of completeness of qualities, the support of the connection would be useless.

analyzed: na ca prakaraṇa gata guṇa lābhena sārthakyāt  vacana vṛtti aṅgīkāra vaiphalyāt
translated: And it is not meaningful because of the gain of qualities in the context.🔽Because accepting a figurative usage would be fruitless.

analyzed: uktam ca yad śabdāḥ yoga vṛttayaḥ iti
translated: And it is said that words have etymological meanings.

analyzed: tat katham ayam vibhāgaḥ
translated: How then is this division?

analyzed: satyam  tathā api anyatra prasiddha tva ādi vat āpāta pratīti anurodhena iyam uktiḥ iti adoṣaḥ
translated: True.🔽Nevertheless, this statement is made in accordance with the apparent understanding, as if it were well-known elsewhere, so there is no fault.

analyzed: vṛttiḥ lakṣaṇa ādiḥ api bhavati iti atas pare mukhya arthaḥ iti uktam
translated: Usage is also definition and so on, therefore the primary meaning is stated.

analyzed: tathā ca mukhya vṛttiḥ iti labhyate
translated: And thus the primary usage is understood.

analyzed: cintyate samarthyate smin pāde iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The remainder is: it is being considered, it is being supported in this section.

analyzed: om sarvatra prasiddha upadeśāt om
translated: Om. Because of the teaching well-known everywhere. Om.

original: kecinmanomayaḥ prāṇaśarīro bhārūpa ityuktaṃ manomayatvādinopāsyatvaṃ paramātmanaḥ pratipādayitumidamadhikaraṇamiti vyācakṣate /
analyzed: kecid manaḥ mayaḥ prāṇa śarīraḥ bhā rūpaḥ iti uktam manaḥ maya tva ādinā upāsya tvam paramātmanaḥ pratipādayitum idam adhikaraṇam iti vyācakṣate
translated: Some explain this section as aiming to establish the supreme self as the object of meditation through being composed of mind and having a body of vital air and the form of light, which is stated in the Upanishad.

analyzed: tat asat iti āśayavān āha sarvaga tvam iti
translated: With the intention that this is not so, he says omnipresence, etc.

analyzed: sarvatra prasiddha upadeśāt
translated: Because of the teaching of what is well-known everywhere.

analyzed: sarvaga tvam tu prathamam pravicāryate
translated: But omnipresence is first considered.

analyzed: tuśabdaḥ va dhāraṇe
translated: The word tu (but) is for emphasis.

original: etamasyāmetaṃ divītyādivākyoktaṃ savargatatvamevātra pāde prathamaṃ parameśvarasya samarthyate /
analyzed: etam asyām etam divi ityādi vākya uktam savarga tatvam eva atra pāde prathamam parameśvarasya samarthyate
translated: In this section, only the omnipresence of the supreme Lord, stated in the passages beginning with this one in this earth, this one in heaven, etc., is first established.

analyzed: na tu manaḥ maya tva ādinā upāsyatvam iti arthaḥ
translated: Not the objectness of meditation through being composed of mind, etc. This is the meaning.

analyzed: satya kāma tva ādi parameśvara dharmāṇām sphuṭa pratibhāsa tvena sandeha ādi anupapatteḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that because the attributes of the supreme Lord such as having true desires are clearly manifest, doubt, etc., are not possible.

original: nanu manomayatvādayaḥ śārīradharmā api pratīyanta iti cenna /
analyzed: nanu manaḥ maya tva ādayaḥ śārīra dharmāḥ api pratīyante iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that being composed of mind, etc., are also perceived as attributes of the embodied self, it is not so.

analyzed: teṣām ānanda maya adhikaraṇa nyāyena sa avakāśa tvāt
translated: Because they have an alternative meaning according to the reasoning of the section on the one consisting of bliss.

analyzed: carama pratītena api niravakāśena prathama pratītasya sa avakāśasya anyathātva upapatteḥ
translated: Even if perceived last, what is without an alternative can make what is perceived first and has an alternative have a different meaning.

analyzed: nanu katham tarhi asmākam api cakṣuḥ maya tva ādīni pūrvapakṣa prāpakāṇi
translated: But then how are the arguments like being made of eyes and so on, which are presented by us, also established?

analyzed: ucyate
translated: It is said:

analyzed: hetu antareṇa pūrvapakṣe sati abhyuccaya mātra tvena teṣām upanyāsaḥ
translated: When there is a prima facie view based on another reason, those [arguments] are presented merely as a reiteration.

original: yathā parasyekṣatyadhikaraṇe prāyapāṭhe niraste 'pyabhyuccayamātratvena prāṇādhikaraṇe tadupanyāsaḥ / /
analyzed: yathā parasya īkṣati adhikaraṇe prāya pāṭhe niraste pi abhyuccaya mātra tvena prāṇa adhikaraṇe tad upanyāsaḥ
translated: Just as, in the section on the vital breaths, after the general application has been refuted in the section on seeing, it is presented there merely as a reiteration.

analyzed: sarvagata tva pratipādanasya prakṛta upayogam daśaryati tatra iti
translated: He shows the relevance of the presentation of omnipresence in the present context with the words tatra tatra (there, there).

analyzed: tatra tatra sthitaḥ viṣṇuḥ tad tad śakti prabodhakaḥ
translated: There, there, Vishnu, the awakener of those powers,🔽...

analyzed: prabodhanam kārya abhimukhīkaraṇam
translated: Awakening means making [the powers] face towards their effects.

original: tatkiṃ dūre sthitaḥ śaktiprabodhane na śakto yena tatratatra tiṣṭhatītyata uktam dūrato 'pīti //
analyzed: tat kim dūre sthitaḥ śakti prabodhane na śaktaḥ yena tatra tatra tiṣṭhati iti atas uktam
translated: But why is it that he is not able to awaken the powers while being far away, for which reason he is said to be there, there? To this it is said: dūrato 'pi (even from far away).

analyzed: dūratas pi atiriktaḥ sa līlayā kevalam prabhuḥ
translated: The Lord, although far away, is only playfully superior...

analyzed: iti jñāpayitum
translated: ...in order to make this known...

analyzed: yadi api sa prabhuḥ viṣṇuḥ dūratas tad tad śakti prabodhane ti śaktaḥ tathā api kevalam
translated: Although that Lord Vishnu is very capable of awakening those powers even from far away, still, only...

original: līlayā tatratatra sthitastattattacchaktīnāṃ prabodhako bhavatīti jñāpayituṃ sarvagatatvamiha
analyzed: līlayā tatra tatra sthitaḥ tad tad tad śaktīnām prabodhakaḥ bhavati iti jñāpayitum sarvagata tvam iha
translated: In order to show that he, remaining playfully here and there, is the awakener of those and those powers, the omnipresence is being discussed here.

analyzed: pravicāryate iti sambandhaḥ
translated: This is the connection.

analyzed: etat uktam bhavati
translated: This is what is said.

analyzed: sva nirgama praveśābhyām deha pātana utthāpanam ityādyāḥ mukhya prāṇa ādi śaktayaḥ tad antargata bhagavat āyattāḥ iti prāc uktam
translated: It has been said before that the principal powers such as the vital breath, etc., by their going out and entering, cause the falling and rising of the body, and are dependent on the Lord who is within them.

analyzed: tat anupapannam
translated: That is not correct.

analyzed: bhagavataḥ sarvagata tva abhāvāt
translated: Because the Lord is not omnipresent.

analyzed: śāstra eka samadhigamyam khalu hi tat
translated: For that is to be understood only from the scriptures.🔽And the scriptures such as This is the immortal have another meaning.

analyzed: śāstram ca etam asyām ityādikam anya param iti āśaṅkayā ukta artha samarthanāya sarva gata tvam atra hareḥ upapadyate iti
translated: Fearing that this may be suspected, in order to establish the intended meaning, it is said that the omnipresence of Hari is appropriate here.

analyzed: athavā na sarvagata tvam hareḥ upapādanīyam
translated: Or else, the omnipresence of Hari need not be established.🔽Fearing that this may be suspected, it is said that the omnipresence of Hari is appropriate here.🔽Or else, the omnipresence of Hari need not be established.

original: tasyānandādivatsraṣṭṛtvādivadvā guṇatvābhāvādityāśaṅkaya na savargatatvaṃ nāma sarvasaṃyogitvamātramiha vivakṣitam /
analyzed: tasya ānanda ādi vat sraṣṭṛ tva ādi vat vā guṇa tva abhāvāt iti āśaṅkaya na savargatatvam nāma sarva saṃyogitva mātram iha vivakṣitam
translated: Because it is not a quality like bliss, or like creativity, etc. Fearing that this may be suspected, it is said that here omnipresence is not meant merely as being connected with everything.

analyzed: kim nāma tad tad śakti preraka tvena
translated: What is it then? It is the instigation of those and those powers.

analyzed: atas tad upapādanam upapadyate iti anena ucyate
translated: Therefore, the establishment of that is appropriate. This is what is being said.

original: athavā na sarvagatatvamatra pratipādanīyam /🔽adṛśyatvādyadhikaraṇe tasya pratipādayiṣyamāṇatvādityāśaṅkaya tatra savargatatvamātramatra tu tattacchaktiprabodhakatvamiti tātparyabhedo 'nenocyate
analyzed: athavā na sarvagata tvam atra pratipādanīyam  adṛśya tva ādi adhikaraṇe tasya pratipādayiṣyamāṇa tvāt iti āśaṅkaya tatra savarga tatva mātram atra tu tad tad śakti prabodhaka tvam iti tātparya bhedaḥ nena ucyate
translated: Or rather, omnipresence is not to be taught here.

original: athavā antaryāmyadhikaraṇe pṛthivyādiṣu sthitevarkṣyamāṇatvānnedamārambhaṇīyamityāśaṅkayātra śaktiprerakatvena tatra tu sattādipradatvena tattadantargatatvamucyata
analyzed: athavā antaryāmi adhikaraṇe pṛthivī ādiṣu sthitā iva ṛkṣyamāṇa tvāt na idam ārambhaṇīyam iti āśaṅkayā atra śakti preraka tvena tatra tu sattā ādi prada tvena tat tat antargata tvam ucyata
translated: Since it will be taught in the section on the imperceptibility, etc., fearing that it might be thought that this is not to be begun because it will be taught as existing in earth, etc. in the section on the inner controller, here it is said that it is contained in each by being the instigator of power, while there it is said to be contained in each by being the bestower of existence, etc.

analyzed: iti anena ācaṣṭe
translated: This is what is stated by this.

original: athavā antaḥsthatvādhikaraṇenedaṃ gatārthamityāśaṅkaya tatra candrādikatipayapadārthāntarasthitatvam atra tu sarvapadārthāntargatatvamabhidhīyata
analyzed: athavā antaḥsthatva adhikaraṇena idam gatārtham iti āśaṅkaya tatra candra ādi katipaya padārtha antara sthitatvam atra tu sarva padārtha antargatatvam abhidhīyata
translated: Or fearing that this is already dealt with by the section on internal existence, there the existence within a few things like the moon is stated, while here the existence within all things is stated.

analyzed: iti pratipādya bhedam etena āha
translated: Thus the difference in the subject matter is stated by this.

analyzed: athavā
translated: Or rather.

analyzed: sarvagata tvam nāma sarva mūrta dravya saṃyogi tvam vā
translated: Omnipresence is either the state of being conjoined with all corporeal substances

analyzed: parama mahā parimāṇa yogi tvam vā su
translated: or the possession of the highest magnitude.

analyzed: prasiddham
translated: This is well known.

original: tadatra yadi sādhyaṃ syāttadā 'rbhakaukastvādityākṣepānupapattiradṛśyatvādyadhikaraṇena gatārthatā e /
analyzed: tat atra yadi sādhyam syāt tadā rbhaka oka tvāt iti ākṣepa anupapattiḥ adṛśya tva ādi adhikaraṇena gatārtha tā e
translated: Here, if this were the probandum, then the objection because of the state of being in the womb would be illogical, and it would be already established by the section on being invisible etc.

analyzed: ca iti āśaṅkaya sarvagata tvam anyathā anena vyācaṣṭe
translated: Fearing this doubt, he explains the omnipresence in another way by this (verse).

original: tattacchaktiprabodhaka iti katham /🔽kartari ceti samāsapratiṣedhāt / na /
analyzed: tad tad śakti prabodhakaḥ iti katham  kartari ca iti samāsa pratiṣedhāt na
translated: How is it said the awakener of those powers?🔽Because of the prohibition of compounding in the nominative case. No.

analyzed: yājaka ādibhiḥ ca iti pratiprasavāt
translated: Because of the re-allowance by and by the sacrificer etc.

analyzed: yat vā
translated: Or rather,

original: prakṛṣṭo bodho yasmāditi vā pacādyajantatvena vā prabodhaḥ /
analyzed: prakṛṣṭaḥ bodhaḥ yasmāt iti vā vā prabodhaḥ
translated: The one from whom there is an excellent awakening or the awakening by the suffix pac etc.

analyzed: śaktīnām prabodhaḥ śakti prabodhaḥ
translated: The awakening of the powers is the awakening of the powers.

analyzed: tatas ca ajñātaḥ
translated: And from that, unknown.

analyzed: iti ka pratyayaḥ iti
translated: Thus the suffix ka is used.

analyzed: atra sūtram karma kartṛ vyapadeśāt ca iti
translated: Here is the sutra: And because of the designation of the object and agent.

analyzed: asya arthaḥ
translated: This is the meaning.

original: ātmānaṃ parasmai śaṃsatīti śaṃsanakriyāyāmātmanaḥ sarvagatasya karmatvena śarīrasya kartṛtvena vyapadeśācca na śārīro 'yaṃ sarvagataḥ /
analyzed: ātmānam parasmai śaṃsati iti śaṃsana kriyāyām ātmanaḥ sarva gatasya karma tvena śarīrasya kartṛ tvena vyapadeśāt ca na śārīraḥ yam sarva gataḥ
translated: And because of the designation of the all-pervading self as the object and the body as the agent in the action of praising, saying he praises himself to another, therefore this all-pervading one is not the embodied self.

analyzed: ekasyām kriyāyām karma kartroḥ eka tva ayogāt
translated: Because it is not possible for the object and agent to be one in one action.

original: nahi devadattaḥ chidāyāṃ kartā karmāpi bhavatīti /
analyzed: nahi devadattaḥ chidāyām kartā karma api bhavati iti
translated: For Devadatta is not both the agent and the object of the action of cutting.

original: tatra kiṃ karmakartṛbhāvo bhedavyāpta uta neti /
analyzed: tatra kim karma kartṛ bhāvaḥ bheda vyāptaḥ uta na iti
translated: There, is the relation of action and agent pervaded by difference or not?

analyzed: na ādyaḥ
translated: Not the first.

analyzed: niyāmaka abhāvena vyāpteḥ aniścayāt
translated: Because the pervasion is not ascertained due to the absence of a determiner.

analyzed: syāt etat
translated: Let this be so.

analyzed: kriyā āśrayaḥ kartā iti tāvat prasiddham
translated: It is well-known that the agent is the substratum of action.

analyzed: para samaveta kriyā janya phala śāli kamara iti ucyate
translated: He is said to be the object of an action that produces a result inhering in another.

analyzed: yathā devadatta samaveta gati kriyā phala saṃyoga śālī grāmaḥ
translated: Just as a village is the object of the action of motion inhering in Devadatta, and is endowed with the result of that action, namely conjunction.

analyzed: kriyā phala śāli tvena eva karma tve saṃyoga śālinaḥ devadattasya api tad prasaṅgaḥ
translated: If something is an object merely by being endowed with the result of an action, then Devadatta, who is endowed with conjunction, would also be an object.

original: tathātve ca devadattaṃ grāmaṃ gacchatīti dvitīyā syāt /
analyzed: tathātve ca devadattam grāmam gacchati iti dvitīyā syāt
translated: And if that were so, then the instrumental case would be used, as in Devadatta goes to the village.

analyzed: atas lakṣaṇa virodhāt karma kartroḥ bhedaḥ niyataḥ iti
translated: Therefore, because of the contradiction with the definition, the difference between the object and agent is determined.

analyzed: mā evam
translated: This is not so.

original: yato devadatto grāmaṃ gacchati tasyāpi devadattasamavetagatikriyāphalavibhāgaśālitvena karmatvaprasaṅgāt /
analyzed: yatas devadattaḥ grāmam gacchati tasya api devadatta samaveta gati kriyā phala vibhāga śāli tvena karma tva prasaṅgāt
translated: Because Devadatta, who is the agent of the action of going to the village, would also be an object, since he is endowed with the result of the action of going inhering in Devadatta, namely disjunction.

original: tathāca devadattaḥ kauśāmbīṃ pāṭalīputraṃ gacchatīti prayogaḥ syāt /
analyzed: tathā ca devadattaḥ kauśāmbīm pāṭalīputram gacchati iti prayogaḥ syāt
translated: And in that case, the expression Devadatta goes from Kaushambi to Pataliputra would be used.

analyzed: kim ca anāgata ādi viṣaya icchā ādi kriyā phala śāli tvam anāgata ādeḥ na asti iti tad karmatvam na syāt
translated: Moreover, since the future and other objects do not have the result of the action of desire etc., they would not be objects.

analyzed: nahi tad abhāve tatra phala utpādaḥ sambhavati
translated: For, in the absence of that, the production of the effect in that [object] is not possible.

analyzed: mā bhūt iti ced na
translated: If it be said that [the effect] may not [be produced], [we say] no.

analyzed: icchā ādīnām sakarmaka tva vyāghātāt
translated: Because it would be contrary to the fact that desire, etc. have an object.

analyzed: tad vācinaḥ dvitīya anupapatti prasaṅga gaḥ ca gāt ca
translated: And because the use of the accusative case [ending] in the expression of that [object] would be impossible.

analyzed: vartamāne pi ghaṭa ādau na jñāna ādi janyam phalam upalabhyate
translated: Even in the present [object] such as a pot, the effect produced by knowledge, etc. is not perceived.

analyzed: tathā hi
translated: To explain:

analyzed: na tāvat jñāta tā  nirākariṣyamāṇa tvāt
translated: First, [the effect] is not the state of being known.🔽Because it will be refuted later.

analyzed: icchā ādīnām tad ajanaka tvāt ca
translated: And because desire, etc. are not its producer.

analyzed: na api saṃskāra ādikam
translated: Nor is it the impression, etc.

analyzed: tasya ātmani eva utpādāt
translated: Because it is produced only in the self.

analyzed: na api vyavahāraḥ  vyavahāra ādi rūpasya tasya kartṛ niṣṭha tvāt
translated: Nor is it the usage.🔽Because that [usage] in the form of usage, etc. is based on the agent.

analyzed: upādāna ādi rūpasya upekṣaṇīya avyāpteḥ  tasmāt kriyā svātantṛyam kartṛ tvam
translated: And because the form of appropriation, etc. is too narrow, as it excludes what should be ignored.🔽Therefore, it must be said that agency is the independence in action,

analyzed: tad viṣaya tvam ca karma tvam iti vācyam
translated: and that the object is that which is the content of that [action].

original: naca tayoḥ kamapi virodhaṃ paśyāmaḥ /🔽anyathā karmakartāpi durlabhaḥ syāt /
analyzed: na ca tayoḥ kam api virodham paśyāmaḥ  anyathā karma kartā api durlabhaḥ syāt
translated: And we do not see any contradiction between the two.🔽Otherwise, the object and the agent would be difficult to find.

analyzed: kim ca asti tāvat kāraka antara samāveśaḥ
translated: Moreover, there is the inclusion of another case [ending].

analyzed: kāṃsya pātṛyā bhuṅkte kāṃsya pātṛyām bhuṅkte ityādi prayoga darśanāt
translated: Because expressions such as he eats with the bronze bowl and he eats in the bronze bowl are seen.

analyzed: tathā karma kartroḥ api samāveśe kaḥ virodhaḥ
translated: Similarly, what is the contradiction in the identity of action and agent?

analyzed: nanu ca dṛśyate tāvat karma kartroḥ bhedaḥ
translated: But the difference between action and agent is indeed seen.

analyzed: na ca vyabhicāraḥ dṛśyate
translated: And there is no seen contradiction.

analyzed: tena vyāpti niścayaḥ iti
translated: Therefore, the determination of pervasion is [established].

analyzed: mā evam
translated: No, that is not so.

analyzed: darśana adarśana mātrasya vyāpti aniścāyaka tāyāḥ vakṣyamāṇa tvāt
translated: Because it will be said that mere seeing and not seeing do not determine pervasion.

analyzed: na ca vyabhicāra adarśanam api
translated: And there is also no non-seeing of contradiction.

analyzed: mām aham jānāmi iti tad darśanāt  anyathā ātma
translated: Because of the seen [fact] that I know myself.

analyzed: sākṣātkāra anupapatti prasaṅgāt
translated: Otherwise, there would be the undesirable consequence that the self would not be directly perceived.

analyzed: na ca nitya anumeyaḥ eva ātmā
translated: And the self is not to be inferred as eternal.

analyzed: sākṣātkārasya apanhotum aśakya tvāt
translated: Because the direct perception [of the self] cannot be denied.

analyzed: kaścid āha mānasa pratyakṣa avaseyaḥ yam ātmā
translated: Someone says: This self is the object of mental perception.

analyzed: tathā api kartṛtā eva asya na karmatā
translated: Even so, its nature is only that of an agent, not that of an object.

analyzed: ātma kartṛke haṃpratyaye pratibhāsa mātreṇa tad āparokṣya siddheḥ iti
translated: Because the self is the agent in the cognition of I, and its [self's] opaqueness is established merely by appearance.

analyzed: riktam eva vacanam
translated: That [statement] is empty, because it does not state anything other than being an object.

analyzed: kim ca aham iti pratyayaḥ sakarmakaḥ na vā
translated: And what is the point of saying I? Is it with an object or not?

analyzed: na iti pakṣaḥ nubhava viruddhaḥ
translated: The position that it is not [with an object] is contradicted by experience.

analyzed: jānāteḥ sadā sakarmaka tvāt aca bhāsāt ca
translated: And because it is always said that [the verb] to know has an object.

analyzed: ādye kim asya karma iti vaktavyam
translated: In the first case, it must be said what its object is.

analyzed: na tāvat ātma atiriktam
translated: Not the body, etc., which are different from the self.

analyzed: ghaṭa ādau ahaṃpratyaya adarśanāt
translated: Because the notion of I is not seen in a pot, etc.

analyzed: ātma sambandhi sukha ādikam iti ced na
translated: If it is said that it is the pleasure, etc. related to the self, no.

analyzed: tanmātrasya
translated: Because the mere that

analyzed: karmatāyām ātma asiddhi prasaṅgāt
translated: would lead to the non-establishment of the self as the object.

analyzed: aham sukham ityādi vyavahāra prasaṅgāt ca
translated: And because the usage I am happy, etc. would follow.

original: atha jñānāśrayaḥ kartā sukhādiviśiṣṭaḥ karmeti cet / na /
analyzed: atha jñāna āśrayaḥ kartā sukha ādi viśiṣṭaḥ karma iti ced na
translated: If it is said that the agent who is the basis of knowledge and is qualified by pleasure, etc. is the object, no.

analyzed: āgatam tarhi aṃśataḥ karma katroḥ aikyam
translated: Then, therefore, the identity of the object and agent is implied in part.

original: kiṃ ca yuñjānasya nirupādhikamātmānaṃ paśyato 'haṃpratyayo nānyakarmaka ityakarmako vā'tmakarmako vābhyupagantavyaḥ /
analyzed: kim ca yuñjānasya nirupādhikam ātmānam paśyataḥ haṃpratyayaḥ na anya karmakaḥ iti akarmakaḥ vā ātma karmakaḥ vā abhyupagantavyaḥ
translated: Moreover, for one who is practicing and sees the self without qualifications, the notion of I cannot be said to have a different object, or to be without an object or to have the self as its object.

analyzed: gati antara abhāvāt
translated: Because there is no other way.

original: aparastu ghaṭādisannikṛṣṭena cakṣurādinopajanitaṃ vijñānaṃ tritayaprakāśarūpaṃ karmatayā viṣayam /
analyzed: aparaḥ tu ghaṭa ādi sannikṛṣṭena cakṣuḥ ādinā upajanitam vijñānam tritaya prakāśa rūpam karmatayā viṣayam
translated: But another [says]: The consciousness produced by the eye, etc. in contact with a pot, etc. has the form of the manifestation of the three [aspects]. It is the object as the object.

analyzed: sva prakāśa tayā svarūpam
translated: It is the form as self-manifestation.

analyzed: āśraya tayā ātmānam vyavasthāpayati iti na ātmanaḥ karma tā
translated: It establishes the self as the basis. Therefore, the self is not the object.

analyzed: nā api tad sākṣātkāra asiddhiḥ iti āha
translated: Nor is the non-establishment of the direct perception of that [self].

analyzed: sa praṣṭavyaḥ
translated: He should be asked:

analyzed: kim idam jñānasya sva prakāśa tvam nāma iti
translated: What is this so-called self-manifestation of knowledge?

analyzed: svakarmaka prakāśa tvam iti ced
translated: If it is said to be the manifestation of its own object,

analyzed: tarhi vṛścika bhiyā palāyamānasya āśīviṣa mukhe nipātaḥ
translated: Then, for one fleeing out of fear of a scorpion, falling into the mouth of a poisonous snake.

analyzed: yat sva lakṣara mātra adhīna virodham karma kartṛ bhāvam parihartum sarva loka avasita virodham kriyā kamar bhāvam abhyupaiti
translated: In order to avoid the contradiction dependent on the measure of one's own definition, he accepts the contradiction established by all people regarding the relation of action and agent.

analyzed: kriyā hi karma kāraka janyā iṣyate
translated: For action is held to be produced by the instrumental and other factors.

analyzed: naca janya janakayoḥ eka tā ucitā
translated: And it is not proper for the produced and the producer to be one.

analyzed: antar bhāvita pūrva apara bhāvi tvāt tasyāḥ
translated: Because it has the nature of being prior and posterior included within itself.

original: naca tadeva svātmānaṃ prati pūrvamaparaṃ ceti yujyate /🔽prakāśāntarānapekṣasiddhaddhi
analyzed: na ca tat eva sva ātmānam prati pūrvam aparam ca iti yujyate  prakāśa antara anapekṣa siddhat hi
translated: And it is not proper that that very thing should be prior and posterior with respect to itself.

analyzed: tvam sva prakāśa tvam iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that it is self-luminous because it is established without depending on another light, that is not so.

analyzed: ghaṭa ādeḥ api sva prakāśa tā āpātāt
translated: Because even a pot and so on would be self-luminous.

analyzed: nahi ghaṭa ādayaḥ sva siddhau prakāśa antaram apekṣante
translated: For pots and so on do not depend on another light for their own establishment.

analyzed: kim nāma prakāśam eva
translated: What indeed is the light?

analyzed: tvam iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that it is established without depending on a light other than itself, that is not so.

analyzed: sva apekṣā bhāvena sva atirikta viśeṣaṇa vaiyarthyāt
translated: Because, being without dependence on itself, a qualification other than itself is useless.

analyzed: prakāśa anapekṣa siddha tvam iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that it is established without depending on a light, that is not so.

analyzed: vyāghātāt
translated: Because of contradiction.

analyzed: śaśaviṣāṇa ādeḥ api evam 🔽siddhi prasaṅgāt ca
translated: And because even the horn of a rabbit and so on🔽would be established in the same way.

analyzed: sva vyavahāra hetu prakāśa tvam iti ced na  sva viṣaye eva vyavahāra hetu tva darśanena a sva viṣayasya
translated: If it is argued that it is the manifestation of the cause of one's own activity, that is not so.

analyzed: sva vyavahāra hetu tā anupapatteḥ
translated: Because it is seen to be the cause of activity only with respect to itself, it is not logically possible for what is not itself to be the cause of one's own activity.

analyzed: tad guṇa saṃvijñāna bahuvrīhi ādikam tu na udāharaṇaṇīyam
translated: But a bahuvrīhi compound with the sense of its attribute, etc., should not be cited as an example.

analyzed: guṇasya api samāsa viṣaya tā aṅgīkārāt
translated: Because even an attribute is accepted as the subject of a compound.

analyzed: kiñca ātmā na cākṣuṣa jñāne vabhāsate
translated: Moreover, the self does not appear in visual cognition.

analyzed: arūpi dravya tvāt ākāśa vat
translated: Because it is a formless substance, like space.

original: anyathā rūpitvaprasaṅgaḥ /🔽kamartayā prakāśe rūpopayoga iti cenna /
analyzed: anyathā rūpi tva prasaṅgaḥ  kamartayā prakāśe rūpa upayogaḥ iti ced na
translated: Otherwise, it would follow that it has form.🔽If it is argued that form is useful in light because of the nature of action, that is not so.

original: prakāśamānaṃ karmatayaiva prakāśata iti vadantaṃ prati viśeṣaṇavaiyarthyāt /
analyzed: prakāśamānam karmatayā eva prakāśate iti vadantam prati viśeṣaṇa vaiyarthyāt
translated: Because, for one who says that what is manifest appears only as the nature of action, the qualification is pointless.

original: etenānumāne 'pi prayojakāntarāśaṅkā nirastā /🔽kiṃ cātmā yadi tadaviṣayo 'pi tatra prakāśate /
analyzed: etena anumāne pi prayojaka antara āśaṅkā nirastā  kim ca ātmā yadi tad aviṣayaḥ tatra prakāśate
translated: By this, the suspicion of another cause in inference is also refuted.🔽Moreover, if the self appears there even though it is not its object,

original: hanta tarhi rūpajñāne raso 'pi kasmānna prakāśate /
analyzed: hanta tarhi rūpa jñāne kasmāt na prakāśate
translated: then why does taste not appear in a cognition of form?

analyzed: anāśraya tvāt iti ced
translated: If it is argued that it is because it has no basis,

analyzed: tat kim yāvat jñāna sambandhi jñāne prakāśate
translated: then is everything related to cognition manifest in cognition?

analyzed: kiṃvā āśrayaḥ eva
translated: Or is it only the basis?

analyzed: ādye cakṣuḥ ādau atiprasaṅgaḥ
translated: In the first case, there is the great fault of visual organs, etc.

analyzed: dvitīye pi niyāmakam vācyam
translated: In the second case also, a determining factor must be stated.

analyzed: nahi ghaṭaḥ yam iti ātmā avabhāsate
translated: For the self does not appear as 'this is a pot'.

analyzed: ghaṭam aham jānāmi iti pratyayaḥ tu ghaṭa jñāna viśiṣṭa ātma karmakaḥ nyaḥ eva
translated: But the cognition 'I know the pot' is different, having the self as its object qualified by the knowledge of the pot.

analyzed: ātma siddhiḥ tu karma tayā api bhaviṣyati iti  etena sva prakāśa tayā ātma siddhiḥ api parāstā
translated: And the self will be established even as the object.🔽By this, the establishment of the self as self-luminous is also refuted.

analyzed: svakam arka prakāśavat tva tad rūpa tva atiriktayāḥ tasyāḥ nirūpayitum aśakya tvāt
translated: Because it cannot be defined as anything other than being the light of its own object and having that form.

original: tadevaṃ kartṛkarmabhāvo na bhedavyāpta iti siddham / /
analyzed: tat evam kartṛ karma bhāvaḥ na bheda vyāptaḥ iti siddham
translated: Thus it is established that the relation of agent and object is not pervaded by difference.

analyzed: karma kartṛ vyapadeśāt ca
translated: And because of the designation of the object and agent.

analyzed: tathā ca katham hetu tvena upādānam iti atas āha karma iti
translated: And how then can it be accepted as the cause? To this he says 'karma' (action).

analyzed: karma kartroḥ utsargataḥ bhidā
translated: The object and agent are different by nature.

original: yāvekasyāṃ kriyāyāṃ karmakartārau tayorbheda ityastyeva vyāptiḥ /
analyzed: yau ekasyām kriyāyām karma kartārau tayoḥ bhedaḥ iti asti eva vyāptiḥ
translated: And in that case, there is indeed the pervasion that if the object and agent are one in an action, they are different.

analyzed: kim tu autsargikī
translated: But this is a general rule.

analyzed: na tu dhūmasya iva agninā saṅkoca anarhā iti arthaḥ
translated: It is not that it cannot be restricted like smoke by fire. This is the meaning.

original: tataḥ kiṃ labdhamiti ceddoṣadvayaṃ parihṛtamiti krameṇāha abhedo 'pīti //
analyzed: tatas kim labdham iti ced doṣa dvayam parihṛtam iti krameṇa āha
translated: If it is asked what is gained by that, the two faults are avoided. He says in order: 'Abheda' (non-difference) etc.

analyzed: abhedaḥ pi viśeṣe syāt balī saḥ pi anapoditaḥ
translated: Non-difference may also be a particular case, and that is strong, and it is not refuted.

analyzed: yasmāt karma kartroḥ utsargataḥ eva bhidā
translated: Because the difference between action and agent is natural.

analyzed: tasmāt viśinaṣṭi sva viṣayam utsarga viṣayāt vayavacchinatti iti viśeṣaḥ upavādaḥ tasmin sati abhedaḥ pi syāt
translated: Therefore, a specific rule is that which distinguishes its own object from the object of the general rule, i.e., excludes it. Even non-difference could be [the case] when there is such a specific rule.

analyzed: tathā ca mām aham jānāmi ityādi
translated: And thus, the statement I know myself etc.

analyzed: ti upapannam bhavati
translated: becomes logically possible.

analyzed: yatas ca utsargaḥ pi apavāda abhāve balī sva sādhya sādhane samarthaḥ
translated: And because even a general rule, when there is no specific rule, is strong, capable of accomplishing what it intends to prove.

analyzed: na ca asti prakṛte pa vādaḥ
translated: And there is no specific rule in the present case.

analyzed: tasmāt atra hetu tvena upadānam api yujyate
translated: Therefore, the statement as a reason is also appropriate here.

original: yathā hi na hiṃsyātsarvā bhūtānītyautsargiko bhūtahiṃsāniṣedho 'gnīṣomīyapaśuhiṃsāvidhināpodyate /
analyzed: yathā hi na hiṃsyāt sarvā bhūtāni iti autsargikaḥ bhūta hiṃsā niṣedhaḥ gnīṣomīya paśu hiṃsā vidhinā apodyate
translated: Just as the general prohibition of harming any beings is overridden by the injunction to kill the animal for Agni and Soma.

analyzed: bhavati ca an apodite brahma hiṃsā ādi a karaṇīya tve pramāṇam
translated: And there is evidence that the killing of Brahmins etc. is not to be done when it is not overridden.

original: nanvevaṃ tarhi prameyatvānityatvayorapyevaṃ vaktuṃ śakyata eva /
analyzed: nanu evam tarhi prameya tva anitya tvayoḥ api evam vaktum śakyate eva
translated: If that is so, then it can be said in the same way about the two, being an object of knowledge and non-eternality.

analyzed: apavādena tu ākāśa ādau nitya tvam
translated: The pervasion of being an object of knowledge by non-eternality is general.🔽But by the specific rule, in the case of ākāśa etc., [it is] eternal.

analyzed: apavāda abhāvāt śabda ādau anitya tva sādhaka tā iti
translated: And in the case of sound etc., it is the prover of non-eternality due to the absence of a specific rule.

analyzed: tatas ca anaikāntika tā ucchedaḥ syāt
translated: And from that, there would be the fallacy of inconclusiveness.

analyzed: mā evam
translated: It is not so.

original: sāmānyaviṣayeṇa hi pramāṇenārthe pratīte sati viśeṣaviṣayeṇāpavādo bhavati /
analyzed: sāmānya viṣayeṇa hi pramāṇena arthe pratīte sati viśeṣa viṣayeṇa apavādaḥ bhavati
translated: For when an object is apprehended by a means of knowledge having a general scope, a subsequent exception can be made by a means of knowledge having a specific scope.

original: tataśca sarvataḥ prasaktā buddhistadviṣayaṃ parityajyānyatra viśrāmyati /
analyzed: tatas ca sarvatas prasaktā buddhiḥ tad viṣayam parityajya anyatra viśrāmyati
translated: And thus the mind, which is attracted to everything, abandons that object and rests elsewhere.

original: naca sarvabhūtahiṃsāniṣedhasyeva prameyatvānityatvavyāpteḥ kenāpi pramāṇena prāptirasti /
analyzed: na ca sarva bhūta hiṃsā niṣedhasya iva prameya tva anitya tva vyāpteḥ kena api pramāṇena prāptiḥ asti
translated: And there is no means of knowledge that establishes the pervasion of being an object of knowledge with non-eternality, as in the case of the prohibition against harming all beings.

original: kiṃ nāma prameyatvaṃ /🔽nityatvānityatvābhyāṃ sahavyavasthitamevopalabhyata sati na tatraapi
analyzed: kim nāma prameya tvam  nitya tva anitya tvābhyām saha vyavasthitam eva upalabhyata sati na tatra api
translated: What then is being an object of knowledge?

analyzed: utsarga apavāda nyāyasya avakāśaḥ
translated: When it is perceived to exist only in association with eternality and non-eternality, there is no room for the principle of general rule and exception even there.

original: evaṃ tarhi karmarkatṛbhāvo 'pi bhedābhedābhyāṃ saha vyavasthita evopalabdha iti kathamatrāpyutsargāpavādanyāyasyāvakāśaḥ /
analyzed: evam tarhi karma ṛkatṛ bhāvaḥ pi bheda abhedābhyām saha vyavasthitaḥ eva upalabdhaḥ iti katham atra api utsarga apavāda nyāyasya avakāśaḥ
translated: If that is so, then the relation of agent and object is also perceived to exist only in association with difference and non-difference. How then can there be room for the principle of general rule and exception here also?

analyzed: mā evam
translated: Not so.

analyzed: pratyaktava parāktava rūpaḥ hi kartṛ karma bhāvaḥ
translated: The relation of agent and object has the form of being directly perceived and being indirectly perceived.

original: sa tāvadāpātato virodhādbhedena ghaṭanīyo vā viśeṣeṇa vā /
analyzed: sa tāvat āpātataḥ virodhāt bhedena ghaṭanīyaḥ vā viśeṣeṇa vā
translated: That must be combined either with difference or with a particular, because of the contradiction in the prima facie view.

analyzed: tatra bhedaḥ mukhyaḥ
translated: Among them, difference is primary.

analyzed: viśeṣaḥ tu pratinidhiḥ iti uktam
translated: But the particular is a substitute, it has been said.

analyzed: na ca mukhya pratinidhyoḥ sama kakṣya tayā pratibhāsaḥ bhavati
translated: And the primary and the substitute do not appear as equals.

original: ato bhedaḥ sāmānyataḥ prāpnoti viśeṣastvapavādeneti yuktamuktam /
analyzed: atas bhedaḥ sāmānyatas prāpnoti viśeṣaḥ tu apavādena iti yuktam uktam
translated: Therefore, it is proper to say that the difference is general, but the particular is by way of exception.

analyzed: yathā ca anugata sāmānya abhāve pi utsarga apavāda nyāya sambhavaḥ tathā vakṣyāmaḥ
translated: And we shall explain how, even in the absence of a pervasive universal, the principle of general rule and exception is possible.

original: sopādhikasambandhasya sādhanāṅgatābhāvavat sopādhikavyabhicārasyāpi na dūṣaṇāṅgatvamiti kimatrālaukikam /
analyzed: sa upādhika sambandhasya sādhana aṅgatā abhāva vat sopādhika vyabhicārasya api na dūṣaṇa aṅgatvam iti kim atra alaukikam
translated: Just as the relation with a limiting condition is not a part of the proof, similarly the deviation with a limiting condition is also not a part of the refutation. What is extraordinary here?

analyzed: vakṣyate ca etat iti
translated: And this will be stated.

analyzed: sarvagata tvam atra adhikaraṇe pratipādyate iti uktam
translated: It has been said that omnipresence is taught in this section.

analyzed: tat kim tanmātram uta anya upalakṣaṇam
translated: Is that just that, or is it a distinguishing mark of something else?

analyzed: ādye sūtrāṇām viśvatomukha tva hāniḥ
translated: In the first case, there is the loss of the all-sidedness of the aphorisms.

analyzed: śāstra aparyavasānam ca āpadyeta
translated: And the conclusion of the scripture would be reduced to absurdity.

analyzed: dvitīye tu upādhiḥ vaktavyaḥ
translated: But in the second case, the limiting condition must be stated.

analyzed: anyathā adhikaraṇa antara abhāva prasaṅgāt iti atas prathama adhikaraṇa upādhim vadan prasaṅgāt sarva adhikaraṇa upādhīn āha etat iti
translated: Otherwise, there would be the contingence of the absence of other sections. Thus, stating the limiting condition of the first section, he states the limiting conditions of all the sections by the way of a discussion, with the words this etc.

original: etad bhāvābhidhaṃ liṅgaṃ kriyāliṅge tataḥ param /
analyzed: etat bhāva abhidham liṅgam kriyā liṅge tatas param
translated: This is the indicative of the expression of existence, and the indicative of action is after that.

analyzed: antaryāmī antaraḥ ca iti kriyā bhāva ākhyam ucyate
translated: The internal and the antarātmā are said to be the linga called kriyābhāva (action and non-action).

analyzed: adṛśya tva ādi abhāva ākhyam śrutiḥ liṅga adhikā parā
translated: The highest śruti, which is superior to the linga, is called the adṛśyatvādi (invisibility, etc.).

analyzed: etat sarva gata tvam bhāva abhidham sattā abhidham
translated: This all-pervasiveness is denoted by the word bhāva (existence).

original: yāvantaḥ śabdāḥ kvacitpratīke sthitivācinaste sarve 'pyanenopalakṣyanta ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: yāvantaḥ śabdāḥ kvacid pratīke sthiti vācinaḥ te sarve pi anena upalakṣyante iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that all the words denoting existence in any symbol are indicated by this.

analyzed: evam uttaratra api jñātavyam
translated: It should be understood in the same way in the subsequent [passages] as well.

analyzed: kriye ca te liṅge ca
translated: And they are the linga of action.

original: tataḥ prathamādhikaraṇātparaṃ dvābhyāmattā carācaragrahaṇāt' /🔽guhāṃ praviṣyāvātmānau hi taddarśanāt' /
analyzed: tatas prathama adhikaraṇāt param dvābhyām attā carācara grahaṇāt  guhām praviṣyau ātmānau hi tad darśanāt
translated: After the first section, the two [sections] beginning with because of the mention of the moving and unmoving (2.1.1),

analyzed: iti etābhyām adhikaraṇābhyām cintyete
translated: and because the two selves enter the cave, as seen in the scriptures (2.1.2), are to be considered.

analyzed: nanu ekam adhikaraṇam vyartham
translated: Isn't one section useless?

analyzed: na vyartham
translated: It is not useless.

analyzed: abhyadhika āśaṅkayā pratyavasthānāt

analyzed: antare upapatteḥ

analyzed: iti antaryāmi adhidaiva ādiṣu tad dharma vyapadeśāt

analyzed: iti ca adhikaraṇa dvayena kriyā pradhānaka bhāva ākhyam liṅgam ucyate pratipādyate

analyzed: atra api pūrvavat na anyatara adhikaraṇa vaiyarthyam

original: ata eva kriyā kriyayā bhāvo bhāvena vyākhyāyata iti parāstam /
analyzed: atas eva kriyā kriyayā bhāvaḥ bhāvena vyākhyāyate iti parāstam

analyzed: adṛśya tva ādi guṇakaḥ dharma ukteḥ

analyzed: iti atra uktam adṛśya tva ādi liṅgam abhāva ākhyam
translated: Here, the mark such as being invisible, etc., mentioned is called non-existence.

analyzed: parā parasmin vaiśvānaraḥ sādhāraṇa śabda viśeṣāt
translated: In the section on The Vaiśvānara is supreme in the other, because of the particular common word,

original: ityadhikaraṇe pratipādyā śrutirnāma na tu liṅgam /
analyzed: iti adhikaraṇe pratipādyā śrutiḥ nāma na tu liṅgam
translated: the scripture to be taught is called scripture, not a mark.

original: tarhi pādāntarbhāvo na sambhavatītyata uktam liṅgādhiketi //
analyzed: tarhi pāda antarbhāvaḥ na sambhavati iti atas uktam liṅga adhika iti
translated: Then, since inclusion in the section is not possible, it is said that it is about marks.

analyzed: liṅāni adhikāni samāna adhikaraṇāni yayā sā liṅga adhikā iti
translated: That by which there are more than marks, which are in the same substratum, it is about marks.

original: yathā prathamapāde 'ntastaddharmopadeśāditi liṅganirṇayo bahunāmasamanvayalābhārthaḥ tathā bahuliṅgasamanvayalābhārtho nāmavicāro 'tra na viruddhayata
analyzed: yathā prathama pāde ntar tad dharma upadeśāt iti liṅga nirṇayaḥ bahu nāma samanvaya lābha arthaḥ tathā bahu liṅga samanvaya lābha arthaḥ nāma vicāraḥ na
translated: Just as in the first section, the determination of marks by the statement because of the teaching of its attributes within is for the sake of obtaining the reconciliation of many names, so the consideration of names here is not contradicted for the sake of obtaining the reconciliation of many marks.

analyzed: iti  sākṣāt prakaraṇa
translated: Thus.

analyzed: ṇiniṣṭha tvāt śruteḥ upādānam ca upapadyate
translated: Because the scripture is directly based on the section, the mention is also appropriate.

analyzed: sā ca sūkta ādi vyāvartaka agni ādi śabda upalakṣaṇam iti jñātavyam
translated: And that should be known as the indication of words such as Agni, which exclude the Sukta, etc.

analyzed: iti sarvagata tva adhikaraṇam
translated: Thus ends the section on the all-pervasiveness.

analyzed: attṛ tva adhikaraṇam
translated: II. The section on being the experiencer.

analyzed: atha attṛ tva adhikaraṇam
translated: Now, the section on being the experiencer.

analyzed: om attā carācara grahaṇāt om
translated: Om. The Self, because of the mention of the moving and unmoving. Om.

analyzed: attā cara acara grahaṇāt
translated: The Self, because of the mention of the moving and unmoving.

original: atrayasya brahma ca kṣatraṃ cobhe bhavata odanaḥ /
analyzed: atrayasya brahma ca kṣatram ca ubhe bhavataḥ odanaḥ

original: mṛtyuryasyopasecanaṃ ka itthā veda yatra saḥ' /

analyzed: iti vākyam udāhṛtya
translated: Having quoted this statement,

analyzed: attāram kecid vṛtti kārāḥ vicāritavantaḥ  tat vihāyasa yat yat eva asṛjata tat tat attum adhriyate
translated: some commentators have considered the Self.🔽Setting that aside, the statement Whatever He created, that He made food

analyzed: iti vākyam udāhṛtya attāram vyacīcarat bhagavān bhāṣyakāraḥ
translated: has been quoted by the revered commentator, and He has examined the Self.

analyzed: kaḥ ca atra viśeṣaḥ
translated: And what is the difference here?

analyzed: ucyate  atra attum adhriyate
translated: It is said:🔽Here, He made food

original: atti' / iti ca attā sākṣātpratīyate /🔽tatra tu odanopasecanapadābhyāmupalakṣaṇīyaḥ /
analyzed: atti iti ca attā sākṣāt pratīyate  tatra tu odana upasecana padābhyām upalakṣaṇīyaḥ
translated: and He eats - the Self is directly understood.🔽But there, it is to be inferred by the words food and sauce.

analyzed: ad adi dhātu anugatiḥ ca atra
translated: And there is conformity with the root da (to give).

analyzed: na ca upalakṣite niyamaḥ sti
translated: And there is no restriction on what is inferred.

original: kiñca carācaragrahaṇāditi heturatra sarvaṃ vāttīti kaṇṭhoktaḥ /
analyzed: kiñca carācara grahaṇāt iti hetuḥ atra sarvam vātti iti kaṇṭha uktaḥ
translated: Moreover, the reason because of the mention of the moving and unmoving is stated outright here as all this is the Self.

analyzed: tatra tu brahma kṣatra mṛtyu padaiḥ carācarasya upalakṣaṇam iti asti mahān viśeṣaḥ
translated: But there, the moving and unmoving is inferred by the words Brahman, Kshatriya, and death - this is a great difference.

original: nanvevaṃ tarhi śrutyanugamāya sarvagrahaṇāditi kuto na kṛtam /
analyzed: nanu evam tarhi śruti anugamāya sarva grahaṇāt iti kutas na kṛtam
translated: If so, then why was not the word 'sarva' (all) used in order to agree with the Śruti?

analyzed: asti prayojanam carācara grahaṇasya
translated: There is a purpose in using the words 'cara' (moving) and 'acaram' (immovable).

analyzed: sarva grahaṇāt iti ukte śaknoti pūrvavādī vaditum
translated: When it is said 'sarva' (all), the former speaker can say,

analyzed: aditiḥ api sarvasya sva bhojyasya anna pāna ādeḥ bhoktrī iti
translated: Aditi is also the enjoyer of all her own food, such as food and drink.

analyzed: tatra na ayam sarva śabdaḥ saṅkucita vṛttiḥ
translated: There, this word 'sarva' (all) is not of limited application.

analyzed: kim tayā vācā
translated: What is it? By that speech, etc.

analyzed: ityādi pūrva vākya paryālocanayā carācara vāci iti vaktavyam
translated: And by considering the preceding sentence beginning with ādi, it should be said to denote the moving and immovable.

analyzed: tat etat anena dyotayati iti
translated: This is what is indicated by this.

analyzed: yat asmin adhyāye samanvīyate tat sarvam lakṣaṇa tvena prakṛtam iti ānanda maya adhikaraṇa ante bhihitam
translated: It has been stated at the end of the section on the bliss-body that everything which is to be identified in this chapter is presented as a characteristic.

original: lakṣaṇaṃ ca lakṣyeṇa brahmaṇābhinnamiti lakṣaṇasūtre pratipāditam /
analyzed: lakṣaṇam ca lakṣyeṇa brahmaṇā abhinnam iti lakṣaṇa sūtre pratipāditam
translated: And it has been established in the defining sūtra that the definition is non-different from Brahman, the defined.

analyzed: atra ca kriyā liṅga samanvayaḥ iti uktam
translated: And here it has been said that there is identification through the indication of action.

analyzed: tathā ca adana ādi kriyāṇām parameśvara sva rūpa tvam uktam iti tat ākṣipati anitya tvāt iti
translated: And thus it has been said that the actions of eating and so on are of the nature of the Supreme Lord. This is objected to by saying because they are non-eternal, etc.

analyzed: anitya tvāt kriyāṇām tu katham eva svarūpa tā
translated: How can actions, because they are non-eternal, be of the nature of the Supreme Lord?

analyzed: tuśabdaḥ sarvagata tva ādi vyavaccheda arthaḥ
translated: The word but is for the purpose of excluding omnipresence, etc.

analyzed: saḥ pi codyasya atra avakāśa sambhāvanā arthaḥ  katham iti ākṣepe
translated: And that also is for the purpose of showing the possibility of an objection here.🔽How? is an objection.

analyzed: katham eva na kathañcid api iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: how indeed, in no way at all.

analyzed: sva rūpa tā parameśvara sva rūpa tā
translated: Own nature means the nature of the Supreme Lord.

analyzed: parameśvarasya hi nitya tvam janma ādi sūtra labdham
translated: For the eternality of the Supreme Lord is established in the aphorism on origination, etc.

analyzed: svayam anityasya sakala kāraṇatva anupapatteḥ
translated: Because it is not logically possible for something impermanent by itself to be the cause of everything.

original: yatkhalu yasya janakaṃ na tasyāsau janako /
analyzed: yat khalu yasya janakam na tasya asau janakaḥ
translated: For what is the producer of something is not its producer.

original: yacca tasya vināśakaṃ na tasyāsau vināśaka iti /
analyzed: yat ca tasya vināśakam na tasya asau vināśakaḥ iti
translated: And what is the destroyer of something is not its destroyer.

analyzed: kriyāṇām tu anitya tvam su prasiddham
translated: But the impermanence of actions is well known.

analyzed: tathā ca nitya anityayoḥ katham abhedaḥ syāt
translated: And how then could there be non-difference between the eternal and the non-eternal?

analyzed: viruddha dharma adhyāsasya bhāva bheda avyabhicārāt
translated: Because the superimposition of contradictory properties is invariably concomitant with the difference of entities.

analyzed: anyathā jagati bheda abhāva prasaṅgāt
translated: Otherwise, there would be the undesirable consequence of the absence of difference in the world.

original: tato yadi nāma sarvagatatvādīnāṃ yāvaddravyabhāvināmabhedaḥ tathāpi na kriyāṇāmasau yujyata iti / /
analyzed: tatas yadi nāma sarvagata tva ādīnām yāvaddravyabhāvinām abhedaḥ tathā api na kriyāṇām asau yujyate iti
translated: Therefore, if indeed there is non-difference of omnipresence, etc., which last as long as the substance, even so, it is not logically possible for actions.

analyzed: pariharati iti ced iti
translated: He answers this with If this is said.

original: iti cet sa viśeṣo 'pi kriyāśaktayātmanā sthiraḥ // / / //
analyzed: iti ced sa viśeṣaḥ pi kriyā śaktayā ātmanā sthiraḥ
translated: If this is said, that particular [action] also is stable in the form of the power of action.

analyzed: na iti adhyāhāraḥ
translated: The negative particle is to be supplied.

analyzed: kutas
translated: Why?

original: na kevalamīśvaraḥ sthiro 'pi tu sa tadīyo viśeṣo dharmo 'pi kriyārūpaḥ sthitaro yata iti śeṣaḥ /
analyzed: na kevalam īśvaraḥ sthiraḥ pi tu sa tadīyaḥ viśeṣaḥ dharmaḥ pi kriyā rūpaḥ yatas iti śeṣaḥ
translated: Not only is God permanent, but also that particular quality of Him, which is in the form of action, is more permanent. This is the remainder of the sentence.

original: atratu kriyāsthiretyetāvadeva vaktavyaṃ viśeṣa iti tu kriyāyāḥ parameśvaraikye 'pyuktavakṣyamāṇanyāyena taddharmatayāpyaṅgīkaraṇīyeti jñāpayitum
analyzed: atra tu kriyā sthirā iti etāvat eva vaktavyam viśeṣaḥ iti tu kriyāyāḥ parameśvara aikye pi ukta vakṣyamāṇa nyāyena tad dharmatayā api aṅgīkaraṇīyā iti jñāpayitum
translated: Here, only this much should be said: 'action is permanent'. But 'particular' is used to indicate that even in the oneness of action with the Supreme Lord, it should be accepted as His quality by the reasoning that will be stated later.

original: na kevalaṃ sa viśeṣaḥ sarvagatatvādiḥ sthiraḥ /
analyzed: na kevalam sa viśeṣaḥ sarvagata tva ādiḥ sthiraḥ
translated: Not only is that particular quality, such as omnipresence, permanent,

original: kintu kriyāpi pārameśvarī sthirā yata iti vā yojyam /
analyzed: kintu kriyā api pārameśvarī sthirā yatas iti vā yojyam
translated: but also the action of the Supreme Lord is permanent. This is how it should be connected.

analyzed: anena kriyāyāḥ api nitya tva pratijñānena viruddha dharma adhyāsasya asiddhiḥ uktā
translated: By this assertion of the permanence of action also, the non-establishment of the superimposition of contradictory properties is stated.

analyzed: tathā hi
translated: It is as follows.

analyzed: īśvarasya saṃharaṇa ādi kriyāṇām anitya tvam kim pramāṇa balāt aṅgīkriyate
translated: Is the impermanence of the actions of God, such as dissolution, etc., accepted due to the force of valid means of knowledge?

analyzed: uta nitya tve bādhaka sadbhāvāt
translated: Or is it due to the presence of contradiction in their permanence?

analyzed: athavā tad sādhaka pramāṇa abhāvāt
translated: Or is it due to the absence of valid means of knowledge establishing them?

analyzed: na ādyaḥ
translated: The first is not so.

original: īśvarasya tatkriyāyāśca apratyakṣatvena tadanityatvasya pratyakṣeṇa pratyetumaśakyatvāt /
analyzed: īśvarasya tad kriyāyāḥ ca apratyakṣa tvena tad anitya tvasya pratyakṣeṇa pratyetum aśakya tvāt
translated: Because the impermanence of that action of God is not capable of being known by perception, since both God and that action are imperceptible.

analyzed: liṅga abhāvena anumāna anupapatteḥ
translated: Because inference is not possible due to the absence of an inferential mark.

analyzed: kriyā tvam liṅgam iti ced
translated: If it is argued that the property of being an action is the inferential mark,

analyzed: tat kim dhātu artha tvam parispanda tvam vā
translated: is it the meaning of the verbal root, or is it vibration?

analyzed: na ādyaḥ
translated: The first is not correct.

analyzed: jñāna icchā prayatnaiḥ sattayā ca vyabhicārāt
translated: Because there is deviation with knowledge, desire, effort, and existence.

analyzed: na dvitīyaḥ
translated: The second is not correct.

analyzed: sarva kriyāṇām aparispanda tvena bhāga asiddha tvāt
translated: Because all actions are not vibrations, and there is partial inapplicability.

analyzed: īśvara parispanda pakṣīkāra iti āśraya asiddheḥ
translated: If the vibration of God is accepted, there is the fallacy of the unestablished locus.

analyzed: pareṇa tasya an aṅgīkṛta tvāt  aṅgīkāre pi anaikāntyam
translated: Because it is not accepted by the opponent.🔽Even if it is accepted, there is inconclusiveness.

original: kvacidanīśvaraparispandānāmapi nityatvasya vakṣyamāṇatvāt /🔽kriyātvasya nityatvena vinā vṛttau bādhakābhāvādaprayojakatā ca /🔽kāryatvena sopādhikatvaṃ ca /
analyzed: kvacid anīśvara parispandānām api nitya tvasya vakṣyamāṇa tvāt  kriyā tvasya nitya tvena vinā vṛttau bādhaka abhāvāt aprayojaka tā ca  kāryatvena sa upādhika tvam ca
translated: Because in some cases, even those that are not the vibration of God are said to be eternal.🔽And there is no inapplicability because there is no contradiction in the occurrence of the property of being an action without eternality.

analyzed: tasya api sādhane bādhaḥ
translated: And there is the fallacy of being inconclusive because of being an effect.

original: pramāṇasya vakṣyamāṇatvāt /🔽asatyāvaraṇādau prāgūrdhvaṃ cānupalambho liṅgamiti cet /
analyzed: pramāṇasya vakṣyamāṇa tvāt  asati āvaraṇa ādau prāk ūrdhvam ca anupalambhaḥ liṅgam iti ced
translated: Because the proof of that is contradicted.🔽Because the proof will be stated later.🔽If it is argued that the non-apprehension before and after in the absence of obstruction, etc. is the inferential mark,

analyzed: anupalambhaḥ kim pratyakṣeṇa uta pramāṇa mātreṇa
translated: is the non-apprehension by perception or by mere proof?

analyzed: na ādyaḥ
translated: The first is not correct.

analyzed: yogya tayā viśeṣaṇe siddheḥ
translated: Because the qualification by capability is not established.

analyzed: anyathā gagana ādinā vyabhicārāt
translated: Otherwise, there would be deviation due to space, etc.

analyzed: dvitīye tu asiddhiḥ
translated: In the second case, there is non-establishment.

analyzed: āgama ādinā upalabdheḥ
translated: Because of the perception of the Veda and so on.

analyzed: etena āvaraṇa ādi abhāve sati kadācid evaḥ labdhiḥ api pratyuktā
translated: By this, the objection that perception occurs only sometimes when there is no obstruction and so on is also refuted.

analyzed: varṇa nitya tva vāde na aikāntyāt ca
translated: And because of the non-exclusiveness of the doctrine of the eternality of sound.

original: kiñca nityo 'pi īśvaraparispandaḥ kadācidabhivyakteḥ kadācidevopalabhyata ityaṅgīkāre na bādhakaṃ paśyāmaḥ /
analyzed: kiñca nityaḥ pi īśvara parispandaḥ kadācid abhivyakteḥ kadācid eva upalabhyate iti aṅgīkāre na bādhakam paśyāmaḥ
translated: Moreover, we do not see any contradiction in accepting that even the eternal activity of God is sometimes perceived due to manifestation, and sometimes not.

analyzed: vyaktiḥ api ādi grahaṇena gṛhyate iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that manifestation is also included by the word and so on, that is not so.

analyzed: sandigdha viśeṣaṇa asiddheḥ
translated: Because the qualifier is doubtful and unestablished.

analyzed: astu tarhi phala anupalambhaḥ liṅgam iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that the non-perception of the effect is then the reason, that is not so.

analyzed: sarvathā anupambhasya asiddha tvāt
translated: Because the non-perception in any way is not established.

original: na hīśvaraparispandakriyā kadāpi na saṃyogavibhāgalakṣaṇaṃ phalaṃ janayatīti yujyate /
analyzed: na hi īśvara parispanda kriyā kadāpi na saṃyoga vibhāga lakṣaṇam phalam janayati iti yujyate
translated: For it is not proper to say that the activity of God's activity never produces an effect characterized by conjunction and disjunction.

analyzed: tathā sati parispanda tva anupapatteḥ
translated: Because in that case, it would not be proper to call it activity.

analyzed: nitya saṃyoga vibhāga janma anupalabdheḥ iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that it is not perceived because it is always produced by conjunction and disjunction, that is not so.

analyzed: nitya guṇa ādinā vyabhicārāt
translated: Because of the fallacy of the eternal qualities and so on.

analyzed: kadācid eva saṃyoga ādi janma vivakṣitam iti ced
translated: If it is argued that what is intended is that it is produced only sometimes by conjunction and so on,

analyzed: tathā api gagana ādinā vyabhicāraḥ
translated: even so, there is the fallacy of the sky and so on.

analyzed: kadācid eva saṃyoga ādi asamavāyi kāraṇa tvam astu iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that let there be the state of being the non-inherent cause of conjunction and so on only sometimes, that is not so.

analyzed: kadācid iti viśeṣaṇa vaiyarthyāt
translated: Because the qualification sometimes would be meaningless.

analyzed: tad parityāge pi asamavāyi kāraṇa tvasya durnirūpa tvena asiddheḥ
translated: Even if that were abandoned, since the property of being a non-inherent cause is difficult to determine, it is not established.

analyzed: kiñca dvi tantuka ārambha keva yave
translated: Moreover, in the part that is the cause of the cloth with two threads,

analyzed: tantau karma utpannam tantu antarāt vibhāgam karoti
translated: the action that arises causes separation from the other thread.

analyzed: tatas dvi tantuka ārambhaka saṃyoga vināśaḥ
translated: Then there is the destruction of the conjunction that is the cause of the cloth with two threads.

analyzed: tad nāśe dvi tantuka vināśaḥ
translated: When that is destroyed, the cloth with two threads is destroyed.

analyzed: atha idānīm tantoḥ kārya saṃyukta pradeśa vibhāgaḥ
translated: Now there is separation of the part of the thread that is connected with the effect.

analyzed: tatas ca uttara deśa saṃyogaḥ
translated: Then there is conjunction with the subsequent part.

analyzed: tasmāt karmaṇaḥ vināśaḥ iti pareṣām prakriyā
translated: From that, the action is destroyed. This is the procedure of others.

original: evaṃ ca yathānekakālavartinyapi kriyā kadācitsaṃyogādyārabhate na yāvatsattvam /
analyzed: evam ca yathā aneka kāla vartinī api kriyā kadācid saṃyoga ādi ārabhate na yāvat sattvam
translated: And just as an action that exists at many times sometimes produces conjunction, etc., not as long as it exists,

analyzed: tathā nityā api kadācid saṃyoga ādi ārabhatām kaḥ virodhaḥ
translated: in the same way, even if it is eternal, let it sometimes produce conjunction, etc. What is the contradiction?

analyzed: sāmānyavat tve sati asmat ādi bāhya indriya grāhya tvam hetuḥ astu iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that the reason is being perceptible by the external sense organs of us etc. while having the property of generality, that is not so.

analyzed: viśeṣya asiddheḥ
translated: Because the qualifier is not established.
Because the property of being of the same kind as what is perceptible by the external sense organs is deviant in the atom etc.

analyzed: kiñca varṇa nitya tve sphuṭaḥ sya vyabhicāraḥ
translated: Moreover, there is a clear deviation in the case of the eternality of color.

analyzed: nā api āgamāt īśvara kriyā nitya tā avagatiḥ  sa hi īśvara kriyā nityā iti evamātmakaḥ vā
translated: Nor is the eternality of God's activity known from scripture, etc.🔽For that [scripture] may have the form God's activity is eternal,

analyzed: saḥ imān lokān asṛjata iti evamātmakaḥ vā
translated: or it may have the form He created these worlds.

analyzed: ādyaḥ tu na upalabhyate
translated: But the first is not perceived.

analyzed: dvitīyaḥ tu sa aikṣata saḥ kāmayata ityādinā tulyaḥ
translated: The second is the same as [the passage] beginning He desired, he created.

analyzed: tatra yadi kriyāyāḥ anitya tvam
translated: If there, the activity is non-eternal,

analyzed: jñāna ādeḥ api kutas na bhavet iti
translated: why should not knowledge, etc. also be so?

original: astu tarhi nityatve bādhakasadbhāvāditi dvitīyaḥ pakṣaḥ /
analyzed: astu tarhi nitya tve bādhaka sadbhāvāt iti dvitīyaḥ pakṣaḥ
translated: Then let it be the second alternative, that [God's activity] is eternal because there is a contradiction [to its non-eternality].

analyzed: tathā hi
translated: For this is so.

original: yadi sṛṣṭisamaye 'pi saṃhārakriyā vidyeta tadā tathaiva śrutyādāvupalabhyeta /
analyzed: yadi sṛṣṭi samaye saṃhāra kriyā vidyeta tadā tathā eva śruti ādau upalabhyeta
translated: If even at the time of creation, the activity of dissolution existed, then it would be perceived in scripture, etc. in that way.

analyzed: janana vināśau ca ghaṭasya yugapad prasajyeyātām
translated: And the production and destruction of the pot would occur simultaneously.

original: kiñca yadīśvarakriyā nityā syāttarhi kriyāyāḥ saṃyogavibhāgau prati anapekṣakāraṇatvāttadutpattisātatyaprasaṅgaḥ /
analyzed: kiñca yadi īśvara kriyā nityā syāt tarhi kriyāyāḥ saṃyoga vibhāgau prati anapekṣa kāraṇa tvāt tad utpatti sātatya prasaṅgaḥ
translated: Moreover, if God's activity were eternal, then because activity is an independent cause with respect to conjunction and disjunction, there would be the consequence of the constant occurrence of their production.

original: api ceśvarakriyā saṃyogavibhāgau karoti na vā /
analyzed: api ca īśvara kriyā saṃyoga vibhāgau karoti na vā
translated: Furthermore, does God's activity produce conjunction and disjunction or not?

analyzed: na iti pakṣe kriyā tvam vyāhanyeta
translated: If not, then the nature of activity is contradicted.

analyzed: ādye pi kim sva sattā uttarakṣaṇe uta viramya
translated: If [it does], then does [activity] produce them in the next moment by its own existence, or after ceasing?

analyzed: na ādyaḥ
translated: Not the first.

original: svasattāyā idaṃ prathamatābhāvena saṃyogādiviśeṣasya vivakṣitakṣaṇādapi pūrvamutpattiprasaṅgāt /
analyzed: sva sattāyāḥ idam prathama tā bhāvena saṃyoga ādi viśeṣasya vivakṣita kṣaṇāt api pūrvam utpatti prasaṅgāt
translated: Because, in that case, the conjunction, etc., would have to be produced prior to the intended moment, since the existence of one's own being is not the first.

analyzed: na dvitīyaḥ
translated: Not the second.

analyzed: pūrva uttara avasthayoḥ aviśiṣṭasya viramya vyāpāra ayogāt
translated: Because what is not distinguished in the prior and subsequent states cannot have a function that is interrupted.

original: uttarasaṃyogasya karmavināśakatvena kṛtasaṃyogasya karmaṇo 'vasthānānupapatteścetyata uktaṃ śaktayātmaneti /
analyzed: uttara saṃyogasya karma vināśaka tvena kṛta saṃyogasya karmaṇaḥ vasthāna anupapatteḥ ca iti atas uktam śaktayā ātmanā iti
translated: And because the destruction of the action by the subsequent conjunction would not allow the action that has been conjoined to remain. Therefore it is said by the manifestation of its power.

analyzed: ayam arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is this.

analyzed: tad tad kārya janana śaktiḥ eva kriyā iti ucyate
translated: The power to produce such and such effects is called action.

original: ataḥ tena rūpeṇa sthirā sā yadā vyajyate tadā vyavahārālambanaṃ tattatkāryajananī ca bhavatīti na kaściddoṣa iti /
analyzed: atas tena rūpeṇa sthirā sā yadā vyajyate tadā vyavahāra ālambanam tad tad kārya jananī ca bhavati iti na kaścid doṣaḥ iti
translated: Therefore, when that [power] is manifested in that form, it becomes the basis of conventional usage and the producer of such and such effects. Thus there is no fault at all.

analyzed: kriyā śaktayā ātmanā vyakti śakti rūpeṇa kāraṇena iti vā
translated: Or, by the manifestation of the power in the form of the power of the individual, which is the cause.

analyzed: nanu kā iyam śakteḥ vyaktiḥ nāma
translated: But what is this so-called manifestation of power?

analyzed: na tāvat pratītiḥ
translated: It is not, to begin with, cognition.

analyzed: īśvara apekṣayā nitya siddha tvena ukta doṣa anuśakteḥ
translated: Because the previously mentioned fault remains, since it is eternally established from the perspective of God.

analyzed: para apekṣayā kadāpi abhāvāt
translated: Because it never exists from the perspective of others.

analyzed: bhāve pi kārya utpādasya tad anapekṣa tvāt
translated: Even if it did exist, the production of the effect would not depend on it.

analyzed: atas eva na āvaraṇa nivṛttiḥ vyaktiḥ iti
translated: For this very reason, manifestation is not the removal of obstruction.

analyzed: mā evam
translated: This is not so.

analyzed: vyakti śabdena śakteḥ eva avasthā viśeṣasya vivakṣita tvāt
translated: Because only a particular state of the power is intended by the word 'manifestation'.

analyzed: tatra yat tāvat uktam
translated: Regarding that, first of all, what was said:

original: yadi sṛṣṭisamaye 'pi saṃhārakriyā syāttadā tathā vyavahriyeteti /
analyzed: yadi sṛṣṭi samaye saṃhāra kriyā syāt tadā tathā vyavahriyeta iti
translated: If the act of dissolution were to occur even at the time of creation, then they would be so designated.

analyzed: tat asat
translated: That is not so.

analyzed: vyakti rūpeṇa eva vyavahāra ālambana tvāt
translated: Because the basis of designation is only in the form of manifestation.

original: yadapi jananavināśau yugapatsyātāmiti tadapi vyaktayavasthāyāmeva śakterjanakatvādanupapannam /
analyzed: yat api janana vināśau yugapad syātām iti tat api vyaktai avasthāyām eva śakteḥ janaka tvāt anupapannam
translated: And what was said about the simultaneity of birth and destruction, that is also not possible, because the power generates only in the state of manifestation.

original: yacca kriyāyā nityatve saṃyogavibhāgotpattisātatyaprasañjanaṃ tadapyevameva parihṛtam /🔽kiṃcaivaṃ paṭasāmagṣāḥ paṭotpattāvanapekṣakāraṇa
analyzed: yat ca kriyāyāḥ nitya tve saṃyoga vibhāga utpatti sātatya prasañjanam tat api evam eva parihṛtam  kiṃca evam paṭa sāmagṣāḥ paṭa utpattau anapekṣa kāraṇa
translated: And the argument that if action is eternal, then conjunction and disjunction would arise continuously, that is also refuted in the same way.

original: tvātpaṭotpattisātatyaṃ syāt /🔽nanu kiṃ sāmagrī tameva paṭaṃ punarjanayatuyet
analyzed: tvāt paṭa utpatti sātatyam syāt  nanu kim sāmagrī tam eva paṭam
translated: Moreover, in this way, since the collection of threads is an independent cause in the production of the cloth, there would be a continuous production of cloth.🔽But how can the collection of threads produce the cloth again?

analyzed: uta paṭa antaram
translated: Or does it produce another cloth?

analyzed: na ādyaḥ
translated: Not the first.

original: paṭaprāgabhāvasyāpi sāmagrīniviṣṭatvāttasya ca paṭotpattyā vinaṣṭatvena sāmagṣā vikalatvāt /
analyzed: paṭa prāgabhāvasya api sāmagrī niviṣṭa tvāt tasya ca paṭa utpattyāḥ vinaṣṭa tvena sāmagṣā vikala tvāt
translated: Because the prior non-existence of the cloth is also included in the collection, and because the collection is incomplete due to its destruction by the production of the cloth.

analyzed: na dvitīyaḥ
translated: Not the second.

analyzed: pūrva paṭena pratibaddha tvāt
translated: Because it is obstructed by the previous cloth.

analyzed: tat katham paṭa utpatti sātatyam
translated: How then is there a continuous production of cloth?

analyzed: satyam
translated: True,

analyzed: samam etat prakṛte pi iti
translated: This is the same in the case of the original (matter).

original: yadapīśvarakriyā saṃyogavibhāgau karoti na veti pṛṣṭham /🔽tatra karotīti brūmaḥ /
analyzed: yat api īśvara kriyā saṃyoga vibhāgau karoti na vā iti pṛṣṭham  tatra karoti iti brūmaḥ
translated: As for the question whether the activity of God produces conjunction and disjunction or not,🔽we say that He does produce them.

analyzed: kuvarntī ca viramyā eva
translated: And He produces them after ceasing (from His activity).

analyzed: na ca tad anupapattiḥ
translated: And this is not impossible.

analyzed: vyaktayā viśiṣṭa tvāt
translated: Because (the activity of God) is qualified by the manifest (world).

analyzed: anyathā avayava kriyā api uttara deśa saṃyogam sva utpatti uttara kṣaṇe eva kuryāt
translated: Otherwise, the activity of the parts would produce conjunction with the subsequent place even in the moment immediately following its origination.

analyzed: na ca kṛta saṃyogasya karmaṇaḥ
translated: And it is not impossible for an action that has produced conjunction to continue to exist.

analyzed: anitya kriyāsu tad vayavasthā upapatteḥ
translated: Because its continuance is possible in non-eternal actions.

original: nanu saṃhārakāle kriyā vyaktā atha na vā /🔽na cetkathaṃ tatra vyavahāro 'rthakriyā vā /
analyzed: nanu saṃhāra kāle kriyā vyaktā atha na vā  na ced katham tatra vyavahāraḥ rtha kriyā vā
translated: Now, at the time of dissolution, is the activity manifest or not?🔽If not, how can there be usage or operation of objects there?

analyzed: ādye katham sṛṣṭi vyavahāra ādi abhāvaḥ
translated: If it is, how can there be no usage, etc. of creation?

analyzed: mā evam
translated: This is not so.

analyzed: vyakteḥ api avāntara ananta viśeṣavat tā aṅgīkārāt
translated: Because even the manifest is accepted to have infinitely many subtle distinctions.

analyzed: tat idam uktam sa viśeṣaḥ pi iti
translated: This is what is said by (the words), Although it has distinctions...

analyzed: evam anaṅgīkāre pareṣām api samānaḥ prasaṅgaḥ
translated: In the same way, even for others, the absurdity is the same if (they) do not accept (this).

analyzed: pārameśvarasya jñāna icchā prayatna lakṣaṇasya saṃhāra vyāpārasya nitya tvāt
translated: Because the operation of dissolution, which is characterized by God's knowledge, will, and effort, is eternal.

original: nityamapi parameśvarecchādikaṃ sahakārisadbhāva eva kāryakārīti cenna /
analyzed: nityam api parameśvara icchā ādikam sahakāri sadbhāve eva kārya kāri iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that even the eternal Supreme Lord's will, etc. produce effects only when auxiliaries are present, that is not so.

analyzed: sahakāriṇam api nitya tvāt
translated: Because the auxiliaries are also eternal.

analyzed: parameśvara icchā ādi āyatta tvāt ca
translated: And because they are dependent on the Supreme Lord's will, etc.

original: necchādimātraṃ saṃhārādikāraṇaṃ kintu sañjihīrṣādikam uta saṃhārādiviśeṣaviśiṣṭaṃ tadeva /
analyzed: na icchā ādi mātram saṃhāra ādi kāraṇam kintu sañjihīrṣā ādikam uta saṃhāra ādi viśeṣa viśiṣṭam tat eva
translated: It is not mere will, etc. that are the cause of dissolution, etc., but rather that which desires to withdraw, etc., or that itself qualified by the particular dissolution, etc.

analyzed: na ādyaḥ
translated: The first is not so.

analyzed: anabhyupagamāt
translated: Because it is not accepted.

analyzed: tatas eva saṃhāra ādi siddhau icchā ādi kalpanā vaiyarthyāt ca
translated: And because the postulation of will, etc. is pointless when dissolution, etc. are established by that alone.

analyzed: sañjihīrṣā ādeḥ ca nitya anitya vikalpa anupapatteḥ
translated: And because the desire to withdraw, etc. cannot be both eternal and non-eternal.

analyzed: na dvitīyaḥ
translated: The second is not so.

original: sati saṃhārādau sañjihīrṣādikaṃ tataḥ saṃhārādiriti parasparāśrayaprasaṅgāt /
analyzed: sati saṃhāra ādau sañjihīrṣā ādikam tatas saṃhāra ādiḥ iti paraspara āśraya prasaṅgāt
translated: Because if dissolution, etc. exist, then the desire to withdraw, etc. exist, and from that dissolution, etc. exist, so there would be the fallacy of mutual dependence.

analyzed: na ca svarūpa satā saṃhāra ādinā icchā ādikam upadhīyate
translated: And dissolution, etc. do not qualify will, etc. which exist in their own form.

analyzed: kintu viṣaya bhūtena iti ced
translated: But rather by being the object, if it is argued.

analyzed: saṃhāra ādi viṣaya tā kim āgantukī
translated: Should the state of being the object of dissolution, etc. be adventitious?

analyzed: athavā nityā iti vaktavyam
translated: Or should it be said to be eternal?

analyzed: na ādyaḥ
translated: The first is not so.

analyzed: guṇeṣu āgantuka dharma utpatteḥ anabhyupagamāt
translated: Because the arising of adventitious properties in the qualities is not accepted.

analyzed: dvitīye tu sarvadā saṃhāra ādi prasaṅgaḥ
translated: But in the second case, there would always be dissolution, etc.

analyzed: tasmāt śakti vyakti rūpa tā sarvathā anusaraṇīyā
translated: Therefore, the form of manifestation of power should be followed in every way.

analyzed: sā ca samā kriyāyām api iti
translated: And that is equal even in action.

original: nanu pārameśvarī jñānādilakṣaṇā saṃhārādikriyā pareṇāpi nityetyaṅgīkṛtam /
analyzed: nanu pārameśvarī jñāna ādi lakṣaṇā saṃhāra ādi kriyā pareṇa api nityā iti aṅgīkṛtam
translated: But the activity characterized by the supreme Lord's knowledge etc., such as withdrawal etc., is accepted by the opponent also as eternal.

analyzed: parispanda lakṣaṇā tu na asti eva
translated: But the activity characterized by vibration does not exist at all.

analyzed: tasmāt vayarthaḥ yam prayatnaḥ
translated: Therefore, this effort is useless.

analyzed: mā evam
translated: This is not so.

analyzed: parispanda abhāve pramāṇa abhāvāt
translated: Because there is no evidence for the absence of vibration.

analyzed: parama mahat parimāṇam asti iti ced na
translated: If it is said that there is the highest magnitude, no.

analyzed: aṇu madhyama parimāṇābhyām sat pratipakṣa tvāt
translated: Because of the counter-evidence of the atomic and medium magnitudes.

original: naca / te na staḥ /🔽paramamahattve 'pi tathā vaktuṃ śakyatvāt /
analyzed: na ca te na staḥ  parama mahattve pi tathā vaktum śakya tvāt
translated: And those two do not exist.🔽Because even in the case of the highest magnitude, it can be said in the same way.

analyzed: aṇoḥ aṇīyān mahataḥ mahīyān iti dvayoḥ api śrauta tvāt
translated: Because both the atomic and the great are mentioned in the scriptures.

analyzed: aṇoḥ aṇīyaḥ tvam apratyakṣa tva upalakṣaṇam iti ced
translated: If it is argued that the atomic nature is a mark of the imperceptible,

original: mahato mahattvamapi paramapūjyatvamiti kiṃ na syāt /
analyzed: mahataḥ mahat tvam api parama pūjya tvam iti kim na syāt
translated: why should not the greatness of the great be the highest honor?

original: virodhādubhayāṅgīkāro nocita iti cet tarhi prathamaprāptatvādaṇutvameva grāhyam /
analyzed: virodhāt ubhaya aṅgīkāraḥ nā ucitaḥ iti ced tarhi prathama prāptatvāt aṇu tvam eva grāhyam
translated: If it is argued that it is not proper to accept both due to contradiction, then the atomic nature should be accepted because it is the first to be obtained.

analyzed: parihariṣyate ca ayam virodhaḥ iti
translated: And this contradiction will be resolved.

analyzed: śakti tā vyakti tā ca iti
translated: The difference is also between potentiality and manifestation.

original: nanu cakriyāyāḥ śaktivyaktirūpe parasparaṃ bhinne 'bhinne vā /🔽ādye śaktireva nityā kriyātvanityetyāpannam /
analyzed: nanu ca kriyāyāḥ śakti vyakti rūpe parasparam bhinne bhinne vā  ādye śaktiḥ eva nityā kriyā tu anityā iti āpannam
translated: Now, is the potentiality and manifestation of action either different from each other or non-different?🔽In the first case, it follows that potentiality alone is eternal and action is non-eternal.
