analyzed: mahāpralaye parameśvareṇa nigīrṇam mahat ādi kāryam tat śarīra rūpaka pradhāna tām gacchati
translated: At the time of the great dissolution, the effect beginning with Mahat, which is swallowed by the Supreme Lord, becomes the principal form of His body.

analyzed: tat ca pradhānam punar mahat ādi kārya upādānam bhavati iti aṅgīkārāt iti
translated: And that Pradhana again becomes the material cause of the effect beginning with Mahat. Because this is accepted.

analyzed: etena ūrṇanābhi ādīnām na vikāri tvaṃtā
translated: By this, the fact that the spider, the wheel-turner, etc. are not modifications

analyzed: ced nirupādānā tantu ādi utpattiḥ prasajyate iti api nirastam
translated: And if it is said that this is not so because the production of threads, etc. would be without a material cause, that is also refuted.

original: evaṃ śrutipurāṇayuktibhirbrahmaṇo nirvikāratvāvagamānna jagadupādānakāraṇatvaṃ kintu nimittatvamevetyuktam /🔽adhunā śrutismṛtipurāṇayukti
analyzed: evam śruti purāṇa yuktibhiḥ brahmaṇaḥ nirvikāra tva avagamāt na jagat upādānakāraṇatvam kintu nimittatvam eva iti uktam  adhunā śruti smṛti purāṇa yukti
translated: Thus, it has been said that Brahman is not the material cause of the world, but only the instrumental cause, because its changelessness is understood from the scriptures, Puranas and reasonings.

analyzed: bhiḥ nimitta tvasya eva ukta tvāt api iti āha apādāna tayā iti
translated: Now, it is also said that it is only the instrumental cause, because it is stated as such by the scriptures, Smritis, Puranas and reasonings. He says as the material cause etc.

analyzed: apādāna tayā viśva kartṛ tvam buddhi pūrvakam
translated: The world is created by Brahman as the material cause, with a purpose, and with intelligence.

analyzed: uktam bhāllavi śākhāyām brahmatarke ca sādaram
translated: This is stated respectfully in the Bhallāvi Śākhā and in the Brahmatarka.

analyzed: viśvakartṛ tvam iti eva iti ukte kulāla ādīnām iva taṭastha kartṛ tvam pratīyate
translated: When it is said that Brahman is the creator of the world, it is understood that it is an independent creation like that of a potter etc.

analyzed: tad nivṛtti atharma pādānatayā iti uktam
translated: To avoid that, it is said that Brahman is the material cause.

analyzed: apādāna tvam iti eva
translated: The case ending is only🔽

analyzed: kte parasya na an iṣyam
translated: If it were said simply the state of being an apadeśa, the opponent would not accept it.

analyzed: upādānasya api apādāna viśeṣa tvena apādāna tva apādāna tvayoḥ avirodhāt
translated: Because even the upādāna, being a particular kind of apadeśa, is an apadeśa, and there is no contradiction between being an apadeśa and being an upādāna.

analyzed: apādāna viśeṣa vivakṣāyām ca parṇa patane vṛkṣasya iva avadhi tva mātram pratīyate
translated: And when the particular apadeśa is intended, only the state of being a limit is understood, like a tree in the falling of a leaf.

analyzed: atas viśvakartṛ tvam iti uktam
translated: Therefore, the state of being the creator of the universe is said.

analyzed: tathā api buddhi pūrvakam iti vyartham
translated: Even so, with prior intention is useless.

analyzed: kartuḥ buddhimatva niyamāt iti
translated: Because it is a rule that an agent must be intelligent.

analyzed: mā evam
translated: This is not so.

analyzed: aśeṣa viśeṣa jñānasya vivakṣita tvāt
translated: Because the knowledge of all particulars is intended.

analyzed: etat uktam bhavati  sakala kārya kriyā kāraka phala viṣaya buddhayā ādimān īśvaraḥ bāhyena rūpeṇa anugṛhṇan āntareṇa
translated: This is what is meant:

analyzed: pradhāna ādīnām pariṇāma ādi śaktīḥ prerayan sva śarīra rūpaka pradhāna ādi pariṇāma bhūta mahat ādi kārya apagame vadhiḥ bhavati iti
translated: God, who possesses the intellect etc. that have as their object all the actions, instruments and results of creation, by favoring through an external form, by stimulating the powers of transformation etc. of pradhāna etc. through an internal form, becomes the limit when the effects such as mahat etc. that have transformed into the form of his own body, pradhāna etc., are destroyed.

analyzed: sa ādara tvam darśayiṣyāmaḥ
translated: We will show the earnestness.

analyzed: tat eva vākya dvayam krameṇa paṭhati icchā mātrāt iti
translated: He quotes those two sentences in order, beginning with by mere will.

analyzed: icchā mātrāt prabhoḥ sṛṣṭiḥ avikārasya sarvadā
translated: The creation is by mere will of the Lord, who is changeless at all times.🔽...

analyzed: svabhāvaḥ yam anantasya rajaḥ yena abhavat jagat
translated: This is the nature of the infinite, by which the world came into being.

analyzed: sva deha ādi chayā viśvam bhukta pūrvam janārdanaḥ
translated: Janardana, having previously enjoyed the universe with his own body, created it

analyzed: sasarja mātā pitṛ vat ūrṇanābhi vat eva vā
translated: as if it were his mother and father, or as if it were the navel of the universe.

analyzed: na tu pariṇāmitayā iti mātrā arthaḥ
translated: The word only means for that purpose, not for transformation.

original: tatra heturavikārasyeti /🔽kiṃ prayojanāddeśenetyata uktam svabhāva iti //
analyzed: tatra hetuḥ avikārasya iti  kim prayojanāt deśena iti atas uktam svabhāvaḥ iti
translated: The reason is stated as of the unchanging one.🔽For what purpose is it stated? For that purpose, it is said.🔽The nature is said.

analyzed: upādāna abhāvāt katham iti atas uktam rajaḥ iti
translated: How is it so, due to the absence of material cause? For that reason, it is said by rajas.

original: yena preritaṃ rajaḥśabdopalakṣitaṃ guṇatrayātmakaṃ pradhānaṃ jagadabhavat /
analyzed: yena preritam rajaḥ śabda upalakṣitam guṇatraya ātmakam pradhānam jagat abhavat
translated: By which rajas, indicated by the word rajas, the prakriti consisting of the three gunas, the world came into being.

analyzed: atra upapādanena ādaraḥ pratīyate
translated: Here, the respect is conveyed by the explanation.

analyzed: sva dehāt saccidānanda ādi ātmaka avadadheḥ
translated: From his own body, which is of the nature of existence, knowledge, bliss, etc.

analyzed: athavā sva dehāt pradhānāt upādānāt
translated: Or, from his own body, which is the material cause, the prakriti.

analyzed: bhukta pūrvam pūrva kalpe bhuktena
translated: Similar to what was enjoyed in a previous kalpa, what was enjoyed

analyzed: saṃhṛtena sadṛśam
translated: and withdrawn.

analyzed: bhukta pūrvam sūkṣma bhāva stha upādānakam iti vā
translated: Or, what was enjoyed in a subtle state, which is the material cause.

analyzed: eva śabdena na tu mṛd ādi vat iti āha
translated: By the word only, it is said not like clay, etc.

analyzed: vā śabdaḥ dṛṣṭānta samuccaye
translated: The word or is for the inclusion of examples.

analyzed: sva dehāt iti bhukta pūrvam iti ca vivṛṇoti pradhānam iti
translated: He explains from his own body and what was enjoyed as the prakriti.

analyzed: pradhānam pariṇāmya īśaḥ nirvikāraḥ svayam sadā
translated: The Lord, having transformed the primordial matter, is always himself changeless.

analyzed: eva śabda uktasya upapādanam nirvikāraḥ iti
translated: The explanation of what is stated by the word eva (only) is is always himself changeless.

analyzed: atra api pūrvavat ādaraḥ gamyate
translated: Here also, as before, respect (for the opponent's view) is understood.

analyzed: prāk cetana tvāt iti anena trayaḥ prayogāḥ sūcitāḥ
translated: And by before consciousness three arguments are indicated.

analyzed: pitāputrau na upādāna upādeya bhūtau cetana tvāt devadatta yajñadatta vat
translated: The father and son are not the material cause and the effect, because of being conscious, like Devadatta and Yajnadatta.

analyzed: putra ādi acetano
translated: The son and other non-conscious things.

analyzed: na pitṛ ādi cetanā upādānakaḥ
translated: Are not the material cause of the conscious father and others.

analyzed: acetana tvāt ghaṭa vat
translated: Because of being non-conscious, like a pot.

analyzed: putra ādi cetanaḥ na
translated: The conscious son and others are not the effect of the non-conscious father and others.

analyzed: cetana tvāt brahma vahma ādi vat iti
translated: Because of being conscious, like Brahman and other conscious beings.

analyzed: sarvatra pakṣa dharmatāyāḥ ca niścita tvāt
translated: And because the presence of the reason in the subject is certain in all cases.

analyzed: dvitīye tāvat vayāptim upapādayati na cetana vikāraḥ syāt iti
translated: First, he explains the pervasion in the second argument, saying it would not be a modification of a conscious being.

original: na cetanavikāraḥ syād yatra kvāpi hyacetanam // / / // /
analyzed: na cetana vikāraḥ syāt yatra kvāpi hi acetanam
translated: No non-conscious thing can ever be a modification of a conscious being.

original: yadi khalu yatra kvāpi deśe kāle vācetanaṃ cetanavikāro dṛṣṭaḥ syāttadaivaṃ vyāptirbhajyeta /
analyzed: yadi khalu yatra kvāpi deśe kāle vā acetanam cetana vikāraḥ dṛṣṭaḥ syāt tadā evam vyāptiḥ bhajyeta
translated: If a non-conscious thing were seen as a modification of a conscious being somewhere, then the pervasion would be broken.

analyzed: na ca evam iti arthaḥ
translated: But it is not so, is the meaning.

analyzed: mahat ādi jagat brahma kāryam upalabdham iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that the world beginning with Mahat is perceived as the effect of Brahman, that is not so.

analyzed: adya api asiddheḥ
translated: Because it is not yet established.

analyzed: ukta vakṣyamāṇa pramāṇaiḥ nirākṛta tvāt ca
translated: And because it has been refuted by the proofs stated and to be stated.

analyzed: tṛtīye vyāptim upapādayati na acetanā iti
translated: In the third, he explains the pervasion, saying not even an effect of the non-sentient...

analyzed: na acetana vikāraḥ cetanaḥ syāt kadācana
translated: Not even an effect of the non-sentient could ever be sentient...

analyzed: vyākhyānam pūrvavat
translated: The explanation is as before.

analyzed: evam na cetana vikāraḥ cetanaḥ u pi upalabdhaḥ iti ādye pi vyāptiḥ upapādanīyā
translated: Thus, the pervasion should be established in the first also, that a sentient being is not perceived as an effect of a sentient being.

analyzed: athavā mahat ādikam na cetana vikāraḥ
translated: Or, the great principle and so on are not effects of a sentient being.

original: acetanatvādghaṭavaditi yuktyantaraviruddhaṃ ca brahmaṇo jagadupādānatvamiti cetasi nidhāyāsya vyāptimupapādayati na cetaneti //
analyzed: acetana tvāt ghaṭa vat iti yukti antara viruddham ca brahmaṇaḥ jagat upādānatvam iti cetasi nidhāya asya vyāptim upapādayati na cetanā iti
translated: Brahman's being the material cause of the world is contradicted by another reason, that it is not sentient, like a pot. Keeping this in mind, he explains the pervasion, saying not even an effect of the non-sentient...

analyzed: nanu ghaṭa ādayaḥ pi brahma vikārāḥ iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that pots and so on are also effects of Brahman, it is not so.

analyzed: mṛd ādi vikāra tvasya pramita tvāt
translated: Because their being effects of clay and so on is well-known.

analyzed: paramparayā iti ced
translated: If it is argued that it is so by a series of effects,

analyzed: evam tarhi na svayam cetana vikārāḥ
translated: then it would be said that they are not themselves effects of a sentient being,

analyzed: kintu tad kāraṇāni iti uktam syāt
translated: but rather are causes of that.

analyzed: tathā ca katham na dṛṣṭānta tā
translated: And how then is it not an example?

analyzed: tarhi tad kāraṇeṣu vyabhicāraḥ iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that there is deviation in those causes, it is not so.

analyzed: teṣām eva pakṣa tvāt
translated: Because they themselves are the subject.

analyzed: sukha duḥkha ādiṣu anaikāntika tvam iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that it is inconclusive in pleasure, pain and so on, it is not so.

analyzed: teṣām antaḥkaraṇa vikāra tva abhyupagamāt
translated: Because they are accepted as modifications of the internal organ.

analyzed: etena etat api pratyuktam
translated: By this, this is also refuted:

analyzed: jagat abhinna nimitta upādānam prekṣā pūrva janita kārya tvāt sukha ādi vat iti
translated: The world has an undifferentiated cause and material cause, because it is produced with a purpose, like pleasure, etc.

analyzed: ghaṭa ādiṣu vyabhicāra rāccaḥ ca
translated: And because there is deviation in pots, etc.

analyzed: teṣām api pakṣīkaraṇe pramāṇa bādhaḥ syāt
translated: If they are also taken as the subject, there would be contradiction by valid cognition.

analyzed: nanu acetanam api jagat cetana vikāraḥ ced tadā kaḥ doṣaḥ syāt
translated: If the insentient world is a modification of the sentient, then what fault would there be?

analyzed: evam tarhi cetanā u pi acetana vikāraḥ syāt
translated: If so, then the sentient would also be a modification of the insentient.

analyzed: na ca etat asti iti āha na acetana iti
translated: And this is not so, he says: the insentient is not a modification of the sentient.

analyzed: ayam abhisandhiḥ
translated: This is the intention:

analyzed: yadi mahat ādikam brahmaṇaḥ vikāraḥ syāt tarhi tat svarūpa anugatimat prasajyeta
translated: If the great elements, etc. were modifications of Brahman, then they would be subject to conformity with its nature.

analyzed: kārye kāraṇa svarūpa anugama darśanāt
translated: Because the nature of the cause is seen to conform to the effect.

analyzed: ghaṭa ādayaḥ mṛd vikārāḥ mṛd anugatimantaḥ dṛṣṭāḥ
translated: Pots, etc., which are modifications of clay, are seen to conform to clay.

analyzed: na ca etat asti
translated: And this is not so.

analyzed: tasmāt na mahādādiḥ
translated: Therefore the great elements, etc.

analyzed: brahma vikāraḥ
translated: are not modifications of Brahman.

original: yadi punaḥ kāraṇasvarūpānugamamantareṇa vikārivikārabhāvo 'bhyupagamyate tadā cetano 'pyacetanavikāraḥ kiṃ nābhyupagantavyaḥ /
analyzed: yadi punar kāraṇa svarūpa anugamam antareṇa vikāri vikāra bhāvaḥ bhyupagamyate tadā cetanā u pi acetana vikāraḥ kim na abhyupagantavyaḥ
translated: But if the relation of modification and modified is accepted without conformity to the nature of the cause, then why should not the sentient be accepted as a modification of the insentient?

analyzed: na ca evam aṅgīkṛtam pareṇa
translated: And this is not accepted by the opponent.

analyzed: tathā hi sati ekaḥ ātmanaḥ śarīre bhāvāt
translated: Thus, in the passage 'because the one Self exists in the body',

original: ityatra parasya bhūtacatuṣyayapariṇāma evāyaṃ cetanavānkāya iti vadantaṃ cārvākaṃ
analyzed: iti atra parasya bhūta catuṣyaya pariṇāmaḥ eva ayam cetanavān kāyaḥ iti vadantam cārvākam
translated: when the Carvaka argues that this sentient body is merely a transformation of the four elements,

original: prati bhūteṣvavidyamānaṃ caitanyaṃ kathaṃ kārye syāditi parihāro madirādravye madaśaktivatsyāditi
analyzed: prati bhūteṣu avidyamānam caitanyam katham kārye syāt iti parihāraḥ madirā dravye mada śakti vat syāt iti
translated: the reply is that how can sentience, which does not exist in the elements, be in the effect? It may be like the power of intoxication in the substance of liquor.

original: punaśca cārvākeṇa codite madiropādāne 'pi sūkṣmarūpamadaśaktivyutpādanaṃ ca vyāhataṃ syāditi / /
analyzed: punar ca cārvākeṇa codite madirā upādāne sūkṣma rūpa mada śakti vyutpādanam ca vyāhatam syāt iti
translated: And again, when the Carvaka objects, the explanation of the subtle form of the power of intoxication in the substance of liquor would be contradicted.

analyzed: yat vā brahma jagatī nā upādāna upādeya bhāvavatī vilakṣaṇa tvāt devadatta ghaṭa vat
translated: Or, the Brahman and the world do not have the relation of material cause and effect, because they are different, like Devadatta and a pot.

original: nanu vilakṣaṇānāmapi mṛdghaṭādīnāmupādānopādeyabhāvo dṛśyata iti cenna /
analyzed: nanu vilakṣaṇānām api mṛd ghaṭa ādīnām upādāna upādeya bhāvaḥ dṛśyate iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that even different things like clay and a pot are seen to have the relation of material cause and effect, it is not so.

analyzed: cetana acetana rūpa vailakṣaṇyasya vivakṣita tvāt
translated: Because the difference in the form of sentient and non-sentient is intended.

original: anumānāntaraṃ vaktuṃ vyāptiniścayāya vyatirekavyāptiṃ tāvadāha ceti /
analyzed: anumāna antaram vaktum vyāpti niścayāya vyatireka vyāptim tāvat āha ca iti
translated: To state another inference, in order to ascertain the pervasion, he first states the negative pervasion: 'If' etc.

analyzed: na ca anyasya anya rūpa tvam vikṛta tve dṛśyate
translated: And the form of one thing is not seen to be different even when transformed.

analyzed: api ca iti yukti samuccaye
translated: And 'if' etc. is for the accumulation of reasons.

analyzed: vikṛti tatve vikṛti daśāyām anyasya anya rūpa tvam anya vikāra tvam na dṛśyate
translated: In the case of modification, in the state of modification, the form of one thing as another, the modification of another, is not seen.

original: vikāravikāriṇāvanyonyamanyatayā kvāpi nopalabdhāviti yāvat /🔽atra dṛṣṭāntamāha neti //
analyzed: vikāra vikāriṇau anyonyam anyatayā kvāpi na upalabdhau iti yāvat  atra dṛṣṭāntam āha na iti
translated: The modified and the modifier are not perceived as different from each other anywhere.

original: na kṣīrādanyatā dadhnaḥ kenacid dṛśyate kvacit // / / //
analyzed: na kṣīrāt anya tā dadhnaḥ kenacid dṛśyate kvacid
translated: Here, he gives an example: No one sees curd as different from milk anywhere.

original: yasya kṣīrasya vikāro yaddadhi tasmātkṣīrādanyatā tasya dadhnaḥ kenāpi kvāpi na dṛśyata ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: yasya kṣīrasya vikāraḥ yat dadhi tasmāt kṣīrāt anya tā tasya dadhnaḥ kena api kvāpi na dṛśyate iti arthaḥ
translated: The curd, which is the modification of that milk, is not seen by anyone as different from that milk. This is the meaning.

original: evamanyatādarśanasya siddhā vikāravikāribhāvādvayāvṛttiḥ /🔽tataḥ kimityata āha sarvajñāditi //
analyzed: evam anya tā darśanasya siddhā vikāra vikāri bhāva advaya āvṛttiḥ  tatas kim iti atas āha sarvajñāt iti
translated: Thus, the exclusion of the perception of difference is established from the relation of the modified and the modifier.

analyzed: sarvajñāt brahmaṇaḥ jagataḥ hi anubhūyate
translated: What follows from this? Therefore, he says: The difference of the world from the omniscient Brahman is experienced.

analyzed: hi śabdaḥ yasmāt iti arthe
translated: The word hi means because.

analyzed: tasmāt na tayoḥ vikāra vikāri bhāvaḥ iti śeṣaḥ
translated: Therefore, there is no relation of the modified and the modifier between them. This is the remainder.

analyzed: ayam atra prayogaḥ
translated: Here is the argument:

analyzed: jagat brahma vikāraḥ na bhavati
translated: The world is not a modification of Brahman

analyzed: tatas nya tvena upalabhyamāna tvāt
translated: because it is perceived as different from it.

original: yo yato 'nyatvenopalabhyate na sa tadvikāro yathā ghaṭaḥ paṭasya /
analyzed: yaḥ yatas na sa tad vikāraḥ yathā ghaṭaḥ paṭasya
translated: That which is perceived as different from something is not its modification, like a pot is not a modification of a cloth.

analyzed: yaḥ ca yad vikāraḥ na asau tatas
translated: And that which is a modification of something else is not perceived as different from it.

analyzed: yathā dadhi kṣīrāt iti
translated: Like curd from milk.

analyzed: yat vā jagat brahmaṇī na anyonya vikāra vikāriṇī
translated: Or, the world and Brahman are not mutually modifying and modified,

analyzed: anyonyam anya tvena upalabhyamāna tvāt
translated: because they are mutually perceived as different.

analyzed: ghaṭa paṭa vat iti prayogaḥ
translated: The application of the argument is: like a pot and a cloth.

analyzed: na ca ayam asiddhaḥ hetuḥ
translated: And this reason is not unestablished.

analyzed: yaḥ iti brahmaṇaḥ sarvajña tva śravaṇāt
translated: Because Brahman is said to be omniscient,

analyzed: jñāna kāryasya sarvathā api anupalambhena jagataḥ jñāna abhāva anumānāt
translated: because the absence of knowledge of the world is inferred from the non-apprehension of the effect of knowledge in any way,

analyzed: viruddha dharma adhikaraṇayoḥ ca anyonyam anya tva upalambha niyamāt iti bhāvena uktam sarvajñāt iti
translated: and because that which has contradictory properties is invariably perceived as different from each other. With this in mind, it is said: Omniscience, etc.

analyzed: nanu vikāra vikāriṇoḥ bheda abhyupagamāt katham ayam hetuḥ iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that since the difference of modification and modifier is accepted, how can this be a reason, it is not so.

analyzed: bhedena eva upalambhasya hetu tvāt
translated: Because the perception itself as different is the reason.

analyzed: tat kim tvad abhyupagama mātreṇa ghaṭa paṭayoḥ abhedaḥ
translated: Then, is the non-difference of pot and cloth only due to your mere acceptance?

analyzed: uta upalambhāt
translated: Or due to perception?

analyzed: na ādyaḥ mad abhyupagamena śuddha bhedasya eva grāhya tvāt
translated: Not the first. Because only the pure difference is to be grasped by my acceptance.

analyzed: na dvitīyaḥ  asiddheḥ
translated: Not the second.🔽Because of non-establishment.

analyzed: abheda anupalambhaḥ vā hetu tvena vivakṣitaḥ
translated: Or the non-apprehension of non-difference is intended as the reason.

analyzed: nanu ayam asiddhaḥ hetuḥ
translated: But this reason is unestablished.

analyzed: jagat brahmaṇā abhinnam sattvāt brahma vat iti anumānena abheda upalambhāt iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that the non-difference is perceived by the inference The world is non-different from Brahman because of existence, like Brahman, it is not so.

analyzed: kharvam svarṇena abhinnam
translated: The lump of iron is non-different from gold.

analyzed: sattvāt sva ṇarvat iti ābhāsamāna yogakṣema tvāt iti āha abhedaḥ iti
translated: Because of existence, like gold. This is the similarity and safety. He says: The non-difference.

analyzed: abhedaḥ sattva mātreṇa syāt kharva su aṇayoḥ api
translated: The non-difference would be by mere existence, even in the case of the lump of iron and gold.

analyzed: yadi jagat brahmaṇoḥ sādhyeta tarhi iti śeṣaḥ
translated: If it were established between the world and Brahman, then - this is the remainder.

analyzed: kharvam ayaḥ kharparam vā
translated: The lump of iron or the iron pan.

analyzed: nanu idam iṣyam eva
translated: But is this not accepted?

analyzed: kharva suvarṇayoḥ abhedasya mayā aṅgīkṛta tvāt iti ced na
translated: Because the non-difference of the lump of iron and gold is accepted by me. If it is said no,

analyzed: abheda śabdena bheda abhāvasya vivakṣita tvāt
translated: because the absence of difference is intended by the word non-difference.

analyzed: atra pramāṇa virodhaḥ iti ced
translated: If it is said that there is contradiction with valid cognition here,

analyzed: jagat brahmaṇaḥ tyantam bhidyate
translated: the world is absolutely different from Brahman, because it is devoid of the nature of that,

analyzed: śūnya tvāt iti
translated: like a pot.

analyzed: tvad anumānasya api
translated: The same reply applies to your inference also.

analyzed: pramāṇa virodhaḥ samam samādhānam
translated: That there is contradiction with valid cognition.

analyzed: atyanta bhedaḥ mama na kvāpi iti aprasiddha viśeṣaṇa tā iti ced na
translated: If it is said that the absolute difference is not accepted by me anywhere, then the qualifier is not well-known. It is not so.

analyzed: mokṣa abhāva prasaṅgāt
translated: Because the consequence of the absence of liberation would follow.

analyzed: tathā hi
translated: It is as follows.

analyzed: jñānena nivṛtta karmaṇā ca mokṣaḥ bhyupeyase
translated: Liberation is accepted to be attained by knowledge and the cessation of action.

analyzed: tat ca atra jñānam ajñānam api bhavati
translated: And that knowledge is also ignorance,

original: nivṛttaṃ karma pravṛttamapi bhavatīti kathaṃ mokṣasādhanaṃ syāt /
analyzed: nivṛttam karma pravṛttam api bhavati iti katham mokṣa sādhanam syāt
translated: and the ceased action is also engaged. How could it be the means of liberation?

analyzed: jñāna tva ādinā tad bhāve jñāna ādeḥ api tad bhāvaḥ
translated: If it were so by being knowledge etc., ignorance etc. would also be so.

analyzed: tathātvam syāt  jñāna ādikam jñāna ādi svarūpeṇa atyanta abhinnam ajñāna ādi svarūpeṇa tu
translated: It would be so.

analyzed: bhinna abhinnam atas na kārya saṅkaraḥ iti ced
translated: If knowledge etc. is absolutely non-different from the nature of knowledge etc., but different and non-different from the nature of ignorance etc., then there is no confusion of effects. If this is argued,

analyzed: tathā api ajñāna ādi abhedena sva kāryasya kartavya tvāt
translated: even so, because the effect must be produced by non-difference from ignorance etc.,

analyzed: evam saṃsāra abhinnaḥ iti amokṣaḥ syāt  mokṣa ātma tānā
translated: in the same way, liberation would also be non-different from worldly existence, so there would be no liberation.🔽If it is argued that it is liberation because of the existence of the nature of liberation,

analyzed: sadbhāvena mokṣa tve tathā syāt
translated: then worldly existence would also be so.

analyzed: yadi vācā ayam abhedaḥ na upalabhyamānaḥ rthakriyāsu nā upayujyate
translated: Or if this non-difference is not perceived and is not useful in practical effects,

analyzed: tadā vyasani tayā eva abhyupagantavyaḥ syāt iti
translated: then it should be accepted only out of obstinacy.

analyzed: brahma svarūpa anugati śūnya tvāt na tad pariṇāmaḥ yam prapañcaḥ iti uktam
translated: It has been said that this world is not a transformation of Brahman because it is devoid of conformity to the nature of Brahman.

analyzed: tatra kim sarva svarūpa anugati śūnyatā abhipretā
translated: There, is it intended that it is devoid of conformity to all forms?

analyzed: uta kiñcid anugama śūnyatā
translated: Or is it devoid of any continuity?

analyzed: na ādyaḥ
translated: The first is not so.

analyzed: sarva anugama abhāve ghaṭa ādīnām
translated: Because even in the absence of all continuity, the fact of pots etc. being modifications of clay etc. is seen.

analyzed: na dvitīyaḥ
translated: The second is not so.

analyzed: sattva anugamena vikāra vikāri bhāva upapatteḥ iti atas āha abhedaḥ iti
translated: Because the relation of modifier and modified is possible by the continuity of existence. To this he says: Non-difference.

analyzed: abhedaḥ vikāra vikāri bhāvaḥ
translated: Non-difference is the relation of modifier and modified.

analyzed: nanu na suvarṇa gatam sattvam kharve nugatam
translated: But the existence in gold is not continuous in the earring.

analyzed: tat katham ayam prasaṅgaḥ
translated: How then is this contingency?

analyzed: tat kim brahma sattvam eva viyat ādīnām  addhā iti ced na
translated: Then is the existence of Brahman itself of ether etc.?

analyzed: pramāṇa abhāvāt
translated: If it is said no, because there is no proof,

analyzed: prāṇāḥ vai satyam teṣām eva satyam
translated: because the statement The vital breaths are truth, their truth alone

analyzed: ityādi śruteḥ prāṇa satya tvasya brahma adhīna tā artha tva upapatteḥ
translated: and other statements can be explained as meaning that the truth of the vital breaths is dependent on Brahman.

original: brahmaṇa eva sāmānyasattā viyadādāvanugateti cettarhi kathaṃ na svarṇasattā kharve 'nugatā / /🔽atha manyase kāraṇameva kāryātmanā bhavatīti pariṇāmavādināṃ matam /
analyzed: brahmaṇaḥ eva sāmānya sattā viyat ādau anugatā iti ced tarhi katham na svarṇa sattā kharve nugatā  atha manyase kāraṇam eva kārya ātmanā bhavati iti pariṇāma vādinām matam
translated: If it is said that the general existence of Brahman alone is continuous in ether etc., then how is the existence of gold not continuous in the earring?🔽Or if you think that the cause itself becomes the form of the effect, according to the view of the proponents of transformation,

analyzed: tatas ca kāraṇam yat svabhāva avyabhicāri tad anugamaḥ kārye vaśyā abhyupagantavyaḥ
translated: and from that it must be accepted that the continuity of the cause, which is invariable in nature, is necessarily accepted in the effect,

original: anyathā kāraṇameva kāryātmanā bhavatīti riktaṃ vacaḥ syāt /
analyzed: anyathā kāraṇam eva kārya ātmanā bhavati iti riktam vacaḥ syāt
translated: Otherwise, the cause itself would become the effect, and the statement would be empty.

analyzed: avyabhicarita svabhāva ananugame kāraṇasya eva ananugama prāpteḥ
translated: Because if the invariable nature is not followed, the cause itself would not be followed.

analyzed: na ca sat mātra svabhāvam suvarṇam
translated: And gold does not have the nature of mere existence.

analyzed: yena kharvam tad vikāraḥ syāt
translated: By which the lump would be its modification.

analyzed: kintu tad avyabhicāri suvarṇa tva ādi anugame sati iti
translated: But rather, when its invariable nature as gold, etc. is followed.

original: evaṃ tarhi jagadapi kathaṃ brahmapariṇāmaḥ syāt /
analyzed: evam tarhi jagat api katham brahma pariṇāmaḥ syāt
translated: If so, then how could the world also be a modification of Brahman?

analyzed: nahi sat mātra svabhāvam brahma
translated: For Brahman does not have the nature of mere existence.

analyzed: kintu vijñānam ānandam brahma ityādi śrutyā vijñāna ādīnām api tad avyabhicāri svabhāva tva avagamāt
translated: But by the scriptures such as Brahman is consciousness, bliss, the invariable nature of consciousness, etc. is understood.

analyzed: na ca vijñāna ānanda ādi anugamaḥ prapañce sti iti samam
translated: And the world does not have the invariable nature of consciousness, bliss, etc., so it is the same.

original: nanu ca kṣīrāvyabhicārisvabhāvamādhuryānugatividhuraṃ dadhi tadvikāro dṛṣṭamiti cenna /
analyzed: nanu ca kṣīra avyabhicāri svabhāva mādhurya anugati vidhuram dadhi tad vikāraḥ dṛṣṭam iti ced na
translated: But curd is seen to be a modification of milk, although it does not have the invariable nature of sweetness of milk, which is contradicted.

analyzed: satkārya vāda bhaṅga prasaṅgāt
translated: No, because it would lead to the refutation of the doctrine of satkārya (effect pre-exists in the cause).

original: kiñca kṣīrakāryaṃ dadhīti niścaye na mādhuryaṃ kṣīrasvabhāva iti kalpyate /
analyzed: kiñca kṣīra kāryam dadhi iti niścaye na mādhuryam kṣīra svabhāvaḥ iti kalpyate
translated: Moreover, when it is ascertained that curd is the effect of milk, sweetness is not imagined to be the nature of milk.

original: mādhuryasya kṣīrasvabhāvatāniścaye vā kṣīravināśe tatkāraṇasya dadhyupādānatvaṃ kalpyata sati na doṣaḥ /
analyzed: mādhuryasya kṣīra svabhāva tā niścaye vā kṣīra vināśe tad kāraṇasya dadhi upādāna tvam sati na doṣaḥ
translated: Or, if the nature of milk as sweetness is ascertained, then when the milk is destroyed, the cause of that, curd, is imagined to be the material cause, and there is no fault in that.

original: api cāgamairanumānaiśca brahmaṇo nirvikāratve siddhe sati apracyutasvarūpasvabhāvasyaiva brahmaṇo
analyzed: api ca āgamaiḥ anumānaiḥ ca brahmaṇaḥ nirvikāra tve siddhe sati apracyuta svarūpa svabhāvasya eva brahmaṇaḥ
translated: Moreover, when the changelessness of Brahman is established by scriptures and inferences, then for one who thinks that Brahman, whose nature is not lost,

original: jagadupādānatvaṃ yo manyate taṃ pratyetau prasaṅgaviparyayāvuktāviti ko virodhaḥ /
analyzed: jagat upādāna tvam yaḥ manyate tam prati etau prasaṅga viparyayau uktau iti kaḥ virodhaḥ
translated: is the material cause of the world, these two consequences and their reversals are stated. What contradiction is there?

original: etena pradhānasya jagadupādanatve 'pyayaṃ samāno doṣa iti nirastam / /
analyzed: etena pradhānasya jagat upādana tve pi ayam samānaḥ doṣaḥ iti nirastam
translated: By this, it is refuted that this same fault is common even when Prakriti is the material cause of the world.

analyzed: atha matam
translated: Now, if it is thought:

analyzed: dvi rūpam brahma abhyupagamyate ananta ānanda cit ātmakam sat ātmakam ca iti
translated: Brahman is accepted to have two forms: consisting of infinite bliss and consciousness, and consisting of existence.

analyzed: tatra ādyena rūpeṇa nimittam
translated: Of these, by the first form it is the instrumental cause.

analyzed: dvitīyena upādānam
translated: By the second it is the material cause.

analyzed: atas na kaścid uktaḥ doṣaḥ
translated: Therefore, none of the stated faults apply.

analyzed: tathā hi
translated: To explain:

analyzed: yat tāvat uktam nirvikāra tvam tat cicchakti viṣaya tvāt śati ādeḥ adūṣaṇam
translated: What was said about changelessness is not a fault for consciousness and existence, because it pertains to the power of consciousness.

original: nimittakāraṇena cicchaktikena prakṛtipradhānādyabhidhānaṃ sacchaktikaṃ brahma pariṇamatītyaṅgīkāre
analyzed: nimitta kāraṇena cicchaktikena prakṛti pradhāna ādi abhidhānam sat śaktikam brahma pariṇamati iti aṅgīkāre
translated: When it is accepted that Brahman, which is called Prakriti, Pradhana, etc., and which has the power of existence, transforms by means of the instrumental cause, which has the power of consciousness,

original: na yuktivirodho 'pi sadātmakasya jagadupādānatvāccaitanyādyananugame 'pi na doṣaḥ /
analyzed: na sat ātmakasya jagat upādāna tvāt caitanya ādi ananugame pi na doṣaḥ
translated: Nor is there any contradiction with reasoning, because the world is the material cause of what has the nature of existence. And even if consciousness etc. are not universal, there is no fault.

analyzed: sat anugamasya vidyamāna tvāt
translated: Because the universal existence is present.

analyzed: anyatva darśanam ca na viruddhayate sarvajñāt
translated: And the view of difference is not contradicted by the omniscient one.

analyzed: tad nimittam eva na upādānam
translated: That is the cause, not the material cause.

analyzed: yat ca upādānam sat rūpam tasmāt bhedena upalabhyate iti āśaṅkayā āha bhogena iti
translated: And what is the material cause, which has the nature of existence, is perceived as different from that. Fearing this, he says by enjoyment, etc.

analyzed: bhāgena pariṇāmaḥ ced bhāgayoḥ bhedaḥ eva hi
translated: If there is transformation by a part, then there is difference between the two parts.

analyzed: yadi brahmaṇaḥ pariṇāmaḥ cit bhāgena nirvikāra tvam aṅgīkriyate
translated: If it is accepted that there is transformation of Brahman by the part of consciousness, without change,

analyzed: tadā vaktavyam
translated: then it should be said.

analyzed: tayoḥ bhogayoḥ abhedaḥ bheda abhedau vā
translated: Whether there is non-difference between the two enjoyments, or difference and non-difference.

analyzed: na tāvat abhedaḥ dvayoḥ api pariṇāmi tva ādi prāptyā bhāga advaya kalpanā vaiyarthyāt
translated: First, there is no non-difference, because both are attained as transformation, and the postulation of two parts is pointless.

analyzed: na api bheda abhedau
translated: Nor are there difference and non-difference.

analyzed: abhedena saṅkara prasaṅgāt
translated: Because of the confusion due to non-difference.

analyzed: bhedaḥ bheda kāryam niruṇaddhi iti ced
translated: If it is said that difference obstructs the effect of non-difference,

analyzed: kim tarhi aprayojakena abhedena
translated: then what is the use of non-difference which is not a cause?

analyzed: tasmāt bhāgayoḥ atyanta bhedaḥ eva aṅgīkaraṇīyaḥ
translated: Therefore, the absolute difference between the two parts must be accepted.

original: tataḥ kimityata āha yo bhāga iti //
analyzed: tatas kim iti atas āha yaḥ bhāgaḥ iti
translated: What follows from that? Therefore he says that part, etc.

original: yo bhāgo na vikārī syāt sa evāsmākamīśvaraḥ // / / //
analyzed: yaḥ bhāgaḥ na vikārī syāt saḥ eva asmākam īśvaraḥ
translated: That part which would be non-changing is for us alone the Lord.

analyzed: parasparam atyanta abhinne dve vastunī
translated: Two things are absolutely different from each other.

analyzed: tatra ekam nirvikāram jagat nimittam eva
translated: Among them, one is non-changing and is only the cause of the world.

original: aparaṃ tu pariṇāmi jagadupādānatamevetyaṅgīkāre neśvarasya kevalanimittatvavādināmasmākaṃ kaścidvivādaḥ /🔽nirvikārasya jagannimittasyāsmābhirīśvaratvena /🔽pariṇāmino jagadupādānasya pradhānatvena svīkṛtatvāt /
analyzed: aparam tu pariṇāmi jagat upādānatam eva iti aṅgīkāre na īśvarasya kevala nimitta tva vādinām asmākam kaścid vivādaḥ  nirvikārasya jagat nimittasya asmābhiḥ īśvara tvena  pariṇāminaḥ jagat upādānasya pradhāna tvena svīkṛta tvāt
translated: But the other is changing and is only the material cause of the world. When this is accepted, there is no dispute at all with us, the proponents of the Lord as the sole cause.🔽Because the non-changing cause of the world is accepted by us as the Lord,

analyzed: vivāda abhāvāt ca prakṛtiḥ ca iti ādi
translated: and the changing material cause of the world is accepted as the primordial matter.🔽And because there is no dispute, the aphorisms beginning with Primordial matter is intelligent

analyzed: sūtrāṇām anārambhaḥ eva iti
translated: are not even begun.

analyzed: atra yaḥ bhāgaḥ iti para abhyupagamena uktam
translated: Here, that part is stated from the acceptance of others.

analyzed: sva matena tu yat vastu iti jñātavyam
translated: But according to our own view, it should be understood as that thing.

original: nahi bhāgina vinā bhāgaḥ sambhavati /🔽nāpi vikāryavikāriṇoḥ kaścidbhāgī vidyate / /
analyzed: nahi bhāgina vinā bhāgaḥ sambhavati  na api vikāri avikāriṇoḥ kaścid bhāgī vidyate
translated: For a part is not possible without a possessor of parts.🔽Nor is there any possessor of parts between the changeable and the unchangeable.

analyzed: nanu asti vivāda viṣayaḥ
translated: But isn't there a subject of dispute?

analyzed: nimitta upādāna bheda vādinā nimittasya eva brahma tvam abhyupagamyate
translated: The proponents of the distinction between cause and material cause accept that Brahman is only the cause.

original: mayā tu sadanantānandacitāṃ samudāyasyeti tadarthamadhikaraṇārambha iti cet /
analyzed: mayā tu sat ananta ānanda citām samudāyasya iti tad artham adhikaraṇa ārambhaḥ iti ced
translated: If it be said that the present section is begun for the purpose of establishing the existence of Brahman, which is the aggregate of infinite bliss and consciousness,

analyzed: kim idam brahmatvam
translated: what is this Brahman?

analyzed: kim brahma nāmavatvam uta jagat kāraṇatva ādi lakṣaṇa arthavattvam  ādyam dūṣayati bhinnānām iti
translated: Is it the name of Brahman, or is it the existence of the meaning characterized by being the cause of the world, etc.?🔽He refutes the first (view) with If the name of the aggregate of different things is Brahman, it would be...

original: bhinnānāṃ samudāyasya nāma brahmeti ced bhavet // / / //
analyzed: bhinnānām samudāyasya nāma brahmā iti ced bhavet
translated: If the name of the aggregate of different things is Brahman, it would be...

analyzed: tat bhavet iti abhyupagamam āha
translated: He accepts it with that would be.

analyzed: tatas ca ayam arthaḥ
translated: And from that, this is the meaning.

analyzed: yadi arthe na vivādaḥ sti tadā anārambhaṇīyam eva adhikaraṇam
translated: If there is no dispute about the meaning, then this section is not to be begun at all.

analyzed: śabda mātre pareṇa vivāda akaraṇāt
translated: Because the opponent does not argue about the mere word.

analyzed: karaṇe pi a śabda śāstra tvāt iti
translated: Even if (he argues), it is not a treatise on non-words.

analyzed: dvitīye pi vivektavyam
translated: In the second (view) also, it should be distinguished.

original: kiṃ parasparaṃ bhinnāḥ saccidānandādyāḥ pratyekaṃ brahmāṇi /
analyzed: kim parasparam bhinnāḥ saccidānanda ādyāḥ pratyekam brahmāṇi
translated: Are Sat, Cit, Ananda, etc., which are mutually different, each Brahman?

original: uta te na brahmāṇi kintu tatsamudāya eveti /
analyzed: uta te na brahmāṇi kintu tad samudāyaḥ eva iti
translated: Or are they not Brahman, but only their aggregate?

analyzed: na ādyaḥ
translated: The first is not so.

analyzed: ekam eva advitīyam ityādi śruti virodhāt
translated: Because it contradicts the scriptures such as Brahman is one without a second.

original: dvitīye 'pi tatsamudāyo nāma kiṃ tadupādānakaṃ dravyāntaraṃ saṅkhayā vā saṃyogo vā /
analyzed: dvitīye pi tad samudāyaḥ nāma kim tad upādānakam dravya antaram saṅkhayā vā saṃyogaḥ vā
translated: In the second also, what is this aggregate? Is it a different substance that is its material cause, or number, or conjunction?

analyzed: sarvatra api doṣam āha brahma iti
translated: Everywhere, he points out the fault with Brahman.

original: brahmopādānatā na syāt tadā viśvasya hi kvacit // / / //
analyzed: brahma upādāna tā na syāt tadā viśvasya hi kvacid
translated: then the universe would not have Brahman as its material cause, in any case.

analyzed: tadā iti
translated: That is,

analyzed: manasi sthitānām vikalpitānām pakṣāṇām vā a aṅgīkāre
translated: if any of the alternatives, which are considered in the mind, are accepted.

analyzed: kvacid pakṣe
translated: In any case.

analyzed: hi śabdena anupapatteḥ prasiddha tām āha
translated: The word 'hi' (in fact) indicates the well-known nature of the impossibility.

original: atra hi brahmopādānasya vā tadguṇino vā jagadupādānatvaṃ prāptamiti viśvasya brahmopādānakatā na syāt /
analyzed: atra hi brahma upādānasya vā tad guṇinaḥ vā jagat upādāna tvam prāptam iti viśvasya brahma upādānaka tā na syāt
translated: For in this case, either Brahman as the material cause or Brahman as possessing that quality would have to be the material cause of the world, so the universe would not have Brahman as its material cause.

original: na hyupādānaguṇigatāḥ śaktayaḥ kāryadravye guṇe vā sambhavanti /
analyzed: na hi upādāna guṇi gatāḥ śaktayaḥ kārya dravye guṇe vā sambhavanti
translated: For the potencies residing in the material cause and its possessor do not exist in the effect substance or quality.

analyzed: tad upādāna tva ādeḥ asambhavāt
translated: Because the nature of being its material cause, etc., is impossible.

original: athavā brahmaṇaḥ kāryatvādguṇatvācca na viśvopādānatvaṃ sambhavatīti vyākhyeyam /
analyzed: athavā brahmaṇaḥ kārya tvāt guṇa tvāt ca na viśva upādāna tvam sambhavati iti vyākhyeyam
translated: Or else, it should be explained that Brahman cannot be the material cause of the universe because it is an effect and a quality.

analyzed: atra brahma upādāna tā iti upalakṣaṇam
translated: Here, 'Brahman as the material cause' is an illustration.

analyzed: brahma nimittaka tā ca na yuktā iti api draṣṭavyam
translated: It should also be seen that Brahman as the cause is not proper.

analyzed: syāt etat  kāla atyaya apadiṣyam etat anumāna jātam
translated: This may be said:🔽This set of inferences is to be stated later,

original: yato vā imāni bhūtāni jāyante'ātmana ākāśaḥ sambhūtaḥ'janmādyasya yataḥ' /
analyzed: yatas vai imāni bhūtāni jāyante ātmanaḥ ākāśaḥ sambhūtaḥ janma ādyasya yatas
translated: because of such statements as 'From which these beings are born' (Tait. Up. 2.1) and 'From the Self, space originated' (Ch. Up. 5.3.1) and 'The origin, etc. of this (universe)' (V.P. 1.1.1).

analyzed: itaya ādi virodhāt
translated: Because of the contradiction with such statements.

analyzed: jani kartuḥ prakṛtiḥ
translated: The nature of the creator is the material cause.

analyzed: iti prakṛtau upādāna lakṣaṇāyām hi pañcamī vidhīyate
translated: Thus, the fifth case is prescribed in the definition of material cause in the context of primordial matter.

analyzed: tathā ca eva udāhṛtam  śṛṅgāt śaraḥ jāyate
translated: And it has been quoted thus:🔽An arrow is born from the horn.

analyzed: gomayāt vṛścikaḥ jāyate iti
translated: A scorpion is born from cow dung.

analyzed: prasiddhaḥ ca atra upādāna upādeya bhāvaḥ iti
translated: And the relation of material cause and effect is well-known in this case.

analyzed: tat idam asaṅgatam
translated: This is irrelevant.

analyzed: pañcamī balāt kila upādāna tvam
translated: Indeed, materiality is to be proved by the force of the fifth case.

analyzed: na ca idam sūtram upādāne pañcamyāḥ vidhāyakam
translated: And this aphorism does not enjoin the fifth case in the sense of material cause.

analyzed: atha matam  apādāne tāvat pañcamī vihitā
translated: Now, if it is thought:🔽The fifth case has been enjoined in the sense of non-material cause.

analyzed: apādāne pañcamī iti
translated: In the sense of non-material cause, the fifth case.

analyzed: upādānam ca apādāna viśeṣaḥ
translated: And material cause is a particular kind of non-material cause.

analyzed: jani kartuḥ prakṛtiḥ iti smaraṇāt
translated: Because it is remembered as the material cause of the producer.

analyzed: tatas u pādāne vihitā pañcamī upādāne pi bhaviṣyati
translated: Therefore, the fifth case enjoined in the sense of non-material cause will also be in the sense of material cause.

analyzed: na ca evam sati pañcamyāḥ niyamena upādāna tva asiddhiḥ
translated: And in that case, the materiality is not established by the fifth case with certainty.

analyzed: viśeṣa smaraṇasya grāhya tvāt iti atas āha śṛṅgāt iti
translated: Because the remembrance of the particular is to be accepted. Therefore, he says from the horn etc.

analyzed: śṛṅgāt śaraḥ vilomabhyaḥ dūrvā gomayataḥ tathā
translated: An arrow from the horn, durva grass from the hair of a cow,

analyzed: vṛścikaḥ ca iti evamādyeṣu apādāna tvam iṣyate
translated: and a scorpion from cow dung - such things are accepted as having non-material causes.

analyzed: tathāśabdaḥ dvitīya udāharaṇena sambaddhayate
translated: The word tatha is connected with the second example.

analyzed: evamādyeṣu udāharaṇeṣu śṛṅga ādīnām śara ādīn prati apādāna tvam iṣyate
translated: In these and other examples, the horns etc. are accepted as the material cause in relation to the arrows etc.

analyzed: pañcamī artha tayā iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The meaning is that they are the material cause in relation to the arrows etc.

analyzed: upalakṣaṇam ca etat
translated: This is an illustration.

analyzed: sūtre ca iti api jñātavyam
translated: And it should be known that the word 'ca' (and) is also to be added in the sutra.

analyzed: etat uktam bhavati
translated: This is what is being said.🔽This would be so in some way if the meaning

analyzed: kathañcid yadi sūtrasya  tad udāharaṇānām ca
translated: of the sutra and

analyzed: para parikalpitaḥ rthaḥ bhavet
translated: of those examples were imagined by others.

analyzed: na ca evam
translated: But it is not so.

analyzed: kim nāma jani kartuḥ prakṛtiḥ iti anena idam ucyate
translated: What is meant by this is that the material cause of the producer is said to be

original: janeḥ karturjāyamānasya yā prakṛtirupādānasaṃsṛṣṭamapāyāvadhibhūtaṃ dravyaṃ tatkārakamapādānasaṃjñaṃ bhavatīti /
analyzed: janeḥ kartuḥ jāyamānasya yā prakṛtiḥ upādāna saṃsṛṣṭam apāya avadhi bhūtam dravyam tad kārakam apādāna saṃjñam bhavati iti
translated: the material cause of the produced, which is the substance that is the limit of the removal in conjunction with the material cause, that is the instrument, and is designated as the material cause.

analyzed: udāharaṇeṣu api yat śṛṅga ādīnām śara ādīn prati apāya avadhi tvam eva pañcamī pratipādyam iti
translated: In the examples also, the meaning conveyed by the fifth case is that the horns etc. are the limit of the removal in relation to the arrows etc.

analyzed: etat eva prapañcayati upādāna iti
translated: He elaborates on this with 'upādāna' etc.

analyzed: upādāna eka deśa tvam yadi api atra pradṛśyate
translated: Even though the state of being a part of the material cause is seen here,

analyzed: api apādāna tā eva atra dṛṣṭāntaḥ brahmaṇaḥ bhavet
translated: the example of Brahman here would still be the state of being the material cause.

analyzed: yadi api atra śṛṅga ādau śara ādi upādāna bhūta eka deśavattvam pratīyate
translated: Even though the state of having a part that is the material cause of the arrow etc. is understood here in the horn etc.,

original: tathāpi yātrāpādānatā apāyāvadhitvalakṣaṇāsti saiva brahmaṇo dṛṣṭānto bhavet /
analyzed: tathā api yātrā apādānatā apāya avadhi tva lakṣaṇā asti sā eva brahmaṇaḥ dṛṣṭāntaḥ bhavet
translated: Still, the state of being the material cause of the journey, characterized by being the limit of the undesirable, would be the example for Brahman.

analyzed: pañcamī artha tāyām udāharaṇam bhavet na tu upādāna tā iti arthaḥ
translated: It would be an example for the meaning of the fifth case, not for the state of being the material cause, is the meaning.

analyzed: ayam abhiprāyaḥ
translated: This is the intention.

original: śṛṅgādikaṃ hyekadeśena śarādīnpratyupādānamekadeśena cāpāyāvadhitayā kārakaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: śṛṅga ādikam hi eka deśena śara ādīn pratyupādānam eka deśena ca apāya avadhi tayā kārakam bhavati
translated: For a peak, etc., is the material cause of arrows, etc., by one part, and by another part it is the limiting adjunct.

analyzed: tasmin asati eka deśa antarasya upādāna tā anupapatteḥ
translated: Because when it is not there, the state of being the material cause of another part is not possible.

original: mudgamāṣādayo hi yadyapi tuṣāntarāvasthitenaivāṃśenāṅkuropādānam /🔽tathāpi na tuṣavikālānāmuptāmaṃśā
analyzed: mudga māṣa ādayaḥ hi yadi api tuṣa antara avasthitena eva aṃśena aṅkura upādānam  tathā api na tuṣa vikālānām uptām aṃśā
translated: Although indeed, beans, lentils, etc., are the material cause of the sprout by the part that is enclosed within the husk,

analyzed: nāma aṅkura janaka tā asti
translated: still, the parts of the husk that are not sown do not produce the sprout.

analyzed: tatra avadhi bhāgaḥ eva apādānam pañcamī vācyaḥ ca
translated: There, the limiting adjunct alone is the material cause and is denoted by the fifth case.

analyzed: tad dṛṣṭāntena brahmaṇaḥ pi pañcamī balāt upādānapradhāna saṃsṛṣṭa avadhi tvam eva bhavati
translated: By that example, even for Brahman, by the force of the fifth case, there is only the state of being the limit mixed with the principal material cause,

analyzed: na tu upādāna tvam iti
translated: not the state of being the material cause.

analyzed: nanu katham tarhi prakṛteḥ mahān mataḥ haṅkāraḥ iti ādi prayogaḥ
translated: But how then is the usage of from primordial matter, Mahat, from Mahat, I, etc.?

original: tatrāpi pariṇatabhāgasaṃsṛṣṭasya apariṇatabhāgasya avadhibhūtasya pañcamīviṣayatvamiti vadāmaḥ /
analyzed: tatra api pariṇata bhāga saṃsṛṣṭasya apariṇata bhāgasya avadhi bhūtasya pañcamī viṣaya tvam iti vadāmaḥ
translated: Even there, we say that the unmanifested part, which is the limit of the manifested part mixed with the manifested part, is the object of the fifth case.

analyzed: yatra sarvasya api pariṇāmaḥ tatra katham
translated: Where there is complete transformation of everything, how is it there?

analyzed: na prayoktavyā eva tatra pañcamī
translated: The fifth case should not be used there at all.

analyzed: nahi kṣīrāt dadhi jātim iti prayuñjate
translated: For they do not use the expression curd is produced from milk.

analyzed: kintu kṣīram eva dadhi jātam iti
translated: But rather milk itself becomes curd.

original: yatra kvacitprayogo dṛśyate sa gauṇo vā sūtrasyārthāntarakalpanāmūlo veti /
analyzed: yatra kvacid prayogaḥ dṛśyate sa gauṇaḥ vā sūtrasya artha antara kalpanā mūlaḥ vā iti
translated: Where the usage is seen somewhere, that is figurative or based on imagining a different meaning of the sutra.

analyzed: atha manyeta
translated: Now, if one thinks:

analyzed: śṛṅgam eva śara upādānam
translated: The horn itself is the material cause,

original: natu kecidavayavā upādānaṃ kecittadavadhaya iti vibhāgaḥ /
analyzed: na tu kecid avayavāḥ upādānam kecid tad avadhayaḥ iti vibhāgaḥ
translated: but there is no division that some parts are the material cause and some are the limit.

original: tathā sati śṛṅgāccharo jāyata iti prayogānupapatteḥ /
analyzed: tathā sati śṛṅgāt śaraḥ jāyate iti prayoga anupapatteḥ
translated: If that were so, because the expression the arrow is produced from the horn would be impossible,

original: yadi ceyaṃ pañcamyupādāne yadi vāvadhau tathāpi śṛṅgāvayavāditi vaktavyam /
analyzed: yadi ca iyam pañcamī upādāne yadi vā avadhau tathā api śṛṅga avayavāt iti vaktavyam
translated: and if this fifth case is in the material cause or if it is in the limit, even then it should be said from the parts of the horn.

analyzed: na ca tarhi avadhi tvam eva astu iti vācyam
translated: And then it should not be said that it should be the limit itself.

analyzed: nirupādāna utpatti prasaṅgāt
translated: Because it would lead to the absurdity of production without a material cause.

analyzed: atas śṛṅgasya eva upādana tvāt tatra pañcamī śravaṇāt upādāne pañcamī iti
translated: Therefore, because the horn itself is the material cause, and because the fifth case is heard there, the fifth case is in the material cause.

analyzed: tatra āha na hi iti
translated: There he says no

analyzed: na hi upādāna tā eva atra  atra śṛṅga ādau upādāna tetaiye
translated: For here, the mere act of taking up is not what is meant.

analyzed: ti na vaktavyam
translated: Here, in the case of the horn, etc., it should not be said that🔽it is the act of taking up that is meant.

analyzed: apariṇata bhāgasya śara aṅkura ādeḥ atyanta bhinnasya pramita tvāt
translated: Because it is well known that the part that is not transformed, such as the sprout of the arrow, is completely different.

analyzed: anyathā idam asya upādānam idam na iti vyavasthā anupapatteḥ iti hi śabda arthaḥ
translated: The meaning of the word hi is that otherwise, it would be impossible to determine that this is its material cause and that is not.

original: kathaṃ tarhi śṛṅgāditi prayoga ityata āha bāhyāvayaveti // /
analyzed: katham tarhi śṛṅgāt iti prayogaḥ iti atas āha bāhya avayava iti
translated: How then is the usage horn, etc.? To this he says because of the heaviness of the external parts.
Because of the heaviness of the external parts.

analyzed: bāhyāḥ śara ākāreṇa pariṇatebhyaḥ nye ye vadhi bhūta avayavāḥ teṣām gauravāt bahu tvāt
translated: Because of the heaviness, the multitude, of the external parts that are delimiters, which are different from those that are transformed in the form of an arrow.

analyzed: etat uktam bhavati
translated: This is what is said.

original: katipayāvayaveṣu pariṇateṣuca bahūnāmavaśiṣṭatvena śṛṅgāntarotpattyā śṛṅgabuddhimātrotpattyā vā śṛṅgaśabdopapattiriti / /
analyzed: katipaya avayaveṣu pariṇateṣu ca bahūnām avaśiṣṭa tvena śṛṅga antara utpattyā śṛṅga buddhi mātra utpattyā vā śṛṅga śabda upapattiḥ iti
translated: When a few parts are transformed, and many remain, either by the arising of another horn or by the mere arising of the cognition of a horn, the word horn is appropriate.

analyzed: nanu kutas sūtra ādeḥ artha antara kalpanā  śabda artha virodhāt iti brūmaḥ
translated: But how can an external object be imagined from a sūtra?🔽We say it is because of the contradiction between the word and its meaning.

analyzed: upādīyate kāryam anena svarūpa tayā svīkriyate iti upādānam
translated: A material cause is that by which an effect is taken up, is accepted as its own form.

original: apādīyate parityajyate kāryamanenetyapādānam iti sphuṭo vipratiṣedhaḥ /
analyzed: apādīyate parityajyate kāryam anena iti apādānam iti sphuṭaḥ vipratiṣedhaḥ
translated: The meaning of 'apādāna' is 'that by which an effect is carried away or abandoned', so there is clear contradiction.

original: kiñca bhāṣyakāreṇāyamapi yogaḥ śakyo 'vaktumiti pratyācakṣāṇenāyameva sūtrārthaḥ sūcitaḥ /
analyzed: kiñca bhāṣyakāreṇa ayam api yogaḥ śakyaḥ vaktum iti pratyācakṣāṇena ayam eva sūtra arthaḥ sūcitaḥ
translated: Moreover, when the author of the Bhāṣya rejects this yoga as not possible to be stated, he indicates this very meaning of the sūtra.

original: yadi tarhi janikartuḥ prakṛtiriti sūtramupādānasyāpādānasaṃjñā vidadhyāt /
analyzed: yadi tarhi jani kartuḥ prakṛtiḥ iti sūtram upādānasya apādāna saṃjñāḥ vidadhyāt
translated: If then the sūtra 'the prakriti of the producer is the upādāna' would prescribe the designation of upādāna for the apādāna,

analyzed: katham tarhi dhruvam apāye pādānam iti anena eva gatārtha tām āha
translated: then how does he say that it is already stated by this very [sūtra] 'apādāna is that which is certainly carried away'?

analyzed: na hi apādānasya apāye dhruva tvam iti
translated: For the upādāna is not certainly carried away when the apādāna is carried away.

analyzed: tasmāt u ca pādāna saṃsṛṣṭasya eva avadhi bhāgasya apādāna saṃjñāyām anena vihitāyām bhāṣya kārīyam dūṣaṇam sambadhyate
translated: Therefore, when the designation of apādāna is prescribed for the part of the limit that is mixed with the upādāna by this [sūtra], the criticism of the author of the Bhāṣya is relevant.

original: tathā sūtraṃ samādadhānairapi tasyaivāyaṃ prapañca ityuktam /
analyzed: tathā sūtram samādadhānaiḥ api tasya eva ayam prapañcaḥ iti uktam
translated: Thus, those who accept the sūtra in this way have also elaborated on this [point].

analyzed: anyathā prāk avadheḥ apādāna saṃjñā uktā
translated: Otherwise, the designation of apādāna is stated before the limit.

analyzed: atra tu upādānasya
translated: Here, however, it is of the upādāna.

analyzed: na hi avadhiḥ upādānam iti iti avakṣyan
translated: For one would not say that the meaning is 'the limit is not the upādāna'.

analyzed: atas teṣām api saṃmataḥ yam arthaḥ iti gamyate
translated: Therefore, it is understood that this meaning is accepted by them also.

analyzed: astu vā upādāne pi pañcamī
translated: Let there be the fifth case even with respect to the upādāna.

analyzed: tathā api yatas iti
translated: Even so, from what [is the effect produced]?

analyzed: pañcamī balāt upādāna tva niścayaḥ na upapadyate
translated: The ascertainment of appropriation from the fifth [reason] is not established.

analyzed: aneka artha tvāt
translated: The fifth case ending is not appropriate to express the sense of upādāna, because it has many meanings.

analyzed: viśeṣa smaraṇāt iti uktam iti ced
translated: If it is argued that it is due to the recollection of the specific meaning,

analyzed: kim idam viśeṣa smaraṇāt
translated: what is this due to the recollection of the specific meaning?

analyzed: jani dhātu grahaṇena iti ced
translated: If it is argued that it is due to the mention of the root jan,

analyzed: tarhi ātmanaḥ ākāśaḥ sambhūtaḥ ityādīnām anudāharaṇīya tvam syāt
translated: then the statements ākāśa was born from the Self etc. would not be examples.

analyzed: kutas ca yatas iti pañcamī iti avadhṛtam
translated: And from where? It is determined that it is the fifth case ending.

analyzed: taseḥ sārvavibhaktika tvāt
translated: Because the suffix ta has all the case endings.

analyzed: ātmanaḥ ākāśa satī anena ekārtha tvāt iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that it has the same meaning as from the Self, ākāśa, it is not so.

analyzed: tasyāḥ pañcamyāṃbhuvaḥ prabhavaḥ  iti viśeṣa avivakṣi
translated: The origin of the earth is from that.🔽Because the specific meaning is not intended to be expressed.

analyzed: hita abhivyakti avadhita artha tvāt
translated: Because the meaning is limited to the manifestation of what is beneficial.

analyzed: tathā ca eva udāhṛtam
translated: And it is quoted in that way.

original: himavato gaṅgā prabhavati prathamamupalabhyata ityathar ityāstāṃ vistaraḥ / /
analyzed: himavataḥ gaṅgā prabhavati prathamam upalabhyate iti iti āstām vistaraḥ
translated: The Ganges has its origin in the Himalayas, it is first perceived. Let this discussion end here.

original: athavā yaduktaṃ na brahmavikāro viśvaṃ tato bhedenopalambhāditi /
analyzed: athavā yat uktam na brahma vikāraḥ viśvam tatas bhedena upalambhāt iti
translated: Or, it is said that the universe is not a modification of Brahman, because it is perceived as different from it.

analyzed: tat asat
translated: That is not so.

analyzed: śara ādiṣu vyabhicārāt
translated: Because of inconstancy in arrows etc.

original: śarādayo hi śṛṅgādayo hi śṛṅgādyupādānāstatā bhedenopādānāstato bhedenopalabhyanta ityato gūḍhābhisandhirāha śṛṅgāditi //
analyzed: śara ādayaḥ hi śṛṅga ādayaḥ hi śṛṅga ādi upādānāḥ bhedena upādānāḥ tatas bhedena upalabhyante iti atas gūḍha abhisandhiḥ āha śṛṅgāt iti
translated: For arrows, etc. are produced from horns, etc. and are perceived separately from them. Therefore, with a hidden intention, he says horns, etc.

analyzed: evamādyeṣu sthaleṣu śara ādīn prati śṛṅga ādīnām api  pāyā avadhi tva lakṣaṇam apādāna tvam eva iṣyate
translated: Thus, in these and other cases, horns, etc. are considered to be the material cause of arrows, etc.

analyzed: na punar upādāna tvam
translated: in the sense of being the upper limit of the material cause, but not in the sense of being the material cause.

original: ato vipakṣatvābhāvādbhedenopalambho na tatra sādhyaṃ vyabhicaratīti /
analyzed: atas vipakṣa tva abhāvāt bhedena upalambhaḥ na tatra sādhyam vyabhicarati iti
translated: Therefore, because there is no counterexample, the perception of difference does not contradict the conclusion there.

analyzed: nanu katham ucyate śṛṅga ādīnām śara ādīn prati na upādāna tvam iti
translated: But how can it be said that horns, etc. are not the material cause of arrows, etc.?

analyzed: tathā sati upādāna antara anupalambhāt śara ādīnām nirupādana utpattiḥ prasajyeta iti atas bhisandhim udghāṭayati upādāna iti
translated: If that were so, it would follow that arrows, etc. would arise without a material cause, because another material cause is not perceived. Therefore, he reveals the intention, saying material cause, etc.

analyzed: śṛṅga ādeḥ ukta rūpa apādāna tve pi na ca śara ādīnām nirupādāna tva ukti prasaṅgaḥ
translated: Even if horns, etc. are the material cause in the mentioned way, it does not follow that arrows, etc. are said to arise without a material cause.

analyzed: katipayānām śṛṅga ādi avayavānām śara ādi upādāna tva abhyupagamāt
translated: Because it is accepted that some parts of horns, etc. are the material cause of arrows, etc.

analyzed: na ca evam anaikāntya tādavasthyam
translated: And it is not the case that the argument remains inconclusive in this way.

analyzed: yadi api atra śṛṅga ādau śara ādi upādāna eka deśa tvam
translated: Even though here in horns, etc. it is seen that they are a part of the material cause of arrows, etc.,

original: tathāpyatra śṛṅgādau yasyaikadeśasyoktasya rūpāpādānatā sa eva brahmaṇo dṛṣṭānto bhavet /
analyzed: tathā api atra śṛṅga ādau yasya eka deśasya uktasya rūpa apādāna tā saḥ eva brahmaṇaḥ dṛṣṭāntaḥ bhavet
translated: Still, here, in the horn, etc., that part of which the form has been mentioned, which is the material cause, that alone could be the example of Brahman.

analyzed: tatas eva śara ādīnām bheda upalambhāt
translated: Because the difference of the arrow, etc., is perceived from that itself.

analyzed: na tu upādāna bhāgaḥ
translated: Not the part that is the material cause.

analyzed: tatas tad abhāvāt
translated: Because that is absent there.

analyzed: etat uktam bhavati
translated: This is what is said.

analyzed: śṛṅga ādeḥ avayavāḥ hi kecid śara ādīnām upādāna bhūtāḥ kecid nimitta bhūtāḥ
translated: For some parts of the horn, etc. are the material cause of the arrow, etc., and some are the instrumental cause.

analyzed: tatra ye nimitta bhūtāḥ teṣu hetu vṛttau api na anaikāntyam
translated: Even if the cause exists in those that are the instrumental cause, there is no fallacy of inconclusive reason.

analyzed: teṣām sapakṣa praviṣṭa tvāt
translated: Because they are included in the similar instances.

original: ye tūpādānabhūtāsteṣāṃ vipakṣapraveśe 'pi na tatra hetuvṛttiriti kuto 'naikāntyamiti /
analyzed: ye tu upādāna bhūtāḥ teṣām vipakṣa praveśe na tatra hetu vṛttiḥ iti kutas na aikāntyam iti
translated: But even if those that are the material cause are included in the dissimilar instances, the cause does not exist there. So how can there be inconclusiveness?

analyzed: yaḥ tu vaiyātyāt manyate
translated: But one who, out of perversity, thinks:

analyzed: na atra apādāna tā asti
translated: Here there is no material cause,

analyzed: kintu upādāna tvam eva kevalam
translated: but only the material nature.

analyzed: tathā ca anaikāntika tvam iti
translated: And so there is inconclusiveness.

analyzed: sa praṣṭavyaḥ
translated: He should be asked:

original: kimatrāvinaṣṭa eva śṛṅgāvayavyupādānamityabhiprāyaḥ /🔽kiṃ vā śṛṅge 'vinaṣṭe tadavayavāḥ sarve 'pīti /
analyzed: kim atra avinaṣṭe eva śṛṅga avayavi upādānam iti abhiprāyaḥ  kim vā śṛṅge vinaṣṭe tad avayavāḥ sarve
translated: What is the intention here? Is the horn-part that is not destroyed the material cause?🔽Or, when the horn is not destroyed, are all its parts also?

analyzed: uta naṣṭe śṛṅge tad avayavāḥ sarve
translated: Or, when the horn is destroyed, are all its parts also?

analyzed: na adya iti āha nahi iti
translated: The first is not so, he says: No, because...

analyzed: atra śṛṅge
translated: On this horn.

analyzed: tathātve suvarṇa vat śare śṛṅgasya api pratīti prasaṅgāt iti hi śabda arthaḥ
translated: The meaning of the word hi is that if it were so, then like gold, the horn would also be perceived in the arrow.

analyzed: na dvitīyaḥ iti āha nahi iti
translated: He says that the second is not so with na hi.

original: avinaṣṭṛṅgeṣu tadavayaveṣu sarveṣu śarādyupādānataiveti na yuktam /
analyzed: a vinaṣṭṛṅgeṣu tad avayaveṣu sarveṣu śara ādi upādāna tā eva iti na yuktam
translated: It is not proper that in the undestroyed horns, in all their parts, there is only the material cause of the arrow etc.

original: tathā sati śṛṅgaśarayoḥ samānadeśatāprasaṅgāditi hiśabdena sūcayati /
analyzed: tathā sati śṛṅga śarayoḥ samāna deśa tā prasaṅgāt iti hi śabdena sūcayati
translated: He indicates with the word hi that if it were so, then the horn and the arrow would have the same location.

analyzed: na tṛtīye iti āha nahi iti
translated: He says that the third is not so with na hi.

original: atra sarveṣvapi śṛṅgāvayaveṣu śṛṅganāśottaraṃ śarādyupādānataiveti na yujyate /🔽ato nānaikāntyamiti hiśabdaḥ /
analyzed: atra sarveṣu api śṛṅga avayaveṣu śṛṅga nāśa uttaram śara ādi upādāna tā eva iti na yujyate  atas na anaikāntyam iti hi śabdaḥ
translated: Here it is not proper that in all the parts of the horn, after the destruction of the horn, there is only the material cause of the arrow etc.🔽Therefore, there is no inconclusiveness. The word hi (means) why is it not proper?

original: kuto na yujyata ityata āha bāhyeti //🔽kāryādbāhyānāmapariṇatānāmavayavānāmupalambhāt /
analyzed: kutas na yujyate iti atas āha bāhya iti  kāryāt bāhyānām apariṇatānām avayavānām upalambhāt
translated: To this he says bahir etc.🔽Because the external parts that are not transformed are perceived from the effect.

analyzed: apariṇatasya api upādāna tve tiprasaṅgāt
translated: Because if that which is not transformed were also the material cause, there would be an overextension.

original: nanu śṛṅgaṃ cennaṣṭaṃ kathaṃ tarhi śarotpattyanantaramapi śṛṅgapratyayaprayogāvityato gauravādityuktam /
analyzed: nanu śṛṅgam ced naṣṭam katham tarhi śara utpatti anantaram api śṛṅga pratyaya prayogau iti atas gauravāt iti uktam
translated: But if the horn is destroyed, then how is there the cognition and usage of the horn even after the production of the arrow? To this he says because of the importance.

analyzed: samādhānam pūrvavat
translated: The solution is as before.

analyzed: mā bhūt bheda upalambhasya atra vyabhicāraḥ
translated: Let there not be the fallacy of the perception of difference here.

original: tathāpi yaduktaṃ nācetanavikāraścetana iti tadatra vyabhicarati /
analyzed: tathā api yat uktam na acetana vikāraḥ cetanaḥ iti tat atra vyabhicarati
translated: Still, what was said - that the conscious is not a modification of the unconscious - is contradicted here.

analyzed: acetanāt gomaya ādeḥ cetanasya vṛścika ādeḥ janana darśanāt iti atas āha na ca iti
translated: Because the birth of a conscious creature like a scorpion is seen from an unconscious thing like cowdung. To this he says: Not from the unconscious, etc.

analyzed: na ca acetanataḥ tatra cetanasya samudbhavaḥ
translated: And the conscious is not produced from the unconscious there.

analyzed: tatra gomaya ādeḥ vṛścika ādi janmani
translated: There, in the birth of a scorpion from cowdung, etc.

analyzed: nanu anādiḥ cetanaḥ iti pūrva abhyasta āhāra abhilāṣa ādinā prasiddham
translated: But it is well known that the conscious being has no beginning, by the desire for food etc. experienced in previous births.

analyzed: anyathā pūrva karma abhāve janmanaḥ pi asambhavāt
translated: Otherwise, in the absence of previous karma, birth would also be impossible.

analyzed: madhye kathañcid sambhave pi ādisarge sarvathā api
translated: Even if somehow possible in the middle, in the initial creation it is completely

analyzed: anupapatteḥ
translated: impossible.

analyzed: tat katham nirdalam idam āśaṅkitam
translated: So how is this groundless doubt raised?

analyzed: satyam
translated: True.

original: tathāpi pareṇa svagranthe niveśitatvāt /🔽acetanāccetanasya janmābhāve gomayād vṛściko jāyata ityādivyavahāravirodha ityata āha upādānatayeti //
analyzed: tathā api pareṇa sva granthe niveśita tvāt  acetanāt cetanasya janma abhāve gomayāt vṛścikaḥ jāyate ityādi vyavahāra virodhaḥ iti atas āha upādānatayā iti
translated: Nevertheless, because it has been introduced by the opponent in his own text.🔽If the birth of the conscious from the unconscious is not accepted, there would be a contradiction with the usage A scorpion is born from cowdung, etc. To this he says: As the material cause, etc.

analyzed: upādāna tayā
translated: As the material cause, etc.

analyzed: pūrveṇa eva sambandhaḥ
translated: The connection is with the previous [verse].🔽We do not deny mere causality, by which there would be a contradiction with usage.

original: na vayaṃ kāraṇatvamātraṃ niṣedhāmo yena vyavahāravirodhaḥ syāt /🔽kintūpādānatayā /
analyzed: na vayam kāraṇa tva mātram niṣedhāmaḥ yena vyavahāra virodhaḥ syāt 🔽kintu upādāna tayā
translated: But [we deny] as the material cause.

analyzed: tasya eva prakṛta tvāt
translated: Because that itself is the subject matter.

analyzed: yadi gomaya ādikam vṛścika ādikam prati na upādānam
translated: If cowdung etc. is not the material cause for a scorpion etc.,

analyzed: kiṃrūpam tarhi kāraṇam
translated: then what kind of cause is it?

analyzed: yena vyavahāra upapattiḥ iti pṛcchati kim tarhi iti
translated: By which there is the possibility of usage. He asks What then?

analyzed: uttaram āha apādānam iti
translated: He answers The ablative case.

analyzed: kim tarhi apādānam hi acetanam
translated: What then is the ablative case? It is the non-sentient.

analyzed: kārya deha gatasya asya cetanasya pradṛśyate
translated: It is seen of this sentient one residing in the body, the effect.

analyzed: asya vṛścika ādi śabda abhidheyasya
translated: Of this, denoted by the word scorpion etc.

analyzed: pradṛśyate hi iti tatas nirgata tva upalambhāt iti arthaḥ
translated: It is seen means it is perceived as coming out from that.

analyzed: nanu eka deśena apādāna tvam abhyupagatam iti
translated: But isn't the state of being the ablative case accepted in part?

analyzed: satyam
translated: True,

analyzed: tad śarīra apekṣayā iti uktam kārya deha gatasya iti
translated: but it is said with reference to that body, residing in the body, the effect.

analyzed: gomaya ādi upādānaka deha gatasya iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is residing in the body produced from cowdung etc.

analyzed: ayam atra samuccaya arthaḥ
translated: The meaning of this combination here is as follows.

analyzed: vṛścika ādi śabdena dvayam ucyate dehaḥ cetanaḥ ca
translated: By the word scorpion etc., two things are meant - the body and the sentient being.

analyzed: tatra gomaya ādi acetanam acetanasya dehasya utpattau eka deśena upādānam eka deśena apādānam ca bhavati
translated: There, the non-sentient cowdung etc. is the material cause in part and the ablative case in part for the production of the non-sentient body.

analyzed: cetanasya tu prādurbhāva lakṣaṇe janane nimittam eva
translated: But in the production characterized by the appearance of the sentient being, it is only the instrumental cause.

analyzed: deva hetu tvāt
translated: Because it is the cause of the deity.

analyzed: tatra eva ca asya prādurbhāvāt
translated: And because it appears there itself.

analyzed: atas eva asya iti pratyakṣa vat nirdeśaḥ kṛtaḥ
translated: For this very reason, it is designated as if it were directly perceived.

analyzed: apagamane tu avadhi tvena apādānam eva
translated: But in the case of removal, it is only the source as a limit.

analyzed: atas na ukta niyama bhaṅgaḥ iti
translated: Therefore, there is no violation of the stated rule.

original: evaṃ brahmaṇo jagadupādānatvābhāve pramāṇānyabhidhāya paropanyāstāni pramāṇāni nirākariṣyan kramasyāprayojakatvapariṇāmāditi sūtrārthatayoktāṃ
analyzed: evam brahmaṇaḥ jagat upādāna tva abhāve pramāṇāni abhidhāya para upanyāstāni pramāṇāni nirākariṣyan kramasya aprayojaka tva pariṇāmāt iti sūtra artha tayā uktām
translated: Thus, having stated the means of valid knowledge regarding Brahman's non-causative nature of the world, he will refute the means of valid knowledge presented by others, stating the meaning of the aphorism because the order is not a means to an end as

analyzed: śrutim tāvat nirācaṣṭe sat ca iti
translated: he refutes the Vedic text, saying sat and so on.

analyzed: sat ca tyad ca abhavat iti na asya viśva tvam ucyate
translated: Sat and tya are not said to be the universe of this [Brahman].

original: sacca tyaccābhavat niruktaṃ cāniruktaṃ ca nilayanaṃ cānilayanaṃ ca vijñānaṃ cāvijñānaṃ ca satyaṃ cānṛtaṃ ca satyamabhavat' /
analyzed: sat ca tyad ca abhavat niruktam ca aniruktam ca nilayanam ca anilayanam ca vijñānam ca a vijñānam ca satyam ca anṛtam ca satyam abhavat
translated: Sat and tya became, defined and undefined, with a resting place and without a resting place, with knowledge and without knowledge, true and false, truth became.

original: ityasyāṃ śrutāvasya brahmaṇaḥ sattyadādiśabdābhidheyamūrtāmūrtārāśidvayātmakaviśvabhāva ucyata iti nāsti /
analyzed: iti asyām śrutau asya brahmaṇaḥ sattya da ādi śabda abhidheya mūrtāmūrtā rāśi dvaya ātmaka viśva bhāvaḥ ucyate iti na asti
translated: In this Vedic text, the nature of the universe consisting of two groups of manifest and unmanifest things denoted by the words sat and so on is not said to belong to this Brahman.

analyzed: kutas na iti atas āha tat sṛṣṭvā iti
translated: Why not? Therefore he says tat-sṛṣṭvā and so on.

original: tat sṛṣṭveti giraivāsya pūrvaṃ viśvasya siddhitaḥ // / / //
analyzed: tat sṛṣṭvā iti girā eva asya pūrvam viśvasya siddhitaḥ
translated: By the statement tat-sṛṣṭvā [in the Vedic text], the universe is already established before this [Brahman].

analyzed: saḥ idam sarvam asṛjata
translated: He created all this.

analyzed: yat idam kiñca  tat sṛṣṭvā tat eva anuprāviśat
translated: Whatever exists.🔽Having created that, He entered into it.

analyzed: tat anupraviśya
translated: Having entered into it,

analyzed: sat ca tyad ca abhavat
translated: He became Being and Non-being.

original: iti vacanena brahmaṇaḥ sattyadādibhavanātpūrvamevāsya mūrtāmūrtarūpasya viśvasyotpatteravagatatvāt /
analyzed: iti vacanena brahmaṇaḥ satti ada ādi bhavanāt pūrvam eva asya mūrta amūrta rūpasya viśvasya utpatteḥ avagata tvāt
translated: By this statement, it is understood that the creation of this entire universe, both in its embodied and unembodied forms, took place prior to the existence of Being and so on of Brahman.

analyzed: etat uktam bhavati
translated: This is what is meant.

analyzed: na idam sat tyad ādi bhavanam
translated: This creation of Being and so on is not the creation of the universe.

analyzed: viśva utpatti uttara kālīna tvāt
translated: Because it occurs after the creation of the universe.

analyzed: yā kriyā yad uttara kālīnā na asau asau
translated: An action that occurs after something else cannot be that.

original: yathā bhuktvā caratītyuktaṃ caraṇaṃ na pūrvakālīnaṃ bhojanamiti /
analyzed: yathā bhuktvā carati iti uktam caraṇam na pūrva kālīnam bhojanam iti
translated: For example, when it is said having eaten, he walks, the walking does not occur before the eating.

analyzed: anupapanna artham ca anyathā vākyam āpadyeta
translated: Otherwise, the sentence would have an impossible meaning.

original: nahi mṛtsuvarṇādikaṃ ghaṭarucakādi sṛṣṭvā tadanupraviśya tadbhavati /
analyzed: nahi mṛd suvarṇa ādikam ghaṭa rucaka ādi sṛṣṭvā tat anupraviśya tat bhavati
translated: For clay, gold, etc. do not become pots, ornaments, etc. after creating them, and then enter into them.

original: yadvā viśvaṃ sattyadādiśabdārthatayātra na vivakṣitam tadbhavanātpūrvakālīnotpattikatvādbhojanavadityādi prayoktavyam / /
analyzed: yat vā viśvam sat tyad ādi śabda artha tayā atra na vivakṣitam tad bhavanāt pūrva kālīna utpattika tvāt bhojana vat ityādi prayoktavyam
translated: Or, if the universe is not intended here as the meaning of the words Being, etc., then the argument should be stated as follows: because its creation occurs before the creation of Being, etc., like eating.

analyzed: kaḥ tarhi śruti arthaḥ iti atas āha sattvāt iti
translated: Then what is the meaning of the Vedic text? To this he says Because of existence, etc.

analyzed: sattvāt tateḥ vaidika tvāt samyak vaktum aśakyataḥ
translated: Because of existence, because of extension, because of being Vedic, because of being incapable of being properly expressed,

analyzed: āśraya tvāt sva āśraya tvāt jñāna tvāt durvida tvataḥ
translated: Because of being the substratum, because of being the self-substratum, because of being knowledge, because of being difficult to know,

analyzed: sattateḥ yātanāt ca eva hi aprāpta tvāt ca durjanaiḥ
translated: Because of existence, because of suffering, and because of being unattainable by the wicked,

analyzed: nitya asādhu guṇa vyāpti yantṛ rūpa tvataḥ sadā
translated: Because of being always pervaded by eternal good qualities, because of being the controller, always,

analyzed: jagat gatena rūpeṇa brahmā eva hi tathā ucyate
translated: Brahman itself is said to be thus, with a form that moves in the world.

original: jagadbhāvaṃ vinā sattvādidharmayogena brahmaiva tathā sattyadādikamucyate /
analyzed: jagat bhāvam vinā sattva ādi dharma yogena brahmā eva tathā sattya da ādikam ucyate
translated: Without the existence of the world, Brahman itself is said to be thus, with the qualities of existence and so on, because of existence and so on.

analyzed: tarhi tat anupraviśya iti asya anvayaḥ na asti
translated: Then there is no connection with the phrase having entered that.

original: nahi brahmaṇaḥ sattvādidharmayoge sadādiśabdavācyatve vā jagatpraveśasyopayogo 'sti /
analyzed: nahi brahmaṇaḥ sattva ādi dharma yoge sat ādi śabda vācya tve vā jagat praveśasya upayogaḥ sti
translated: For when Brahman has the qualities of existence and so on, or is denoted by words like sat (existence) and so on, there is no use for the world to enter it.
