original: nāpi tataḥ pūrvakālīnatā /🔽kiñcaivaṃ sati prasiddhivirodhaḥ sattyadādiśabdānāṃdve vā va brahmaṇo rūpe' /
analyzed: na api tatas pūrva kālīna tā  kiñca evam sati prasiddhi virodhaḥ sat tyad ādi śabdānām dve vā brahmaṇaḥ rūpe
translated: Nor is there priority to that.🔽Moreover, in that case there is contradiction with common knowledge, because Brahman is said to have two forms by the words sat (existence) and so on.

original: ityādau mūrtāmūrtavācitayā prasiddhatvāt ityato jagadgatena rūpeṇetyuktam /
analyzed: ityādau mūrta amūrta vāci tayā prasiddha tvāt iti atas jagat gatena rūpeṇa iti uktam
translated: Because it is well-known as denoting the embodied and the unembodied in passages like There are two forms of Brahman. Therefore it is said with a form that moves in the world.

original: yadyapyananyāpekṣayā sarvadā sattvādidharmayogaḥ sadādiśabdavācyatā ca brahmaṇaḥ /
analyzed: yadi api an anya apekṣayā sarvadā sattva ādi dharma yogaḥ sat ādi śabda vācya tā ca brahmaṇaḥ
translated: Although Brahman is always connected with the attributes of existence, etc., and is denoted by the words sat (existent), etc., independently of anything else,

analyzed: tathā api tad tad vastu gata rūpeṇa eva tad tad śabda vācya tvam iti asti vyavasthā
translated: nevertheless, it is established that it is denoted by those words only in the form of that and that entity.

original: tathāca mūrtāmūrtajagadgatena rūpeṇa brahmasadādiśabdavācyamityataḥ tadanupraviśyeti sambaddhayate /
analyzed: tathā ca mūrta amūrta jagat gatena rūpeṇa brahma sat ādi śabda vācyam iti atas tat anupraviśya iti sambaddhayate
translated: And thus, since Brahman is denoted by the words sat (existent), etc., in the form of the manifest and unmanifest world, therefore it is connected by the words having entered that.

analyzed: parameśvara sannidhānāt eva mūrta amūrta ādeḥ api sat ādi śabda vācya tā ca upapadyate iti  sattvāt uttama tvāt sat
translated: And the denotation of the manifest and unmanifest, etc., by the words sat (existent), etc., is also logically possible only through the presence of the Supreme Lord.

analyzed: tateḥ vyāpteḥ tyat  tanu vistāre iti asmāt yat pratyayaḥ
translated: It is sat (existent) because of existence, due to being the best.🔽It is tyat (that) because of the extension of tata (from that).🔽The suffix yat is from tanu (to extend).

analyzed: vaidika tvāt niruktam
translated: It is nirukta (explained) because it is Vedic.

analyzed: niścayena uktam hi niruktam
translated: For nirukta (explained) is that which is stated with certainty.

original: nahi vedādṛte 'nyena brahma niścayena vaktuṃ śakyate /
analyzed: nahi vedāt ṛte brahma niścayena vaktum śakyate
translated: For Brahman cannot be stated with certainty by any other means than the Veda.

analyzed: samyak vastum aśakya tvataḥ niruktam  yadi api niścayena uktam na bhavati iti aniruktam
translated: It is anirukta (unexplained) because it cannot be properly explained.🔽Although it is anirukta (unexplained) because it is not stated with certainty,

original: tathāpi niruktamityanena virodhātsamyak kātsnaryena vaktumaśakyatvata ityuktam /
analyzed: tathā api niruktam iti anena virodhāt samyak kātsnaryena vaktum aśakya tvataḥ iti uktam
translated: nevertheless, by the word nirukta (explained), it is stated that it cannot be properly explained completely.

original: nanu vedetarapramāṇenāniruktamiti kuto na vyākhyāyate / na /
analyzed: nanu veda itara pramāṇena aniruktam iti kutas na vyākhyāyate na
translated: But why is it not explained as not specified by means other than the Veda? No.

analyzed: prakṛta parityāga prasaṅgāt
translated: Because it would entail abandoning the subject matter.

analyzed: vedena niruktam iti hi prakṛtam
translated: For it is the subject matter that it is specified by the Veda.

analyzed: kiñca ukteḥ śabda dharma tvāt pratyakṣa anumānābhyām aniruktam iti ayuktam
translated: Moreover, since the statement is a property of sound, it is not appropriate to say it is not specified by perception and inference.

analyzed: smṛtīnām api veda ātmaka tvena virodha tādavasthyam
translated: And since the Smritis are also of the nature of the Veda, the contradiction remains.

analyzed: mahima ādhikyam ca atra labhyate iti
translated: And here the superiority of greatness is obtained.

analyzed: jagat āśraya tvāt nilayanam
translated: It is a resting place because it is the support of the world.

analyzed: niścitam ayante pravartante smin iti
translated: It is said that they are determined in it, i.e., they function in it.

analyzed: raḥ laḥ iti yogavibhāgāt la tvam
translated: The la is due to the division of the compound.

analyzed: ni pūrvasya līṅ
translated: The li of the ni-prefix

original: śleṣaṇa ityasya vādhikaraṇe lyuṭi kṛte rūpametat /🔽svāśrayatvādanilayanam /
analyzed: śleṣaṇe iti asya vā adhikaraṇe lyuṭi kṛte rūpam etat  sva āśraya tvāt anilayanam
translated: is the form obtained by adding lyuṭ to the sense of adhesion.🔽It is not a resting place because it is the basis of itself.

analyzed: na vidyate sva atiriktam nilayanam yasya iti
translated: It is said that it does not have a resting place other than itself.

analyzed: jñāna tvāt viśeṣa jñāna rūpa tvāt vijñānam
translated: It is knowledge because it is of the nature of specific knowledge.

analyzed: durvida tvataḥ durjñeya tvāt avijñānam
translated: It is not knowledge because it is difficult to know.

original: na vidyate vijñānaṃ sakalaviśeṣāvagāhijīvajñānaṃ yadviṣaya iti /
analyzed: na vidyate vijñānam sakala viśeṣa avagāhi jīva jñānam yad viṣayaḥ iti
translated: It is said that it does not have knowledge, i.e., the knowledge of the soul that comprehends all particulars.

analyzed: sattateḥ samyak vyāpteḥ yātāna adyatanam prati hetu tvāt ca satyam
translated: It is true because it is continuous, because it pervades correctly, and because it is the cause of the past in relation to the present.

analyzed: tanoteḥ ḍvi pratyaye takāra mātram rūpam
translated: The form of tanute is only ta, with the affix dviprayaya.

analyzed: tena sat śabdasya bahuvrīhiḥ
translated: Therefore, the word sat is a bahuvrihi compound.

original: yatī prayatna ityasyāntarṇītaṇyarthasya ḍapratyaye yamiti rūpam /
analyzed: prayatnaḥ iti asya antar ṇīta ṇi arthasya ḍapratyaye yam iti rūpam
translated: The word yama is formed from yati prayatna with the affix da, where the meaning of ni is understood.

analyzed: tatas karmadhārayaḥ  ayasmā ayadīni chandasi
translated: Then it is a karmadharaya compound.🔽The word ayasmayadin is used in the Vedas.

analyzed: iti bha saṃjñā āśrayaṇāt ja ś tva abhāvaḥ
translated: By adopting the designation bha, the jash suffix is not formed.

analyzed: durjanaiḥ a prāpya tvāt eva anṛtam ca
translated: And it is false because it cannot be attained by evil people.

analyzed: na tu mithyātvāt
translated: But not because it is false.

analyzed: yadi api ṛtam prāptam na iti anṛtam
translated: Although it is false because it is not attained by truth,

analyzed: tathā api brahma vidā āpnoti param
translated: Still, One who knows Brahman attains the highest.

analyzed: ityādi śruti virodha parihārāya durjanaiḥ iti uktam
translated: In order to avoid contradiction with such Vedic statements, it is said that it is not attained by evil people.

analyzed: hi śabdaḥ brahmaṇaḥ mithyātva abhāve prasiddhim dyotayati
translated: The word hi indicates the well-known fact of the absence of falsity in Brahman.

analyzed: nitya sādhu guṇa vyāpti yantṛ rūpa tvataḥ satyam
translated: It is true because it is pervaded by eternal good qualities and is the ruler.

analyzed: atra nitya tvataḥ iti ekam vyākhyānam
translated: Here, eternality is one explanation.

analyzed: nitya satya śabdayoḥ aikāthya ṛsya vakṣyamāṇatvāt
translated: Because the words nitya and satya are said to be synonymous later.

analyzed: sat sādhu guṇāḥ sadbhāve sādhu bhāve ca iti
translated: As it is said, Sat are the good qualities, in the sense of existence and goodness.

analyzed: vacanāt teṣām vyāptiḥ bāhulyam takāreṇa uktam
translated: By the word ta, their pervasion, which is abundance, is stated.

analyzed: pūrvavat tanoteḥ bhāve ḍvi pratyayaḥ
translated: The affix da is used in the sense of bhāva from tanute, as before.

analyzed: tasya yantṛ rūpa tva ādyam
translated: The first is because it is in the form of the controller of that.

original: yama uparama iti dhātoḥ ityato ḍaḥ /
analyzed: yamaḥ uparamaḥ iti dhātoḥ ityataḥ ḍaḥ
translated: The affix 'ḍa' is added according to the rule: 'yama uparame'.

analyzed: bhakteṣu sādhu guṇa bāhulya preraka tvāt iti yāvat
translated: This means that it is the instigator of abundance of good qualities in devotees.

original: abhavaditi vacanādbrahmaṇaḥ sattvādikaṃ sādīti śaṅkānirāsāyoktam sadeti //
analyzed: abhavat iti vacanāt brahmaṇaḥ sattva ādikam sādi iti śaṅkā nirāsāya uktam sadā iti
translated: In order to remove the doubt that Brahman has existence etc. because of the statement 'it was not', it is said 'sat' (existent).

analyzed: pratyekam ca asya sambandhaḥ
translated: And this (word 'sat') is connected with each (of the qualities).

original: tarhi kathamabhavaditi prayoga ityata āha vyaktiriti //
analyzed: tarhi katham abhavat iti prayogaḥ iti atas āha vyaktiḥ iti
translated: Then how is the usage 'it was not' (possible)? To this he says 'vyakti' (manifestation).

analyzed: vyaktiḥ ukta guṇānām hi puruṣa apekṣayā nṛṇām
translated: For the manifestation of the qualities mentioned, of men, in relation to the Purusha,

analyzed: bhavet abhavat iti ādyaḥ prayogaḥ ca atra yujyate
translated: the first usage 'it was' etc. is appropriate here.

analyzed: ukta guṇānām sat ādi śabda ukta ktānām
translated: Of the qualities mentioned, which are said to be the qualities of existence etc.,

analyzed: dharmāṇām vyaktiḥ pratītiḥ
translated: the manifestation is the understanding.

original: nṛṇāmupadeṣyṛpuruṣāpekṣayā sṛṣṭau satyāveva bhavet hi yasmādasmātkāraṇāt /
analyzed: nṛṇām upadeṣyṛ puruṣa apekṣayā sṛṣṭau satyau eva bhavet hi yasmāt asmāt kāraṇāt
translated: It would be only when creation exists in relation to the instructing Purusha, because of this reason.

original: atra ca nityaguṇe 'pi brahmaṇi sadādikamabhavaditiprayogo yujyate /
analyzed: atra ca nitya guṇe brahmaṇi sat ādikam abhavat iti prayogaḥ yujyate
translated: And here, even in Brahman which has eternal qualities, the usage 'it was existent etc.' is appropriate.

analyzed: tatas ca ayam śruti arthaḥ sampadyate
translated: And thus this meaning of the scripture is accomplished.

original: tat brahma mūrtāmūrtātmakaṃ viśvaṃ sṛṣṭvā tatprerakatvena nānārūpaistadeva viśvaṃ
analyzed: tat brahma mūrta amūrta ātmakam viśvam sṛṣṭvā tad preraka tvena nānā rūpaiḥ tat eva viśvam
translated: That Brahman, having created the universe consisting of the embodied and the unembodied, by being the instigator of that, by various forms, that very universe,

analyzed: praviśya prāk sṛṣṭeḥ upadeṣyṝṇām upadeśyānām ca śarīra indriyavatām abhāvāt apratīta guṇakam
translated: Having entered before creation, when those to be instructed and those to be taught do not have bodies and senses, it existed with its qualities unknown.

original: sat athedānīmupadeṣyṝṇāmupadeśyānāṃ ca śaṇīrendriyavattve sati pratītasattvādiguṇamabhavaditi /
analyzed: sat atha idānīm upadeṣyṝṇām upadeśyānām ca śaṇīra indriyavat tve sati pratīta sattva ādi guṇam abhavat iti
translated: Now, when those to be instructed and those to be taught have bodies and senses, it exists with its qualities such as existence known.

analyzed: tat anena pārameśvarī sṛṣṭiḥ yogyānām sva guṇa jñāna arthā iti uktam bhavati
translated: By this it is said that the creation of the Supreme Lord is for the sake of knowing its own qualities for those who are fit.

analyzed: yathā uktam
translated: As it is said:

original: so 'yaṃ vihāra iha me tanubhṛtsvabhāvasambhūtaye bhavati bhūtikṛdeva bhūtyāḥ' / iti / /
analyzed: saḥ yam vihāraḥ iha me tanubhṛt svabhāva sambhūtaye bhavati bhūti kṛt eva bhūtyāḥ iti
translated: This sport of mine becomes the cause of prosperity for embodied beings, for the sake of their own nature coming into existence.

analyzed: brahma pariṇāma nirākaraṇam upasaṃharati tasmāt iti
translated: He concludes the refutation of the transformation of Brahman with tasmāt (therefore).

analyzed: tasmāt aśeṣa kartā ekaḥ nirvikāraḥ ramāpatiḥ
translated: Therefore, the one unchanging Lord of Ramā is the sole creator of all.

analyzed: nirvikāraḥ eva aśeṣa kartā iti sambandhaḥ
translated: The connection is that He is the unchanging creator of all.

original: dvibhāgaṃ brahmeti yannirākṛtaṃ tasyopasaṃhāra eka iti /
analyzed: dvi bhāgam brahma iti yat nirākṛtam tasya upasaṃhāraḥ ekaḥ iti
translated: The summary of what was refuted as Brahman having two parts is one.

analyzed: pariṇāma anupapattau ukta yukteḥ anuvādaḥ vā
translated: Or it is a restatement of the reason stated in the non-applicability of transformation.

original: ato na brahmopādānatvaṃ prakṛtyadhikaraṇārtha iti sambandhaḥ śeṣaḥ /
analyzed: atas na brahma upādāna tvam prakṛti adhikaraṇa arthaḥ iti sambandhaḥ śeṣaḥ
translated: Therefore, the meaning of the topic on Prakṛti is not that Brahman is the material cause - this is the connection. The rest is implied.

analyzed: kaḥ tarhi tad arthaḥ iti atas āha śabdaiḥ iti
translated: Then what is its meaning? To that he says śabdaiḥ (by the words).

analyzed: śabdaiḥ prakṛtiḥ ityādyaiḥ strī liṅgaiḥ abhidhīyate
translated: It is designated by words like Prakriti in the feminine gender.

analyzed: iti arthaḥ usya iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The meaning is that this is so, is the remainder.

analyzed: anena apavyākhyāna nirākaraṇasya sva vyākhyāna dārḍhya artha tvāt na asaṅgatiḥ iti api sūcitam
translated: By this, it is also indicated that the refutation of misinterpretation is for the purpose of strengthening one's own interpretation, so there is no irrelevance.

analyzed: nanu vaktavya arthasya avaśiṣṭa tvāt katham upasaṃhāraḥ kriyate
translated: But how is the conclusion made when the remaining meaning to be stated is not yet stated?

analyzed: tathā hi
translated: To explain:

analyzed: pratijñā dṛṣṭānta an uparodhāt iti uktam tāvat dūṣaṇīyam
translated: It has been said that the non-contradiction with the thesis and example should be refuted.

analyzed: satyam
translated: True.

analyzed: vivarta nirākaraṇena nirākariṣyate  tarhi abhidhyā upadeśāt ca iti atra uktam bahu syām prajāyeya
translated: It will be refuted by the refutation of the doctrine of manifestation.

analyzed: iti vākyam dūṣaṇīyam iti ced na
translated: Then, if it is argued that the statement May I become many, may I be born should be refuted because it is a statement of desire, it is not so.

original: asyāpi sacca tyacca' /🔽iti vākyavyākhyānanyāyenaiva vyākhyātatvādityāha bahu syāmiti //
analyzed: asya api sat ca tyat ca  iti vākya vyākhyāna nyāyena eva vyākhyāta tvāt iti āha bahu syām iti
translated: Because this also has been explained by the same method of explaining the statement That which is real and that which is not real.🔽Therefore, it is said May I become many.

analyzed: bahu syām iti tasya eva hi ukta mārgeṇa yujyate
translated: For it is only of that which is said in the above manner that it is proper to say May I become many.

analyzed: tasya eva nirvikārasya eva  ukta mārgeṇa iti asya eva
translated: Of that alone which is without change.

analyzed: vivaraṇam tad tad gatena rūpeṇa iti
translated: The explanation of in the above manner is given by in the form of that and that.

analyzed: tad tad gatena rūpeṇa
translated: In the form of that and that...🔽...

original: tattadanantapadārthaprerakānantarūpairbahu syāmiti so 'kāmayatetyasyāḥ śruterartha ityarthaḥ /🔽evaṃ tarhisa idaṃ sarvamasṛjata' /
analyzed: tad tad ananta padārtha preraka ananta rūpaiḥ bahu syām iti sā u kāmayata iti asyāḥ śruteḥ arthaḥ iti arthaḥ  evam tarhi saḥ idam sarvam asṛjata
translated: The meaning is that the meaning of this Vedic text is that he desired to become many with infinite forms that inspire the infinite things.🔽If so, then the subsequent statement He created all this

analyzed: iti uttara vākyam asaṅgatam syāt
translated: would be irrelevant.

analyzed: na hi anya artham saṅkalpam abhidhāya anya kriyā abhidhānam saṅgacchate
translated: For it is not appropriate to mention a resolve for one purpose and then speak of an action for another purpose.

analyzed: nahi īśvaraḥ svatantraḥ satyakāmaḥ vā iti atas āha tad artham iti
translated: And it is not that the Lord is not independent or does not have a true desire. Therefore he says for that purpose.

analyzed: tad artham hi asṛjat jagat
translated: For he created the world for that purpose.🔽After the desire for the many forms that regulate each thing, because regulation depends on the regulated.
For that purpose, for the purpose of the many forms that regulate,

analyzed: niyamyam jagat tāvat asṛjat
translated: he first created the regulated, the world.

analyzed: tatas niyāmaka bahu svarūpaḥ bhūtvā
translated: Then, having become the many forms that regulate,

analyzed: tat eva anuprāviśat iti
translated: he entered into that very world.

analyzed: vākya yojana upapatteḥ kā atra asaṅgatiḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: Since the connection of the sentences is appropriate, what is the irrelevance here? This is the meaning.

analyzed: anena eva tat ātmānam svayam akuruta iti
translated: By this very [verse], the Vedic text He himself made that Self

analyzed: śrutiḥ vyākhyātā veditavyā
translated: should be understood to be explained.

analyzed: na hi atra ātmānam prapañca ātmanā akuruta iti śrūyate
translated: For here it is not heard that he makes the Self in the form of the world.

analyzed: ubhaya āmnānam ca ūrṇanābhi dṛṣṭānta aktyā eva nirastam
translated: And the mention of both is refuted by the very example of the spider.

analyzed: na hi ūrṇanābheḥ utpadyamānasya
translated: For what is produced from the spider

analyzed: tasmin eva līyamānasya ca
translated: and dissolves into it

analyzed: tantoḥ ūrṇanābhiḥ upādānam
translated: the thread is not the material cause of the spider.

original: kintu tadupabhuktamannamevetyuktam /🔽yoniścetyetatprāgeva nirastamiti yukta evopasaṃhāra iti / /
analyzed: kintu tad upabhuktam annam eva iti uktam  yoniḥ ca iti etat prāk eva nirastam iti yuktaḥ eva upasaṃhāraḥ iti
translated: But rather the food it has consumed, as has been stated.🔽And the word source has already been refuted earlier. Thus the conclusion is proper.

original: apavyākhyānānantaraṃ dūṣayitumanuvadati yacceti // /🔽yaccāvikṛtamevaitad brahma viśvātmanā mṛṣā /
analyzed: apavyākhyāna anantaram dūṣayitum anuvadati yat ca iti  yat ca avikṛtam eva etat brahma viśvātmanā mṛṣā
translated: After the false explanation, he repeats it to refute it, with And what is said.

original: dṛśyate mandadṛṣṭayaiva sa sarga iti kathyate // / / //
analyzed: dṛśyate manda dṛṣṭayā eva sa sargaḥ iti kathyate
translated: And what is said to be creation is that Brahman, unchanged, is seen falsely as the universe by those of dull vision.

analyzed: brahma viśva ātmanā dṛśyate iti yat
translated: That Brahman is seen as the universe,

original: sa sarga iti kathyata ityetāvatpariṇāmavāde 'pi samam /
analyzed: sa sargaḥ iti kathyate iti etāvat pariṇāma vāde samam
translated: that is said to be creation - this much is the same even in the doctrine of transformation.

analyzed: atas uktam avikṛtam eva iti
translated: Therefore it is said unchanged.

analyzed: avikṛta tvam kutas iti atas uktam ekam iti
translated: How is it unchanged? For that it is said one.

analyzed: a dvitīyam
translated: Without a second.

analyzed: niravayavam ca iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: without parts.

analyzed: tathā hi
translated: For thus:

analyzed: kim brahmaṇaḥ svatas eva viśva ākāra pariṇāmaḥ
translated: Is the transformation of Brahman into the form of the universe from itself?

analyzed: kim vā paratas
translated: Or from another?

analyzed: na ādyaḥ kvāpi adarśanāt
translated: Not the first, because it is not seen anywhere.

analyzed: yat api kṣīravat hi iti udāhṛtam
translated: What has been cited as an example, like milk,

analyzed: tat kāla ādeḥ vidyamāna tvāt ayuktam
translated: That is not proper, because time and so on exist.

analyzed: sva icchayā eva iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that it is by its own will, that is not so.

analyzed: prayojana abhāvāt
translated: Because there is no purpose.

analyzed: svabhāvaḥ yam iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that this is its nature, that is not so.

analyzed: prekṣāvat tva hāneḥ
translated: Because it would lose its rationality.

analyzed: na dvitīyaḥ
translated: The second is not so.

analyzed: a dvitīya tvāt
translated: Because it is without a second.

analyzed: na ca niravayavam kvāpi pariṇatam dṛṣṭam
translated: And nothing partless is seen to transform anywhere.

analyzed: ākāśam saṃyoga ādimat upalabdham iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that space is perceived as having conjunction and so on, that is not so.

analyzed: dravya akāraṇa pariṇāmasya prakṛta tvāt
translated: Because the transformation of the substance cause is the topic.

analyzed: paramāṇu ādayaḥ tu svarūpeṇa eva na siddhāḥ iti
translated: But atoms and so on are not established even in their own form.

original: avikṛtamevānyadanyātmanā dṛśyata ityasambhavi ityata uktam mṛṣeti //
analyzed: avikṛtam eva anyat anya ātmanā dṛśyate iti asambhavi iti atas uktam mṛṣā iti
translated: It is impossible that something else is seen in the form of something else without being transformed. Therefore it is said to be false.

analyzed: mṛṣā śabdena viśvasya brahma tādātmyasya tad darśanasya ca anirvacanīya tā ucyate
translated: By the word false, the inexpressibility of the identity of the universe with Brahman and of its vision is stated.

analyzed: yathā rajjuḥ avikṛtā eva mṛṣā bhujaṅga ādi ākāreṇa ābhāsate tathā eva iti
translated: Just as a rope appears falsely in the form of a snake, etc., without being transformed, so is it.

analyzed: tarhi viśva upādānam anyat vaktavyam iti atas uktam manda dṛṣṭayā eva iti
translated: Then another material cause of the universe must be stated. Therefore it is said by mere false vision.

original: mandā bhavati dṛṣṭiryayā sā mandadṛṣṭistayā māyayetyarthaḥ /
analyzed: mandā bhavati dṛṣṭiḥ yayā sā manda dṛṣṭiḥ tayā māyayā iti arthaḥ
translated: The vision by which one becomes slow is the slow vision. By that illusion, is the meaning.

analyzed: athavā asambhava parihāra artham uktam manda dṛṣṭayā eva iti
translated: Or, to avoid the impossibility, it is said by mere false vision.

analyzed: mandā ca asau dṛṣṭiḥ ca manda dṛṣṭiḥ bhrāntiḥ tayā iti arthaḥ  bhrānteḥ api yāthārthyāt viśvasya
translated: And that is slow, and that is vision, that is slow vision, that is error, is the meaning.

analyzed: satya tā āpattiḥ iti atas uktam mṛṣā iti
translated: And because of the truthfulness of error, there would be the consequence of the truth of the universe. Therefore it is said to be false.

analyzed: tat etat mithyā prapañca āropa adhiṣṭhāna tvam eva brahmaṇaḥ prakṛtiḥ ca ityādinā kathyate iti
translated: This very being the substratum of the superimposition of the false manifestation is being stated by the words Prakṛti etc. of Brahman.

analyzed: etat uktam bhavati
translated: This is what is being said.

analyzed: prakṛtiḥ ca ityādi sūtraiḥ ukta rītyā brahmaṇaḥ jagat upādāna tvam ucyate
translated: By the aphorisms beginning with Prakṛti etc., the fact of Brahman being the material cause of the world is being stated in the manner described.

analyzed: upādāna tvam ca na pariṇāmi tayā
translated: And the fact of being the material cause is not by way of transformation.

analyzed: api tarhi avidyā pariṇāma mṛṣā viśva bhrama adhiṣṭhāna tvena eva
translated: But rather by being the substratum of the false manifestation of the world, which is the transformation of ignorance.

analyzed: atas na ukta doṣaḥ iti
translated: Therefore, there is no fault stated.

analyzed: dūṣayitum upakramate kathyate iti
translated: He begins to refute by saying is being stated.

analyzed: yat brahma vivarta vādinā kathyate
translated: What is being stated by the one who advocates the manifestation of Brahman,

analyzed: tasya dūṣaṇam kathyata
translated: the refutation of that is being stated.

analyzed: iti āvṛttyā yojanīyam  tat ca na iti nañ anuvṛttiḥ vā kartavyā
translated: This should be connected by repetition.🔽And that is not, the negative particle should be repeated.

analyzed: kutas na iti atas vikalpena pṛcchati sā iti
translated: From where is it not? Therefore, he asks by way of an alternative with that.

analyzed: sā manda dṛṣṭiḥ tasya eva brahmaṇaḥ kim tatas
translated: Is that slow vision of Brahman itself or is it elsewhere?

original: viśvasya brahmavivartatve nirākartavye mandadṛṣṭayāśrayapraśno 'nupapanna ityata uktam seti //
analyzed: viśvasya brahma vivarta tve nirākartavye manda dṛṣṭayā āśraya praśnaḥ nu papannaḥ iti atas uktam sā iti
translated: When the universe is to be refuted as a manifestation of Brahman, the question based on the view of the slow-witted is not proper. Therefore it is said: that (in the verse).

analyzed: ekasya
translated: Of that one, who is not fallen from truth, by the manifestation characterized by the appearance of many forms contrary to the previous true form.

analyzed: tad upādāna tayā
translated: By that being the material cause.

analyzed: ca uktā iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: is said.

original: mandadṛṣṭāvāśrayānirūpaṇādinā nirākṛtāyāṃ sarvamidaṃ nirākṛtaṃ bhavatīti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: manda dṛṣṭau āśraya anirūpaṇa ādinā nirākṛtāyām sarvam idam nirākṛtam bhavati iti bhāvaḥ
translated: When the view of the slow-witted is refuted by the non-determination of the substratum and so on, all this becomes refuted. This is the idea.

analyzed: tasya eva yad avaṣṭambhaḥ viśvaḥ vivartaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: Of that very one. The meaning is: the universe is a manifestation that is supported by that (Brahman).

analyzed: tatas nyagāḥ jīva gatā iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: it is present in something other than that, in the individual souls.

analyzed: kim śabdasya ubhayatas sambandhaḥ
translated: The word what is connected with both (Brahman and the individual souls).

original: māyāvādino hi kecit brahmaiva svāvidyayā jagadākāreṇa vivartate svapnādivaditi manyante /
analyzed: māyā vādinaḥ hi kecid brahma eva sva avidyayā jagat ākāreṇa vivartate svapna ādi vat iti manyante
translated: For some Advaitins believe that Brahman itself, by its own ignorance, manifests as the world in the form of the world, like in a dream and so on.

analyzed: bimba sthānīyam brahma māyā śaktimat kāraṇam
translated: Brahman, which is like the original object, is the cause, possessing the power of Maya.

analyzed: jīvāḥ ca pratyekam avidyā anubaddhāḥ iti apare
translated: And the individual souls are each bound by ignorance. This is the view of others.🔽Brahman, reflected in the Maya-ignorance, is the cause of the world.

analyzed: viruddham ca brahma abhūta tva ālambanam jīvāḥ ca avidyā anubaddhāḥ iti anye
translated: And it is contradictory that the individual souls are bound by ignorance, while Brahman is the object of the notion of reality. This is the view of others.

original: jīvā eva svāvidyayā pratyekaṃ prapañcākāreṇa brahma vibhrāmyanti /
analyzed: jīvāḥ eva sva avidyayā pratyekam prapañca ākāreṇa brahma vibhrāmyanti
translated: The individual souls, by their own ignorance, delude Brahman into the form of the world, each one separately.

analyzed: sādṛśyāt ca prapañca eka tā avabhāsaḥ aneka avagata dvitīya candra vat
translated: And the appearance of the oneness of the world is due to similarity, like the appearance of two moons seen by one with defective vision.

analyzed: svarūpa apekṣayā ca brahma jagat kāraṇam iti eke
translated: And some consider Brahman to be the cause of the world in relation to its own nature.

analyzed: tatra avāntarabhedam a vivakṣitvā dvedhā eva vikalpitam
translated: There, without intending any internal divisions, it is only twofold.

original: iha jīvagetyanuktvā tato 'nyageti vadatā sa jīvaḥ kiṃ brahmaṇo 'nyo'nanyo vā
analyzed: iha jīvagā iti an uktvā tatas nyagā iti vadatā sa jīvaḥ kim brahmaṇaḥ vā
translated: By saying going to something other than that without mentioning going to the individual soul, it is also suggested that the individual soul is either different from Brahman, not different,

analyzed: na vā iti api vikalpaḥ sūcitaḥ
translated: or neither.

original: tatra dvitīyaḥ prathame praviśatīti taṃ dūṣayati brahmaṇaścediti //
analyzed: tatra dvitīyaḥ prathame praviśati iti tam dūṣayati brahmaṇaḥ ced iti
translated: There, the second one is included in the first, so he refutes it with If of Brahman, where is omniscience?

analyzed: brahmaṇaḥ ced kva sārvajñyam  yadi brahmaṇaḥ viśva
translated: If of Brahman, where is omniscience?

analyzed: bhramaḥ tadā bhramasya viśeṣa ajñāna pūrvaka tvāt tat api brahmaṇaḥ ṅgīkaraṇīyam
translated: If the delusion of the world is of Brahman, then since delusion must be preceded by ignorance of particulars, that too must be accepted as belonging to Brahman.

analyzed: tathā ca tasya sārvajñyam na syāt
translated: And in that case, its omniscience would not be possible.

analyzed: yadi ca na brahmaṇi sārvajñyam
translated: And if omniscience does not belong to Brahman,

analyzed: tarhi kva tat syāt
translated: then where would it be?

analyzed: na tāvat jīve
translated: Not first in the individual soul.

analyzed: anubhava virodhāt
translated: Because it contradicts experience.

analyzed: nā api jaḍe jñāna mātra asambhavāt
translated: Nor in the insentient, because knowledge is not possible.

analyzed: tathācayaḥ sarvajñaḥ
translated: And thus He is all-knowing.

analyzed: ityādi śruti vaiyarthyam syāt
translated: And thus the uselessness of such Vedic passages as The Self is all-knowing would result.

analyzed: nanu sārvajñyam api brahmaṇaḥ bhrāntyā evā iti ced na
translated: If it be said that even omniscience belongs to Brahman only through illusion, we reply: No.

analyzed: yādṛśa tādṛśasya api viśeṣa jñāna virodhi tvāt
translated: Because even such and such knowledge of particulars is incompatible with it.

original: anyathā śuktijñānavato 'pi tadajñānaṃ na viruddhayateti bhramānucchedaprasaṅgaḥ /
analyzed: anyathā tad ajñānam na bhrama anuccheda prasaṅgaḥ
translated: Otherwise, even one who knows mother-of-pearl would not contradict the ignorance of that [mother-of-pearl as silver], and there would be the undesirable consequence of the non-cessation of illusion.

analyzed: upalakṣaṇam ca etat
translated: And this is only an illustration.

analyzed: brahmaṇaḥ viśeṣa abhāvāt tad anavabhāsa nimittaḥ bhramaḥ nā upapadyate
translated: Because Brahman has no particulars, an illusion having that [Brahman] as its cause is not possible.

analyzed: sva rūpam tu sva prakāśa tayā siddham
translated: But its own nature is established as self-luminous.

analyzed: a siddha tve vācā
translated: If it be not established, then

analyzed: sutarām vibhrama anupapattiḥ
translated: the occurrence of illusion is all the more impossible.

analyzed: adhiṣṭhāna anupalambhāt iti api draṣṭavyam  dvitīyasya ādyam dūṣayati anya gā ced iti
translated: It should also be seen that [illusion] is not possible because the substratum is not perceived.

analyzed: anya gā ced svatas nyatā
translated: He refutes the first of the second [objection]: If it belongs to another, then otherness from itself...

original: yadi brahmavyatiriktajīvāśrayā viśvabhrāntiraṅgīkriyate tadā bhrāntyāśrayasya bhrāntikalpitatvāyogāt jīvabrahmaṇoranyatā svābhāvikītyāpannam
analyzed: yadi brahma vyatirikta jīva āśrayā viśva bhrāntiḥ aṅgīkriyate tadā bhrānti āśrayasya bhrānti kalpita tva ayogāt jīva brahmaṇoḥ anyatā svābhāvikī iti āpannam
translated: If the illusion of the universe is accepted as having as its substratum a jiva separate from Brahman, then, because it is not possible for the substratum of illusion to be imagined by illusion, it follows that the jiva and Brahman are naturally different.

analyzed: tatas ca apasiddhāntaḥ iti
translated: And from that, there is the undesirable consequence of contradicting one's own doctrine.

analyzed: nanu astu jīva brahma bhedaḥ vāstavaḥ
translated: But let the difference between the jiva and Brahman be real.

analyzed: anātma prapañcaḥ astu bhrānti kalpitaḥ brahmaṇi iti atas āha na iti
translated: Let the non-Self-proliferation be imagined in Brahman. To this he says, no.

analyzed: na a deha yoginaḥ dṛṣṭiḥ iti tat kāraṇam svatas
translated: The vision of one not united with the body is its cause from itself.

analyzed: yadi api na evam māyā vādinaḥ manyante
translated: Even though the Māyāvādins do not think thus,

analyzed: tathā api sūtra artha nirākaraṇāya pravṛttasya tatra eva anupapatti vyutpādanam ślāghyam iti ārambhaḥ
translated: nevertheless, for one engaged in refuting the meaning of the aphorism, it is praiseworthy to teach the inconsistency right there. This is the beginning.

analyzed: na kevalam brahma vyatiriktānām jīvānām akalpita tvam
translated: Not only is the non-Brahman jīvas not imagined,

original: kintu dehayogarahitasyendriyābhāvātatpadārthadarśanaṃ na sambhavatītyato hetoḥ āropakāraṇamindriyaṃ tadāśrayo dehaśca kalpanāṃ vinaivāstītyaṅgīkaraṇīyam
analyzed: kintu deha yoga rahitasya indriya abhāvāt tad padārtha darśanam na sambhavati iti atas hetoḥ āropa kāraṇam indriyam tad āśrayaḥ dehaḥ ca kalpanām vinā eva asti iti aṅgīkaraṇīyam
translated: but also the body and sense organs, the basis of which is the absence of sense organs, the vision of the objects of those is not possible. Therefore, the cause of superimposition, the sense organs, and the body which is their basis, must be accepted as existing without imagination.

original: nahi sukhādivadrajatādivadvāsya prapañcasya sākṣimātrasiddhatvaṃ paro manyate dehendriyāṇāmapyutpattimatvāt /
analyzed: nahi sukha ādi vat rajata ādi vat vā asya prapañcasya sākṣi mātra siddha tvam paraḥ manyate deha indriyāṇām api utpattimat tvāt
translated: For the other does not consider this proliferation of pleasure etc. or silver etc. to be established by the mere witness, because the body and sense organs also have a cause.

analyzed: tad kāraṇam ca svatas iti aṅgīkaraṇīyam
translated: And that cause must be accepted as from itself.

original: astu brahmavyatiriktānāṃ jīvānāṃ sakāraṇānāṃ tadīyadehendriyāṇāṃ cābhrāntikalpitatvam /
analyzed: astu brahma vyatiriktānām jīvānām sa kāraṇānām tadīya deha indriyāṇām ca a bhrānti kalpita tvam
translated: Let the jīvas other than Brahman, with their causes, and their bodies and sense organs, be imagined by non-error.

original: draṣṭṛtvena darśanakaraṇatvena tadāśrayatvena tatkāraṇatvena ca bhrānteḥ pūrvabhāvitvāt /
analyzed: draṣṭṛ tvena darśana karaṇa tvena tad āśraya tvena tad kāraṇa tvena ca bhrānteḥ pūrva bhāvi tvāt
translated: Because error exists prior to it, as the seer, as the instrument of seeing, as its substratum, and as its cause.

original: tadatiriktāstu prapañco 'stu bhrāntikalpita ityata āha dehina iti //
analyzed: tad atiriktāḥ tu prapañcaḥ stu bhrānti kalpitaḥ iti atas āha dehinaḥ iti
translated: But let the world be imagined by error, apart from that. To this he says 'of the embodied'.

original: dehinaḥ kāraṇayutā dehāśca yadi na bhramāt // / / //
analyzed: dehinaḥ kāraṇa yutāḥ dehāḥ ca yadi na bhramāt
translated: If the embodied beings along with their causes and the bodies are not due to error,

analyzed: kim bhrānti kalpitam tatra
translated: then what is imagined by error there?

analyzed: kāraṇa śabdena jñāna kāraṇānām indriyāṇām deha indriya kāraṇānām ca grahaṇam
translated: By the word 'cause', the sense-organs which are the causes of knowledge and the causes of the body and sense-organs are included.

analyzed: siddhāḥ iti śeṣaḥ
translated: 'Are established' is the remainder.

analyzed: kim ākṣepe
translated: 'What?' is in the sense of reproach.

analyzed: tatra tarhi prapañce brahmaṇi iti vā
translated: 'There', then, in the world, or in Brahman.

analyzed: ananta jīva sa kāraṇa deha indriya atiriktasya prapañcasya abhāvāt
translated: Because apart from the infinite individual souls, the causes, the bodies and the sense-organs, there is no other world.

analyzed: viṣayāṇām api deha indriya nirvāha ārthatvāt iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The meaning is that even the objects exist for the sake of maintaining the body and sense-organs.

analyzed: tathāca na kevalam apasiddhāntaḥ
translated: And thus not only is there a contradiction with your own doctrine,

analyzed: prakṛtiḥ ca ityādi sūtrāṇām nirviṣaya tva āpattiḥ ca syāt iti śeṣaḥ
translated: but also the Sūtras beginning with 'Prakṛtiśca' would become meaningless, this is the remainder.

analyzed: nanu anya gā ced svatas iti uktam
translated: But it has been said that if it belongs to another, it is other than itself.

analyzed: jīva brahma bhedasya api bhrānti siddha tvāt
translated: Because the difference between the individual soul and Brahman is also established by error.

original: bhrāntyā brahmaṇo bhinnasya bāhyādhyātmikārthabhrama iti hi manyata ityata āha bhedo 'pīti //
analyzed: bhrāntyā brahmaṇaḥ bhinnasya bāhya ādhyātmika artha bhramaḥ iti hi manyate iti atas āha
translated: He thinks that the error of the external and internal objects is due to the error of Brahman being different. Therefore he says: The difference also, if born of error...

analyzed: bhedaḥ pi bhrama jaḥ yadi
translated: If the difference is also born of error,

analyzed: na kevalam prapañcaḥ
translated: not only the world,

original: kintu jīvabrahmaṇorbhedo 'pi yadi bhramajo bhramasiddhaḥ aṅgīkriyate /
analyzed: kintu jīva brahmaṇoḥ bhedaḥ yadi bhrama jaḥ bhrama siddhaḥ aṅgīkriyate
translated: but also the difference between the individual soul and Brahman, if accepted as established by error,

analyzed: tadā anyonya āśraya tā syāt iti sambandhaḥ
translated: then there would be mutual dependence. This is the connection.

analyzed: atra anyonya āśraya tā śabdena cakrakam ucyate tasya api bahuṣu anyonya āśraya tvāt
translated: Here, by the word mutual dependence, a circle is meant, because that also has mutual dependence in many cases.

analyzed: katham anyonya āśraya tā iti atas uktam bhrānteḥ iti
translated: How is there mutual dependence? To this it is said: Due to the delusion...

analyzed: bhrānteḥ ajñāna mūla tvāt tasya bheda vyapekṣayā
translated: Because delusion has ignorance as its root, and that depends on difference...

analyzed: bhrānteḥ jīva brahma bheda hetoḥ bhāva rūpa ajñāna kāraṇa tvāt
translated: Because delusion, the cause of the difference between the individual soul and Brahman, has the form of existence and is caused by ignorance.

analyzed: tasya ajñānasya ca bheda sāpekṣa tvāt
translated: And because that ignorance depends on difference.

analyzed: ajñānam anādi tvāt katham bheda vyapekṣayā syāt iti atas uktam na ajñāna iti
translated: How can ignorance, being beginningless, depend on difference? To this it is said: There is no...

analyzed: na ajñāna kalpakam kiñcid anyonya āśraya tā yatas
translated: There is no cause of ignorance, because of mutual dependence...

analyzed: yatas brahma vyatirikta jīvāt ṛte na ajñāna kalpakam kiñcid asti
translated: Because apart from the individual soul other than Brahman, there is no cause of ignorance at all.

analyzed: etat uktam bhavati  jīva brahmaṇoḥ
translated: This is what is said.🔽The difference between the individual soul and Brahman,

analyzed: bhedaḥ yayā bhrāntyā siddhaḥ
translated: which is established by an illusion,

analyzed: sā tāvat ajñāna apekṣā
translated: that depends on ignorance.

analyzed: bhrānteḥ svarūpataḥ viṣayaḥ ca ajñāna kāryatva aṅgīkārāt
translated: Because the form and object of the illusion are accepted as effects of ignorance.

analyzed: yadi api bheda viṣayā bhrāntiḥ sākṣi caitanyam  tathā api tasya asaṅgasya āropita artha saṃsṛṣṭa rūpaṃpa tā
translated: Although the illusion that has difference as its object is the consciousness of the witness,

analyzed: na ajñānena vinā utpadyate
translated: nevertheless, that [consciousness], which is unattached, does not arise without ignorance, having a form mixed with an imposed object.

analyzed: tat ca ajñānam bheda sāpekṣam
translated: And that ignorance depends on difference.

analyzed: anādi tve pi bhrānti kalpita tvasya aṅgīkṛta tvāt  anyathā satya tā āpātāt
translated: Even though it is beginningless, the nature of being imagined by illusion is accepted.

analyzed: bhrānteḥ ca
translated: Otherwise, there would be the fault of [the illusion] being real.🔽And because the nature of the illusion
being dependent on the individual soul is accepted.

analyzed: bheda kalpanayā vinā ca jīvasya abhāvāt
translated: And because there is no individual soul without the imagination of difference.

analyzed: na ca avidyā āropaḥ brahmaṇi eva iti yuktam
translated: And it is not proper to say that the imposition of ignorance is only on Brahman.

analyzed: sarvasya api tad āśraya tva upapattau ardhajaratīya anupapatteḥ
translated: Because when it is possible for everything to be its substratum, the [view] of half-decay is not proper.

analyzed: atas bhrama jñāna jīva bhedānām anya sāpekṣa tvāt cakrakam iti
translated: Therefore, because the illusion, knowledge, and difference of the individual soul depend on something else, there is a circle.

analyzed: athavā bhedasya bhrānti kalpita tve bhrānteḥ ca bheda sāpekṣa tvāt anyonya āśraya tvam anena uktam
translated: Or else, this [verse] states the mutual dependence, because the difference is imagined by illusion, and the illusion depends on difference.

analyzed: vyutpādana artham eva ajñānam madhye niveśitam iti draṣṭavyam  anena jīva ajñāna vāda upakṣaḥ
translated: It should be seen that ignorance is placed in the middle only for the purpose of instruction.

analyzed: pi nirastaḥ
translated: By this, the theory of the Jiva's ignorance is also refuted.

analyzed: itaretara āśraya ādi doṣa sāmyāt
translated: Because of the similarity of the faults of mutual dependence, etc.

analyzed: bīja aṅkura vat adoṣaḥ iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that there is no fault like the seed and sprout, it is not so.

analyzed: vaiṣamyāt
translated: Because of inequality.

analyzed: vyakti bhedena hi tatra adoṣa tvam
translated: For there is no fault there due to the difference in manifestation.

analyzed: na ca jīva avidyā vyakti bhedaḥ sti iti
translated: And there is no difference in the manifestation of the Jiva's ignorance.

analyzed: yat uktam na a deha yoginaḥ ityādi tat anupapannam
translated: What was said, that it is not for one not united with the body, etc., is not correct.

analyzed: deha ādeḥ api bhrānti kalpita tvāt
translated: Because the body, etc. are also imagined by error.

analyzed: na ca tatra kāraṇa abhāvaḥ pūrva deha ādeḥ vidyamāna tvāt
translated: And there is no absence of cause there, because the previous body, etc. exist.

analyzed: na ca evam anavasthā
translated: And there is no such infinite regress.

analyzed: anādi tvāt iti
translated: Because it is beginningless.

analyzed: mā evam  ādisarge deha ādi darśana anupapatteḥ
translated: This is not so.🔽Because the appearance of the initial body, etc. is not possible.

analyzed: na hi ayam sākṣi mātra siddhaḥ rthaḥ iti uktam
translated: For it has been said that this is not an object established by the mere witness.

analyzed: kiñca syāt ayam anavasthā parihāraḥ
translated: Moreover, this may be the avoidance of infinite regress.

analyzed: yadi pūrva pūrvatara ādi deha ādeḥ api bhrānti siddha tvam pramitam syāt
translated: If the establishment by error of the previous, earlier, etc. bodies were known.

analyzed: anyathā evam
translated: Otherwise, it would be so.

analyzed: sarvatra anavasthā parihāraḥ prasajyeta
translated: The avoidance of infinite regress would be admitted everywhere.

analyzed: na ca atra pramāṇam asti
translated: And there is no evidence for this.

analyzed: nanu katham na asti
translated: But how is it not?

original: neha nānā' / ityādiśrutervidyamānatvāditi etadāhaityata āha🔽bhramatve tviti //
analyzed: na iha nānā ityādi śruteḥ vidyamāna tvāt iti etat āha eti atas āha  bhrama tve tu iti
translated: Because the Vedic text, 'Neha nāna' etc., is present. To this he says

analyzed: bhrama tve tu iyam uktiḥ ca tad antar patanāt na hi
translated: 'But if it were an illusion, this statement would fall within that, and therefore not...'

analyzed: yat vā sarvaḥ pi ayam prasaṅgaḥ viparyaya payarvasāna hīna tvāt ābhāsaḥ eva
translated: Or, this entire reductio argument is only an appearance, because it lacks the conclusion of the opposite.

original: neha nānetyādiśrutyā sarvasyāpi viyadādeḥ prapañcasya bhrāntikalpitatvābhidhānāt ityāśaṅkayedamuditam /
analyzed: na iha nānā ityādi śrutyā sarvasya api viyat ādeḥ prapañcasya bhrānti kalpita tva abhidhānāt iti āśaṅkayā idam uditam
translated: The doubt is raised that all this universe beginning with ether is said to be imagined by error by the Vedic text beginning with 'Neha nāna' etc. To this he says

analyzed: upapatti aviruddhaḥ hi veda arthaḥ grāhyaḥ
translated: The meaning of the Veda should be accepted if it is not contradicted by reasoning.

analyzed: anyathā andhaḥ maṇim avindat ityādeḥ api grahaṇa prasaṅgāt
translated: Otherwise, there would be the absurd consequence of accepting even such statements as 'The blind man found a gem' etc.

analyzed: vicāra śāsnā anārambha prasaṅgāt ca
translated: And because it would lead to the absurdity of not beginning the study of reasoning.

analyzed: na iha nānā ityādi vākyam ca upapatti viruddham
translated: And the statement beginning with 'Neha nāna' is contradicted by reasoning.

original: tathāhi /🔽yadi viyadādikaṃ sarvaṃ bhramasiddhaṃ syāt tadā tadantaḥpātitvādiyaṃ śrutiśca tathā syāt /
analyzed: tathā hi  yadi viyat ādikam sarvam bhrama siddham syāt tadā tad antaḥpāti tvāt iyam śrutiḥ ca tathā syāt
translated: This is how.🔽If all this beginning with ether were established by error, then this Vedic text would be so, because it would fall within that.

original: bhramāropitaṃ viyadādikaṃ sarvaṃ bhramasiddhaṃ syāt tadā tadantaḥpātitvādiyaṃ śrutiśca tathā syāt /
analyzed: bhrama āropitam viyat ādikam sarvam bhrama siddham syāt tadā tad antaḥpāti tvāt iyam śrutiḥ ca tathā syāt
translated: If all this beginning with ether, superimposed by error, were established by error, then this Vedic text would be so, because it would fall within that.

analyzed: bhrama āropitam ca asat iti śruteḥ api asattvāt na artha dhī hetutvam iti
translated: And what is superimposed by error is unreal. Therefore, even verbal testimony cannot be the cause of the cognition of objects, because it is unreal.

original: bhramaśabdaḥ jñāne arthe ca pareṣāṃ prasiddha iti bhramatva ityuktam /
analyzed: bhrama śabdaḥ jñāne arthe ca pareṣām prasiddhaḥ iti bhrama tve iti uktam
translated: The word error is well-known to others both in relation to knowledge and objects. Therefore, it is said in error.

original: yadyapyayamarthaḥ prathamasūtre varṇitaḥ tathāpi tatrādhyātmikaḥ prasaṅgaḥ prapañco
analyzed: yadi api ayam arthaḥ prathama sūtre varṇitaḥ tathā api tatra ādhyātmikaḥ prasaṅgaḥ prapañcaḥ
translated: Although this meaning has been stated in the first aphorism, still there the internal contingency is elaborated,

analyzed: atra tu bāhya ṣava ṣayaḥ iti bhedaḥ
translated: but here the external object is different.

analyzed: adhika vivakṣayā ca uktasya punaruktiḥ iti
translated: And the repetition of what has been said is due to the desire to say more.

original: nanu sarvo 'pyayaṃ prapañco bhrāntisiddho 'pi vyāvahāriko bhavatyeva /
analyzed: nanu sarvaḥ pi ayam prapañcaḥ bhrānti siddhaḥ pi vyāvahārikaḥ bhavati eva
translated: But all this elaboration, though established by error, is indeed conventional.

analyzed: atas tad antar patitā śrutiḥ api vyāvahārika tvāt artha hetuḥ bhaviṣyati iti atas āha vyāvahārika tā iti
translated: Therefore, even verbal testimony, which falls within that, will be the cause of meaning because it is conventional. To this he says conventional nature.

analyzed: vyāvahārika tā ca asya syāt abādhya tve eva hi
translated: And its conventional nature would be only if it were not contradicted.

analyzed: caḥ tu arthaḥ
translated: The word ca (and) has the meaning of tu (but).

original: syādapyevaṃ yadi prapañcasya vyāvahārikatā tāvat tava🔽śakyāṅgīkārā syāt /
analyzed: syāt api evam yadi prapañcasya vyāvahārika tā tāvat tava  śakya aṅgīkārā syāt
translated: This would be so if the conventional nature of the elaboration could be accepted by you.

analyzed: na ca evam
translated: But it is not so.

original: yato 'sya prapañcasya vyāvahārikatā tu abādhyatva eva syāt /
analyzed: yatas sya prapañcasya vyāvahārika tā tu abādhya tve eva syāt
translated: Because the conventional nature of this elaboration would be only if it were not contradicted.

analyzed: etat uktam bhavati
translated: This is what is meant.

analyzed: yadi prapañcaḥ vyāvahārikaḥ ṅgīkriyeta
translated: If the world were accepted as conventional,

analyzed: tarhi abādhyaḥ pi aṅgīkartavyaḥ prasajyeta
translated: then it would follow that it should be accepted as non-refuted.

analyzed: na ca tathā aṅgīkriyate bhavatā
translated: And it is not accepted as such by you.

analyzed: atas na vyāvahārikā api aṅgīkartum ucitaḥ iti
translated: Therefore, it is not proper to accept it even as conventional.

analyzed: satya tva aṅgīkāra āpādane tviṣi āpādanam syāt
translated: But if it were argued that the acceptance of reality would be absurd, that would be an absurd consequence,

analyzed: pareṇa api kathañcid satya tvasya api aṅgīkṛta tvāt
translated: because the other party somehow accepts reality too.

analyzed: atas bādhya tve eva iti uktam
translated: Therefore, it is said that it is only in terms of non-refutation.

analyzed: nanu śakti rajata ādeḥ bādhyasya api abhijñā abhivadana rūpa vyavahāra viṣaya tvāt vayāpti hīnaḥ yam tarkaḥ iti atas āha bādhyam iti
translated: But since even the refuted silver, etc. are the objects of cognition and speech, this reasoning is devoid of pervasion. To this he says what is refuted...

analyzed: bādhyam na arthakriyā kāri
translated: What is refuted does not perform a function.

analyzed: satyam bādhyam śukti rajata ādikam
translated: True, silver, etc. are refuted.

analyzed: abhijñā ādikam vyavahāra viṣayaḥ iti
translated: They are the objects of cognition, etc.

analyzed: tathā api arthakriyā kāri na bhavati
translated: Nevertheless, they do not perform a function.

analyzed: nahi tena rajata ucitā valaya nirmāṇa ādi arthakriyā jāyamānā dṛṣṭā
translated: For the function of silver, such as the making of bracelets, etc., is not seen to arise from it.

analyzed: arthakriyā kāri tva lakṣaṇam eva vyāvahārika tvam iha prakṛtam
translated: Here, what is meant by being conventional is only performing a function,

analyzed: na abhijñā ādi viṣaya tvam
translated: not being the object of cognition, etc.

analyzed: śruteḥ artha dhī janaka tva upanyasta tvāt
translated: Because the production of the cognition of the meaning of the Veda is presented.

analyzed: atas na tarkasya aṅga vaikalyam iti
translated: Therefore, reasoning is not defective in its parts.

analyzed: nanu bādhya tvam śuktikā ādi adhiṣṭhānasya dharmaḥ
translated: But the substratum of mother-of-pearl, etc. is subject to being contradicted.

analyzed: vijñātasya anyathā
translated: The cognition is otherwise.

analyzed: iti ukta tvāt
translated: Thus it has been stated.

analyzed: śuktikā ādikam ca arthakriyā kāri iti katham ucyate bādhyam na arthakriyā kāri iti
translated: And mother-of-pearl, etc. are causally efficient. How can it be said that what is contradicted is not causally efficient?

analyzed: mā evam
translated: This is not so.

analyzed: niṣedhya tva lakṣaṇa bādhya tvasya para abhyupagatasya atra āśrayaṇāt
translated: Because the contradiction characterized by being negated, which is accepted by the opponent, is relied upon here.

original: nanu tathāpyasatyasya svāpnakāminīsambhogādeḥ caramadhātuvisargādyarthakriyākāritvadarśanāt vyāptivikalastarka ityata āha na ceti //
analyzed: nanu tathā api asatyasya svāpna kāminī sambhoga ādeḥ carama dhātu visarga ādi artha kriyā kāri tva darśanāt vyāpti vikalaḥ tarkaḥ iti atas āha na ca iti
translated: But even so, because the causal efficiency of the emission of the final element, etc. is seen in the case of the unreal, such as the enjoyment of a woman in a dream, reasoning is devoid of pervasion. To this he says not, etc.

analyzed: na ca svapnaḥ na u mṛṣā
translated: And even a dream is not false for us.

analyzed: svapnaḥ iti svapna avasthā upalabdhaḥ rthaḥ
translated: A dream is an object perceived in the state of dreaming.

analyzed: na u smākam bādarāyaṇīyānām mate
translated: Not for us, the followers of Badarayana.

original: tarhi mama matena vyāptibhaṅgo 'stu mayā mṛṣātvenāṅgīkṛtatvāt iti cenna /
analyzed: tarhi mama matena vyāpti bhaṅgo stu mayā mṛṣātvena aṅgīkṛta tvāt iti ced na
translated: Then let there be a breach of pervasion according to my view, because it is accepted by me as false. If this is argued, it is not so.

analyzed: bādarāyaṇīyena tathā aṅgīkartum aśakya tvāt
translated: Because it cannot be accepted as such by the follower of Badarayana.

original: nanu kathaṃ bādarāyaṇasya na mṛṣā svapna ityata āha vāsaneti //
analyzed: nanu katham bādarāyaṇasya na mṛṣā svapnaḥ iti atas āha vāsanā iti
translated: But how is it that a dream is not false for Badarayana? To this he says due to impressions, etc.

analyzed: vāsanā janita tvena tasya api aṅgīkṛta tvataḥ
translated: Because that also is admitted to be produced by impressions.

original: tasya svapnasyāpi māyāmātramiti vadatā sūtrakāreṇa vāsanājanitatvenāṅgīkṛtatvāt idaṃ jñāyate /
analyzed: tasya svapnasya api māyā mātram iti vadatā sūtrakāreṇa vāsanā janita tvena aṅgīkṛta tvāt idam jñāyate
translated: By the author of the aphorisms, who says that even that dream is mere illusion, it is admitted to be produced by impressions. From this it is understood that

original: yat na tasya svapno mṛṣābhimata iti /
analyzed: yat na tasya svapnaḥ mṛṣā abhimataḥ iti
translated: he does not consider that dream to be false.

analyzed: nahi kaścid a vidyamānasya kāraṇam nirūpayet
translated: For no one would posit a cause for what does not exist.

original: kiñca śrutyanusārī hi sūtrakārasya siddhāntaḥ syāt /
analyzed: kiñca śruti anusārī hi sūtrakārasya siddhāntaḥ syāt
translated: Moreover, the author of the aphorisms' established conclusion would be in accordance with the Veda.

original: śrutyā ca svāpnārthasya kartāraṃ vadantyā satyatvamevābhipretamiti na mṛṣātvaṃ sūtrakṛto 'bhimatamityāha sa hīti // /
analyzed: śrutyā ca svāpna arthasya kartāram vadantyā satya tvam eva abhipretam iti na mṛṣātvam sūtrakṛtaḥ bhimatam iti āha sa hi iti
translated: And the Veda, speaking of the creator of the dream object, intends only true existence, not falsity, as the author of the aphorisms' intention. He says that etc.

analyzed: sa hi kartā iti vākyāt ca
translated: And from the sentence He is the creator etc.

analyzed: nanu katham svapnaḥ na mṛṣā
translated: But how is the dream not false?

analyzed: māyā mātram
translated: Mere illusion.

original: iti sūtrakṛtaiva tanmithyātvasya vakṣyamāṇatvādityato vāha vāsaneti //
analyzed: iti sūtrakṛtā eva tad mithyātvasya vakṣyamāṇatvāt iti atas vā āha vāsanā iti
translated: Because the author of the aphorisms himself will declare its falsity. For this reason he says impressions etc.

analyzed: na māyā mātra padena svapnasya mṛṣātvam abhimatam
translated: The word mere illusion does not intend the falsity of the dream.

analyzed: kintu vāsanā janita tvam
translated: But it intends being produced by impressions.

analyzed: atas na mṛṣā iti arthaḥ
translated: Therefore the meaning is not false.

analyzed: yathā ca etat tathā upapādayiṣyate
translated: And how this is so will be explained.

original: tasyāgāminaḥ sūtrasya vāsanājanitatvapratipādakatvena asmābhiraṅgīkṛtatvāditi vā yojyam /
analyzed: tasya āgāminaḥ sūtrasya vāsanā janita tva pratipādaka tvena asmābhiḥ aṅgīkṛta tvāt iti vā yojyam
translated: Or it should be connected as follows: because we accept that it is a teaching that generates the impression of that future sutra.

original: na kevalaṃ vakṣyamāṇopapattivaśāt mṛṣātvaṃ na sūtrārthaḥ /
analyzed: na kevalam vakṣyamāṇa upapatti vaśāt mṛṣātvam na sūtra arthaḥ
translated: Not only is falsity not the meaning of the sutra due to the reason that will be stated,

analyzed: kintu śruti vaśāt ca iti āha sa hi iti
translated: but also due to the power of the scriptures. He says sa hi (he indeed).

analyzed: yat vā svāpna arthaḥ na tāvat anādi nityaḥ
translated: Or, the meaning of the dream is not beginningless and eternal.

analyzed: paścāt adṛṣṭayā ādi virodhāt
translated: Because it is not seen later on, etc., there is contradiction.

analyzed: na api sa ādi vināśī
translated: Nor is it beginningless and perishable.

analyzed: upādāna nimittayoḥ anirūpaṇāt
translated: Because the material cause and the instrumental cause are not determined.

analyzed: na ca prakāra antaram sambhavati
translated: And no other mode is possible.

analyzed: tat katham na mṛṣā iti atas āha vāsanā iti
translated: How then is it not false? Therefore he says vāsanā (impression).

analyzed: na upādāna abhāvaḥ iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The rest is not the absence of a material cause.

original: na mṛṣā' / iti pūrveṇa vā sambandhaḥ /
analyzed: na mṛṣā iti pūrveṇa vā sambandhaḥ
translated: Or the connection is with the previous not false.

analyzed: evam upādānam nirūpya nimittam upapādayati sahi iti
translated: Having thus determined the material cause, he explains the instrumental cause with sa hi (he indeed).

analyzed: nimittam ca īśvaraḥ jñāyate iti śeṣaḥ
translated: And the instrumental cause is known to be God. This is the rest.

original: na mṛṣā' / iti pūrveṇaiva vā anvayaḥ / /
analyzed: na mṛṣā iti pūrveṇa eva vā anvayaḥ
translated: Or the connection is with the previous not false itself.

analyzed: nanu katham tarhisvapnamāyāsa rūpā
translated: But how then is the dream like an illusion,

analyzed: ityādau svapnasya bhrānti tva uktiḥ iti atas āha jāgratvam iti
translated: etc.? Thus, how is the dream said to be an error? Therefore he says jāgrat-tvam (waking state).

analyzed: jāgrat tvam iti hi bhramaḥ
translated: The error is indeed jāgrat-tvam (waking state).

analyzed: iti śabdaḥ ādi arthe
translated: The word iti (thus) has the meaning of ādi (beginning).

analyzed: ullekha arthe vā
translated: Or in the sense of superimposition.

analyzed: jāgrat aham asmi iti draṣṭuḥ yat jāgrat tvam
translated: The state of being awake of the seer, who thinks 'I am awake',

analyzed: yat ca etat padārthānām jāgrat dṛśā dṛśā adṛṣṭa padārthaiḥ aikyam
translated: and the identity of the objects of the waking state with the objects seen or unseen by the waking state,

analyzed: bāhya mṛd ādi janya tvam vā
translated: or the fact of being produced from external clay etc.,

analyzed: evamādi pratibhāsaḥ bhramaḥ
translated: such appearance is an error.

analyzed: bādhya tvāt iti hi śabda arthaḥ
translated: The meaning of the word 'hi' is 'because it is to be refuted'.

analyzed: tad apekṣayā śruti ādi vacanāni iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the statements of the scriptures etc. are in relation to that.

analyzed: nanu ca rajjau sarpa bhrame
translated: But in the case of the error of a snake in a rope,

analyzed: asatyasya api sarpasya sarpa ucita bhaya kampa ādi arthakriyā kāri tvam dṛśyate
translated: the function of producing fear, trembling etc. appropriate to a snake is seen even in the non-existent snake.

original: tathā sarpe samāropitāyāḥ kusumamālāyāḥ santoṣakāritā upalabhyate /
analyzed: tathā sarpe samāropitāyāḥ kusuma mālāyāḥ santoṣa kāri tā upalabhyate
translated: Similarly, the satisfaction produced by the garland of flowers superimposed on the snake is perceived.

analyzed: atas vyāpti bhaṅgaḥ tarkasya iti atas āha sarpa iti
translated: Therefore, there is a contradiction of the logical argument. To this he says 'snake' etc.

analyzed: sarpa bhrama ādau api hi jñānam asti eva tādṛśam
translated: For even in the case of the error of a snake, there is indeed such a cognition.

analyzed: na bhūt atra sarpaḥ
translated: 'There is no snake here.'

analyzed: itivat na sarpa jñānam abhūt  iti bādhaka anudayāt
translated: Similarly, 'The cognition of a snake did not occur.'

analyzed: abhūt eva iti anuvṛtteḥ ca
translated: Because the refuting cognition does not arise.🔽And because of the occurrence of the cognition 'It did occur.'

analyzed: bhrama tvasya viṣaya vaiparītya mātreṇa upapatteḥ iti hi śabda arthaḥ
translated: The meaning of the word 'hi' is that the error is explained merely by the discrepancy between the object and the cognition.

analyzed: kim atas untataḥ yadi jñānam asti eva iti atas āha tat eva iti
translated: What then? If knowledge exists, then what? To this he says: That alone is the cause of effective action.

analyzed: tat eva arthakriyā kāri
translated: That alone is the cause of effective action.

analyzed: eva śabdena sarpa ādikam
translated: By the word alone, he excludes the snake and so on.

analyzed: sati api sarpa ādau asati ca jñāne
translated: Even when the snake exists and the knowledge does not exist,

analyzed: bhaya kampa ādi anutpatteḥ
translated: fear, trembling, and so on do not arise.

analyzed: sati ca tasmin
translated: But when that [knowledge] exists,

analyzed: tad utpatteḥ jñāna kāryam eva bhaya kampa ādikam na sarpa kāryam
translated: fear, trembling, and so on are the effect of knowledge, not the effect of the snake.

analyzed: tad kāryam tu abhisarpaṇa daṃśana ādikam
translated: But the effect of that [snake] is crawling, biting, and so on.

analyzed: maraṇam api dhātu vyākula tā nimittakam
translated: Death also is caused by the disturbance of the elements.

original: sā ca viṣadravyeṇeva bhayādināpi bhavatīti na bādhyasyasyāpi
analyzed: sā ca viṣa dravyeṇa iva bhaya ādinā api bhavati iti na
translated: And that occurs not only through poisonous substances, but also through fear and so on. Therefore, even for the negated snake,

analyzed: sarpa ādeḥ arthakriyā kāri tvam
translated: there is the quality of being the cause of effective action.

original: nanu kiṃ jñānamātraṃ bhayādijanakaṃ kiṃvā viṣayāvacchinnam /
analyzed: nanu kim jñāna mātram bhaya ādi janakam kiṃvā viṣaya avacchinnam
translated: But is it mere knowledge that produces fear and so on, or is it knowledge qualified by an object?

analyzed: na ādyaḥ
translated: Not the first.

analyzed: ghaṭa jñānasya api jñāna tvena tad āpatteḥ
translated: Because even the knowledge of a pot would result from that by being knowledge.

analyzed: dvitīye na tāvat viṣayaḥ rajju ādiḥ
translated: In the second case, first, the object such as a rope is not [the cause].

analyzed: rajjuḥ iyam ityādi jñānasya api bhaya ādi hetu tā āpātāt
translated: Because the knowledge this is a rope would also be the cause of fear and so on.

analyzed: sarpa ādiḥ ced viśeṣaṇatayā tasya api bhaya ādi hetu tvam prāptam
translated: And if it is a snake and so on, then its quality as a qualifier would also be accepted as the cause of fear and so on.

analyzed: atra kaścid āha
translated: To this someone says:

analyzed: na ayam doṣaḥ
translated: This is not a fault.

analyzed: jñāna vyāvartaka tayā upayuktasya sarpa ādeḥ viṣayasya jñāna janya arthakriyāyām apraveśāt
translated: Because the object that is useful for turning away knowledge, such as a snake, does not enter into the operation of the object produced by knowledge.

original: nahi kurūṇāṃ kṣetre vasati /🔽gurūṇāṃ ṭīkāṃ paṭhati ityādau viśeṣaṇasyāpi kārakatvamasti /
analyzed: nahi kurūṇām kṣetre vasati  gurūṇām ṭīkām paṭhati ityādau viśeṣaṇasya api kāraka tvam asti
translated: For he does not reside in the field of the Kurus.🔽In the statement he reads the commentary of the teachers, the qualifier also has the nature of an agent.

analyzed: kintu ati prasaktayoḥ kṣetraṭīkayoḥ vyāvṛtti mātreṇa caritārtha tvam iti
translated: But in the case of the field and the commentary, which are very common, the purpose is served merely by the exclusion.

analyzed: tat asat
translated: That is not correct.

analyzed: evam api bādhyasya sarpa ādeḥ vyāvartaka tvasya avaśya abhyupagamanīya tvāt
translated: Even so, because the excluded snake must necessarily be accepted as the turner away,🔽for being a turner away consists in producing the cognition of exclusion.

analyzed: tatra api jñāna abhyupagamena parihāre vyāvartaka upādānena prasaṅga tādavasthyam iti
translated: And in the answer by accepting knowledge there, the objection remains the same by accepting the turner away.

analyzed: tatra āha tādṛśam iti
translated: There he says such (knowledge).

analyzed: yādṛśam satya sarpa ullekhi jñānam
translated: The knowledge that indicates a real snake.

analyzed: tādṛśam iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is such.

analyzed: satya sarpa jñānam tāvat ghaṭa ādi jñānāt vayāvṛttam anubhūyate  vyāvṛttiḥ ca vyāvartaka dharma
translated: First, the knowledge of a real snake is experienced as excluded from the knowledge of a pot, etc.

analyzed: yoga kṛtā sarvatra upalabdhā
translated: And the exclusion is produced by the connection with the turner away. It is found everywhere.

analyzed: na ca viṣayaḥ vyāvartakaḥ
translated: And the object is not the turner away.

analyzed: tasya a tad dharma tvāt
translated: Because it is not that property.

analyzed: sambaddham hi vyāvartakam bhavati
translated: For what is related can be a distinguisher.

analyzed: anyathā atiprasaṅgāt
translated: Otherwise there would be an overextension.

analyzed: viṣaya sambandhaḥ astu iti ced na
translated: If it be said that the relation to the object may be the distinguisher, no (says the siddhāntin).

analyzed: tasya saṃyoga ādi rūpasya abhāvāt
translated: Because that relation, which is of the nature of conjunction, etc., does not exist.

analyzed: atas kaścid jñāna gataḥ eva dharmaḥ bhyupagantavyaḥ
translated: Therefore some property belonging to the cognition itself must be admitted.

original: kiñca vilakṣaṇasamāgrījanmanorjñānayoryathā parokṣatvāparokṣatvarūpo viśeṣaḥ viṣayopādhinā vinābhyupagamyate /
analyzed: kiñca vilakṣaṇa sama agrī janmanoḥ jñānayoḥ yathā parokṣa tva aparokṣa tva rūpaḥ viśeṣaḥ viṣaya upādhinā vinā abhyupagamyate
translated: Moreover, just as the difference in the form of being non-perceptual and being perceptual is admitted to belong to two cognitions arising from different causal conditions, without [the help of] an external object,

original: evamaparokṣajñāne 'pi kathaṃ svagato viśeṣo nāṅgīkaraṇīyaḥ /🔽api ca sarpajñānasya vilakṣaṇārthakriyā na svagatenātiśayena vinopapadyate / nahi
analyzed: evam aparokṣa jñāne pi katham svagataḥ viśeṣaḥ nā aṅgīkaraṇīyaḥ  api ca sarpa jñānasya vilakṣaṇā arthakriyā na svagatena atiśayena vinā upapadyate nahi
translated: in the same way, why should not a difference belonging to itself be accepted even in a non-perceptual cognition?🔽Moreover, the different practical efficiency of the cognition of a rope and the cognition of a snake cannot be explained without the help of a difference belonging to themselves. For

analyzed: devadatta sambandhi tā mātreṇa kalama bījam kalama bīja antara kārya vilakṣaṇam kāryam upajanayati
translated: a tamarind seed, merely by its connection with Devadatta, does not produce an effect different from the effect of another tamarind seed.

original: sa cāyaṃ viśeṣaḥ satyasarpajñāne samīcīnayā sāmagṣā jātaḥ /
analyzed: sa ca ayam viśeṣaḥ satya sarpa jñāne samīcīnayā sāmagṣā jātaḥ
translated: And this difference, when the cognition of a real snake arises, is produced by a perfect causal complex,

analyzed: mithyā sarpa jñāne tu asamīcīnayā iti na kaścid viśeṣaḥ
translated: while in the case of the false cognition of a snake it is produced by an imperfect causal complex. Thus there is no difference at all.

original: ato viṣayāntarbhāvamantareṇa svagatenaiva viśeṣeṇa sarpādijñānasya bhayādijanakatvānna sarpasya kiñcitkaratvamiti /
analyzed: atas viṣaya antarbhāvam antareṇa svagatena eva viśeṣeṇa sarpa ādi jñānasya bhaya ādi janaka tvāt na sarpasya kiñcitkaratvam iti
translated: Therefore, the knowledge of a snake, etc. generates fear, etc. by its own particularity, without being included in the object. So a snake does not do anything.

original: tadevaṃ yatrātharkriyā niścitā na tatra mithyātvam /
analyzed: tat evam yatra athar kriyā niścitā na tatra mithyātvam
translated: Thus, where the efficacy of an object is certain, there is no falsity.

original: yatra tu mithyātvaṃ na tatrārthakriyeti na tarkamūlavyāpteḥ kvāpi bhaṅgaḥ /
analyzed: yatra tu mithyātvam na tatra arthakriyā iti na tarka mūla vyāpteḥ kvāpi bhaṅgaḥ
translated: But where there is falsity, there is no efficacy of an object. So the pervasion based on reasoning is not contradicted anywhere.

analyzed: iti upasaṃharati tat iti
translated: Thus he concludes with that etc.

analyzed: tat sa deva artha kārakam
translated: That alone is the true cause of the effect of an object.

original: nanvarthakriyākāritvaṃ yathā vipakṣānmithyābhūtādvayāvṛttam evaṃ sapakṣādbrahmaṇo 'pi vyāvṛttatvādasādhāraṇam /
analyzed: nanu arthakriyā kāri tvam yathā vipakṣāt mithyābhūtāt vayāvṛttam evam sapakṣāt brahmaṇaḥ vyāvṛtta tvāt asādhāraṇam
translated: But just as the capacity to produce an effect is excluded from the dissimilar class, the false, so it is also excluded from the similar class, Brahman. Therefore it is not a property of the similar class.

analyzed: na ca jñānasya satyasya arthakriyā uktā iti vācyam
translated: And it cannot be said that knowledge, which is true, has an effect.

original: tasyāpi prapañcāntarbhāvena vipratipannatvādityata āha brahma tviti //
analyzed: tasya api prapañca antarbhāvena vipratipanna tvāt iti atas āha brahma tu iti
translated: Because that also is included in the world and is disputed. To this he says Brahman etc.

original: brahma tvarthakriyākāri parataḥ svata eva vā /
analyzed: brahma tu arthakriyā kāri paratas svatas eva vā
translated: Brahman is the cause of the effect of an object, either from another or by itself.

analyzed: aṅgīkṛtam hi tena eva
translated: For that itself has been accepted.

original: tena māyāvādinaiva brahma prapañcādapyatiśayenārthakriyākāryamaṅgīkṛtameva hi janmādisūtre jagatkāraṇatvenoktatvāt /
analyzed: tena māyā vādinā eva brahma prapañcāt api atiśayena arthakriyā kāryam aṅgīkṛtam eva hi janma ādi sūtre jagat kāraṇa tvena ukta tvāt
translated: Therefore, by the Māyāvādin himself, Brahman is admitted to be the cause of the world, as it is said in the aphorism beginning with birth, and so it is more than the mere manifestation of Brahman.

analyzed: atas sapakṣa praveśi tvāt na asādhāraṇyam mantavyam
translated: Therefore, it should not be considered as inconclusive, because it is included in the similar instance.

original: nanu mayāṅgīkriyamāṇaṃ brahmaṇo 'rthakriyākāritvaṃ ca na svābhāvikam /
analyzed: nanu mayā aṅgīkriyamāṇam brahmaṇaḥ rthakriyā kāri tvam ca na svābhāvikam
translated: But the causal efficiency of Brahman, which I admit, is not natural.

analyzed: kintu paratas eva
translated: But it is only from another.

analyzed: māyāyām
translated: It is brought about in Māyā by that.

analyzed: tatas iti aṅgīkārāt
translated: Because it is accepted that it is from that.

original: ataḥ kathamāpādakasya sapakṣapraveśa ityata āha parata iti //
analyzed: atas katham āpādakasya sapakṣa praveśaḥ iti atas āha paratas iti
translated: Therefore, how can the reasoner be included in the similar instance? To this he says from another.

analyzed: aṅgīkṛtam tāvat arthakriyā kāri tvam brahmaṇaḥ
translated: The causal efficiency of Brahman has been admitted.

analyzed: tat svatas paratas vā astu kim anena prakṛta anupayuktena
translated: Let it be from itself or from another, what is the use of this irrelevant matter?

analyzed: nahi svatas ṛthakriyā kāri tvam āpādaka tvena asmābhiḥ abhihitam
translated: For we have not stated the causal efficiency from itself as the reason,

original: pareṇa vā prastāvitam /🔽anyathā sāmānyataḥ prayuktasya dhūmāderviśeṣākāreṇa sapakṣāpraveśitayāsādhāraṇyaṇa
analyzed: pareṇa vā prastāvitam  anyathā sāmānyatas prayuktasya dhūma ādeḥ viśeṣa ākāreṇa sapakṣa apraveśi tayā asādhāraṇyaṇa
translated: nor has it been proposed by the opponent.

analyzed: sya vaktum śakya tvena tad bhaṅgaḥ syāt
translated: Otherwise, there would be a refutation of the reason, as it would be possible to say that smoke, which is used in general, is not included in the similar instance by its specific form, and so is inconclusive.

analyzed: syāt etat
translated: This may be said:

original: brahmaṇo'rthakriyākāritvaṃ parata ityasya nāyamarthaḥ dāruyantrasyeva parādhīnam iti /
analyzed: brahmaṇaḥ ṛthakriyā kāri tvam paratas iti asya na ayam arthaḥ dāruyantrasya iva para adhīnam iti
translated: The meaning of this is not that the causal efficiency of Brahman is dependent on another, like that of a wooden machine.

original: nāpi kulālasyeva prayojanādyapekṣamiti /🔽kintu gagane malinateva niṣkriyā eva brahmaṇi māyāsambandhādarthakriyādi
analyzed: na api kulālasya iva prayojana ādi apekṣam iti  kintu gagane malina tā iva niṣkriyā eva brahmaṇi māyā sambandhāt arthakriyā ādi
translated: Nor is it that it depends on a purpose, etc., like that of a potter.🔽But just as the impurity in the sky appears, so the causal efficiency, etc.,

original: avabhāsata iti /🔽na caivaṃvidhena sapakṣapraveśo bhavatyāpādakasyetyata āha paratastva iti /
analyzed: avabhāsate iti  na ca evaṃvidhena sapakṣa praveśaḥ bhavati āpādakasya iti atas āha paratastve iti
translated: appear in Brahman, which is really inactive, due to the connection with māyā.🔽And the reasoner does not enter into such a similar instance. Therefore he says paratva (dependence on another).

analyzed: paratas tve na ca pramā  brahmaṇaḥ ṛthakriyā kāri tvasya iti śeṣaḥ
translated: If there is dependence on another, there is no valid cognition.🔽The remainder is of Brahman's causal efficiency.
If there is dependence on another, if it is defined.

analyzed: pramā pramāṇam
translated: Valid cognition is a means of valid knowledge.

analyzed: ayam atra āśayaḥ
translated: This is the idea here.

analyzed: brahmaṇaḥ jagat nirmāṇa ādi arthakriyā pratītā na vā
translated: Is the causal efficiency of Brahman in the creation of the world, etc., known or not?

analyzed: na ced katham lakṣaṇa tvena ucyate
translated: If not, how can it be stated as a definition?

analyzed: kasya ca māyā maya tvam aṅgīkriyate
translated: And whose māyā-nature is accepted?

analyzed: pratīta tve pi na tāvat pratyakṣa anumānābhyām
translated: Even if it is known, it is not by perception or inference.

analyzed: tad agocara tvāt
translated: Because that is not its domain.

analyzed: atas śrutyā eva iti vaktavyam
translated: Therefore it must be said by scripture alone.

analyzed: tathā ca katham māyika tvam
translated: And how then is it māyā-like?

analyzed: tat kim śruti pratītam sarvam eva satyam
translated: Is everything known by scripture true?

analyzed: addhā
translated: Certainly.

analyzed: bādhaka abhāve tu tathā eva
translated: But in the absence of any sublating cognition, it is true.

original: nacaivaṃ brahmaṇo 'rthakriyāyāḥ paratastve pramāṇamasti yadbādhakaṃ bhavet /
analyzed: na ca evam brahmaṇaḥ rthakriyāyāḥ paratastve pramāṇam asti yat bādhakam bhavet
translated: And in this way, there is no means of knowledge regarding the extrinsic nature of the operation of Brahman, which could be sublated.

analyzed: bādhaka abhāva mātreṇa katham satya artha tvam iti ced
translated: If it is asked how truthfulness is established merely by the absence of sublating cognition,

analyzed: prāmāṇyasya svatas tvāt iti brūmaḥ
translated: we say that the validity of a means of knowledge is intrinsic.

original: paratastve ca prāmāṇyasyānavasthāpātena na pramā niścīyeta /
analyzed: paratas tve ca prāmāṇyasya anavasthā pātena na pramā niścīyeta
translated: And if the validity of a means of knowledge were extrinsic, there would be an infinite regress, and knowledge could not be ascertained.
It is said in the scriptures: It is peaceful, fruitless, and inactive.

analyzed: ityādi śrutayaḥ bādhikāḥ iti ced
translated: If it is argued that these scriptures are sublating,

original: evaṃ śrutibalena parastve 'rthakriyāyāḥ svīkṛte tadabhidhātrīsa idaṃ sarvamasṛjata' /
analyzed: evam śruti balena parastve ṛthakriyāyāḥ svīkṛte tad abhidhātrī idam sarvam asṛjata
translated: then, in this way, if the extrinsic nature of the operation is accepted on the strength of the scriptures, then scriptures like It created all this

analyzed: ityādi śrutiḥ na pramā syāt
translated: would not be valid knowledge.

analyzed: pratipādita artha mithyātva atiriktasya aprāmāṇyasya abhāvāt  kiñca aviśeṣāt niṣkalam niṣkriyam
translated: Because there is no invalidity except for the falsity of the meaning conveyed.🔽Moreover, how could it not be that the scripture It is partless and inactive

original: iti śrutiretacchativirodhātparatastve na prameti kiṃ na syāt /
analyzed: iti śrutiḥ etad śati virodhāt paratastve na pramā iti kim na syāt
translated: is not valid knowledge regarding the extrinsic nature of the operation, due to contradiction with the other scriptures?

analyzed: anyat uttaratra vakṣyāmaḥ iti
translated: We will explain something else later.

analyzed: nanu astu abādhyam eva arthakriyā kāri prapañcam api abādhyam aṅgīkaromi
translated: Well then, I accept the world, which performs operations, to be non-sublatable.

analyzed: ātyantika abādhya tva abhāve pi prāk brahma ātma aikya jñānāt abādhya tvāt
translated: Even in the absence of absolute non-sublation, it is not sublated before the knowledge of Brahman as the Self.

analyzed: atas tad antargatā śrutiḥ api amukhya satya tvāt sādhikā bhaviṣyati iti atas āha amukhyā iti
translated: Therefore, the Vedic text contained therein will also be valid because of its secondary truth. To this he says:

analyzed: amukhya satya mānasya sādhaka tve sadā āvayoḥ
translated: In the case of the validity of secondary truth, there is always disagreement between us.

original: na hi sampratipattiḥ syādatastiṣṭhatu sā pramā // / / //
analyzed: na hi sampratipattiḥ syāt atas tiṣṭhatu sā pramā
translated: There would be no agreement, therefore let that valid cognition remain.

analyzed: sadā iti anena
translated: By always

analyzed: prameyasya prāk eva upapādita tvam iti ācaṣṭe
translated: he points out that this subject matter has already been established earlier.

analyzed: tatas ca punarukti doṣaḥ parihṛtaḥ bhavati
translated: And thus the fault of repetition is avoided.

analyzed: tiṣṭhatu na vaktavyā iti yāvat
translated: Let it remain, it need not be stated - this is the meaning.

analyzed: sā pramā brahma jñāna bādhyam pramāṇam iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: that valid cognition is the means of knowledge that is to be sublated by the knowledge of Brahman.

analyzed: yasmāt sā śrutiḥ apramā tasmāt tiṣṭhatu iti vā
translated: Or, because that Vedic text is not a valid means of knowledge, therefore let it remain.

analyzed: prapañca mithyātvam hi tat atharḥ
translated: The meaning of that is the falsity of the world.

analyzed: na ca asau brahma svarūpam
translated: And that is not the nature of Brahman.

analyzed: sa upādhika tvāt
translated: Because it is qualified.

analyzed: bādhya tvam āvaśyakam  bādhya artham ca apramāṇam iti prasiddham eva
