translated: Therefore, its sublatability is necessary.🔽And it is well known that what has a sublatable meaning is not a valid means of knowledge.

analyzed: bādhya artha tve pi prāk brahma jñānāt abādhya artha tvena prāmāṇyam astu iti atas uktam amukhya iti
translated: Even if it has a sublatable meaning, let there be validity by having a non-sublatable meaning before the knowledge of Brahman. To this he says: secondary etc.

analyzed: satyam abādhya artham
translated: Truth is that whose object is not contradicted.

original: nahi kālavilambena bādhitārthaṃ pramāṇaṃ bhavatīti vakṣyāmaḥ /
analyzed: nahi kāla vilambena bādhita artham pramāṇam bhavati iti vakṣyāmaḥ
translated: For we shall say that an instrument of knowledge is not that whose object is contradicted by the delay of time.

analyzed: astu evam svarūpataḥ viṣayataḥ ca asatya tvāt sādhaka tvena vipratipannā śrutiḥ
translated: Let it be so. The Veda, which is disputed as to its being a means of valid knowledge, is not true either in its own nature or in its object.

original: tathāpi prapañcamithyātvasādhanāya tadupanyāsaḥ kuto na kāryaḥ ityata āha na hīti //
analyzed: tathā api prapañca mithyātva sādhanāya tad upanyāsaḥ kutas na kāryaḥ iti atas āha na hi iti
translated: Even so, why should not its statement be made for the purpose of proving the unreality of the world? To this he says: Not so, etc.

original: na hi vipratipannena śakyaṃ sādhayituṃ kvacit // / / //
analyzed: na hi vipratipannena śakyam sādhayitum kvacid
translated: For nothing can be established by what is disputed.

analyzed: tathātve svarūpa asiddha kāla atītayoḥ api upanyāsaḥ syāt
translated: If it were so, then even the [two fallacies called] svarūpāsiddha and kālātyaya would be stated.

analyzed: āropa mātrasya tatra api sulabha tvāt iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that mere superimposition is easily obtained even in those [two fallacies].

analyzed: syāt etat
translated: Let this be so.

analyzed: āstām iyam pramāṇa sat asat tva cintā
translated: Let this consideration of the existence or non-existence of a means of valid knowledge be set aside.

analyzed: pramāṇena eva prameya siddheḥ
translated: For the object to be known is established by a means of valid knowledge alone.

original: anyathā bhavatāmapi prapañcamithyātvanirākaraṇe tatsatyatvasādhane ca pramāṇābhāvena kathābhāvaprasaṅgāt /
analyzed: anyathā bhavatām api prapañca mithyātva nirākaraṇe tad satya tva sādhane ca pramāṇa abhāvena kathā bhāva prasaṅgāt
translated: Otherwise, even for you, when the unreality of the world is denied and its reality is established, there would be the undesirable consequence of the absence of discussion due to the absence of a means of valid knowledge.

analyzed: yuṣmābhiḥ upanyasyamānam pramāṇam satyam asatyam vā syāt
translated: The means of valid knowledge that you adduce would be either true or false.

original: na tāvatsatyaṃ māṃ prati vaktumucitam mayā satyasya sādhakatvānaṅgīkārāt /
analyzed: na tāvat satyam mām prati vaktum ucitam mayā satyasya sādhaka tva anaṅgīkārāt
translated: It cannot be true, for it is not proper for you to speak to me, because I do not accept the truth as a means of valid knowledge.

original: yatsatyaṃ na tatra kriyā'veśaḥ yatra ca kriyā'veśo na tatsatyamiti /
analyzed: yat satyam na tatra kriyā āveśaḥ yatra ca kriyā āveśaḥ na tat satyam iti
translated: What is true, there is no engagement of action; and where there is engagement of action, that is not true.

original: naca vācyaṃ sākṣiṇaḥ satyasya sādhakatvaṃ tvayāṅgīkṛtamiti /
analyzed: na ca vācyam sākṣiṇaḥ satyasya sādhaka tvam tvayā aṅgīkṛtam iti
translated: And it cannot be said that you accept the truth of the witness as a means of valid knowledge.

analyzed: kathaccit sukha ādau tasya śakya upanyāsa tve pi bāhya prapañce tad ayogāt
translated: Even if it can somehow be applied to pleasure etc., it is not appropriate for the external world.

analyzed: bāhya pramāṇa viṣayaḥ hi asau
translated: For it is the object of external means of valid knowledge.

analyzed: anyathā andha badhira ādi abhāva prasaṅgāt
translated: Otherwise, there would be the undesirable consequence of the non-existence of the blind, the deaf, etc.

analyzed: saḥ eva ca atra prakṛtaḥ iti
translated: And that alone is the subject here.

original: nāpyasatyaṃ bhavadbhiranaṅgīkṛtatvādityata āha sādhakatvamiti // /🔽sādhakatvaṃ tu satyasya sākṣiṇo hyāvayordvayoḥ /
analyzed: na api asatyam bhavadbhiḥ anaṅgīkṛta tvāt iti atas āha sādhaka tvam iti  sādhaka tvam tu satyasya sākṣiṇaḥ hi āvayoḥ dvayoḥ
translated: Nor is it false, because it is not accepted by you. Therefore he says: The means of valid knowledge is...

analyzed: samyak sampratipannam tat na bhavet
translated: The means of valid knowledge is indeed the truth of the witness, which is well-known to both of us. That would not be the view of the world's manifestation.

analyzed: satyasya tu iti sambandhaḥ
translated: The connection is: of the truth.

analyzed: samyak iti mukhyatas eva
translated: Well means primarily.

analyzed: na tu adhikaraṇa siddhānta tvena
translated: Not as the conclusion of the topic.

original: hiśabdaḥ / sarvaṃ vastu jñātatayājñātatayā vā sākṣicaitanyasya viṣaya evetyāditatprasiddhidyotakaḥ /
analyzed: hi śabdaḥ sarvam vastu jñāta tayā ajñāta tayā vā sākṣi caitanyasya viṣayaḥ eva ityādi tad prasiddhi dyotakaḥ
translated: The word indeed indicates the well-known fact that all things, whether known or unknown, are only the objects of the consciousness of the witness.

analyzed: tat iti avyayam
translated: The indeclinable tat (that).

analyzed: tena sākṣiṇā
translated: By that witness.

analyzed: viśva vivarta matam na bhavet
translated: The view of the world's manifestation would not be.

analyzed: nirākurmaḥ iti yāvat
translated: We refute it, that is, we deny it.

analyzed: upalakṣaṇam ca etat
translated: And this is an illustration.

original: viśvasya satyatāmapi tenaiva sādhayāma ityapi draṣṭavyam /
analyzed: viśvasya satya tām api tena eva sādhayāmaḥ iti api draṣṭavyam
translated: It should be seen that we also establish by that very [argument] the truth of the universe.

analyzed: tathā ca vakṣyate
translated: And that will be stated.

analyzed: na kā api pramāṇa prameya ādi vyavasthā mayā aṅgīkṛtā
translated: I do not accept any arrangement of means of valid knowledge, objects of valid knowledge, etc.

analyzed: kintu parakīya rītyā eva sarvam ucyate
translated: But everything is said according to the method of others.

original: tatkathaṃ kimapyanaṅgīkurvāṇaṃ māṃ prati sākṣiṇaḥ sādhakatvaṃ tvayāṅgīkṛtamityucyata ityata āha yadīti //
analyzed: tat katham kim api an aṅgīkurvāṇam mām prati sākṣiṇaḥ sādhaka tvam tvayā aṅgīkṛtam iti ucyate iti atas āha yadi iti
translated: Then how is it said that you accept the probative nature of the witnesses against me who accept nothing? To this he says if [verse 1].

analyzed: yadi nā aṅgīkṛtam kiñcid anaṅgīkṛtatā api hi
translated: If nothing is accepted, then even the state of being unaccepted

analyzed: na aṅgīkṛtā iti mūkaḥ syāt iti na asmad vivādi tā
translated: is not accepted, so one would be silent. Thus we are not disputing.

analyzed: na vidyate ṅgīkṛtam aṅgīkāraḥ yasya iti anaṅgīkṛtaḥ
translated: One who has no acceptance, no acceptance of anything, is one who does not accept.

analyzed: tasya bhāvaḥ na aṅgīkṛta tā
translated: The state of that is the state of not being accepted.

analyzed: anaṅgīkāri tvam iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is the state of not being accepted.

analyzed: iti śabda dvayam hetau
translated: The two words iti are reasons.

analyzed: yadi paraḥ brūyāt mayā kiñcid na aṅgīkṛtam iti
translated: If the opponent says I do not accept anything,

analyzed: tadā asau vaktavyaḥ
translated: then he should be told:

analyzed: sarvathā anaṅgīkṛta tvam ātmanaḥ tvayā aṅgīkṛtam na vā
translated: Do you accept in every way that you yourself are not accepted, or not?

original: ādye'pi kiñcidapi nāṅgīkṛtamiti pakṣahāneḥ ātmano 'naṅgīkartṛtāpi nāṅgīkṛteti dvitīya evāṅgīkaraṇīyaḥ /
analyzed: ādye api kiñcid api na aṅgīkṛtam iti pakṣa hāneḥ ātmanaḥ na aṅgīkartṛ tā api na aṅgīkṛtā iti dvitīyaḥ eva aṅgīkaraṇīyaḥ
translated: In the first case, since he does not accept anything, he loses his position. Therefore, he does not even accept the fact that he does not accept the self. Thus, the second alone should be accepted.

analyzed: tathāca asau mūkaḥ syāt
translated: And in that case, he would be dumb.

analyzed: aṅgīkāra anaṅgīkāra udāsīnasya mṛtakasya iva vākya pravṛtteḥ ayukta tvāt
translated: Because it is not proper for one who is indifferent to acceptance and rejection, like a dead person, to engage in speech.

analyzed: tathā ca maunam avalambamānasya na asmad prativādi tā iti kim atra vaktavyam
translated: And thus, what can be said here about one who relies on silence and is not our opponent?

analyzed: satyam etat
translated: This is true.

original: vastutastu vayaṃ sarvato nivṛttāḥ svataḥ siddhe cidātmani brahmatatve kevale bhāramavalambya caritārthāḥ sukhamāsmahe /
analyzed: vastutas tu vayam sarvatas nivṛttāḥ svatas siddhe cit ātmani kevale bhāram avalambya caritārthāḥ sukham āsmahe
translated: But in reality, we are completely detached, content with the sole burden of the self-evident truth of Brahman, the pure consciousness-self, and live happily.

original: ye tu svaparikalpitasādhanadūṣaṇādivyavasthayā vicāramavatārya tattvaṃ nirṇetumicchanti tānprati brūmo na sādhvīyaṃ bhavatāṃ vicāravyavastheti
analyzed: ye tu sva parikalpita sādhana dūṣaṇa ādi vyavasthayā vicāram avatārya tattvam nirṇetum icchanti tān prati brūmaḥ na sādhvī iyam bhavatām vicāra vyavasthā iti
translated: But for those who, by establishing means of knowledge and objects of knowledge imagined by themselves, wish to enter into inquiry and determine the truth, we say that this inquiry and establishment of yours is not proper.

analyzed: mā evam
translated: No, it is not so.

analyzed: evam api parakīya vicāra vyavasthiteḥ asādhu tvasya avaśyam aṅgīkaraṇīya tvāt
translated: Even so, the fact that the inquiry and establishment of others is improper must be necessarily accepted.

analyzed: anyathā tad vyutpādanam vyartham syāt
translated: Otherwise, the teaching of that would be pointless.

analyzed: atha tanmātram aṅgīkṛtya pramāṇa ādi vyavasthā na aṅgīkṛtā iti manyase
translated: Now, if you think that you accept only the existence of the pramāṇas and so on, but do not accept their establishment,

analyzed: tat na
translated: that is not so.

analyzed: pramāṇa ādinā vinā para vyavasthāyāḥ asādhu tvasya vyutpādayitum aśakya tvāt
translated: Because without the pramāṇas and so on, it is impossible to teach the invalidity of the establishment of others.

original: bhavatkalpitavyavasthaiva vyāhatatvādasādhvī bhavadvayavastheti brūmo na punaratra kimapi pramāṇamaṅgīkurma iti cenna /
analyzed: bhavat kalpita vyavasthā eva vyāhata tvāt asādhvī bhavat vayavasthā iti brūmaḥ na punar atra kim api pramāṇam aṅgīkurmaḥ iti ced na
translated: If you say that we say that your own establishment is invalid because it is contradictory, and we do not accept anything as a pramāṇa here, that is not so.

analyzed: yat sva abhyupagata vyavasthā viruddham tat asādhu iti asya api pramāṇasya aṅgīkartavya tvāt
translated: Because even the pramāṇa that says what is contradictory to one's own accepted establishment is invalid must be accepted.

analyzed: etat api pareṇa abhyupagatam eva āśrīyate iti ced na
translated: If you say that this is accepted only by the other party, that is not so.

original: kiṃ parakīyavyavasthāyā asādhutvasvayamavabuddhaya paraṃ prati bodhyate 'navabuddhayaiva vā /
analyzed: kim parakīya vyavasthāyāḥ asādhu tva svayam avabuddhayā param prati bodhyate nava buddhayā eva vā
translated: Does one understand oneself the invalidity of the other's establishment and teach it to others, or does one teach it without understanding it oneself?

analyzed: dvitīye vipralambhaka tvam syāt
translated: In the second case, it would be deception.

analyzed: vijigīṣu kathāyām evam eveta ced na
translated: If you say that it is so only in the case of a debate between two disputants, that is not so.

analyzed: śiṣyasya api
translated: Because the disciple also needs to understand.

analyzed: ādye smāt anyasmāt vā pramāṇāt svayam boddhavyam
translated: In the first case, one should understand it oneself from this or that pramāṇa.

analyzed: tat katham pramāṇa ādi anaṅgīkartṛ tvam
translated: How then can one not accept the pramāṇas and so on?

analyzed: tasmāt
translated: Because the means of valid knowledge, etc. are accepted only as the cause of valid knowledge, etc.

analyzed: abhyupagama udāsīnaiḥ pramāṇa ādikam aṅgīkṛtya ucyate iti vaktavyam
translated: Therefore, it must be said that those who are indifferent to the acceptance of existence, non-existence, truth, and untruth, speak after accepting the means of valid knowledge, etc.

original: tacca prāgeva nirastamiti / /🔽evaṃ viśvasya brahmavivartatvaṃ nirākṛtya tatsattā
analyzed: tat ca prāk eva nirastam iti  evam viśvasya brahma vivarta tvam nirākṛtya tad sattā
translated: And that has already been refuted earlier.🔽Thus, having refuted the universe being a manifestation of Brahman, he states the means of valid knowledge for the truth of its existence

analyzed: tya tāyām pramāṇam āha viśvam iti
translated: and non-existence in the verse beginning with viśvam.

analyzed: viśvam satyam yat ciketa praghā anvasya yathārthataḥ
translated: The universe is true, which he who knows truly the beginning of this,

analyzed: ityādi śrutayaḥ sarvāḥ viśva satya tva vācakāḥ  yathārthataḥ iti anena kaviḥ manīṣī
translated: all these scriptures beginning with this declare the truth of the universe.

analyzed: iti śrutim upādatte
translated: By truly he quotes the scripture the wise one.

analyzed: vyāvahārika satyatā parāḥ śrutayaḥ iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that the scriptures are meant for conventional truth, it is not so.

original: tatsatyam' / ityasyā api tathātvaprasaṅgāt /🔽śrutyantaravirodhāditi cedatrāpiasadevedam' /🔽iti śrutivirodhāt /
analyzed: tat satyam iti asyāḥ api tathātva prasaṅgāt  śruti antara virodhāt iti ced atra api asat eva idam  iti śruti virodhāt
translated: Because this would lead to the same for that is true also.🔽If it is argued that it is due to contradiction with another scripture, here also there is contradiction with the scripture this is indeed false.

analyzed: a puruṣa artha tvāt na prapañca satya tāyām tātparyam iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that the truth of the universe is not the purport due to being not for human goals, it is not so.

analyzed: niṣprapañca ātma jñāna sādhya advitīya tā āpattiḥ upapuruṣa artha viruddham prapañca satya tvam iti
translated: Because the knowledge of the supreme greatness of the Lord, such as His being the true creator of the world, is itself the means and purpose of human goals.

analyzed: ced tarhi brahma satya tvam api śūnya paribhāvanā labhya śūnyatā āpatti lakṣaṇa mokṣa viruddham iti samānam
translated: If it is argued that the truth of the world is opposed to the attainment of non-duality, which is to be accomplished by the knowledge of the non-dual Self free from conceptual elaborations, then the same applies to the truth of Brahman, as it is opposed to liberation, which consists in the attainment of emptiness characterized by the realization of emptiness obtained through the contemplation of emptiness.

analyzed: tat pramāṇa ananuguṇam iti ced
translated: If it is argued that this [truth of Brahman] is not in accordance with valid means of knowledge,

analyzed: samam etat api iti vakṣyāmaḥ
translated: we will say that this is the same [for the truth of the world].

analyzed: anumānam api prapañca satya tāyām athar kriyā kāri tvam draṣṭavyam
translated: Inference should also be seen as establishing the truth of the world by the performance of effective action.

original: prāguktatarkopapādanenaiva asyopapāditvāditi / /🔽evamāgamānumānābhyāṃ siddhe viśvasatyatve pratyakṣamapyāha satyatvamiti //
analyzed: prāc ukta tarka upapādanena eva asya upapādi tvāt iti  evam āgama anumānābhyām siddhe viśva satya tve pratyakṣam api āha satya tvam iti
translated: Because this has been established by the same reasoning stated earlier.

analyzed: satya tvam gagana ādeḥ ca sākṣi pratyakṣa sādhitam
translated: Thus, when the truth of the universe is established by scripture and inference, perception also establishes it. He says that the truth of space and so on is established by the perception of the witness.

analyzed: caśabdaḥ pramāṇa samuccaye
translated: The word and is for the inclusion of the means of knowledge.

original: na kevalamāntarasya sukhādeḥ kintu bāhyasya gaganādeśceti vā /
analyzed: na kevalam āntarasya sukha ādeḥ kintu bāhyasya gagana ādeḥ ca iti vā
translated: Not only of internal pleasure etc., but also of external space etc.

analyzed: tatra api kāla gagana diś ādayaḥ sākṣāt sākṣi siddha satya tvāḥ
translated: Among them, time, space, direction etc. are directly established as true by the witness.

analyzed: stambha kumbha ādayaḥ tu vakṣyamāṇena prakāreṇa iti jñāpayitum gagana ādeḥ iti uktam
translated: But the pillar, the jar, etc., are to be explained by the method to be stated. In order to make this known, it is said 'of the sky, etc.'

analyzed: anyathā viśvasya prakṛta tvāt tat eva atra anuvartiṣyate kim anena
translated: Otherwise, since the universe is the subject, that alone will continue here. What is the use of this?

original: sākṣītyevokte sākṣiṇo 'prāmāṇyāt prāmāṇye vā pramāṇatritvabhaṅgāt na viśvasatyatvaṃ pramitamiti śaṅkā syāt /
analyzed: sākṣī iti eva ukte sākṣiṇaḥ prāmāṇyāt prāmāṇye vā pramāṇa tri tva bhaṅgāt na viśva satya tvam pramitam iti śaṅkā syāt
translated: If it is said 'witness' alone, then there would be the doubt that the truth of the universe is not known because the witness is not a means of valid knowledge or because if it is a means of valid knowledge, the three means of valid knowledge are broken.

analyzed: tad nivṛtti artham pratyakṣa iti uktam
translated: In order to remove that doubt, it is said 'perception'.

original: tathāca vakṣyate /🔽pratyakṣetyevokte atīndriyārthasatyatāyāṃ na pramāṇamuktaṃ syāt /
analyzed: tathā ca vakṣyate  pratyakṣa iti eva ukte atīndriya artha satya tāyām na pramāṇam uktam syāt
translated: And it will be stated thus.🔽If it is said 'perception' alone, then it would not be stated that there is a means of valid knowledge for the truth of the supersensible object.

original: naca sākṣirā vinā bāhyapratyakṣamātreṇaindriyakāṇāmapi satyatā siddhayatītyataḥ sākṣītyuktam /
analyzed: na ca sākṣi rāḥ vinā bāhya pratyakṣa mātreṇa aindriyakāṇām api satyatā siddhayati iti atas sākṣī iti uktam
translated: And the truth of the sensible objects is not established by mere external perception without the witness. Therefore, it is said 'witness'.

analyzed: ubhaya vādi siddham pramāṇam asmad pakṣe sti iti uktena eva asya arthasya labdha tvāt sādhitam iti āha
translated: By the statement that there is a means of valid knowledge established by both parties in our view, this meaning is obtained by the statement itself. Therefore, it is said 'accomplished'.

original: tathāpi tadupapādanāya punurupanyāsaḥ / /🔽kecidiha vihaṅgamaḥ patatīti cakṣurvyāpārānantaraṃ pratibhāsanādākāśādeḥdīnāṃ
analyzed: tathā api tad upapādanāya punar upanyāsaḥ  kecid iha vihaṅgamaḥ patati iti cakṣuḥ vyāpāra anantaram pratibhāsanāt ākāśa ādeḥ
translated: Nevertheless, the restatement is for the purpose of explaining that.🔽Some, because of the appearance of the sky, etc., after the operation of the eye, in the statement 'a bird flies here',

analyzed: cākṣuṣa tām āsthiṣata
translated: have accepted the state of being perceived by the eye of the sky, etc.

analyzed: tat anupapannam
translated: That is not correct.

analyzed: rūpa rahita dravya tvena cākṣuṣa tā sāmagrī vaikalyāt
translated: Because it lacks form, it is not a substance, and it lacks the completeness of the conditions for being perceptible.

analyzed: anyathā ātma pavanayoḥ api tad prasaṅgāt
translated: Otherwise, it would follow that the self and the wind also have that [perception].

analyzed: katham tarhi eṣa pratibhāsaḥ iti ced
translated: If it is asked how then this appearance [of space] is,

analyzed: sākṣi siddha ākāśa ādi sambandhi tayā iti brūmaḥ
translated: we say it is by the relation to space etc. established by the witness [consciousness].

analyzed: dṛṣṭaḥ hi pramāṇa antara upanītena api surabhi candanam ityādi viśiṣṭa pratyayaḥ
translated: For an object qualified by something presented by another means of knowledge, such as 'fragrant sandalwood', is seen.

original: pareṣāṃ ca iha bhūtale ghaṭābhāva iti / /
analyzed: pareṣām ca iha bhū tale ghaṭa abhāvaḥ iti
translated: And for others, 'the absence of a pot here on the ground'.

analyzed: aparaḥ āha
translated: Another says:

analyzed: āloka maṇḍalam āśritya ayam pratyayaḥ iti
translated: This cognition is based on the circle of light.

analyzed: tat asat
translated: That is not correct.

analyzed: iha ālokaḥ iti api pratyaya darśanāt
translated: Because the cognition here is light is also seen.

analyzed: tad avayān āśritya iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that that [light] is also based on the parts of that [space], that is not so.

analyzed: laukikānām avayava āśraya tayā avayavi buddheḥ abhāvāt
translated: Because worldly people do not conceive of wholes as based on their parts.

analyzed: nahi te hasta ādiṣu śarīram iti vyavaharanti
translated: For they do not use the expression the body in the hands etc.

analyzed: kintu tad ātmaka tayā eva
translated: But rather as identical with that [whole].

original: kiñcaivamapi nehāloka itīhālokatryaṇukamiti ca pratyayo duḥsampādaḥ /
analyzed: kiñca evam api na ihālokaḥ iti iha āloka tryaṇukam iti ca pratyayaḥ duḥsampādaḥ
translated: Moreover, even so, the cognition here is not light and here is the triadic atom of light is difficult to accomplish.

analyzed: pramāṇa anta upanīta avayavam āśritya iti ced
translated: If it is argued that it is based on the parts presented by another means of knowledge,

analyzed: evam tarhi tathābhūtam ākāśa ādikam eva āśritya eha pakṣī
translated: then in that case, it is based on just that space etc. of that nature, and this [cognition] is [based] on that side [of the space etc.].

analyzed: ityādi pratyayaḥ kutas na samarthanīyaḥ
translated: Why is this kind of condition not accepted?

analyzed: tathā ca laukika anubhavaḥ pi anusṛtaḥ syāt
translated: And thus worldly experience would also be followed.

analyzed: tathā api anumāna vedyam ākāśam astu iti ced na
translated: Even so, let space be known through inference. No.

analyzed: liṅga abhāvāt
translated: Because there is no logical ground.

analyzed: atha matam
translated: Now, if it is thought:

analyzed: śabdaḥ tāvat pratyakṣa siddhaḥ
translated: Sound is indeed established by perception.

analyzed: sa ca guṇaḥ sāmānyavat tve sati asmāt ādi bāhya eka indriya grāhya tvāt rūpa vat iti
translated: And it is a quality, because it has a universal, and is perceptible by one external sense organ like this, like color.

analyzed: guṇa tvāt dravya āśritaḥ tadvat eva
translated: Because it is a quality, it inheres in a substance, just like that.

analyzed: iti sāmānyatas dravya siddheḥ dravya siddhau
translated: Thus, the substance is established in general. When the substance is established,

analyzed: dravye siddhe
translated: when the substance is established,

analyzed: śabdaḥ na sparśavat viśeṣa guṇaḥ pratyakṣa tve satya kāraṇa guṇa pūrvaka tvāt
translated: sound is not a specific quality with touch, because it is perceptible and preceded by the quality of its cause.

analyzed: a yāvat dravya bhāvi tvāt
translated: Because it does not exist as long as the substance does,

analyzed: sukha ādi vat
translated: like pleasure and so on.

analyzed: sparśavat viśeṣa guṇa
translated: In being a specific quality with touch,

analyzed: tve tad anupalambha prasaṅgaḥ
translated: its non-apprehension would follow.

original: śabdo hi śrotreṇa prāpto vā gṛhyate 'prāpto vā /
analyzed: śabdaḥ hi śrotreṇa prāptaḥ vā gṛhyate prāptaḥ vā
translated: For sound is either apprehended when it reaches the ear or when it does not reach it.

analyzed: aprāpta grahaṇe ti prasaṅgaḥ  prāptiḥ tu śabda śravasoḥ na sambhavati
translated: If it is apprehended without reaching it, there would be an overextension.🔽But the reaching of the sound and the hearing of it is not possible.

original: sā hi na tāvacchrotrasya gamanena sambhavati /
analyzed: sā hi na tāvat śrotrasya gamanena sambhavati
translated: For that is not possible by the ear going to it,

analyzed: gati abhāteḥ asambhavāt
translated: because there is no motion in what is incorporeal.

analyzed: na api śabdasya āgamanena
translated: Nor is it by the movement of the sound.

analyzed: sa hi na tāvat śaṅkha ādikam āśrayam parityajya āgantum alam
translated: For that [sound] is not able to abandon its support such as a conch and come [to the ear].

analyzed: guṇa tvāt
translated: Because it is a quality.

analyzed: na api śaṅkha ādi āgamanena śrotrasya  pratyāsattiḥ
translated: Nor is there proximity of the ear by the movement of the conch, etc.

analyzed: tad anupalambhāt
translated: Because that [movement] is not perceived.

analyzed: na ca śabda antara utpāda paramparayā
translated: Nor by the production of another sound in a series.

analyzed: guṇasya sva āśraye sva āśraya āśrite vā guṇe samavāyikāraṇa tvāt
translated: Because a quality cannot be an inherent cause of another quality in its own substratum or in the substratum of its substratum.

original: naca śaṅkhaśravasormadhye śaṅkho vā tadārabdhadravyaṃ vāsti /🔽tasmācchaṅkhādinimittānyapahāyāśrayāntare vartamāno vīcītaraṅganyāyena karṇaśaṣkulīga
analyzed: na ca śaṅkha śravasoḥ madhye śaṅkhaḥ vā tad ārabdha dravyam vā asti  tasmāt śaṅkha ādi nimittāni apahāya āśraya antare vartamānaḥ vīcī taraṅga nyāyena karṇa śaṣkulīga
translated: And there is no conch or substance produced from it between the conch and the ear.

analyzed: mantam ākāśa deśam āpannaḥ upalabhyate na anyathā iti sthitam
translated: Therefore, it is established that [the sound] is perceived as existing in another substratum, abandoning the causes such as the conch, in the manner of waves, reaching the space in the cavity of the ear, and not otherwise.

analyzed: na api ātma guṇaḥ
translated: Nor is it a quality of the self.

analyzed: bāhya indriya pratyakṣa tvāt ātma antara grāhya tvāt ātmani asamavāyāt ahaṅkāreṇa vibhaktasya grahaṇāt ūpa ādi vat
translated: Because it is perceived by an external sense organ, because it is grasped by another self, because it is not inherently related to the self, and because it is grasped as distinct from the ego like a pot, etc.

analyzed: na viś kāla manasām guṇaḥ
translated: It is not a quality of the mind of one who is not in a state of meditation.

analyzed: pratyakṣa tvāt viśeṣa guṇa tvāt ca
translated: Because it is perceptible and because it is a specific quality.

analyzed: iti prasakta pratiṣedhe pariśeṣāt ebhyaḥ tiriktam dravyam
translated: Thus, by the exclusion of what is connected and prohibited, it is established by the remainder that there is a substance other than those [earth, etc.].

analyzed: tat ākāśam iti
translated: Then it is space.

analyzed: tat ayam pramāṇa arthaḥ
translated: This is the meaning of the proof.

analyzed: śabdaḥ u sya dravya atirikta dravya āśritaḥ
translated: Sound also is dependent on a substance other than the elements.

analyzed: tad vṛttau bādhaka upapanna tve sati guṇa tvāt rūpa tvāt iti  tat idam ayuktam jāti badhirāṇām ākāśa śādi
translated: Because it is a quality, like color, when it is established that it exists in that [space] and there is no contradiction.

analyzed: pratibhāsa anupapatti prasaṅgāt
translated: This is not correct, because it would lead to the absurdity that the blind and deaf would not perceive space, etc.

analyzed: tatas ca iha ālokaḥ na asti iti pratītiḥ na syāt
translated: And from that, the cognition there is no light here would not occur.

analyzed: mūrta avakāśena teṣām ākāśa anumānam iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that they infer space from the space occupied by the material [objects], that is not so.

analyzed: mūrta antara abhāvena anyathā asiddha tvāt
translated: Because it is established otherwise by the absence of another material [object].

analyzed: marta abhāvasya adhikaraṇena bhāvyam iti ced
translated: If it is argued that the absence of material [objects] must have a substratum,

analyzed: satyam
translated: that is true.

analyzed: tathā api tasya apratītau āśraya asiddheḥ
translated: Nevertheless, when that [substratum] is not cognized, the basis is not established.

analyzed: pratītau ca sādhikaraṇasya eva pratīta tvāt anumāna anavakāśaḥ
translated: And when it is cognized, since that with a substratum is itself cognized, there is no scope for inference.

original: kiñca śabdo varṇātmā vā pakṣo dhvanirūpo vā /
analyzed: kiñca śabdaḥ varṇa ātmā vā pakṣaḥ dhvani rūpaḥ vā
translated: Moreover, is sound the subject, having the nature of a letter, or having the nature of a sound?

analyzed: na ādyaḥ
translated: Not the first.

analyzed: tasya guṇa tva asiddheḥ
translated: Because its being a quality is not established.

analyzed: na ca ukta anumānāt tad siddhiḥ
translated: And its establishment is not by the stated inference.

original: ghaṭādīnāmekendriyagrāhyatvābhāve 'pi ātmanastathātvavad dravyasyaiva sato bāhyaikendriyagrāhyatve 'pi virodhābhāvāt /
analyzed: ghaṭa ādīnām eka indriya grāhya tva abhāve pi ātmanaḥ tathātva vat dravyasya eva sataḥ bāhya eka indriya grāhya tve pi virodha abhāvāt
translated: Even though pots, etc. are not perceptible by a single sense, like the self, there is no contradiction in the existence of a substance that is perceptible by a single external sense.

original: yadi śabdo dravyaṃ syāt bāhyendriyagrāhyo na syāt /
analyzed: yadi śabdaḥ dravyam syāt bāhya indriya grāhyaḥ na syāt
translated: If sound were a substance, it would not be perceptible by the external sense organs.

analyzed: niravayava dravyasya bāhya indriya agrāhya tvena pratibandhāt iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that this is because a non-composite substance cannot be perceived by the external sense organs, it is not so.

analyzed: niravayavasya api indriya grāhya tva vat bāhya indriya grāhya tve pi
translated: Even if sound is perceptible by the external sense organs, like a non-composite substance,

analyzed: bādhaka abhāvena pratibandha aniścayāt
translated: there is no contradiction, and so the relation cannot be ascertained.

analyzed: dvitīye tu āśraya dravya siddhau api na ākāśa siddhiḥ
translated: In the second case, even if the substance that is its substratum is established, space is not established.

analyzed: pṛthivī ādi guṇa tva upapatteḥ
translated: Because it can be explained as a quality of earth and so on.

analyzed: pratyakṣa tve satya kāraṇa guṇa pūrvakatva ayāvaddravyabhāvitvayoḥ piṭhara pāka pakṣe tad gata rūpa ādinā vyabhicārāt
translated: If it is argued that it is because it is perceptible, it must be preceded by a quality that is not a cause, and must exist as long as the substance exists, then there is an invalidation by the color etc. in the case of the cooking of the pot.

analyzed: pratyakṣa tve sati iti ca kimartham vaktavyam
translated: If it is argued that the phrase being perceptible should be stated,

analyzed: pārthiva paramāṇu rūpa ādi vyāvṛttya  parihāra artham iti ced
translated: in order to avoid the exclusion of the color etc. of the earth atom,

analyzed: kutas tat pariharaṇīyam
translated: then why should that be avoided?

analyzed: pramita tvāt iti ced
translated: If it is argued that it is because it is known,

original: tarhi śabdasyāpi śaṅkhādyāśrayatayā pramitatvādvayāptigrahaṇasamaye tadvayavacchedārthaṃ api
analyzed: tarhi śabdasya api śaṅkha ādi āśraya tayā pramita tvāt vayāpti grahaṇa samaye tad vayavaccheda artham api
translated: then even in the case of sound, because it is known as the substratum of the conch etc., the distinguishing qualifier should be used even at the time of grasping the pervasion,

analyzed: viśeṣaṇam upādeyam eva
translated: in order to exclude that.

analyzed: na ca sparśavat viśeṣa guṇa tve bādhakam paśyāmaḥ
translated: And we do not see any invalidation in the quality of being a special quality that possesses touch.

analyzed: anupalabdhiḥ tu na prasajyate
translated: But non-apprehension does not arise.

analyzed: cakṣuṣaḥ iva śrotrasya gatyā sannikarṣa upapatteḥ
translated: Because proximity is possible for the ear, like for the eye, through movement.

analyzed: amūrtasya tad anupapattiḥ tu ākāśa siddhayuttara kālīnā eva
translated: But the impossibility of that for the incorporeal is only after the establishment of space.

original: śrotrasya cakṣuṣa iva gatvāgrāhitve śabde diksaṃśayo na syāditi cet /
analyzed: śrotrasya cakṣuṣaḥ iva gatvā agrāhi tve śabde diś saṃśayaḥ na syāt iti ced
translated: If the ear, like the eye, does not grasp by going, there would be no doubt about the direction of sound.

analyzed: a ga tva a grāhi tve diś niścayaḥ na syāt
translated: Even the ascertainment of direction would not be possible if there were no going.

analyzed: saṃśayāt api niścayaḥ mahīyān garīyān
translated: Ascertainment is greater and weightier than doubt.

analyzed: śaṅkha ādi avayava āgamanena vā sannikarṣa upapattiḥ
translated: Or proximity is possible through the coming of the parts of the conch, etc.

analyzed: na ca ukta doṣaḥ  ghrāṇa gandha sannikarṣa tulya yogakṣema tvāt
translated: And there is no fault stated.🔽Because it is equal in safety with the proximity of smell to the nose.

analyzed: kiñca vāyu guṇa tve hetu dvayam asiddham
translated: Moreover, in the case of sound being a quality of air, the two reasons are unestablished.

analyzed: tarkaḥ ca anupapannaḥ
translated: And the reasoning is unestablished.

analyzed: na evam yuktam
translated: This is not proper.

analyzed: śrotrasya praatiniyata artha grāhaka tvena bahis indriya tvāt
translated: Because the ear, being an external sense organ that grasps objects with specific characteristics,
is necessarily a quality of the same kind as the object grasped, as it is for an external sense organ.

analyzed: śabdasya vāyavīya tve śrotrasya api tathātva prasaṅgāt iti ced na
translated: If sound were of air, it would follow that the ear would also be so. This is not so.
It is not so.🔽The ear is not a quality of the object grasped.

analyzed: śabdasya indriya antara a grāhya grāhaka artha tve manasi vyabhicārāt  indriya antara a grāhyasya eva grāhakam iti abhiprāye sattā ādi grāhaka tvena asiddhiḥ
translated: Because there is deviation in the mind when sound is the object of another sense organ.🔽If the intention is that it is the apprehender of only what is not apprehended by another sense organ, then it is not established because it apprehends existence and so on.

analyzed: bahis indriya tve pi na grāhya sajātīya viśeṣa guṇavat tva niyamaḥ
translated: Even when it is an external sense organ, there is no restriction that it must have a specific quality that is of the same kind as the object.

analyzed: sneha grāhake cakṣuṣi vyabhicārāt
translated: Because there is deviation in the eye that apprehends oil.

analyzed: śrotrasya vāyavīya tve pi na bādhakam paśyāmaḥ
translated: Even though the ear is made of air, we do not see any contradiction.

analyzed: sāmagrī bhedena pratiniyata artha tva upapatteḥ
translated: Because it is possible to have a specific object due to the difference in the collection of causes.

analyzed: ghrāṇa ādīnām api evam eka prakṛti tvam syāt iti ced
translated: If it is argued that in this way, the nose and other sense organs would also have the same origin,

analyzed: astu
translated: let it be so.

analyzed: bādhaka sadbhāve tu tatas evā anyā gatiḥ bhaviṣyati
translated: But if there is an obstructing factor, then another solution will be found from that itself.

original: śabdo na vāyavīyaḥ viśeṣaguṇatve sati tvagindriyāvedyatvādgandhavaditi cenna /
analyzed: śabdaḥ na vāyavīyaḥ viśeṣa guṇa tve sati tvac indriya avedya tvāt gandha vat iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that sound is not made of air because it is a specific quality and is cognized by the skin sense organ, like smell, that is not so.

analyzed: vipakṣe bādhaka abhāvāt
translated: Because there is no obstructing factor in the opposite case.

analyzed: anyathā pāka ja rūpa ādayaḥ pi na pārthivāḥ
translated: Otherwise, it could be argued that the colors produced by cooking are not of earth,

analyzed: ghrāṇa avedya tvāt śabda vat iti iti api syāt
translated: because they are cognized by the nose, like sound.

analyzed: kiñca ātma guṇaḥ kasmāt na syāt
translated: Moreover, why should it not be a quality of the self?

analyzed: dharma ādīnām apratyakṣa tve pi sukha ādīnām pratyakṣa tva vat asya bāhya indriya pratyakṣa tva upapatteḥ
translated: Even though dharma etc. are not perceptible, like the perceptibility of pleasure etc., its perceptibility by the external sense organs is logically possible.

analyzed: anyathā na syāt
translated: Otherwise, the bitter taste that transcends the eight substances would not be perceptible.

analyzed: tad siddhau bādhaḥ
translated: If that is established, there is contradiction.

analyzed: asiddhau aprasiddha viśeṣaṇa tā iti ced na pariśeṣa anumāne api sāmyāt
translated: If it is not established, the qualifier is not well-known. If it is argued that this is not so because it is the same in the inference by elimination, it is not so.

analyzed: ātma antara grāhya tvasya ca kaḥ ṛthaḥ
translated: And what is the meaning of being apprehensible by another self?

original: akenapratipattṛsādhāraṇatvamiti cenna sandhigdhāsiddheḥ /🔽santānānumānena mūlapratyabhijñānannaiṣa doṣa iti cettarhi sukhādīnāmapyanumānenānekapratipattṛsādhāraṇyeṇatve
analyzed: a kena pratipattṛ sādhāraṇa tvam iti ced na sandhigdha asiddheḥ  santāna anumānena mūla pratyabhijñānan na eṣa doṣaḥ iti ced tarhi sukha ādīnām api anumānena aneka pratipattṛ sādhāraṇyeṇa tve
translated: If it is argued that it is the commonality with all cognizers, it is not so because of the inconclusive nature of the evidence.

analyzed: na anaikāntika tvam syāt
translated: If it is argued that this fault does not arise because of the recognition of the original cognition through the inference of the continuum, then in the case of pleasure etc. also, there would be inconclusiveness due to the commonality with many cognizers through inference.

original: ātmasamavetasyaiva vīcītaraṅganyāyena mūlapratyabhijñānopapattau vipakṣe bādhakābhāvāc ca /
analyzed: ātma samavetasya eva vīcī taraṅga nyāyena mūla pratyabhijñāna upapattau vipakṣe bādhaka abhāvāt ca
translated: Because in the case of the recognition of the original cognition in the manner of waves and ripples, which is inherent in the self, there is no contradiction in the opposite case.

analyzed: aparaḥ āha
translated: Another says:

analyzed: grāhaka stha tvena agrahaṇam ātma antara grāhyam iti
translated: The apprehensibility by another self is the non-apprehension as being located in the apprehender.

analyzed: tat asiddham
translated: That is not established.

analyzed: ātmani asamavāyāt tad siddhiḥ iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that its establishment is due to the non-inherence in the self, it is not so.

analyzed: tasya api asiddheḥ
translated: Because that is also not established.

analyzed: ahaṅkāreṇa vibhaktasya grahaṇāt tad siddhiḥ iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that its existence is established by the perception of what is differentiated by egoism, it is not so.

original: pāde me sukhaṃ śirasi me duḥkhaṃ mano me duḥkhitamiti darśanātsukhādiṣu vyabhicārāt /
analyzed: pāde me sukham śirasi me duḥkham manaḥ me duḥkhitam iti darśanāt sukha ādiṣu vyabhicārāt
translated: Because there is deviation in pleasure etc., as shown by the statements I have pleasure in my foot, I have pain in my head, my mind is sorrowful.

analyzed: grahaṇam pramitiḥ iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that perception is valid cognition, it is not so.

analyzed: sandigdha asiddha tvāt  kāla ādi guṇaḥ vā kim na syāt
translated: Because of the uncertainty of the establishment.

analyzed: pratyakṣa tvāt iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that it may not be a quality like time, because it is perceptible, it is not so.

analyzed: sparśasya api pratyakṣa tvena avāyavīya tva prasaṅgāt
translated: Because even touch is perceptible, it would lead to the consequence that it is not made of air.

analyzed: kāla ādīnām viśeṣa guṇavat tve bādhaka abhāvāt  tad virahita tayā eva tad siddhiḥ i
translated: Because there is no contradiction in time etc. having specific qualities.

analyzed: dheḥ na iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that its existence is established by the absence of that, it is not so.

analyzed: anyathā tad siddheḥ vakṣyamāṇa tvāt
translated: Because the establishment of that in another way will be stated.

original: kiñcātra sarvatra sāhacaryadarśane saṅkoca eva dravyāntarakalpanāyā laghīyān /
analyzed: kiñca atra sarvatra sāhacarya darśane saṅkocaḥ eva dravya antara kalpanāyāḥ laghīyān
translated: Moreover, in all this, when the concomitance is seen, the contraction itself is simpler in the assumption of another substance.

analyzed: pariśeṣa anumānam tu aṣṭa dravya atirikta dravya a prasiddha viśeṣaṇam
translated: But the inference by elimination has as its qualifier a substance other than the eight substances, which is not well-known.

analyzed: prasiddhau ca anumāna vaiyarthyam
translated: And if it is well-known, the inference is pointless.

original: aṣṭadravyātiriktāśrita ityeva sādhane guṇādivṛttisāmānyādapi vyāvṛttatvenāsādhāraṇatā syāt /
analyzed: aṣṭa dravya atirikta āśritaḥ iti eva sādhane guṇa ādi vṛtti sāmānyāt api vyāvṛtta tvena asādhāraṇa tā syāt
translated: If the proof is stated as dependent on something other than the eight substances, there would be the fault of being inconclusive, because it would also exclude universals that occur in qualities etc.

original: śabdāśrayaḥ itarebhyo bhidyate śabdāśrayatvāt vyatirekeṇa pṛthivīvat iti prayoga iti cetna /
analyzed: śabda āśrayaḥ itarebhyaḥ bhidyate śabda āśraya tvāt vyatirekeṇa pṛthivī vat iti prayogaḥ iti ced na
translated: If it be argued that the substratum of sound is different from the others because it is the substratum of sound, like earth, as in the case of difference, this is not so.

analyzed: pṛthivī ādi pratiyogika aneka bhedānām pratyekam sādhane ba ādīnām sapakṣa tvena tatra avṛttyāḥ asādhāraṇyāt
translated: Because in proving each of the many differences with earth etc. as the counter-correlate, sound etc. are co-substrates, and do not occur there, so it is not a common property.

analyzed: samudita sādhane purana prasiddha viśeṣaṇa tvāt
translated: And in the proof of the aggregate, the qualifier is not well-known.

original: abhāvasya sādhyatvādabhāvābhāvasya ca bhāvatvena pratiyogyanapekṣatayā vyāptigrahaṇasambhavānna doṣa iti cenna /
analyzed: abhāvasya sādhya tvāt abhāva abhāvasya ca bhāva tvena pratiyogi anapekṣa tayā vyāpti grahaṇa sambhavāt na doṣaḥ iti ced na
translated: If it be argued that there is no fault because the absence is to be proved, and the absence of absence is possible to be grasped as pervasion by the nature of existence without dependence on the counter-correlate, this is not so.

analyzed: tathā api pratiṣedha mukhena pratīteḥ anivāraṇāt
translated: Because even so, the cognition through the door of prohibition is not prevented.

analyzed: śabda āśrayaḥ na itarebhyaḥ bhidyate prameya tvāt ghaṭa vat iti sat pratipakṣa tvāt ca
translated: And because there is a counter-argument, like the pot, that the substratum of sound is not different from the others because it is an object of knowledge.

analyzed: sarva pratiyogika eka bheda sādhane tu pramāṇa bādhaḥ ca adhikaḥ
translated: And if the single difference with all counter-correlates is proved, there is the additional fault of contradiction by valid cognition.

analyzed: pratiyogi bhedena bheda bhedasya api darśanāt iti
translated: Because even the difference of difference is seen to be different with the difference of the counter-correlate.

analyzed: astu vā śabda guṇaka ākāśa siddhiḥ anumānāt
translated: Or let there be the proof of the sky qualified by the quality of sound by inference.

analyzed: tathā api avyākṛta ākāśa siddhiḥ sākṣiṇā eva
translated: Even so, the proof of the unmanifested sky is by the witness itself.

analyzed: tad sādhaka liṅga abhāvāt
translated: Because there is no inferential mark that proves it.

original: ākāśadvaitaṃ ca viyadadhikaraṇe vakṣyate /🔽jātibadhirāṇāmapyākāśapratīternāgamo 'pi tatra pramāṇamiti sākṣisiddhameva gaganam /
analyzed: ākāśa dvaitam ca viyat adhikaraṇe vakṣyate  jāti badhirāṇām api ākāśa pratīteḥ na āgamaḥ tatra pramāṇam iti sākṣi siddham eva gaganam
translated: And the duality of space will be stated in the section on space.🔽Even for those who are deaf from birth, space is cognized. Therefore, even scripture is not a means of valid knowledge regarding it. Thus, space is established by the witness itself.

original: tadbhāgā eva diśo na dravyāntaramiti tāsāmapi sākṣivedyasiddhataiva /
analyzed: tad bhāgāḥ eva diśaḥ na dravya antaram iti tāsām api sākṣi vedya siddha tā eva
translated: The directions are nothing but parts of space, not a different substance. Thus, they too are established as known by the witness itself.

analyzed: anyat sva avasare vakṣyāmaḥ
translated: The rest we will explain at the appropriate time.

analyzed: nanu astu gagana ādikam sākṣi siddham
translated: Now, let space and so on be established by the witness.

original: na tāvatā tasya traikālikabādhavaidhuryalakṣaṇaṃ sattvaṃ siddhayati /
analyzed: na tāvatā tasya traikālika bādha vaidhurya lakṣaṇam sattvam siddhayati
translated: Even so, its existence, characterized by being free from the contradiction of the three times, is not established.

analyzed: pratītasya api śukti rajata ādeḥ bādha darśanāt
translated: Because even what is cognized, such as the silver in a shell, is seen to be contradicted.

analyzed: iti atas āha sākṣi siddhasya iti
translated: Thus, he says of what is established by the witness and so on.

analyzed: sākṣi siddhasya na kvāpi bādhya tvam tad adoṣataḥ
translated: What is established by the witness is never contradicted, because it is free from faults.

analyzed: kvāpi kāle tasya sākṣiṇaḥ adoṣa tvāt
translated: At any time, because that witness is free from faults.

analyzed: autsagirkam hi pratyayānām prāmāṇyam
translated: For the validity of cognitions is intrinsic.

analyzed: aprāmāṇyam tu doṣa apavādāt
translated: But invalidity is due to the exclusion of faults.

analyzed: na ca sākṣi jñānam doṣa janyam
translated: And the knowledge of the witness is not produced by faults.

analyzed: tasya anādi tvāt
translated: Because it is beginningless.

analyzed: evam eva ayathārtha tve muktau api
translated: Thus, if it were not in accordance with reality, it would be so even in liberation.

analyzed: tathā prasaṅgāt
translated: Because of the same consequence.

analyzed: avidyā doṣa saṃsargāt sākṣiṇaḥ bādhya artha pratibhāsasi  tvam iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that the cognition of the object to be negated by the witness is due to the contact of the witness with the fault of ignorance, it is not so.
Because it has been said that the connection with ignorance is not possible according to your view.

analyzed: asmābhiḥ api avidyāyāḥ kārya antarasya eva abhyupagata tvāt iti
translated: And because we also accept ignorance to be only the effect of something else.

analyzed: nanu tarhi idam āpannam
translated: But then this is the consequence.

analyzed: gagana ādi svarūpam sākṣi siddham
translated: The nature of the sky etc. is established by the witness.
But its being unobstructed in all three times is by the means of knowing the validity of that witness.
Because even the validity is not different from the nature of being unobstructed.

analyzed: tathā ca satya tvam gagana ādeḥ ca  iti ayuktam iti atas āha sarva iti
translated: And thus the truth of the sky etc.🔽This is not proper. Therefore it is said:

analyzed: sava ṛkāleṣu abādhya tvam sākṣiṇā eva pratīyate
translated: The unobstructedness in all times is cognized only by the witness.

analyzed: abādhya tvam gagana ādīnām iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The remainder is that the unobstructedness of the sky etc.

original: sākṣiṇa eva hi sākṣiprāmāṇyagrāhakatvasya vakṣyamāṇatvāditi bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: sākṣiṇaḥ eva hi sākṣi prāmāṇya grāhaka tvasya vakṣyamāṇa tvāt iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The meaning is that only the witness is said to be the means of knowing the validity of the witness.

analyzed: yat vā gagana ādi svarūpam sākṣi siddham
translated: Or, the nature of the sky etc. is established by the witness.

analyzed: tasya traikālika abādhya tvam tu tad prāmāṇya grahaṇa dvārā siddhayati iti uktam
translated: But its unobstructedness in the three times is established by the means of knowing its validity. This is what is said.

analyzed: idānīm sākṣiṇaḥ traikālika abādhya artha gocara tvasya vakṣyamāṇa tvāt sārvakālika bādhā bhāva viśiṣṭa tayā eva gagana ādi grāhaka tvam asti iti āha sarva kāleṣu iti
translated: Now, since it will be said that the witnesses have as their object the truth that is not contradicted at any time, he says that the apprehension of space etc. exists only by way of being qualified by the absence of contradiction at all times.

original: nanu kāla eva kutaḥ siddhaḥ /🔽yena sarvakāleṣvabādhyatvaṃ sākṣiṇā pratīyata ityata āha kālo hīti //
analyzed: nanu kālaḥ eva kutas siddhaḥ  yena sarva kāleṣu abādhya tvam sākṣiṇā pratīyate iti atas āha kālaḥ hi iti
translated: But how is time itself established?

original: kālo hi sākṣipratyakṣaḥ suṣuptau ca pratītitaḥ // / / //
analyzed: kālaḥ hi sākṣi pratyakṣaḥ suṣuptau ca pratītitaḥ
translated: By which the non-contradiction at all times is cognized by the witness. To this he says Time is indeed directly perceived by the witness, and is known in deep sleep.

analyzed: suṣuptau hi indriyāṇām uparata tvāt na bāhya pratyakṣa anumāna āgamānām tatra pravṛttiḥ
translated: For in deep sleep, because the senses have ceased, external perception, inference and scripture do not operate there.

analyzed: asti tadā api kāla pratibhāsaḥ
translated: But even then, the appearance of time exists.

original: etāvantaṃ kālaṃ sukhamahamasvāpsamiti suṣuptyutthitasya parāmarśadarśanāt na hyananubhūtasya parāmarśo yujyate /
analyzed: etāvantam kālam sukham aham asvāpsam iti suṣupti utthitasya parāmarśa darśanāt na hi ananubhūtasya parāmarśaḥ yujyate
translated: Because one who has arisen from deep sleep perceives, For so long I slept happily, the perception of what was not experienced is not possible.

analyzed: atiprasaṅgāt
translated: Because of the absurdity of over-extension.

analyzed: atas pariśeṣāt sākṣi vedyaḥ eva iti gamyate
translated: Therefore, it is understood that it is known only by the witness, by elimination.

analyzed: atra ayam prayogaḥ
translated: Here is the argument:
Time is known by a means of knowledge other than external perception etc.

analyzed: asatsu api teṣu pratīyamāna tvāt
translated: Because it is perceived even when those [means of knowledge] do not exist.

analyzed: yadi asmin iti pratīyate tat tatas rikta pramāṇa vedyam
translated: If it is cognized as being in that [state], then it is cognizable by a non-empty means of knowledge.

analyzed: yathā asati cakṣuṣi pratīyamānaḥ gandhaḥ tad atirikta ghrāṇa vedyaḥ iti
translated: Just as when the eye is absent, the perceived smell is cognizable by the nose, which is different from the eye.

analyzed: syāt etat evam
translated: This may be so.

analyzed: yadi suṣuptau anubhūyamānasya ayam parāmarśaḥ bhavet
translated: If this reflection were of what is experienced in deep sleep.

analyzed: na etat asti
translated: This is not so.

original: kintu tadaivātītaṃ suṣuptikālamanubhūya tadātano duḥkhābhāvo 'numīyata ityata āha atīteti //
analyzed: kintu tadā eva atītam suṣupti kālam anubhūya tadātanaḥ duḥkha abhāvaḥ numīyate iti atas āha atīta iti
translated: But rather, having experienced the past time of deep sleep itself, the absence of suffering at that time is inferred. Therefore he says past etc.

analyzed: atīta anāgatau kālau api na a sākṣi gocarau
translated: Even the past and future times are not within the range of perception.

original: utthitasya kiṃ sākṣiṇātītakālānubhavamabhyupagamya sukhaparāmarśo nirākriyate uta pramāṇāntareṇa /
analyzed: utthitasya kim sākṣiṇā atīta kāla anubhavam abhyupagamya sukha parāmarśaḥ nirākriyate uta pramāṇa antareṇa
translated: When one has arisen, is the reflection of happiness denied by the witness on the basis of the experience of the past time, or by another means of knowledge?

analyzed: ādye siddham naḥ samīhitam
translated: If the first, then what we desire is established.

analyzed: pareṇa api kālasya sākṣi vedya tayā aṅgīkṛta tvāt
translated: Because even the opponent accepts that time is known by the witness.

analyzed: dvitīye tu idam upatiṣṭhate
translated: If the second, then this is presented.

analyzed: a sākṣi gocarau sākṣi itara pramāṇa viṣayau
translated: The past and future are not within the range of the witness, but are the objects of other means of knowledge.

analyzed: athavā sauṣuptika pratīti balāt astu vartamāna kālasya sākṣi vedya tvam
translated: Or, let the present time be known by the witness by the power of the experience in deep sleep.

original: atītānāgatakālayostu sākṣivedyatvābhāvātkathaṃ traikālikābādhyabhāvaḥ sākṣiṇā prapañcasya siddhayatītyata āha atīteti //
analyzed: atīta anāgata kālayoḥ tu sākṣi vedya tva abhāvāt katham traikālika ābādhya bhāvaḥ sākṣiṇā prapañcasya siddhayati iti atas āha atīta iti
translated: But since in the past and future times there is no direct perception, how is it that the existence of the world in the three times is established by the witness? To this he says: 'In the past' etc.

analyzed: api padena sākṣi pratītau iti samākṛṣṭate
translated: By the word 'api' (even) the meaning of 'is perceived by the witness' is extended.

analyzed: kutas iti atas āha na iti
translated: Why? To this he says: 'Not' etc.

analyzed: sākṣi itara pramāṇa gocarau
translated: The past and future are not the objects of other means of knowledge.

analyzed: pratīyate ca
translated: And they are perceived.

analyzed: tasmāt sākṣi gocarau iti arthaḥ
translated: Therefore they are the objects of the witness - this is the meaning.

analyzed: tat katham etat iti ced na
translated: If it is asked how this is so, it is not so.

analyzed: na tāvat pati akṣa vedyaḥ kālaḥ iti uktam
translated: It has been said that time is not known by perception.

analyzed: jāti badhirāṇām api pratibhāsanāt
translated: And it is not known by scripture, because it appears even to the deaf and blind.

analyzed: anumānam api
translated: Inference also.

analyzed: kālam eva pakṣīkṛtya pravartate  na ādyaḥ iti āha pakṣīkartum iti
translated: Does it operate with time itself as the subject or with something else?🔽He says that the first is not so: 'Because it cannot be made the subject'.

analyzed: pakṣīkartum aśakya tvāt na anumā tatra vartate
translated: Because it cannot be made the subject, inference does not operate there.

analyzed: kālasya asiddhau āśraya asiddhayā
translated: When time is not established, it is because of the non-establishment of the substratum.

analyzed: siddhau siddha sādhana tvena pakṣīkartum aśakya tva tvāt
translated: When it is established, it cannot be made the subject because of the fallacy of proving what is already established.

analyzed: dvitīye pi etat eva uttaram
translated: The same answer applies to the second case also.

analyzed: pakṣīkartum aśakya tvāt iti upalakṣaṇam
translated: 'Because it cannot be made the subject' is a mere indication.

analyzed: vyāpti smaraṇa pakṣa dharma tā jñānayoḥ ayogāt iti api draṣṭavyam
translated: It should also be seen that there is no possibility of the recollection of pervasion and the knowledge of the property of the subject.

analyzed: kāla pratītim antareṇa iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The remainder is without the cognition of time.

analyzed: tat eva prapañcayati tat etat iti
translated: He elaborates on that with that.

original: tadetaditi sarvaṃ ca dṛśyaṃ vā smṛtigocaram /
analyzed: tat etat iti sarvam ca dṛśyam vā smṛti gocaram
translated: And all this visible world or the object of memory

analyzed: sākṣi siddhena kālena khacitam hi eva vartate
translated: Indeed exists only as pervaded by time established by the witness.

original: tasmānna taṃ vinā kiñcit smartuṃ draṣṭumathāpi vā /
analyzed: tasmāt na tam vinā kiñcid smartum draṣṭum atha api vā
translated: Therefore, without it, nothing can be remembered or seen.

analyzed: śakyam
translated: It is possible. .. .🔽. ..

original: yasmāttaditi smṛtigocarametaditi dṛśyaṃ vā sarvamapi sākṣisiddhena kālena khacitaṃ sambaddhameva vartate /
analyzed: yasmāt tat iti smṛti gocaram etat iti dṛśyam vā sarvam api sākṣi siddhena kālena khacitam sambaddham eva vartate
translated: Because all this, the object of memory, or the visible world, indeed exists only as connected, as pervaded by time established by the witness.

original: tasmāttaṃ kālaṃ vinā kālapratibhāsaṃ vinā kiñcidvayāptyādikaṃ smartuṃ vā dharmyādikaṃ draṣṭumiti vā na śakyamityarthaḥ /
analyzed: tasmāt tam kālam vinā kāla pratibhāsam vinā kiñcid vayāpti ādikam smartum vā dharmya ādikam draṣṭum iti vā na śakyam iti arthaḥ
translated: Therefore, without that time, without the appearance of time, it is not possible to remember anything like pervasion, or to see the subject and so on. This is the meaning.

analyzed: idam uktam bhavati
translated: This is what is said:

original: anubhūtavyāptikasya puṃso 'nubhūyamāne smaryamāṇe vā dharmiṇi vyāpyadharmasyānubhavāt smaraṇādvā prāganubhūtāṃ vyāptiṃ smṛtavato vyāptasya
analyzed: anubhūta vyāptikasya puṃsaḥ nubhūyamāne smaryamāṇe vā dharmiṇi vyāpya dharmasya anubhavāt smaraṇāt vā prāk anubhūtām vyāptim smṛtavataḥ vyāptasya
translated: For a person who has experienced the pervasion, when the subject is being experienced or remembered, due to the experience of the pervaded property or the recollection of it, one who has remembered the previously experienced pervasion,

analyzed: pakṣe nu sandhānam anumānam
translated: the ascertainment of the pervaded in the subject is inference.🔽...

analyzed: tat ca vyāpaka sambandha pramiti lakṣaṇa anumiti kāraṇam
translated: And that is the cause of inference, which is characterized by the cognition of the relation of pervasion.

analyzed: smṛti anubhava rūpāḥ ca sarvāḥ pratītayaḥ na kevalam artham avagāhante
translated: And all cognitions in the form of memory and experience do not merely comprehend the object,

analyzed: api tu kāla kalitam eva
translated: but are connected with time as well.

analyzed: tat iti hi smṛtiḥ utpadyate
translated: For memory arises as that,

original: na punā rūpamityeva tattā ca pūrvakālasambandhitaiva /
analyzed: na punar rūpam iti eva tad tā ca pūrva kāla sambandhi tā eva
translated: not merely as this is form, and that is connected with the past time.

analyzed: evam anubhavaḥ pi cakṣuḥ ādi janyaḥ tāvat etat iti jāyate
translated: Similarly, experience produced by the eye, etc. arises as this.

original: anumānādijanyo 'pyabhūditi vā bhavatīti vā bhaviṣyatīti vodeti /
analyzed: anumāna ādi janyā u pi abhūt iti vā bhavati iti vā bhaviṣyati iti vā udeti
translated: Even that produced by inference, etc. arises as it was, it is, or it will be.
And this that etc. is nothing but the connection with the present time, etc.

analyzed: etat ca sarva anubhava siddha tvāt na apalāpam arhati
translated: And this is well-established in all experience and cannot be denied.

analyzed: na ca evam sati kālasya cākṣuṣa tva ādi prasaṅgaḥ
translated: And in this case, there is no possibility of time being perceived by the eye, etc.

analyzed: sākṣi siddha viśeṣaṇa viśiṣṭa pratyaya upapatteḥ
translated: Because the cognition qualified by the qualification established by the witness is possible.

original: tathāca vyāptyādiviṣayā api pratītayo na kālāviśiṣṭaṃ svārthaṃ gocacayituṃ śaknuvanti /
analyzed: tathā ca vyāpti ādi viṣayāḥ api pratītayaḥ na kāla a viśiṣṭam svārtham gocacayitum śaknuvanti
translated: And thus, even the cognitions having pervasion, etc. as their objects cannot make the object qualified by time their object,

analyzed: tāsām api idam tat iti evam ākāreṇa eva utpatteḥ iti
translated: because they arise in the form this is that, and so on.

analyzed: tatas kim iti atas āha tat iti
translated: What then? To this he says: that.

original: tannityasiddherhi nānumāvasaro bhavet // / / //🔽tasya kālasya nityasiddhervyāptyādigrahaṇa eva sākṣiṇā siddhatvānna kālānumānasyāvasaro bhavet aniścite hyarthe nyāsyāvasaraḥ /
analyzed: tat nitya siddheḥ hi na anumā avasaraḥ bhavet  tasya kālasya nitya siddheḥ vyāpti ādi grahaṇe eva sākṣiṇā siddha tvāt na kāla anumānasya avasaraḥ bhavet aniścite hi arthe nyāsya avasaraḥ
translated: For the establishment of its eternality, there would be no occasion for inference.

original: niścitaviṣayaṃ tu siddhasādhanatvāt pareṣāmāśrayāsiddham asmākaṃ tvasaṅgatamiti / /
analyzed: niścita viṣayam tu siddha sādhana tvāt pareṣām āśraya asiddham asmākam tu asaṅgatam iti
translated: Because that time is eternally established, being established by the witness itself in the apprehension of pervasion etc., there would be no occasion for the inference of time. For an occasion for reasoning is only when the matter is uncertain. But when the matter is certain, it is futile for others and unestablished for us, but for us it is irrelevant.

original: evaṃ kālaviṣayāṇi sarvānumānāni sāmānyato nirākṛtya viśeṣato nirākaroti tadetaditi //
analyzed: evam kāla viṣayāṇi sarva anumānāni sāmānyatas nirākṛtya viśeṣataḥ nirākaroti tat etat iti
translated: Having thus refuted in general all inferences regarding time, he refutes them in particular, saying this.

analyzed: tathā hi
translated: This is how.

analyzed: kālaḥ para apara vyatikara yaugapadya ayaugapadya cira kṣi pratyaya liṅgaḥ iti pareṣām bhāṣyam
translated: The commentary says: Time is the mark of the notions of far and near, simultaneity and non-simultaneity, long and short.

analyzed: tat evam kecid vayācakṣate
translated: Some explain it thus.

analyzed: asti tāvat sthavire paraḥ yam iti pratyayaḥ
translated: There is indeed the notion this is far regarding an old man,

analyzed: yūni ca apare iti
translated: and this is near regarding a young man.

analyzed: saḥ yam diś kṛta para apara pratyaya vilakṣaṇa tvāt para apara vyatikara pratyayaḥ
translated: This notion of far and near is different from the notion of far and near based on direction.

original: tathā yugapadāgatau ayugapadāgatau cireṇāgataḥ kṣipramāgataḥ iti pratyayāḥ /
analyzed: tathā yugapad āgatau ayugapad āgatau cireṇa āgataḥ kṣipram āgataḥ iti pratyayāḥ
translated: Similarly, there are the notions they came simultaneously, they came non-simultaneously, he came long ago, he came quickly.

analyzed: te ete ṣaṭ pratyayāḥ kālasya liṅgāni
translated: These six conditions are the signs of time.

analyzed: katham  sthavira ādi viṣayeṣu jāyamānānām eṣām kālam antareṇa viṣaya anavakḷpteḥ
translated: How?🔽Because, in the absence of time, these [conditions] are not possible in objects like the aged, etc.

analyzed: nahi dravya ādikam eva eṣām ālambanam
translated: For these [conditions] do not have substance, etc. alone as their object.

analyzed: tad pratyaya vilakṣaṇa tvāt iti
translated: Because they are different from the conditions of that [substance, etc.].

analyzed: etat ayuktam
translated: This is not correct.

analyzed: tathā hi
translated: Because it is like this.

analyzed: tat iti param iti etat aparam iti
translated: That means the other. This means the non-other.

analyzed: yugapad ādīnām upalakṣaṇam etat
translated: This is an indication of simultaneous, etc.

analyzed: dṛśyam vā smṛti gocaram vā
translated: Or what is seen, or the object of memory,

analyzed: pratīyamānam iti yāvat
translated: means what is being cognized.

original: tatsarvaṃ sākṣisiddhena kālena khacitameva vartate /🔽tasmāttannityasiddheḥ nānumānāvasaro bhavet /
analyzed: tat sarvam sākṣi siddhena kālena khacitam eva vartate  tasmāt tat nitya siddheḥ na anumāna avasaraḥ bhavet
translated: All that exists as pervaded by time, which is established by the witness [consciousness].🔽Therefore, since it is established as eternal, there would be no occasion for inference.

analyzed: tasmāt ityasya eva vivaraṇam na tam vinā iti
translated: The explanation of therefore is not without that.

analyzed: na śakyam hi iti sambandhaḥ
translated: The connection is for it is not possible.

analyzed: etat uktam bhavati  para apara ādi viṣayāḥ
translated: This is what is said.🔽The conditions having objects like the other, the non-other, etc.,

analyzed: pratyayāḥ tāvat kāla viśiṣṭa piṇḍa viṣayāḥ iti pareṇa eva uktam
translated: are indeed about a lump qualified by time, as stated by the opponent himself.

original: tathāca liṅgapratītāveva liṅginaḥ kālasya sphuraṇātkathaṃ tena tadanumānam /
analyzed: tathā ca liṅga pratītau eva liṅginaḥ kālasya sphuraṇāt katham tena tad anumānam
translated: And thus, when the inferred sign is cognized, the time which is the signified is manifested. How can it be inferred by that [sign]?

analyzed: nahi daṇḍi jñānena daṇḍaḥ numīyate
translated: For a stick is not inferred from the cognition of a stick-holder.

original: atha viśiṣṭajñānatvādidaṃ viśeṣaṇajñānapūrvakam /🔽viśeṣaṇaṃ ca na kālātiriktamastītyanumīyate /
analyzed: atha viśiṣṭa jñāna tvāt idam viśeṣaṇa jñāna pūrvakam  viśeṣaṇam ca na kāla atiriktam asti iti anumīyate
translated: Now, if this is preceded by the knowledge of a qualifier because of being the knowledge of a particular,🔽and there is no qualifier other than time, it is inferred.

analyzed: tarhi na idam kāla anumānam
translated: Then this is not an inference of time.

analyzed: kintu jñāna anumānam
translated: But it is an inference of knowledge.

analyzed: tat ca siddha sādhanam  sākṣi siddha kāla viśiṣṭa pratyaya abhyupagamāt iti
translated: And that is a futile rejoinder.🔽Because time qualified by the self-evident is accepted.

analyzed: atha balī palita kārkaśya ādinā kāla sambandhe nu mite
translated: Now, when the connection with time is inferred by graying of hair, wrinkles, and so on,

original: vipratipannaṃ prati parāparādipratyayānāṃ kāryatvena nimittānumānamidaṃ bhāṣyamiti /
analyzed: vipratipannam prati para apara ādi pratyayānām kārya tvena nimitta anumānam idam bhāṣyam iti
translated: this commentary is an inference of the cause of the notions of far and near, etc. for one who disagrees.

analyzed: mā evam
translated: This is not so.

analyzed: śarīra avasthayā hi tasya kāla sambandhaḥ numīyate
translated: For its connection with time is inferred by the condition of the body.

analyzed: yat kiñcid dravya sambandhaḥ vā
translated: Or by the connection with some substance.

analyzed: ādye kim asmāt anumānāt prāk kālaḥ siddhaḥ thavā na iti vācyam
translated: In the first case, it must be said whether time is established before this inference or not.

original: ādye tannityasiddhestasya kālasya prāganumānānnityena sākṣiṇā siddheḥ /
analyzed: ādye tat nitya siddheḥ tasya kālasya prāk anumānāt nityena sākṣiṇā siddheḥ
translated: In the first case, because that time is eternally established, it is established by the eternal self-evident before the inference of time.

analyzed: dvitīye ca aprasiddha viśeṣaṇa tvāt na anumāna avasaraḥ bhavet
translated: In the second case, because of the unknown qualifier, there would be no opportunity for inference.

analyzed: kiñca valī palita kārkaśya
translated: Moreover, the form of wrinkles and gray hair

original: diśarīrāvasthā kāraṇatvena kālānumāne tannityasiddhestasya kālasambandhasya nityaṃ
analyzed: diśarīra avasthā kāraṇa tvena kāla anumāne tad nitya siddheḥ tasya kāla sambandhasya nityam
translated: In the inference of time based on the state of the body in relation to space, since that [state] is always established, the relation of that [state] to time is always established.

analyzed: sarvadā valī palita ādi vaidhurya daśāyām api siddheḥ nitye paramāṇau api siddheḥ bādhita viṣaya tvena
translated: Since it is established even in the state of freedom from wrinkles, gray hair, etc., it is established even in the eternal atom. Therefore, being contradicted,

analyzed: na anumāna avasaraḥ bhavet
translated: it would not be the occasion for inference.

analyzed: atha bahu kāla sambandhaḥ numīyate
translated: If, on the other hand, the relation to much time is inferred,

analyzed: tat na
translated: that is not so.

original: bahutvaṃ hi kālasya kiṃ paramāṇūnāmiva sahaiva /
analyzed: bahu tvam hi kālasya kim paramāṇūnām iva saha eva
translated: For how is the plurality of time like that of atoms, together?

analyzed: uta kriyāṇām iva
translated: Or like that of actions, only in the relation of prior and posterior existence?

analyzed: na ādyaḥ
translated: Not the first.

analyzed: tad sambandhasya api nitya siddheḥ na itaraḥ na uttaraḥ
translated: Because the relation to that [time] is also always established. Not the second,

analyzed: tasya kālasya nitya siddheḥ
translated: because that [time] is always established.

analyzed: nitya tayā aṅgīkṛta tvāt
translated: Because it is accepted as eternal.

analyzed: na dvitīyaḥ
translated: Not the second.

analyzed: tasya nitya siddheḥ siddha sādhana tvāt
translated: Because it is always established, the proof is superfluous.

analyzed: atha pariśeṣāt itara niṣedhaḥ kariṣyate iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that the negation of the other will be done by elimination, that is not so.

analyzed: pariśeṣa avadhāraṇa anupapatteḥ iti
translated: Because the determination by elimination is not possible.

analyzed: anye tu vyācakṣate
translated: Others explain it thus.🔽Being born separated by much lightning and motion is distance.

analyzed: alpatara saura sañcāra antarita janma tvam ca apara tvam
translated: And being born separated by less solar motion is nearness.

analyzed: eka tapana pracāra viśiṣṭa tvam yaugapadyam
translated: Simultaneity is the quality of being distinguished by the operation of a single heat.

analyzed: aneka tad viśiṣṭa tvam ayaugapadyam  bahu kriyā viśiṣṭa tvam cira tvam
translated: Non-simultaneity is the quality of being distinguished by many such [operations].🔽Duration is the quality of being distinguished by many actions.

analyzed: katipaya kriyā viśiṣṭa tvam kṣipra tvam
translated: Swiftness is the quality of being distinguished by a few actions.

original: tatpratyayaiḥ kālo 'numīyate /🔽taraṇiparispandā hi padārthasārthe viśiṣṭapratyayotpattau svapratyāsattimapekṣante /
analyzed: tad pratyayaiḥ kālaḥ numīyate  taraṇi parispandāḥ hi padārtha sārthe viśiṣṭa pratyaya utpattau sva pratyāsattim apekṣante
translated: Time is inferred from those [actions].🔽For the vibrations of lightning require their own proximity in the production of a distinct cognition in the group of objects.

analyzed: pratyāsanna tve sati viśiṣṭa vyavahāra janaka tvāt
translated: Because, while not being naturally proximate, they produce a distinct usage.

analyzed: candana saurabha vat
translated: Like sandalwood and fire.

analyzed: parampara sambandhinaḥ ca sākṣāt sambandha virahe sati sambandhi tvāt
translated: And because it is related to what is related through a series, while being devoid of direct relation.
Like the blue color related to a cloth in contact.

original: ataḥ piṇḍatapanaparispandayoḥ saṃyuktasaṃyogisamavāyātmani paramparāsambandhe yaddravyaṃ nimittaṃ sa kāla iti / /
analyzed: atas piṇḍa tapana parispandayoḥ saṃyukta saṃyogi samavāya ātmani paramparā sambandhe yat dravyam nimittam sa kālaḥ iti
translated: Therefore, the substance that is the cause in the series-relation consisting of the inherence of conjunction with what is conjoined to the individual and the heat-vibration is time.

analyzed: etat api asat
translated: This is also wrong.

analyzed: ghaṭa śūnyam bhū talam ityādi vat svabhāva pratyāsattyā eva viśiṣṭa pratyaya upapatteḥ
translated: Because a distinct cognition is possible by natural proximity itself, as in the ground is empty of pot and so on.

analyzed: anyathā abhāve para apara yaugapadya ādi pratyaya anupapatti prasaṅgāt
translated: Otherwise, the occurrence of cognitions like simultaneity of the higher and lower would be impossible.

analyzed: dṛśyate ca yugapad utpannau abhāvau ityādi pratyayaḥ
translated: And cognitions like the two appearances arose simultaneously are seen.

analyzed: atra sambandhe bādhaka abhāvāt na evam iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that in this case, it is not so because there is no contradiction in the relation, it is not so.

analyzed: anya samaveta tvasya eva bādhaka tvāt  upanāyaka dravya antara kalpanayā tad upapattiḥ iti ced
translated: Because the very fact of inhering in something else is contradictory.🔽If it is argued that it is possible by postulating a different substance as the connecting factor,

analyzed: tarhi bhū tala ghaṭa abhāvayoḥ tṛtīya sambandha kalpanayā upapattau bādhaka abhāvāt
translated: then in the case of the absence of a pot on the ground, it is possible by postulating a third relation, and there is no contradiction.

analyzed: svārasika sambandhena eva viśiṣṭa pratyaya upapattau kim apratīyamāna sambandha kalpanayā iti ced
translated: If it is argued that when the cognition of the qualified is possible by the natural relation itself, what is the use of postulating an imperceptible relation,

original: tarhi tathaiva parāparādiviśiṣṭapratyayotpattau kimapratīyamānadravyakalpanayeti samānam /🔽tadidamuktam teṣāṃ viśiṣṭapratyayānāṃ nityasiddherdravyāntarakalpānāṃ vinā svabhāvādeva siddheḥ dravyāntarānumānāvasaro na bhavediti /
analyzed: tarhi tathā eva para apara ādi viśiṣṭa pratyaya utpattau kim apratīyamāna dravya kalpanayā iti samānam  tat idam uktam teṣām viśiṣṭa pratyayānām nitya siddheḥ dravya antara kalpānām vinā svabhāvāt eva siddheḥ dravya antara anumāna avasaraḥ na bhavet iti
translated: then the same applies to the arising of the cognition of the qualified like higher and lower, what is the use of postulating an imperceptible substance?🔽This is what is meant: because those cognitions of the qualified are always established, and because they are established by their own nature alone, without postulating another substance, there is no occasion for inferring another substance.

analyzed: tat anena pratyāsanna tve sati iti viśeṣaṇa asiddhiḥ
translated: By this, the qualification when not naturally proximate is not established.

analyzed: viśiṣṭa vyavahāra janaka tva mātrasya ca anaikāntyam uktam bhavati
translated: And it is said that the mere production of a qualified cognition is inconclusive.

analyzed: nanu viṣamaḥ upanyāsaḥ
translated: But the example is not similar.

analyzed: bhū tala abhāvayoḥ asti sānnidhyam
translated: There is proximity between the absence and the ground.

analyzed: tena sambandha abhāve pi bhaviṣyati viśiṣṭa vyavahāraḥ
translated: Therefore, even in the absence of a relation, there will be a qualified cognition.

analyzed: darśanasya durapahnava tvāt
translated: Because perception is undeniable.

analyzed: sambandha antara kalpanasya ca vyartha tvāt
translated: And because postulating another relation is pointless.

analyzed: na ca taraṇi parispandānām piṇḍa sānnidhyam asti
translated: But there is no proximity of the sparks of fire to the lump.

analyzed: tatas bhavitavyam madhye dravya antareṇa iti
translated: Therefore, there must be another substance in between.

analyzed: mā evam
translated: This is not so.

analyzed: vinā api sānnidhyena ghaṭa jñānam iti viśiṣṭa pratyaya darśanāt
translated: Because we see qualified cognitions like the cognition of the pot without proximity.

original: kiñcābhāvasyāpi na bhūtalasānnidhyaṃ parapakṣe kimapi paśyāmaḥ /
analyzed: kiñca abhāvasya api na bhū tala sānnidhyam para pakṣe kim api paśyāmaḥ
translated: Moreover, we do not see any proximity of absence to the ground in the opponent's view.

original: astu vā tapanaparispandānāṃ piṇḍaṃ pratyupanāyakaṃ dravyāntaram /
analyzed: astu vā tapana parispandānām piṇḍam pratyupanāyakam dravya antaram
translated: Or let there be another substance that brings the sparks of fire to the lump.

analyzed: tat ca pṛthivī ādikam kim na syāt
translated: And why should that not be earth and so on?

analyzed: tapana piṇḍābhyām a saṃsargāt na iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that it cannot be so because it does not come in contact with the sun and the lump, that is not so.

analyzed: ekaikasya avyāpaka tve pi bahūnām saṃyukta saṃyoga bhūyaḥ tvena kriyā upanāyaka tva upapatteḥ
translated: Even though each one is not all-pervading, many can act as the cause of motion by the abundance of the conjunction of the conjoined.

original: naca taraṇipiṇḍāntakāle tāni na santyanupalambhāditi vācyam /
analyzed: na ca taraṇi piṇḍa anta kāle tāni na santi anupalambhāt iti vācyam
translated: And it should not be said that at the time of the dissolution of the mass of lightning, those [qualities] do not exist because they are not perceived.

analyzed: sūkṣmāṇām kalpanīya tvāt
translated: Because the subtle [qualities] must be imagined.

analyzed: na ca vinigamanāyām kāraṇa abhāvaḥ
translated: And there is no absence of a reason for determining [which qualities exist].

analyzed: saṃśaye pi pariśeṣa avadhāraṇa anupapatteḥ
translated: Because even in doubt, the ascertainment by elimination is not possible.

analyzed: dharmi kalpanātaḥ dharma kalpanasya laghīyaḥ tvāt
translated: Because imagining a quality is less cumbersome than imagining a substance.

analyzed: ākāśaḥ vā kim na syāt
translated: Or why should not space be [the substance]?

analyzed: na syāt
translated: It should not be [the substance].

analyzed: viśeṣa guṇavat tvāt pṛthivī ādi vat iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that it is not, because it has special qualities, like earth etc., that is not so.

analyzed: viśeṣaṇa guṇavataḥ pi nīla dravyasya paṭe nīlima upasaṅkrāmaka tva darśanāt
translated: Because even a blue substance with a qualifying quality is seen to transfer blueness to a cloth.

original: sūryagatyupanāyakatvaṃ ca dravyasvarūpaṃ vā atīndriyaśaktirvā sahakāriśaktirvā /
analyzed: sūrya gati upanāyaka tvam ca dravya svarūpam vā atīndriya śaktiḥ vā sahakāri śaktiḥ vā
translated: And the quality of being the guide for the sun's motion is either the substance's own form, or a supersensible power, or a cooperating power.

analyzed: na ādyaḥ
translated: The first is not so.

analyzed: dravya mātre prasaṅgāt
translated: Because it would follow for mere substance.

analyzed: na dvitīyaḥ
translated: The second is not so.

analyzed: anabhyupagamāt  tṛtīye api kim tad vayāpaka tvam vā
translated: Because it is not accepted.🔽In the third case also, it should be analyzed whether it is the pervasiveness of that,

analyzed: viśeṣa guṇa virahaḥ vā iti  vayam tu brūmaḥ
translated: or the absence of special qualities.🔽But we say:

analyzed: vyāpaka tvam eva tat iti
translated: That is only the pervasiveness.

analyzed: anyathā manasaḥ api tad prasaṅgāt
translated: Otherwise, it would follow for the mind also.

analyzed: vyāpaka tvasya prayojaka tāyām ātmanaḥ api tad prasaṅgaḥ iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that it would follow for the self also in the employment of pervasiveness as the cause, that is not so.
