analyzed: tad vayāpaka tva abhāvasya vakṣyamāṇa tvāt  vyāpaka tve pi aniṣya abhāvāt
translated: Because it will be said that it is not the pervader of that.🔽Even if it were the pervader, because there is no undesirable consequence.

analyzed: kriyā upanāyaka tvam khalu āntarālikasya dravyasya na ubhaya saṃyoga atiriktam kiñcid
translated: For the substance in the interval is the conveyor of action, nothing more than the connection with both.

analyzed: tat ekasya iva anekeṣām api samānam
translated: That is the same for many as for one.

analyzed: yadi ākāśaḥ
translated: If space

analyzed: sva sambandhena anya gatam dharmam anyatra saṅkrāmayet
translated: were to transfer a property present in one thing to another by its own connection,

original: tadā sarvaṃ sarvatra saṅkrāmayet aviśeṣāditi cenna /
analyzed: tadā sarvam sarvatra saṅkrāmayet aviśeṣāt iti ced na
translated: then it would transfer everything everywhere, because there is no distinction. If this is said, it is not so.

analyzed: niyata upasaṅkrāmaka tvasya eva kalpanīya tvāt
translated: Because only the transfer of what is restricted is to be imagined.

analyzed: gurvī hi dharma mātra kalpanā atas dharmi kalpanā
translated: For the imagination of a property is heavier than the imagination of a substance.

analyzed: anyathā kāle pi samānaḥ prasaṅgaḥ
translated: Otherwise, the same consequence would apply to time as well.

analyzed: tad siddhaya siddhibhyām anavasara duḥstha tvam iti ced na
translated: If it is said that it is not so, because of the difficulty of the impossibility of the occasion of its establishment and non-establishment, it is not so.

analyzed: bhāva anavabodhāt
translated: Because of the non-understanding of existence.

original: viśiṣṭapratyayadarśanānantaraṃ bahavaḥ pakṣāḥ prāpnuvanti /🔽kimayaṃ svarasambandhanibandhanaḥ kiṃ vā atiriktasambandhādhīna iti /
analyzed: viśiṣṭa pratyaya darśana anantaram bahavaḥ pakṣāḥ prāpnuvanti  kim ayam svara sambandha nibandhanaḥ kim vā atirikta sambandha adhīnaḥ iti
translated: After seeing a particular cognition, many alternatives are obtained.🔽Is this based on its own connection or dependent on an additional connection?

original: dvitīye 'pi kiṃ sākṣātsambandho 'tra nimittamuta dravyāntarakṛta iti /
analyzed: dvitīye pi kim nimittam uta dravya antara kṛtaḥ iti
translated: In the second case also, is the direct connection the cause here or is it produced by another substance?

analyzed: uttaratra apa tat dravyam prasiddheṣu anyatamam vā bhavatu anyat vā iti
translated: And in the subsequent part also, that substance should be either one of the well-known ones or something else.

original: sarvatra bādhakāni paryālocayanprasiddhadravyeṣu yadbādhakaṃ paśyettadaprasiddhe 'pi kalpyamāne kathaṃ nānusandadhyāt /
analyzed: sarvatra bādhakāni paryālocayan prasiddha dravyeṣu yat bādhakam paśyet tat aprasiddhe kalpyamāne katham na anusandadhyāt
translated: Everywhere, considering the refutations, whatever refutation one sees among the well-known substances, how could one not connect that even when imagining something unknown?

original: anusandadhānaśca tatsvābhāvyena parihāraṃ cintayankalpanāgauravavyasanamapahāya laghīyāṃsameva pakṣaṃ na kathaṃvā
analyzed: anusandadhānaḥ ca tad svābhāvyena parihāram cintayan kalpanā gaurava vyasanam apahāya laghīyāṃsam eva pakṣam na kathaṃvā
translated: And thinking of the refutation as natural, rejecting the addiction to the heaviness of imagination, how could one not delight in the lighter position?

analyzed: rocayate iti asya arthasya vivakṣita tvāt
translated: Since this meaning is intended.

analyzed: para prasiddha tvena prasaṅgasya na doṣaḥ iti asya api ayam eva abhiprāyaḥ
translated: This is also the very idea that the reductio is not faulty by being well-known to others.

analyzed: kiñca ayam prasaṅgaḥ vastutas sādhuḥ atha ābhāsaḥ
translated: Moreover, is this reductio good in reality or is it fallacious?

analyzed: na ādyaḥ
translated: Not the first.

analyzed: kāla pratīti uttara kālam vyāpti bhaṅgāt
translated: Because the pervasion is broken after the time of dependence on time.

analyzed: dvitīye katham ākāśasya kriyā upanāyaka tvam tyājayet
translated: In the second case, how could one abandon the fact that space is the conveyor of action?

analyzed: anyathā jāti nirākaraṇam api na syāt iti
translated: Otherwise, the refutation of universals would also not be possible.

original: astu vā'kāśasya viśeṣaguṇavataḥ kriyopanāyakatvābhāvaḥ diśastu syāt viśeṣaguṇaśūnyatvāt vyāpakatvācca /
analyzed: astu vā ākāśasya viśeṣa guṇavataḥ kriyā upanāyaka tva abhāvaḥ diśaḥ tu syāt viśeṣa guṇa śūnya tvāt vyāpaka tvāt ca
translated: Or let there be the absence of space's being the conveyor of action, even though it has special qualities, but it may be so for direction, because it is devoid of special qualities and because it is all-pervading.

analyzed: tasyāḥ saṃyoga upanāyaka tvena siddha tvāt na iti ced na
translated: If it be said that this is not so, because it is already established as the cause of the conjunction of that (sound), we say no.

analyzed: ubhaya upanāyaka tve pi bādhaka abhāvāt
translated: Because, even if it is the cause of both, there is no contradiction.

analyzed: sahakāri bhedena ca vyavasthita avyavasthita pratīti janaka tvam kalpyatām lāghavāt eva
translated: And let it be assumed that it produces the cognition which is fixed or unfixed according to the difference of auxiliaries, because that is simpler.

analyzed: anyathā kāle pi bheda kalpanā prasaṅgāt iti
translated: Otherwise, there would be the contingence of assuming difference even in time.

analyzed: tat idam uktam
translated: This is what is said.

original: tasya viśiṣṭapratyayasya nityena niyatena prasiddhenaiva pṛthivyādinā siddhernāprasiddhe dravye 'numānāvasaro bhavediti / /🔽anye tu paramparaśabdābhyāṃ paratvāparatve guṇau yuvasthavirapiṇḍavartinau
analyzed: tasya viśiṣṭa pratyayasya nityena niyatena prasiddhena eva pṛthivī ādinā siddheḥ na aprasiddhe dravye numāna avasaraḥ bhavet iti  anye tu parampara śabdābhyām paratva aparatve guṇau yuva sthavira piṇḍavartinau
translated: Because that particular cognition is established by the well-known, eternal, and fixed earth etc., there is no occasion for inference of an unknown substance.

analyzed: gatau ācakṣate
translated: But others, using the words 'parampara' (succession), explain 'paratva' (distance) and 'aparatva' (proximity) as qualities residing in the bodies of the young and the old.

original: tau asamavāyikāraṇasaṃyogāśrayatayā nimittakāraṇāpekṣābuddhisampādakatayā vā kālamanumāpayata iti /
analyzed: tau asamavāyi kāraṇa saṃyoga āśraya tayā nimitta kāraṇa apekṣā buddhi sampādaka tayā vā kālam anumāpayataḥ iti
translated: They say that these (qualities) indicate time either as the substratum of the conjunction which is the non-inherent cause, or as the producer of the cognition which requires an instrumental cause.

original: tadapyuktanyāyena nirastamiti / /🔽kiñca parāparādipratyayānāṃ sūryagatayo vā parātvā
analyzed: tat api ukta nyāyena nirastam iti  kiñca parāpara ādi pratyayānām sūrya gatayaḥ vā parātvā
translated: That also is refuted by the reasoning stated.

original: paratve vā yadyālambanaṃ tadā astu kālānumānam /
analyzed: paratve vā yadi ālambanam tadā astu kāla anumānam
translated: Moreover, if the cognitions of 'far' and 'near' etc. have as their object either the motions of the sun or distance and proximity, then let there be inference of time.

analyzed: na ca etat asti
translated: But this is not so.

analyzed: kāla bhedānām eva viśeṣaṇa tayā pratīteḥ
translated: Because time differences are understood as qualifications.

original: tathāhi /🔽paro 'yamityādi prayuktavantaḥ ko 'syārtha iti pṛṣṭāḥ laukikāḥ parīkṣikāśca bahukālīnano 'yamityādi
analyzed: tathā hi  paraḥ yam ityādi prayuktavantaḥ kaḥ sya arthaḥ iti pṛṣṭāḥ laukikāḥ parīkṣikāḥ ca yam ityādi
translated: To explain:🔽When the expressions this is far etc. are used, when asked what is the meaning of this?, the worldly people and the investigators are seen explaining

analyzed: iti vyācakṣāṇāḥ dṛśyante
translated: this is far etc.

analyzed: tatra kāla svarūpam sākṣi siddham
translated: There, the nature of time is established by the witness.

original: tadbahutvādi ca kvacitsākṣiṇā kvacidanumānādinā ca jñāyata iti /
analyzed: tad bahu tva ādi ca kvacid sākṣiṇā kvacid anumāna ādinā ca jñāyate iti
translated: And its plurality etc. is known in some cases by the witness, and in some cases by inference etc.

analyzed: etat api uktam tat etat iti ślokābhyām
translated: This is also stated in the two verses beginning with that.

analyzed: anayā eva diśā para apara pratyaya ādi liṅga tvam nirākartavyam
translated: In the same way, the indication of directions by the notions of far and near etc. should be refuted.

analyzed: tam ā id etam cirantanam panthānam arocayamānāḥ navīnāḥ tu diś kālayoḥ anyathā anumānam āhuḥ
translated: Not approving of this ancient path, the modern ones state the inference of time and space in a different way.

original: vivādādhyāsitaṃ kāryaṃ viśeṣaguṇarahitadravyābhyāṃ janyate kāryatvāt antaḥkaraṇadvayasaṃyogavaditi /
analyzed: vivāda adhyāsitam kāryam viśeṣa guṇa rahita dravyābhyām janyate kārya tvāt antaḥkaraṇa dvaya saṃyoga vat iti
translated: The effect under dispute is produced by two substances devoid of specific qualities, because it is an effect, like the conjunction of two internal organs.

analyzed: etat api ayuktam
translated: This is also incorrect.

analyzed: sādhye bahuvacana prayoga īkṣepe
translated: In the use of the plural in the conclusion,

analyzed: ti prasaṅgāt
translated: there would be an overextension.

analyzed: na ca dṛṣṭānta abhāvaḥ
translated: And there is no absence of an example.

analyzed: antaḥkaraṇa gata bahu tvasya sattvāt
translated: Because the plurality belonging to the internal organ exists.

analyzed: na ca antaḥkaraṇa dvaya saṃyoge pramāṇam asti
translated: And there is no proof for the conjunction of two internal organs.

original: mano manasā saṃyujyate mūrtatvāccharīravaditi ca ākālike vidyadādau sandigdhavyabhicāram / /
analyzed: manaḥ manasā saṃyujyate mūrta tvāt śarīra vat iti ca ākālike vidyat ādau sandigdha vyabhicāram
translated: The argument The mind is conjoined with the mind, because it is material, like the body is inconclusive when applied to the present time, such as in the case of a lamp.

analyzed: aparaḥ āha
translated: Another says:

analyzed: parama mahat parimāṇam dravya catuṣyaya vṛtti parimāṇa tvāt aṇu tva vat iti  atra yadi ākāśa ātma gata
translated: The highest magnitude belongs to the four substances, because it is magnitude, like atomicity.

analyzed: parimāṇa pakṣīkāraḥ tadā siddha sādhanam ātmanām bahu tvāt
translated: In this case, if the magnitude belonging to the self of space is accepted as the subject, then it is an established thesis, because there are many selves.

analyzed: ātma tvena aikyam upādāya prayoge pi bādhaḥ
translated: Even if the argument is made on the basis of their unity as selves, there is still contradiction.

analyzed: parimāṇa dvayasya dravya catuṣyaya vṛtti tva ayogāt
translated: Because it is not possible for two magnitudes to belong to the four substances.

analyzed: ekaika dravya vṛtti khalu parimāṇam
translated: For magnitude belongs to each substance individually.

analyzed: atas eva na kāla ādi gatasya pakṣīkāraḥ
translated: For this very reason, the magnitude belonging to time, etc. cannot be accepted as the subject.

analyzed: āśraya asiddhiḥ ca adhikā
translated: And there is the additional fallacy of the substratum being unestablished.

analyzed: parama mahat parimāṇa sāmānyam viśeṣa guṇa śūnya dravya adhikaraṇa aneka vyakti vṛtti parimāṇa tāratamya viśrānti viṣaya jāti tvāt aṇu parimāṇa vṛtti jāti vat iti
translated: The universal of highest magnitude belongs to many individuals that are the substrata of substances devoid of specific qualities, because it is the class that is the resting place of the gradation of magnitude, like the class that belongs to atomic magnitude.

analyzed: ca anupapannam
translated: This is also not correct.

analyzed: parama mahat parimāṇa sāmānyam hi parimāṇa tvam vā tad avāntara jātiḥ vā
translated: For the universal of highest magnitude is either magnitude itself or a subordinate class of it.

analyzed: ādye manaḥ siddhayā api asya sambhavena artha antara tā
translated: In the first case, it is superfluous, as it can be accomplished by the establishment of the mind.

analyzed: sāmānyasya api aneka vṛtti tāyāḥ nirākariṣyamāṇa tvena bādhā āśraya asiddhī ca
translated: And there is the fallacy of the substratum being unestablished, as the plurality of the universal is going to be refuted.

analyzed: na dvitīyaḥ  tasyāḥ tasya
translated: The second is not so.

analyzed: nirākariṣyamāṇa tvāt  varṇa siddhayā artha antara tvāt ca
translated: Because that is going to be refuted.🔽And because it is superfluous, as it can be accomplished by the establishment of the letters.

analyzed: aneka pada sthāne bahu pada prakṣepe atiprasaṅgāt ca
translated: And because there is the absurdity of too wide a definition, if many words are substituted for one word.

analyzed: astu kālasya diśaḥ ca bahu tvam
translated: Let there be plurality of time and space.

original: ātmavadupasaṅgrāhakaikyena dravyāṇāṃ navatvopapattiriti cettarhi diśā kālena vā sādhyaparyavasānāsambhavā🔽dubhayasādhakatvamasya na syāt /
analyzed: ātma vat upasaṅgrāhaka aikyena dravyāṇām nava tva upapattiḥ iti ced tarhi diśā kālena vā sādhya paryavasāna asambhavā  dubhaya sādhaka tvam asya na syāt
translated: If it is argued that the number of substances can be nine by the unity of the comprehender like the self, then, because the conclusion cannot be reached either by space or time,🔽this cannot be the proof of both.

analyzed: mā bhūt iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that let it not be so, it cannot be so.

analyzed: aneka pada vaiyarthyāt
translated: Because it is superfluous to have many words.

analyzed: anyatara sādhane nyatareṇa artha antara tā prasaṅgāt  hetu dṛṣṭāntayoḥ ca anupapattiḥ vakṣyate iti alam pallavena
translated: Because if one is proved, the other would be superfluous.🔽And it will be shown that the reason and example are not proper. So enough of this trifling.

analyzed: gagana ādeḥ sakala prapañcasya traikālika abādhya tvam sākṣi siddham iti uktam artham upasaṃharan vivṛṇoti atas iti
translated: It has been said that the non-obstructedness of the entire universe including space in the three times is established by the witness. The author concludes and explains this meaning with the word ataḥ (therefore).

analyzed: atas doṣa pratītasya satya tvam sākṣiṇā matam
translated: Therefore, the truth of what is known without fault is accepted by the witness.

original: na vidyate doṣaḥ kāraṇaṃ yasya jñānasya tena pratītasya viṣayīkṛtasyādoṣeṇa pratyakṣādinā vā pratītasya gaganādeḥ prapañcasya satyatvaṃ traikālikābādhyatvaṃ 🔽sākṣiṇā mataṃ siddham /
analyzed: na vidyate doṣaḥ kāraṇam yasya jñānasya tena pratītasya viṣayīkṛtasya adoṣeṇa pratyakṣa ādinā vā pratītasya gagana ādeḥ prapañcasya satya tvam traikālika abādhya tvam  sākṣiṇā matam siddham
translated: The truth, i.e., the non-negation in the three times, of the world, which is known by the knowledge whose cause is not a fault, or of the sky etc. which is known by perception etc. without fault, is accepted, i.e., established, by the witness.

analyzed: prāmāṇya grahaṇa ādinā iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The rest is: by the apprehension of validity etc.

analyzed: ayam atra abhiprāyaḥ
translated: This is the intention here.

analyzed: ākāśa kāla diś ātma manāṃsi sukha ādayaḥ ca sākṣāt sākṣi siddhāḥ
translated: Space, time, direction, self, and mind, as well as pleasure etc., are directly established by the witness.

analyzed: tad itare tu padārthāḥ yathāsvam yathāyatham
translated: But other things, according to their own nature, are

analyzed: indriya liṅga śabda gamyāḥ
translated: perceived by the senses, inference, and words.

analyzed: jñānam ca bhāva abhāva lakṣaṇam sva viṣayam sattvena eva avagāhate
translated: And knowledge, characterized by existence and non-existence, penetrates its own object as existent alone.

analyzed: na a sattvena
translated: Not as non-existent.

analyzed: na api udāsīnena rūpeṇa
translated: Nor as a neutral form.

original: nacaivaṃ ghaṭo 'sti ghaṭo nāstītipratyayānupapattiḥ paunaruktyādvayāghātācceti yuktam /
analyzed: na ca evam ghaṭaḥ sti ghaṭaḥ na asti iti pratyaya anupapattiḥ paunaruktyāt vayāghātāt ca iti yuktam
translated: And thus, the non-apprehension of the cognitions the pot exists, the pot does not exist is not proper, because of repetition and contradiction. This is not proper.

analyzed: ghaṭaḥ sti iti deśa kāla viśeṣa sambandhi sattā viṣaya tvāt
translated: Because the cognition the pot exists has as its object existence related to a particular place and time.

analyzed: kvacid viparīta ākāṅkṣā vyavaccheda atha ṛtvāt
translated: Because it has the purpose of excluding a desire for the opposite in some cases.

analyzed: kvāpi vyākhyāna vyākhyeya bhāvāt
translated: because in some cases there is the relation of the expounder and the expounded.

analyzed: na asti ityasya ca deśa kāla viśeṣa sambandhi sattā pratiṣedha paratvāt
translated: And because the word 'not' has for purport the denial of existence related to a particular place and time.

analyzed: nahi satā sakala deśa kāla satā bhavitavyam iti niyāmakam asti
translated: For there is no rule that what is existent must exist in all places and times.

original: jñānagataṃ ca yāthārthyalakṣaṇaṃ prāmāṇyaṃ jñānagrāhakeṇaiva gṛhyate /
analyzed: jñāna gatam ca yāthārthya lakṣaṇam prāmāṇyam jñāna grāhakeṇa eva gṛhyate
translated: And the truth-concordance-characterized validity belonging to the cognition is apprehended only by the cognition-apprehender.

analyzed: jñāna grāhakaḥ ca sākṣī iti avivādam vādi prativādinoḥ
translated: And there is no dispute between the disputants that the witness is the apprehender of the cognition.

original: tathāca sākṣiṇā jñānaprāmāṇyaṃ gṛhṇatā tadviṣayasya sakalaprapañcasya traikālikābādhyatvalakṣaṇaṃ satyatvameva gṛhītaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: tathā ca sākṣiṇā jñāna prāmāṇyam gṛhṇatā tad viṣayasya sakala prapañcasya traikālika abādhya tva lakṣaṇam satya tvam eva gṛhītam bhavati
translated: And thus, when the witness apprehends the validity of the cognition, it is only the truth-characterized as non-sublation at any time, of the entire world which is the object of that [cognition] that is apprehended.

original: yadi hi jñānagocarasya nityasya vā anityasya vā sarvagatasya vā asarvagatasya vā arthasya svadeśakālaprakāropādhāvasattvā'vedanalakṣaṇo bādhaḥ
analyzed: yadi hi jñāna gocarasya nityasya vā anityasya vā sarvagatasya vā asarvagatasya vā arthasya sva deśa kāla prakāra upādhāva sattva āvedana lakṣaṇaḥ bādhaḥ
translated: For if there is sublation in the form of non-apprehension of the non-existence of the object which is the content of the cognition, whether eternal or non-eternal, all-pervading or not all-pervading, in the limiting adjuncts of its own place, time and form,

analyzed: kaḥ rthaḥ tadā jñāna prāmāṇyam sākṣiṇā pramitam iti asya iti
translated: then what is the purpose of saying that the validity of the cognition is apprehended by the witness?

original: yadi tarhi jñānasvarūpagrāhakaḥ sākṣī tatprāmāṇyamapi gṛhṇanprapañcasatyatāṃ niścinuyāt /
analyzed: yadi tarhi jñāna svarūpa grāhakaḥ sākṣī tad prāmāṇyam api gṛhṇan prapañca satyatām niścinuyāt
translated: If then the witness which is the apprehender of the form of the cognition were to apprehend its validity also, it would ascertain the truth of the world.

original: śuktirajatādijñānasvarūpagrāhako 'pi sa eveti tatprāmāṇyamapi gṛhṇan śuktirajatādikamapi satyaṃ vyavasthāpayet /
analyzed: śukti rajata ādi jñāna sva rūpa grāhakaḥ pi saḥ eva iti tad prāmāṇyam api gṛhṇan śukti rajata ādikam api satyam vyavasthāpayet
translated: He is also the apprehender of the form of the cognition of silver in a shell, etc. Therefore, apprehending its validity, he would also establish the truth of silver in a shell, etc.

analyzed: na ca śukti rajata ādi jñānānām prāmāṇyam eva na asti
translated: And it is not right to say that the cognitions of silver in a shell, etc. do not have validity at all.

analyzed: kim sākṣiṇā gṛhyatām iti yuktam
translated: How can that be grasped by the witness?

original: prapañcagocarāṇāmapi jñānānāṃ prāmāṇyābhāvātkiṃ sākṣirā gṛhyata ityapi vaktuṃ śakyatvāt /
analyzed: prapañca gocarāṇām api jñānānām prāmāṇya abhāvāt kim sākṣi rā gṛhyate iti api vaktum śakya tvāt
translated: For it can be said that even the cognitions having the world as their object do not have validity, so how can that be grasped by the witness?

original: tasmātsākṣiṇā prapañcasatyatāsiddhimabhilaṣatā jñānagrāhakasya sākṣiṇaḥ prāmāṇyagrāhakatvaṃ svabhāva iti vaktavyam /
analyzed: tasmāt sākṣiṇā prapañca satyatā siddhim abhilaṣatā jñāna grāhakasya sākṣiṇaḥ prāmāṇya grāhaka tvam svabhāvaḥ iti vaktavyam
translated: Therefore, one who desires to establish the truth of the world by the witness must say that it is the nature of the witness, which apprehends cognitions, to apprehend the validity of cognitions.

analyzed: tathā ca uktaḥ tiprasaṅgaḥ iti atas uktam adoṣa iti
translated: And thus the aforementioned absurdity is stated. Therefore it is said that it is not defective.

analyzed: ayam arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is this.

analyzed: na sākṣī jñānam gṛhṇan pramāṇam eva etat iti gṛhṇāti
translated: When the witness apprehends a cognition, it does not apprehend that it is valid.

analyzed: kintarhi atva
translated: But rather,

analyzed: doṣam ced pramāṇam sa doṣam apramāṇam iti
translated: if there is a defect, it is invalid, and if there is no defect, it is valid.

analyzed: vyavasthayā
translated: This is the determination.

original: yadā tvarthitvena prāmāṇyaṃ nirdidhārayiṣitaṃ tadā sajātīyavijātīyasaṃvādavisaṃvādabhāvābhāvalakṣaṇayā parīkṣayā doṣabhāvaṃ niścitya
analyzed: yadā tu arthi tvena prāmāṇyam nirdidhārayiṣitam tadā sajātīya vijātīya saṃvāda visaṃvāda bhāva abhāva lakṣaṇayā parīkṣayā doṣa bhāvam niścitya
translated: But when the validity is to be ascertained by the desire for the object, then, having ascertained the absence of defects by the examination characterized by the presence and absence of agreement and disagreement of the same and different kinds,

analyzed: prāmāṇyam avadhārayati tu aprāmāṇyam
translated: one determines the validity. But when the defects are seen, there is invalidity.

analyzed: prapañca pratīteḥ ca prayatnena anviṣya api doṣam a paśyan prāmāṇyam eva avadhārayati ivati tat satya tvam sākṣi siddham
translated: And because the manifestation of the world is well known, even though one may search for the defect with effort, not seeing the defect, one determines the validity itself. Thus, the truth of that is established by the witness.

analyzed: na ca evam śukti rajata ādīnām  doṣa apratīti daśāyām prāmāṇya anavadhāraṇāt
translated: But this is not so in the case of silver in a shell, etc.🔽Because in the state of non-apprehension of the defect, the validity is not ascertained.

analyzed: tad pratītau tu aprāmāṇya niścayāt
translated: But when it is apprehended, the invalidity is ascertained.

analyzed: nanu śukti rajata ādi jñānasya api prāmāṇyam nirdhāryate eva
translated: But is not the validity of the knowledge of silver in a shell, etc. also determined?

analyzed: katham anyathā niḥśaṅkā pravṛttiḥ iti ced
translated: Otherwise, how could there be action without doubt? If this is argued,

analyzed: satyam
translated: it is true.

analyzed: na asau sākṣi rūpa avadhāraṇā
translated: But that is not the determination in the form of the witness.

analyzed: api tu mānasī iti vakṣyāmaḥ
translated: Rather, we will say it is mental.

analyzed: manasaḥ ca doṣa saṃsarga sambhavena na tāvatā prāmāṇya siddhiḥ iti
translated: And because the mind can be associated with defects, the validity is not established by that alone.

original: nanu yadi parīkṣāsahakṛtaḥsākṣī jñānaprāmāṇyaṃ gṛhṇīyāt tadānavasthā syāt /
analyzed: nanu yadi parīkṣā sahakṛtaḥ sākṣī jñāna prāmāṇyam gṛhṇīyāt tadā anavasthā syāt
translated: But if the witness assisted by examination would grasp the validity of knowledge, then there would be an infinite regress.

analyzed: parīkṣā api hi svayam pramāṇa tvena avadhṛtā para prāmāṇya avadhāraṇāya alam
translated: For, indeed, an examination, which is itself ascertained to be a means of valid knowledge, is sufficient for the ascertainment of the validity of another [means of valid knowledge].

analyzed: na anyathā
translated: Not otherwise.

analyzed: tathā ca tatra api parīkṣā antaram avataraṇīyam iti
translated: And so, in that case too, another examination would have to be introduced.

original: kiñca sākṣiṇo 'pyanavadhṛtapramāṇabhāvasya svayaṃ duḥsthasya na paraprāmāṇyāvadhāraṇasamārthyamiti
analyzed: kiñca sākṣiṇaḥ api anavadhṛta pramāṇa bhāvasya svayam duḥsthasya na para prāmāṇya avadhāraṇa samārthyam iti
translated: Moreover, the witness, whose nature as a means of valid knowledge is not ascertained, is itself in a precarious position and is not capable of ascertaining the validity of another [means of valid knowledge].

analyzed: tad prāmāṇya avadhāraṇāya parīkṣā antara apekṣā grāhaka antara apekṣā ca iti anavasthā evā iti atas
translated: Therefore, for the ascertainment of its validity, there would be a dependence on another examination and another apprehender, and thus there would be an infinite regress. In response to this,

analyzed: āha parīkṣā ādeḥ ca iti
translated: he says And the truth of the examination, etc.

original: parīkṣādeśca satyatvaṃ tena hyeva mataṃ bhavet // / / //
analyzed: parīkṣā ādeḥ ca satya tvam tena hi eva matam bhavet
translated: And the truth of the examination, etc. would be accepted by that alone.

analyzed: ādi padena sākṣī gṛhyate
translated: The word etc. includes the witness.

analyzed: caḥ tu arthaḥ
translated: The word ca (and) has the meaning of tu (but).

analyzed: satya tvam yathārtha tvam
translated: Truth means being in accordance with reality.

original: tena sākṣiṇaiva kevalena na tu parīkṣāyuktenasahakṛtena /
analyzed: tena sākṣiṇā eva kevalena na tu parīkṣā yuktena sahakṛtena
translated: By that alone, by the witness alone, and not by that in association with the examination.

analyzed: hi śabdaḥ sya arthasya anubhava siddha tvam dyotayati
translated: The word hi (for) indicates that this meaning is well-established by experience.

analyzed: tasmāt na anavasthā iti hetau vā
translated: Therefore, there is no infinite regress. This is the reason.

original: etaduktaṃ bhavati /🔽doṣābhāvāvadhāraṇārthaṃ nyāyānusandhānaṃ hi khalu parīkṣā /
analyzed: etat uktam bhavati  doṣa abhāva avadhāraṇa artham nyāya anusandhānam hi khalu parīkṣā
translated: This is what is meant.🔽Indeed, the examination is the investigation of reasoning for the purpose of determining the absence of defects.

analyzed: sandigdhaḥ ca arthaḥ nyāya viṣayaḥ
translated: And a doubtful object is the subject of reasoning.

analyzed: sandehaḥ ca ubhaya koṭi prāpaka sadbhāve bhavati
translated: And doubt arises when there is the possibility of both alternatives being true.

original: evañca yatra yatra doṣasambhāvanayā tatsandehastatra tatraiva parīkṣāpekṣā nānyatra /
analyzed: evam ca yatra yatra doṣa sambhāvanayā tad sandehaḥ tatra tatra eva parīkṣā apekṣā na anyatra
translated: And thus, where there is doubt due to the possibility of error, there alone is the need for examination, not elsewhere.

analyzed: na ca sarvatra doṣa sandehaḥ sti
translated: And there is no doubt of error everywhere.

analyzed: sākṣi siddhe rthe tad prāpti abhāvāt
translated: Because in a matter established by the witness, there is no possibility of its occurrence.

analyzed: atas na tāvat parīkṣā anavasthā
translated: Therefore, there is no infinite regress of examination.

analyzed: tathā hi
translated: To explain:

original: astyatra purataḥ pānīyamiti vākyaṃ śrutavato bhavati sandehaḥ kimidaṃ viparyayādimūlamuta neti /
analyzed: asti atra puratas pānīyam iti vākyam śrutavataḥ bhavati sandehaḥ kim idam viparyaya ādi mūlam uta na iti
translated: When one hears the statement There is water here in front, there arises doubt as to whether this is based on error or not.

analyzed: puruṣa vacasām ubhayathā darśanāt
translated: Because the words of men are seen to be of both kinds.

original: tata evārthe sandihānaḥ pratyāsīdan rūpaviśeṣādinānuminoti pānīyametaditi /
analyzed: tatas eva arthe sandihānaḥ pratyāsīdan rūpa viśeṣa ādinā anuminoti pānīyam etat iti
translated: Suspecting the matter to be so, he approaches and infers by means of specific forms etc. that this is water.

analyzed: tatra api bhavati saṃśayaḥ
translated: Even there, doubt arises.

analyzed: kim idam anumānam uta ābhāsam saḥ iti  vyāpti ādi grāhiṇām yāthārthya a yāthārthya upalambhāt
translated: As to whether this is inference or semblance of inference.🔽Because the perception of the apprehenders of pervasion etc. is seen to be both true and false.

analyzed: pratyāsannaḥ ca udaka abhyavahāra anantaram rasa viśeṣāṇā anumāya api pūrvavat sandigdhe
translated: And one who is approaching, even after inferring the specific taste of water, is doubtful as before.

analyzed: pīta udakaḥ tu udanyā ādi nimitta duḥkha abhāvam sukham ca anubhavan na tatra saṃśete
translated: But one who has drunk water experiences the absence of pain caused by hunger etc. and pleasure, and does not doubt there.

analyzed: sukha ādau tad abhāve ca sākṣi siddhe kadāpi anyathābhāva ādi anupalambhāt
translated: Because in pleasure etc. and its absence, which are established by the witness, there is never the apprehension of any other nature etc.

analyzed: na ca pratīta tva sāmānyena tatra api saṃśayaḥ
translated: And there is no doubt even there by the general fact of being known.

analyzed: viśeṣa niṣṭhasya niścāyakasya sadbhāvāt
translated: Because there exists a determiner confined to the particular.

analyzed: anyathā saṃśaya anucchedena vyavahāra abhāva prasaṅgāt
translated: Otherwise, there would be the undesirable consequence of the absence of worldly activity due to the non-cessation of doubt.

original: saṃśayābhāve ca na tatpūrvikā parīkṣeti kuto 'navasthā /
analyzed: saṃśaya abhāve ca na tad pūrvikā parīkṣā iti kutas navasthā
translated: And in the absence of doubt, there is no examination preceded by that. So how can there be an infinite regress?

analyzed: atas eva sākṣa prāmāṇya avadhāraṇe parīkṣā anavasthā api parihṛtā
translated: For this very reason, the infinite regress in the ascertainment of the validity of perception is also avoided.

analyzed: grāhaka anavasthā tu na asti eva
translated: But there is no infinite regress of the apprehender.

analyzed: sākṣiṇaḥ sva prakāśa tvena sva prāmāṇya grāhaka tvāt
translated: Because the witness is self-luminous and is the apprehender of its own validity.

analyzed: etāvān atra viśeṣaḥ
translated: There is only this much difference here.

original: indriyaliṅgaśabdajanyeṣu jñāneṣvanādau saṃsāre dvayīṃ gatimanusandadhatsākṣī na sahasaiva pramāṇametaditi niścetuṃ śaknoti /
analyzed: indriya liṅga śabda janyeṣu jñāneṣu anādau saṃsāre dvayīm gatim anusandadhat sākṣī na sahasā eva pramāṇam etat iti niścetum śaknoti
translated: In the cognitions produced by sense organs, inferential marks, and words, the witness, considering the two courses in beginningless worldly existence, is not able to ascertain suddenly that this is valid knowledge.

analyzed: kintu  doṣa abhāvam ca na svayam eva
translated: But only through the ascertainment of the absence of defects.

analyzed: avadhārayitum īṣye
translated: And the absence of defects is not to be determined by itself alone.

analyzed: api kim tu parīkṣā sahakṛtaḥ eva
translated: But only in association with examination.

original: parīkṣāyāṃ cendriyaliṅgaśabdajāyāṃ pūrvanyāyena parīkṣāntaramanusarati yāvatsākṣātsvaviṣaye sukhādāvavatarati /🔽naca svātmanyanena kadāpyanyathābhāvo 'vagata iti sandehābhāvātparīkṣānusaraṇānnivartate /
analyzed: parīkṣāyām ca indriya liṅga śabda jāyām pūrva nyāyena parīkṣā antaram anusarati yāvat sākṣāt sva viṣaye sukha ādau avatarati  na ca sva ātmani anena kadāpi anyathābhāvaḥ vagataḥ iti sandeha abhāvāt parīkṣā anusaraṇāt nivartate
translated: And in the case of the examination by the senses, by inference, and by verbal testimony, he follows another examination in the same way as before, until he comes to the direct perception of his own object, such as pleasure, etc.🔽And since it is never found that this (direct perception) is otherwise than it is in itself, there is no doubt, and therefore he does not turn back from following the examination.

original: nahi jñānasvarūpaṃ prāmāṇyaṃ ca viṣayīkartuṃ svamahimnaiva śaknoti /
analyzed: nahi jñāna svarūpam prāmāṇyam ca viṣayīkartum sva mahimnā eva śaknoti
translated: For the form of knowledge and its validity cannot be made the object of knowledge by its own power.

original: tasya tu mānasyā doṣaśaṅkayā prāmāṇyagrahaṇaśaktiḥ pratibaddhā /
analyzed: tasya tu mānasyā doṣa śaṅkayā prāmāṇya grahaṇa śaktiḥ pratibaddhā
translated: But the power of the mind to apprehend validity is obstructed by the suspicion of defects.

analyzed: atas vyavasthā eva tat spṛśati
translated: Therefore, the determination (of validity) alone touches it.

analyzed: na tu avadhāraṇasya iṣye
translated: But not the ascertainment (of validity).

original: parīkṣayā ca pratibandhe 'pagate nijayaiva śaktyā prāmāṇyamavadhārayati /
analyzed: parīkṣayā ca pratibandhe nijayā eva śaktyā prāmāṇyam avadhārayati
translated: And when the obstruction is removed by the examination, it ascertains validity by its own power alone.

original: nacāsya vyutpādanasyāprāmāṇye 'pi samatvāttasyāpi svato grahaṇamiti vācyam /
analyzed: na ca asya vyutpādanasya aprāmāṇye sama tvāt tasya api svatas grahaṇam iti vācyam
translated: And it should not be said that even in the case of the teaching of the Veda, the apprehension of its validity is the same, since it is not valid,

analyzed: vaiṣamyāt  prāmāṇya avadhāraṇe hi parīkṣāyāḥ pratibandhaka nivartaka tva mātram śakyate vadhārayitum
translated: because of the inequality (of the two cases).🔽For in the ascertainment of validity, it is only possible to ascertain that the examination merely removes the obstruction.
Because when the validity of the witness is apprehended without the obstruction, it is not required.

analyzed: sahakāri tve hi sarvatra tad apekṣā syāt
translated: For if it were a cooperating cause, it would be dependent on that everywhere.

analyzed: tathā ca anavasthā iti uktam
translated: And thus the infinite regress has been stated.

analyzed: anyathā kāraṇa tvam vyāhanyeta
translated: And otherwise, the causal nature would be contradicted.

original: na cāprāmāṇyaṃ kvāpi parīkṣānapekṣeṇa sākṣiṇā niścitacaram /
analyzed: na ca aprāmāṇyam kvāpi parīkṣā anapekṣeṇa sākṣiṇā niścita caram
translated: And non-authoritativeness is not ascertained anywhere by the witness that does not depend on examination.

analyzed: yena pratibandhaka nivartaka tvam tasyāḥ pratīmaḥ
translated: By which we understand its nature as the remover of the obstruction.

analyzed: kintu sārvatrika tvāt kāraṇa tvam eva
translated: But rather, it is a cause everywhere, because it is universal.

analyzed: pratibandhakasya sārvatrika tvāt anyathā asiddham sārvatrika tvam iti ced na
translated: If it be said that its universality is otherwise established because the obstruction is universal, it is not so.

analyzed: haṇe ca parīkṣāyāḥ kāraṇa tva upapatteḥ
translated: Because in the cessation of the obstruction, the cause of the ascertainment of non-authoritativeness is established.

analyzed: evam sati gauravam iti ced na
translated: If it be said that in this case there is complexity, it is not so.

analyzed: viśeṣa avadhāraṇāyāḥ aśakya tvasya eva kalpaka abhāvāt  tathā api
translated: Because there is no reason for the impossibility of the determination of the particular.

analyzed: tvasya anyathā asiddhiḥ śaṅkayataḥ iti ced na
translated: If it be said that even so, the universality of the concomitance and non-concomitance of examination is suspected to be otherwise established, it is not so.

analyzed: pratibandhakasya sārvatrika tāyāḥ kvāpi adarśanena anyathāsiddhi śaṅkā nirāsāt
translated: Because the suspicion of otherwise establishment is removed by the non-observation of universality anywhere of the obstruction.

analyzed: anyathā sarvatra sahakāriṇām tathātvam syāt
translated: Otherwise, everywhere the cooperating causes would be so.

original: yadi jñānagrāhakātiriktasya yathākathamapi praveśātprāmāṇyasya paratastvamiti matam /
analyzed: yadi jñāna grāhaka atiriktasya yathā katham api praveśāt prāmāṇyasya paratas tvam iti matam
translated: If it is held that the extrinsicality of validity is due to the admission in some way or other of something other than the cognition of the cognition,

original: tadā sākṣiṇa eva svataḥprāmāṇyamanyasya parata ityaṅgīkāre 'pi na kaścidvirodha iti saṅkṣepaḥ /🔽vistarastu svayameva
analyzed: tadā sākṣiṇaḥ eva svatas prāmāṇyam anyasya paratas iti aṅgīkāre pi na kaścid virodhaḥ iti saṅkṣepaḥ  vistaraḥ tu svayam eva
translated: then, even if it is admitted that the validity of the latter is self-sufficient, while that of the former is extrinsic, there is no contradiction at all. This is the upshot.

analyzed: ācāryeṇa vakṣyate
translated: The details will be stated by the teacher himself.

analyzed: atha matam
translated: Now, it is argued:

analyzed: sākṣī pratyakṣa ādīnām prāmāṇyam gṛhṇan api katipaya kāla katipaya puruṣa sambandhi bandhi vaidhurya rūpam eva
translated: Even when the witness grasps the validity of perception, etc., it is only in the form of the absence of bondage in some persons for some time.

original: na punarasya kadācitkutrāpi kenāpi svārthavyabhicāro na bhaviṣyatītyevaṃrūpam /
analyzed: na punar asya kadācid kutra api kena api sva artha vyabhicāraḥ na bhaviṣyati iti evaṃrūpam
translated: But not in the form that there will never be any failure of its object anywhere by anyone.

analyzed: tat katham tena ātyantika bādhā abhāva lakṣaṇam satya tvam viśvasya
translated: How then can it establish the truth of the universe, which consists in the absence of ultimate contradiction?

original: siddhayedityata āha anyatheti //🔽anyathā śrutiyuktayādipramāṇaiśca sahaiva tu /
analyzed: siddhayet iti atas āha anyathā iti  anyathā śruti yuktayā ādi pramāṇaiḥ ca saha eva tu
translated: To this he says 'otherwise', etc.

original: akasmād vinivṛttiśca kiṃ viśvasya na śaṅkayate // / / //
analyzed: akasmāt vinivṛttiḥ ca kim viśvasya na śaṅkayate
translated: Otherwise, why is the sudden cessation of the universe not suspected along with the scriptures, reasonings, etc.?

original: sākṣiṇaḥ sarvathā bādhavaidhurvalakṣaṇaprāmāṇyāgrāhakatve viśvasya pūrṇasya brahmaṇo 'pi prapañcavadvinivṛttiḥ kiṃ kasmānna śaṅkayate /
analyzed: sākṣiṇaḥ sarvathā bādha vaidhurva lakṣaṇa prāmāṇya a grāhaka tve viśvasya pūrṇasya brahmaṇaḥ pi prapañca vat vinivṛttiḥ kim kasmāt na śaṅkayate
translated: If witnesses do not apprehend the validity characterized by the absence of contradiction and confusion in any way, why is the complete Brahman not suspected of cessation like the world?

analyzed: nivartaka abhāvāt iti atas uktam akasmāt iti  nanu ca satyam jñānam tat satyam  ityādi śrutyā
translated: It is said without any reason to avoid the objection that it is because there is no means of cessation.

original: brahma na nivṛttimat ajñānatatkāryātiriktatvāt ityādyanumānena /🔽niradhiṣṭhānakasyāsākṣikasya bhramasya /
analyzed: brahma na nivṛttimat ajñāna tad kārya atirikta tvāt ityādi anumānena  niradhiṣṭhānakasya asākṣikasya bhramasya
translated: But is it not true that Brahman is not subject to cessation, because it is different from ignorance and its effects, as shown by the inference?🔽And because a delusion without a basis, without a witness,

analyzed: niravadhikasya bādhasya ca adarśanāt prapañca āropa ādi anyathā anupapattyā
translated: and a contradiction without a limit are not seen, and because it is not possible for the world to be otherwise than the product of Brahman,

analyzed: brahmaṇaḥ satyatā avagamāt tat na iti atas uktam śruti iti
translated: it is understood that Brahman is true. Therefore it is said the scriptures.

analyzed: eteṣām api pramāṇānām pratyakṣa ādīnām iva vinivṛttiḥ śaṅkayatām iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the cessation of these means of knowledge, beginning with perception, should be suspected.

analyzed: etat uktam bhavati
translated: This is what is said.

original: prapañcaviṣayāṇāṃ pratyakṣādipramāṇānāṃ nātyantikaṃ prāmāṇyaṃ sākṣī gṛhṇāti /
analyzed: prapañca viṣayāṇām pratyakṣa ādi pramāṇānām na ātyantikam prāmāṇyam sākṣī gṛhṇāti
translated: The witness does not apprehend the absolute validity of the means of knowledge such as perception, etc. which have the world as their object,

analyzed: kintu tātkālikam eva
translated: but only the temporary validity.

analyzed: iti vadan vaktavyaḥ
translated: Saying this, he should be asked:🔽What is the reason for the cessation of the means of knowledge?

analyzed: sākṣiṇaḥ kim ātyantika prāmāṇya grahaṇe śaktiḥ asti uta na asti
translated: Do the witnesses have the power to apprehend the absolute validity of the Vedas, or do they not?

original: ādye kathaṃ prapañcaviṣayāṇāṃ pratyakṣādīnāṃ prāmāṇyamātyantikaṃ na gṛhṇīyāt /
analyzed: ādye katham prapañca viṣayāṇām pratyakṣa ādīnām prāmāṇyam ātyantikam na gṛhṇīyāt
translated: If the former, then how could they not apprehend the absolute validity of perception and other means of knowledge which have the world as their object?

original: dvitīye brahmaṇaḥ satyatāpratipādakānāṃ śrutyādīnāmapi nātyantikaṃ prāmāṇyaṃ gṛhṇīyāt /
analyzed: dvitīye brahmaṇaḥ satya tā pratipādakānām śruti ādīnām api na ātyantikam prāmāṇyam gṛhṇīyāt
translated: If the latter, then they would not apprehend the absolute validity of the scriptures etc. which teach the truth of Brahman.

analyzed: tathāca na brahmaṇaḥ bādhya tvam ātyantikam siddhayet
translated: And thus the absolute non-sublation of Brahman would not be established.

analyzed: tatas ca sādhaka bādhaka pramāṇa abhāvāt tasya api bādhaḥ śaṅkayeta
translated: And then, in the absence of means of knowledge to prove or disprove it, its sublation also could be suspected.

original: evaṃca tajjñānamapi na tattvajñānamiti na tadarthaḥ prayatnaḥ syāt /
analyzed: evaṃca tat jñānam api na tattva jñānam iti na tad arthaḥ prayatnaḥ syāt
translated: And thus that knowledge also would not be the knowledge of reality, and so effort for that purpose would not be proper.

original: atha kvacicchaktiḥ kvacinneti brūyāttadā niyāmakaṃ vācyamiti / /
analyzed: atha kvacid śaktiḥ kvacid na iti brūyāt tadā niyāmakam vācyam iti
translated: If, on the other hand, one were to say that there is power in some cases and not in others, then a determining factor would have to be stated.

original: nanu yadi brahma bādhārhaṃ syāttarhīyatā kālena kuto na nivṛttam /
analyzed: nanu yadi brahma bādhā arham syāt tarhi īyatā kālena kutas na nivṛttam
translated: But if Brahman were liable to sublation, then why did it not cease to exist at that time?

original: tasmāditaḥpūrvaṃ bādharahitatvānnottaratrāpi bādhaḥ śaṅkayata iti cenna /
analyzed: tasmāt itas pūrvam bādha rahita tvāt na uttaratra api bādhaḥ śaṅkayate iti ced na
translated: Therefore, since it is free from sublation prior to this, sublation cannot be suspected even later. If this is said, it is not so.

analyzed: ukta uttara tvāt
translated: Because the answer has been given.

analyzed: asyāḥ api upapatteḥ sākṣi grāhya pramāṇa bhāvāyāḥ ātyantika prāmāṇya asiddheḥ
translated: Because this is also possible, the absolute validity of the means of knowledge apprehended by the witness is not established.

analyzed: anyathā prapañca grāhiṇām pratyakṣa ādīnām api tathātvasya anivāraṇāt
translated: Otherwise, even perception etc. grasping the world would not be excluded from being so.

analyzed: vyavasthāpaka abhāvāt
translated: Because there is no establishing factor.

analyzed: dūṣaṇa antaram āha itas pūrvam iti
translated: He states another fault, beginning with before this.

original: itaḥ pūrvaṃ tathābhāvād yadi no saṃsṛtergatiḥ // / / //
analyzed: itas pūrvam tathābhāvāt yadi no saṃsṛteḥ gatiḥ
translated: If there is no cessation of worldly existence before this due to non-existence,

analyzed: tathābhāvāt nivṛtti abhāvāt
translated: due to non-existence, due to non-cessation.

original: yadi brahmaṇo nivṛttinar śaṅkayata iti sambandhaḥ /
analyzed: yadi śaṅkayate iti sambandhaḥ
translated: If one doubts the cessation of Brahman, is the relation.

analyzed: tarhi iti adhyāhāraḥ
translated: Then is to be supplied.

analyzed: gatiḥ nivṛttiḥ syāt iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The remainder is there would be cessation, i.e. non-cessation.

analyzed: ayam āśayaḥ
translated: This is the idea.

analyzed: itas pūrvam anivṛtta tvāt iti kim brahmaṇaḥ nivṛtti abhāve sambhāvanā ukta tā anumānam
translated: Is this an inference stated as a possibility due to the non-cessation of Brahman before this,

analyzed: na ādyaḥ
translated: The first is not so.

analyzed: sambhāvanāyāḥ api saṃśaya rūpa tvena śaṅkā nivāraṇa a sāmarthyāt
translated: Because even possibility, being of the nature of doubt, is not capable of excluding doubt.

analyzed: na dvitīyaḥ
translated: The second is not so.

analyzed: tathā sati saṃsṛteḥ avidyāyāḥ nivṛtti abhāva prasaṅgāt
translated: Because in that case, there would be the undesirable consequence of the non-cessation of worldly existence, i.e. ignorance.

analyzed: na hi itas prāk mūla avidyā nivṛttā
translated: For the primordial ignorance before this has not ceased.

analyzed: anyathā tasyām eva vyabhicāraḥ syāt iti
translated: Otherwise, there would be an exception to that itself.

analyzed: kiñca śukti rajata ādikam prāk anivṛttam eva nivartate
translated: Moreover, the silver in a shell etc. ceases even before it has ceased.

analyzed: nivṛttasya nivṛtti ayogāt
translated: Because what has ceased cannot cease again.

analyzed: atas viruddha tā ca
translated: Therefore, there is also contradiction.

analyzed: anyathā ityādi anyathā vyākhyāyate
translated: Otherwise, etc. is explained differently.
Otherwise, if the witness does not grasp the absolute validity of the perception, etc. that grasps the world,

original: viśvasya viyadāderuttarakṣaṇa eva nivṛttirvināśaḥ kiṃ na śaṅkayate /
analyzed: viśvasya viyat ādeḥ uttara kṣaṇe eva nivṛttiḥ vināśaḥ kim na śaṅkayate
translated: why is the destruction, i.e. cessation, of the world, i.e. of ether, etc., not suspected even in the next moment?

analyzed: tathā ca sarva pravṛtti vilayaḥ syāt
translated: And thus there would be the dissolution of all activity.

analyzed: parameśvara sañjihīrṣā ādi abhāvāt iti atas uktam akasmāt iti
translated: Because there is no desire, etc. on the part of the Supreme Lord, it is said: suddenly.

analyzed: pṛṣṭhe draṣṭavyam
translated: The word anu (after) should be seen.

analyzed: nanu īśvara icchayā eva śruti smṛti itihāsa purāṇāni prapañca pralayam pratipādayanti
translated: But the scriptures, traditions, histories and puranas, by the will of God, teach the dissolution of the world.

analyzed: viśva vināśaḥ na nirhetukaḥ vināśa tvāt paṭa nāśa vat iti anumānam api
translated: And there is also an inference: the destruction of the universe is not without a cause, because it is a destruction, like the destruction of a cloth.

analyzed: tat katham evam śaṅkayate iti atas uktam śruti iti
translated: How then can it be suspected in this way? To this it is said: the scriptures, etc.
The cessation of the means of knowledge is the absolute absence of validity.

analyzed: tātparyam pūvar vat  nanu prāk itas na prapañca vi  kasmāt abhūt
translated: The purport is as before.🔽But before this, the dissolution of the world did not occur suddenly.

analyzed: tat katham uttaratra api śaṅkayeta iti atas uktam
translated: How can it be suspected even later? To this it is said:

analyzed: āha itas pūrvam iti
translated: It is said: before this.

original: kimatra yatpūrvaṃ nābhūttaduttaratrāpi na bhaviṣyatīti vyāptiḥ /
analyzed: kim atra yat pūrvam na abhūt tat uttaratra api na bhaviṣyati iti vyāptiḥ
translated: Is it the pervasion that what did not exist before will not exist later either?🔽Or is it that what was previously destroyed without a cause will not be destroyed in that way later either?

original: kiṃvā yatpūrvaṃ na nirhetukaṃ vinaṣṭaṃ na taduttaratrāpi tathā vināśavaditi /🔽yadvā yannirhetukaṃ na tadbhaviṣyatīti vyāptiḥ /
analyzed: kiṃvā yat pūrvam na nirhetukam vinaṣṭam na tat uttaratra api tathā vināśa vat iti  yat vā yat nirhetukam na tat bhaviṣyati iti vyāptiḥ
translated: Or is the pervasion that what is without a cause will not exist?

analyzed: pūrva uktiḥ tu tad upapādanāya iti
translated: But the previous statement is for the purpose of establishing that.

analyzed: na ādyaḥ
translated: The first is not so.

analyzed: saṃsṛteḥ avidyāyāḥ nivṛtti abhāva prasaṅgāt
translated: Because it would lead to the undesirable consequence that the cessation of ignorance in the cycle of birth and death would not occur.

analyzed: na dvitīyaḥ
translated: The second is not so.

analyzed: saṃsāra nivṛtti prasaṅgāt
translated: Because it would lead to the undesirable consequence that the cycle of birth and death would cease.

analyzed: tathā hi
translated: It is like this.
Knowledge is the cause of the cessation of the cycle of birth and death.

analyzed: sā api avidyā ātmaka tvāt saṃsṛtiḥ eva
translated: That too is the cycle of birth and death itself because it has ignorance as its nature.

analyzed: na ca tasyāḥ nivartaka antaram asti
translated: And there is no other cause of its cessation.

original: tathācākasmātkimapi na nivartata ityaṅgīkāre no saṃsṛtergatiḥ /
analyzed: tathā ca akasmāt kim api na nivartate iti aṅgīkāre no saṃsṛteḥ gatiḥ
translated: And thus, if it is accepted that nothing ceases without a cause, there is no way out of the cycle of birth and death.

original: vidyā svayameva svanivṛttiheturavidyāmātravirodhitvāditi cenna /🔽evaṃ tarhi prapañco 'pyuttarakṣaṇe svayameva
analyzed: vidyā svayam eva sva nivṛtti hetuḥ avidyā mātra virodhi tvāt iti ced na  evam tarhi prapañcaḥ pi uttara kṣaṇe svayam eva
translated: If it is argued that knowledge itself is the cause of its own cessation because it is only opposed to ignorance, that is not so.

analyzed: nivartiṣyate iti śaṅkā syāt
translated: If so, then the doubt would arise that the world itself will cease by itself in the next moment.

analyzed: atas eva na tṛtīyaḥ pi iti
translated: For this very reason, the third is not so either.

analyzed: uktam eva artham vivṛṇoti vākya iti
translated: He explains the very same meaning with the words statement and so on.

analyzed: vākya anumāditaḥ ced syāt tad prāmāṇyam ca sākṣitaḥ
translated: If it were from the inference of the statement, then the validity of that would be from the witness.

analyzed: athavā no saṃsṛteḥ gatiḥ iti uktam
translated: Or it has been said that there is no way out of saṃsāra.

analyzed: saṃsāra gateḥ śruti ādi siddha tvāt
translated: Because the way out of saṃsāra is established by scripture etc.,

analyzed: tad asiddhayā ca hetoḥ viśeṣaṇāt iti atas āha vākya iti
translated: and because the reason is qualified by the non-establishment of that. Therefore he says 'from the statement' etc.

original: brahmaṇo 'pi nivṛttyāśaṅkāyāmāpāditāyāṃ yadi paro vākyānumādito nivṛttyabhāvaniścayaḥ syāditi brūyāt /
analyzed: nivṛtti āśaṅkāyām āpāditāyām yadi paraḥ vākya anumāditaḥ nivṛtti abhāva niścayaḥ syāt iti brūyāt
translated: If, when the doubt of cessation of Brahman is raised, the opponent were to say that there would be certainty of the absence of cessation from the inference of the statement,

original: yadi vā ākasmikottarakṣaṇe pralayaśaṅkāpādane vākyānumāditaḥ parameśvarecchādinaiva syāditi manyeta /
analyzed: yadi vā ākasmika uttara kṣaṇe pralaya śaṅkā āpādane vākya anumāditaḥ parameśvara icchā ādinā eva syāt iti manyeta
translated: or if he were to think that in the raising of the doubt of dissolution in the next moment, it would be only by the will etc. of the Supreme Lord from the inference of the statement,

original: yadi ca vākyānumāditaḥ saṃsāranivṛttiḥ syāditi vadet /
analyzed: yadi ca vākya anumāditaḥ saṃsāra nivṛttiḥ syāt iti vadet
translated: and if he were to say that the cessation of saṃsāra would be from the inference of the statement,

original: tadā tasya vākyādeḥ prāmāṇyaṃ kena niścitamiti vaktavyam /
analyzed: tadā tasya vākya ādeḥ prāmāṇyam kena niścitam iti vaktavyam
translated: then it should be said by whom is the validity of that statement etc. ascertained.

original: sākṣītareṇetyaṅgīkāre jñānasya sākṣivedyatvena parataḥ prāmāṇyagrahāpatteḥ sākṣiṇaiveti vaktavyam / /
analyzed: sākṣī itareṇa iti aṅgīkāre jñānasya sākṣi vedya tvena paratas prāmāṇya graha āpatteḥ sākṣiṇā eva iti vaktavyam
translated: If it is accepted that it is by another, then because knowledge is known by the witness, the apprehension of validity from another would follow. Therefore it should be said that it is by the witness itself.

analyzed: tatas kim iti ced
translated: If it is asked what then,

original: sākṣī kiṃ brahmasatyatvādipratipādakānāṃ vākyādīnāṃ prāmāṇyaṃ tātkālikameva gṛhṇāti kiṃvā'tyantikam /
analyzed: sākṣī kim brahma satya tva ādi pratipādakānām vākya ādīnām prāmāṇyam tātkālikam eva gṛhṇāti kiṃvā ātyantikam
translated: Does the witness accept the validity of the statements etc. that teach the truth of Brahman etc. only for the present time, or eternally?

original: ādye na tena brahmābādhyatvādisiddhiriti noktaśaṅkānivṛttiḥ /🔽dvitīye tvāha tatprāmāṇyamiti //
analyzed: dvitīye tu āha tat prāmāṇyam iti
translated: If the first, then Brahman is not established to be unnegatable etc. by that, so the doubt stated is not removed.

analyzed: tad prāmāṇyam yathā sākṣī sthāpayati evam eva hi
translated: If the second, he says: As the witness establishes the validity of that, so indeed,

analyzed: sarva kāleṣu api sthairyāt vyabhicāram apohya ca
translated: By the stability in all times and by removing the deviation,

analyzed: evam akṣa jamāna tva siddhām viśvasya satya tām
translated: Thus the truth of the universe established by the witness,

analyzed: kim iti sthāpayet na ayam
translated: Why would he not establish it?

analyzed: yathā śabdasya atra uttaratra ca sambandhaḥ
translated: The word yathā is connected here and later.

original: tasya brahmasatyatvādipratipādakavākyādeḥ prāmāṇyaṃ yathā sākṣī vartamānakālīnaṃ sthāpayati gṛhṇāti /
analyzed: tasya brahma satya tva ādi pratipādaka vākya ādeḥ prāmāṇyam yathā sākṣī vartamāna kālīnam sthāpayati gṛhṇāti
translated: As the witness establishes, i.e., accepts, the validity of the statements etc. that teach the truth of Brahman etc. as pertaining to the present time,

analyzed: evam eva sarva kāleṣu api sthairyeṇa gṛhṇāti
translated: so indeed he accepts it by stability in all times.

analyzed: hi śabdaḥ para prasiddhi dyotakaḥ
translated: The word hi indicates the well-known fact of others.

analyzed: sthairyam eva vivṛṇoti
translated: He explains the stability itself.

analyzed: vyabhicāram bādham apohya nirākṛtya eva iti
translated: By removing, i.e., rejecting, the deviation, i.e., the contradiction.

original: na kevalaṃ brahmasatyatvatvādivākyādiprāmāṇyaṃ sākṣī tātkālikaṃ gṛhṇāti kintvātyantikamevetyarthaḥ / /
analyzed: na kevalam brahma satya tva tva ādi vākya ādi prāmāṇyam sākṣī tātkālikam gṛhṇāti kintu ātyantikam eva iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is not only that the witness grasps the present validity of the statements about Brahman's truth, etc., but that it grasps it eternally.

analyzed: athavā yathā śabdasya uttareṇa eva sambandhaḥ
translated: Or, the word 'yathā' is connected only with the following.

analyzed: sthāpayati āntikam eva gṛhṇāti iti arthaḥ  asya eva vivaraṇam evam eva iti
translated: The meaning is that it establishes, i.e., grasps eternally.🔽The explanation of this very [word] is 'in this way'.

analyzed: iti śabdaḥ dhyāhāryaḥ
translated: The word 'iti' should be supplied.

original: sarvakāleṣvapīdamevameva na kadāpi viṣayāpahāralakṣaṇaṃ bādhamāpnotīti vyabhicāramapohya tata eva sthairyeṇa gṛhṇātīti /
analyzed: sarva kāleṣu api idam evam eva na kadāpi viṣaya apahāra lakṣaṇam bādham āpnoti iti vyabhicāram apohya tatas eva sthairyeṇa gṛhṇāti iti
translated: Even in all times, this is just so, and never at any time does it undergo contradiction in the form of the removal of the object. Thus, avoiding error, it grasps through that very stability.

analyzed: yat vā evam śabdaḥ samuccaye
translated: The word 'va' (in fact) is for addition.

analyzed: sākṣī brahma ādi viṣaya vākya ādi prāmāṇyam sthāpayati ātyantikam gṛhṇāti
translated: The witness establishes, i.e., grasps eternally, the validity of the statements about Brahman, etc.

original: ata eva tadviṣayamapi brahmādikaṃ sarvakāleṣvapi sthairyādatiśayena vyabhicāramapohyaiva sthāpayatīti /🔽prāmāṇyātyantikatvā
analyzed: atas eva tad viṣayam api brahma ādikam sarva kāleṣu api sthairyāt atiśayena vyabhicāram apohya eva sthāpayati iti  prāmāṇya ātyantika tvā
translated: For this very reason, it also establishes, i.e., avoids error, through stability, even in all times, with regard to Brahman, etc., which are the objects, in an exceptional way.

analyzed: ntargata tvāt viṣaya abādhya tāyāḥ iti hi śabda atharḥ
translated: Because the non-sublation of the object is included within the eternality of validity, this is the meaning of the word 'hi'.

analyzed: evam iti dārṣyāntika uktiḥ
translated: 'In this way' is the statement of the opponent.

original: ayaṃ sākṣī yadi tatsatyamityādipramāṇaprāmāṇyamātyantikaṃ gṛhṇan tadviṣayasya brahmādestraikālikābādhyatvaṃ
analyzed: ayam sākṣī yadi tat satyam ityādi pramāṇa prāmāṇyam ātyantikam gṛhṇan tad viṣayasya brahma ādeḥ traikālika abādhya tvam
translated: If one accepts the absolute validity of the means of valid knowledge such as this is the witness, if that is true, etc., then the Brahman etc. which are the objects of that [means of valid knowledge] are not to be negated at any time.

analyzed: vyavasthāpayet tarhi tathā eva viśva viṣayasya akṣaja ādi jñānasya ātyantikam prāmāṇyam gṛhṇan
translated: If the witness, accepting the absolute validity of the means of knowledge such as this is true if he is the witness, establishes the non-obstructedness in the three times of Brahman, etc., which are the objects of that [means of knowledge], then he would indeed accept the absolute validity of the knowledge such as that produced by the senses, which has the universe as its object,

analyzed: tad antargatām viśvasya abādhya tām api sthāpayet eva
translated: and would also establish the non-obstructedness of the universe included in that [knowledge].

analyzed: t aviśeṣāt iti samudāya arthaḥ
translated: The meaning of the whole [argument] is that there is no distinction [between the two cases].

analyzed: nanu gṛhṇātu ātyantikam prāmāṇyam akṣaja ādīnām sākṣī
translated: But let the witness accept the absolute validity of the knowledge produced by the senses, etc.

analyzed: tasya tathātvam tu kutas
translated: But how is that [absolute validity] of the witness established?

analyzed: tatas ca na viśva satyatā siddhiḥ iti atas āha nirdoṣa iti
translated: And therefore the truth of the universe is not established. To this he says faultless, etc.
From the power of the faultless knowledge [of the witness], etc.

analyzed: sākṣiṇaḥ nirdoṣa jñāna rūpa tva śaktyā tathātvam api siddhayati
translated: By the power of the witness being of the form of faultless knowledge, that [absolute validity] is also established.

analyzed: anyathā brahma satya tva ādi api na
translated: Otherwise, even the truth of Brahman would not be established.

analyzed: yat vā tat satyam ityādeḥ ātyantikam prāmāṇyam gṛhṇāti sākṣī
translated: Or, the witness accepts the absolute validity of that is true, etc.,

original: viśvaviṣayasyākṣajādestu tātkālikameveti kiṃ na syādityata āha nirdoṣeti //
analyzed: viśva viṣayasya akṣaja ādeḥ tu tātkālikam eva iti kim na syāt iti atas āha nirdoṣa iti
translated: but the knowledge produced by the senses, etc., which has the universe as its object, has only temporary [validity]. Why should this not be so? To this he says faultless, etc.

analyzed: ayam arthaḥ
translated: This is the meaning [of the verse].

original: tatsatyamityādijñānasyātyantikaṃ prāmāṇyaṃ gṛhṇāti sākṣītyatra kiṃ nimittam /
analyzed: tat satyam ityādi jñānasya ātyantikam prāmāṇyam gṛhṇāti sākṣī iti atra kim nimittam
translated: What is the reason for the witness to grasp the absolute validity of the knowledge That is true etc.?

original: jñānaṃ gṛhṇan tasya nirdoṣatāyāṃ prāmāṇyamapi gṛhṇātīti sākṣiṇaḥ svabhāvo 'yamiti cet /
analyzed: jñānam gṛhṇan tasya nirdoṣa tāyām prāmāṇyam api gṛhṇāti iti sākṣiṇaḥ svabhāvaḥ yam iti ced
translated: If it is argued that in grasping the knowledge, it also grasps its validity as being faultless, this is the nature of the witness.

original: kathaṃ tarhyakṣajāderapi ātyantikaṃ prāmāṇyaṃ na gṛhṇīyāt /
analyzed: katham tarhi akṣaja ādeḥ api ātyantikam prāmāṇyam na gṛhṇīyāt
translated: Then how can it not grasp the absolute validity of what is produced by the senses etc.?
Because that also has the form of faultless knowledge.

analyzed: śakti sadbhāvāt iti
translated: Because of the existence of the power.

original: athavā kiṃ sākṣī kutrāpi prāmāṇyamātyantikaṃ grahītuṃ na śaknoti /
analyzed: athavā kim sākṣī kutra api prāmāṇyam ātyantikam grahītum na śaknoti
translated: Or rather, can the witness not grasp absolute validity anywhere?

analyzed: kiṃvā kvacid śaktaḥ kvacid aśaktaḥ
translated: Or is it able in some cases and unable in others?

analyzed: ādyasya uttaram anyathā ityādi
translated: The answer to the first is Otherwise etc.

analyzed: dvitīyasya uttaram vākya iti
translated: The answer to the second is In a sentence etc.

analyzed: syāt etat evam yadi akṣaja ādi jñānam nirdoṣam syāt
translated: This may be so if the knowledge produced by the senses etc. were faultless.

analyzed: na ca evam
translated: But it is not so.

analyzed: avidyā kṛta prapañca viṣaya tvāt śukti rajata ādi jñāna vat
translated: Because it has as its object the world created by ignorance, like the knowledge of silver in a shell.

analyzed: nanu avidyā kim āśritā iti ced
translated: If it is asked what is the basis of ignorance,

analyzed: jīva āśritā iti brūmaḥ
translated: we say it is based on the individual soul.

analyzed: nanu atra api dūṣaṇam uktam svatas iti
translated: But has not a fault been stated here too, namely difference from itself?

analyzed: na etat asti
translated: This is not so.

analyzed: tad bhedasya api āvidyaka tvāt
translated: Because the difference between them is also due to ignorance.

analyzed: na ca cakraka ādi doṣaḥ
translated: And there is no fault of an infinite regress etc.

analyzed: prapañca viśva
translated: The universe of manifestation

analyzed: sya jīva ajñāna kṛta tvena śruti ādi siddha tvāt
translated: is established by scripture etc. as being created by the ignorance of the individual souls.

analyzed: pramite ca arthe tarkāṇām avakāśa abhāvāt
translated: And when a matter is established, there is no scope for arguments.

analyzed: na ca kalpya abhāva doṣaḥ
translated: And there is no fault of the absence of postulation.

analyzed: viśvasya eka ajñāna kṛta tva aṅgīkārāt
translated: Because the oneness of ignorance that creates the universe is accepted.

analyzed: tad atirikta jīva jaḍa prapañcasya kalpya tva upapatteḥ
translated: It is proper to postulate the multiplicity of individual souls and the universe of insentient entities apart from that.

analyzed: eka jīva vādaḥ hi māyā vādinām param hṛdayam
translated: The doctrine of one individual soul is the supreme heart of the Mimamsakas.

analyzed: bahu jīva vādaḥ tu mandānām ābhimukhyāya avatāritaḥ iti atas āha eka iti
translated: But the doctrine of many individual souls is propounded for the sake of attracting the dull-witted. Therefore he says one etc.

analyzed: eka jñāna kṛtam viśvam iti yat coṣyate mṛṣā
translated: And the answer to the false assertion that the universe is created by one consciousness

analyzed: bahu jñāna kṛtam viśvam iti tasya uttaram bhavet
translated: would be that the universe is created by many consciousnesses.

analyzed: ucyate brahma vivarta vādibhiḥ
translated: It is said by the Mimamsakas who hold that the universe is a manifestation of Brahman.

analyzed: mṛṣā pramāṇena vinā
translated: Falsely, without any proof.

analyzed: etat uktam bhavati  syāt api idam kathañcid
translated: This is what is meant.🔽This might be so in some way,

analyzed: yadi viśvasya eka jīva ajñāna kalpita tvam syāt
translated: if the universe were postulated as created by the ignorance of one individual soul.

analyzed: na ca etat asti
translated: But this is not so.

analyzed: pramāṇa abhāvāt
translated: Because there is no proof.

analyzed: śruti ādeḥ anupadam eva samyak vyākhyāsyamāna tvāt
translated: Because scripture etc. will be properly explained immediately.

original: bahūnāmīśvarasya tatpreritānāṃ brahmādīnāṃ ca jñānecchāprayatnairnimittatve śrutyādipramāṇasadbhāvena tadviruddhatvācceti / /
analyzed: bahūnām īśvarasya tad preritānām brahma ādīnām ca jñāna icchā prayatnaiḥ nimitta tve śruti ādi pramāṇa sadbhāvena tad viruddha tvāt ca iti
translated: Because it is contradicted by the existence of such means of knowledge as scripture, etc., in the case of the causality of the many, of God, of His inspirers, of Brahman and others, by their knowledge, will and effort.

original: kiñcaikajīvājñānaparikalpitaṃ jīvajaḍātmakaṃ samastamiti vadanpraṣṭavyaḥ kimasāveko jīvastvam utānya iti /
analyzed: kiñca eka jīva ajñāna parikalpitam jīva jaḍa ātmakam samastam iti vadan praṣṭavyaḥ kim asau ekaḥ jīvaḥ tvam uta anyaḥ iti
translated: Moreover, one who says that the entire universe consisting of souls and the insentient is imagined by the ignorance of one soul, should be asked whether that one soul is you or another.

analyzed: anyaḥ ced tad ajñāna kalpitasya tava bandha mokṣa abhāvāt vayartham pārivrājya ādikam ām iti āpadyeta
translated: If it is another, then for you, who are imagined by its ignorance, there would be no bondage or liberation, and therefore the uselessness of wandering forth as a mendicant and so on would follow.

analyzed: ādye pi prativādi pramukhān jīvān paśyasi na vā
translated: In the first case also, do you see the souls, with the opponent at their head, or not?

analyzed: prathame pi kim
translated: In the first case also, do you say

analyzed: santi iti uta na santi iti
translated: that they exist or that they do not exist?

analyzed: ādyam dūṣayati parasya iti
translated: He refutes the first view, saying The thief of his own self, etc.🔽Even though knowing the truth of the other, he who says There is no other

original: parasya satyatāṃ jānannapi yaḥ svātmataskaraḥ /🔽paro nāstīti vadati / / / // / /c //
analyzed: parasya satya tām jānan api yaḥ sva ātma taskaraḥ  paraḥ na asti iti vadati
translated: is the thief of his own self.

original: yaḥ parasya prativādyādeḥ satyatāṃ jānannapi paro nāstīti vadati /
analyzed: yaḥ parasya prativādi ādeḥ satya tām jānan api paraḥ na asti iti vadati
translated: The construction is: He who, even though knowing the truth of the other, the opponent and so on, says There is no other,

analyzed: sa sva ātma taskaraḥ iti yojanā
translated: is the thief of his own self.

original: svātmānamiva paramapi satyatayā paśyato 'hameka eva satyo madajñānakalpitāḥ sarve jīvā jaḍāśceti vacanaṃ svānubhavaviruddhamityarthaḥ /
analyzed: sva ātmānam iva param api satya tayā paśyataḥ ham ekaḥ eva satyaḥ mad ajñāna kalpitāḥ sarve jīvāḥ jaḍāḥ ca iti vacanam sva anubhava viruddham iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the statement I alone am true, all other living beings and insentient objects are imagined due to ignorance of Me is contrary to one's own experience.

analyzed: nahi tvad ajñāna parikalpitam samastam iti atra balavat pramāṇam asti
translated: For there is no strong evidence that all this is imagined due to ignorance of you.

analyzed: yena darśanam api bādhyeta
translated: By which even the vision would be contradicted.

analyzed: nahi sattvena pratīyamānasya api gandharvanagara ādeḥ asattvam eva aṅgīkriyate
translated: For the unreality of a gandharva city, etc., which is cognized as existent, is not accepted.

analyzed: kintu balavat pramāṇa bādhāt
translated: But because it is contradicted by strong evidence.

analyzed: anyathā prativādī ajñāna kalpitaḥ tvam iti katham na syāḥ
translated: Otherwise, how could it not be that you are imagined by the ignorance of the opponent?

original: tathā cāniścayena na mokṣārthā pravṛttiḥ syāditi / /
analyzed: tathā ca aniścayena na mokṣa arthā pravṛttiḥ syāt iti
translated: And thus, due to uncertainty, there would be no engagement for the sake of liberation.

analyzed: dvitīya tṛtīyau nirācaṣṭe kim iti
translated: He refutes the second and third [arguments] with What?

analyzed: kim iti unmatta vat vadet
translated: What would one say like a madman?

analyzed: yadi paraḥ prativādi ādi jīvān na paśyati
translated: If the opponent does not see the other living beings, etc.,

analyzed: paśyan vā na santi iti paśyati
translated: or if seeing, sees that they do not exist,

analyzed: tadā kim iti unmatta vat vavadet  na kathāyām praviśet
translated: then what would one say like a madman?🔽One would not enter into a discussion.

analyzed: na śāstram viracayet vayākuryāt vā
translated: One would not compose a treatise or explain it.

original: anyathonmattavannāyaṃ laukiko nāpi parīkṣaka ityupekṣaṇīyaḥ syāt /
analyzed: anyathā unmatta vat na ayam laukikaḥ na api parīkṣakaḥ iti upekṣaṇīyaḥ syāt
translated: Otherwise, he would not be a worldly person nor an investigator, like a madman, and should be ignored.

analyzed: kutas na vadet
translated: Why does he not speak?

analyzed: yena vadan unmatta padavīm āsādayet iti atas āha parābhāve iti
translated: By which he would attain the state of a madman, therefore he says parābhava (defeat of the opponent).

analyzed: parābhāve hi vāc vyarthā
translated: For when there is defeat of the opponent, speech is useless.

analyzed: vācaḥ para bodhana artha tvāt
translated: Because speech is for the purpose of informing others.

original: parābhāve ca tadvaiyarthyādvayarthyāṃ vācaṃ na prayuñjīta /
analyzed: parābhāve ca tad vaiyarthyāt vayarthyām vācam na prayuñjīta
translated: And when there is defeat of the opponent, because of the futility of that, he would not use speech that is not useless.

analyzed: prayuñjānaḥ ca katham unmattaḥ na syāt iti
translated: And when using it, how could he not be a madman?

analyzed: satyam parābhāve vacanam anarthakam
translated: It is true that speech is meaningless when there is defeat of the opponent.

original: mayāpi kimapi nocyata ityata āha yadīti //
analyzed: mayā api kim api na ucyate iti atas āha yadi iti
translated: Since I also do not say anything, therefore he says yadi (if).

analyzed: yadi na eva ucyate tadā
translated: If it is not said at all, then

analyzed: kaśā vetra ādikam tasya taskarasya uttaram vadet
translated: what reply would he give to that thief with a stick?

original: mayā kimapi kadāpi naivocyata iti yadyucyate tadā svakriyāvirodhiśraḥ sakalalokāvagatārthāpalāpinastasya taskarasyaiva daṇḍa evocito na pratyuttaram
analyzed: mayā kim api kadāpi na eva ucyate iti yadi ucyate tadā sakala loka avagata artha apalāpinaḥ tasya taskarasya eva daṇḍaḥ eva ucitaḥ na pratyuttaram
translated: If it is said that I never say anything at all, then he who contradicts his own action and denies the meaning understood by all people deserves only punishment, not a reply, like a thief.🔽If it is said that it is said that ultimately nothing is said,

analyzed: paramārthataḥ na ucyate iti ucyate iti ced
translated: then

original: tatkiṃ pratīyogyabhāve niścite vyavahārato 'pi vadantaḥ prekṣāvanto bhavanti /
analyzed: tat kim prati yogi abhāve niścite vyavahārataḥ pi vadantaḥ prekṣāvantaḥ bhavanti
translated: So, when the contradictory nature is ascertained, do the wise speak even from usage?

analyzed: yena idam ucyeta iti
translated: By which this is said.

original: prāk prapañcamithyātvasiddhaye parodāhṛtānāṃ śrutīnāṃ bāhyopapattivirodhaḥ pratipā🔽vyutpāditaḥ /
analyzed: prāk prapañca mithyātva siddhaye para udāhṛtānām śrutīnām bāhya upapatti virodhaḥ  vyutpāditaḥ
translated: Previously, for the purpose of establishing the falsity of the world, the contradiction with external reasoning of the scriptures cited by others was refuted.

analyzed: idānīm āntara anupapatti pradarśana pūrvakam tāsām aviruddha artha vyākhyāna artham uttaraḥ granthaḥ
translated: Now, the subsequent text is for the purpose of explaining their non-contradictory meaning, preceded by the demonstration of internal inconsistency.

analyzed: athavā sarva śruti sādhāraṇa anupapattiḥ prāk prapañcitā
translated: Or, previously, the general inconsistency with all scriptures was elaborated.

analyzed: idānīm asādhāraṇa anupapattiḥ vyutpādyate
translated: Now, the uncommon inconsistency is being explained.

original: tatra tāvatprapañco yadi vidyetetyādivākyadvayaṃ paṭhitvā parābhimate 'rthe 'nupapattimāha prapañca iti //
analyzed: tatra tāvat prapañcaḥ yadi vidyeta ityādi vākya dvayam paṭhitvā para abhimate rthe nupapattim āha prapañcaḥ iti
translated: There, having recited the two statements beginning with If the world exists, he states the inconsistency in the meaning accepted by the opponent with The world...

original: prapañco yadi vidyeta nivarteta na saṃśayaḥ /
analyzed: prapañcaḥ yadi vidyeta nivarteta na saṃśayaḥ
translated: If the world were to exist, it would undoubtedly cease.

analyzed: māyā mātram idam dvaitam advaitam paramārthataḥ
translated: This duality is mere illusion, non-duality is the ultimate truth.

analyzed: vikalpaḥ vinivarteta kalpitaḥ yadi kenacid
translated: If an option were to be imagined by someone, it would cease.

analyzed: upadeśāt ayam vādaḥ jñāte dvaitam na vidyate
translated: This statement is due to instruction; in the unknown, duality does not exist.

original: ityatra yadiśabdau ca nivarteteti ca dvayam /
analyzed: iti atra yadi śabdau ca nivarteta iti ca dvayam
translated: In this, if the words 'if' and 'not' are both,

analyzed: viśvasya satya tām āhuḥ
translated: they declare the truth of the universe.

original: nanvatra sūtragṛhītatayā pareṇopāttānāṃ śrutīnāmanupapattyādikaṃ prathamatā vaktavyam /
analyzed: nanu atra sūtra gṛhīta tayā pareṇa upāttānām śrutīnām anupapatti ādikam prathamatā vaktavyam
translated: But here, since they are included in the aphorism, the non-establishment etc. of the scriptures accepted by the opponent should be stated first.

analyzed: satyam  tathā api eka jīva ajñāna parikalpita tve samastasya
translated: True.🔽Nevertheless, in the imagined nature of the entire universe by the ignorance of one individual soul,

analyzed: na pramāṇam asti iti anantaram eva uktam
translated: there is no means of knowledge, as stated immediately after.

analyzed: asyām ca tat āpātataḥ pratīyate
translated: And in this, that is understood provisionally.

analyzed: anādi māyayā suptaḥ yadā jīvaḥ
translated: When the individual soul, asleep by beginningless illusion, awakens,

analyzed: iti ukta tvāt
translated: as it has been said.

analyzed: atas ubhaya ānuguṇyāt asyāḥ prathama prāptiḥ
translated: Therefore, due to the conformity of both, this is obtained first.

original: ityatra ślokadvaye yadiśabdadvayaṃ nivarteteti liṅprayogadvayaṃ ca /
analyzed: iti atra śloka dvaye yadi śabda dvayam nivarteta iti liṅ prayoga dvayam ca
translated: In this, in these two verses, the two words 'if', the two usages of the verbal root 'to be', and the two usages of the verbal root 'to exist' are to be removed.

analyzed: upalakṣaṇam ca etat
translated: And this is an indication.

analyzed: vidyeta iti api grāhyam
translated: The words 'exist' should also be included.

analyzed: tathā kenacid iti
translated: Similarly, by someone.

analyzed: satyatām iti upalakṣaṇam
translated: 'Truth' is an indication.

analyzed: an ādi tām ca iti grāhyam  āhuḥ iti avagamayanti iti arthaḥ
translated: And 'beginninglessness' should be included.🔽'Declare' means 'make known'.

analyzed: tathā ca viśva mithyātva para tayā vyākhyāne tad anupapattiḥ iti śeṣaḥ
translated: And thus, in the explanation as referring to the falsity of the universe, the non-establishment of that is the remainder.

analyzed: yat yatra prapañca mithyātvam abhisaṃ
translated: If here the falsity of the world is accepted as the meaning of the scriptures,

original: dhitsitaṃ syāttadā yo 'yaṃ prapañco vidyata iva dṛśyate sa nivartiṣyate /
analyzed: dhitsitam syāt tadā yaḥ yam prapañcaḥ vidyate iva dṛśyate sa nivartiṣyate
translated: If it were intended, then this world, which appears as if existent, would cease to exist.

original: ajñānena kalpito vikalpo vinivartiṣyata iti vaktavyam /
analyzed: ajñānena kalpitaḥ vikalpaḥ vinivartiṣyate iti vaktavyam
translated: It should be said that the conceptualization imagined by ignorance will cease.

analyzed: yadi ādyāḥ tuśabdāḥ vigata arthāḥ viruddha arthāḥ ca
translated: If the words if are meaningless and contradictory,

analyzed: tad prayoge hi prasaṅga dvaya param etat vākya dvayam iti vijñāyate
translated: then in their usage, it is understood that these two statements are only for the sake of the two reductio arguments.

original: yadi parvato niragniko bhavet tarhi nirdhūmo 'pi syāditi yathā / /
analyzed: yadi parvataḥ niragnikaḥ bhavet tarhi nirdhūmaḥ syāt iti yathā
translated: If the mountain were without fire, then it would also be without smoke, just as it is.

original: prasaṅgasya ca viparyaye paryavasānādanivṛttyādikameva vākyasāmarthyāllabhyata iti parakīyamarthamapākurvataiva śrutitātparyaṃ sūcitam /
analyzed: prasaṅgasya ca viparyaye paryavasānāt anivṛtti ādikam eva vākya sāmarthyāt labhyate iti parakīyam artham apākurvatā eva śruti tātparyam sūcitam
translated: And since the reductio argument necessarily concludes in the opposite, non-cessation etc. is obtained by the power of the statement itself. By simply refuting the opponent's meaning, the purport of the scripture is indicated.

analyzed: tat spaṣṭīkurvan vidyeta iti asya artham tāvat āha vidyeta iti
translated: Making that clear, he first explains the meaning of exist by saying exist etc.

analyzed: vidyeta utpattim eva ca
translated: And existence and origination exist.

analyzed: iti etat śabda rūpam utpattim eva āha
translated: This form of the word exist only expresses origination.

analyzed: na tu sattām iti prakṛti artha kathanam
translated: But not existence. This is the explanation of the meaning of the sentence.

analyzed: caśabdena nivarteta iti vināśam āha
translated: By the word and, it expresses cessation, which is destruction.

analyzed: na tu bādham iti samuccinoti
translated: But not contradiction. This is the combination.

original: vidyaterutapattyarthatvaṃ kuta ityata āha videti //🔽vidotpattāviti hyasmād dhātor / / / // / / //
analyzed: vidyateḥ utapatti artha tvam kutas iti atas āha vidā iti  vidā utpattau iti hi asmāt dhātoḥ
translated: How is it known that the root vid has the sense of origination? To this he says: because of the explanation of the root.🔽For from this root vid, etc.

analyzed: vidā utpattau iti hi asmāt dhātoḥ
translated: For from this root vid, etc.
